Armistice Day was observed by Saks Thirty-fourth Street at 11 o'clock yesterday morning with a patriotic tableau of staff models on the main floor, on a specially erected dais facing Thirty-fourth Street. Miss Edna Barnes was dressed as a Red Cross nurse and Miss Beatrice Krepp held a floral wreath, while Sergeant Charles Wilson of the old Sixty-ninth Regiment sounded Taps.

Taxpayers may help to reduce their taxes by showing an aggressive interest in means to improve the credit of their municipalities, Morris S. Tremaine, New York State Controller, said in a statement to the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Proposing "controlled" inflation as the alternative to wholesale repudiation of debts by farmers, N.P. Hull of Lansing, Mich., president of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation, called upon the Federal Government today to cheapen the dollar in terms of commodities so that the 360,000 farm families affiliated with the federation and their neighbors can discharge their debts with agricultural products.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Nov. 7 shows no change for the week in total loans and investments and decreases of $29,000,000 in net demand deposits, $12,000,000 in time deposits and $27,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks.

Three men attempted to hold up the plant of the Alaska Ice Cream Products Company at 67 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday while the payroll was being made up but fled when they found a policeman on guard in the office.
VIENNA, Nov. 12. -- The anniversary of the founding of the Austrian republic passed quietly today, but there were many signs of nervousness in government quarters. There were many arrests.
The following article continues the interpretation of rulings issued by the Federal Reserve Board under the provisions of Regulation T, relating to restricted accounts.

A memorial shaft to the men of the lower East Side who lost their lives in the World War was unveiled yesterday afternoon at Armistice Day ceremonies in Union Square. The exercises were preceded by a parade of 2,000 men through the crowded streets below Fourteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Believing that the market for State and municipal bonds is steadily improving, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today offered for public sale on Nov. 23 an additional block of fifty-six such issues, aggregating $5,340,000, which it had taken over from the Public Works Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Lowest reasonable costs for dealers handling coal for Manhattan and the Bronx were set today by the NRA special committee for the Retail Solid Fuel Industry. The figure for domestic anthracite was put at $2.60 a ton, pea coal $2.40 a ton and steam coal $1.60 a ton.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Senator Borah said today that he had "a great bulk of charges" to back up his assertions of a few days ago that relief money had been wasted and used to persuade voters.

THE weekly session of the Standing, Sitting and Running Debating Society that gathers around Chick Meehan was an overflow affair. Some of the wing-backs had to stand in the corridor and watch for a chance to rush in as substitutes for departing orators.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Efforts of four government agencies to promote a reopening of foreign markets were advanced today at a White House conference.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 12. -- The Cabinet of Count Charles de Broqueville will hand in its resignation when the parliamentary session opens tomorrow afternoon, it was announced today. The consensus here is that the crisis will quickly be resolved, and the man most frequently mentioned to succeed to the Premiership is the veteran politician Henri Jaspar, now Minister of Foreign Affairs.
Captain Daniel Corry of the Irish Free State Army team last night won the International Individual Military Championship Challenge Trophy at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

Financial and commodity markets were closed yesterday in observance of Armistice Day, a recently established holiday in New York State. The banks in New York a well as the Exchanges were shut, so that no business was done in the financial district.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Official cognizance of Thomas J. Mooney's persistently repeated demand for freedom was taken today by the Supreme Court, which directed the warden of San Quentin penitentiary to show cause within forty days why Mooney's lawyers should not be allowed to file a petition for a habeas corpus writ.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- An investigation of the condition of railroads that hold and seek loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, particularly in cases where earnings are substantially under fixed charges, will be made by the RFC, Chairman Jones made known today.

An exhibition of figure and landscape canvases by Jean Baptiste Camille Corot opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, to remain through Dec. 1. It had been previously announced for Nov. 5, but was postponed because of delay in receiving pictures from Europe, among them several that were in the recently concluded Corot exhibition at the Kunsthaus in Zurich.

An international exhibition of children's paintings from forty-two countries was opened last night in the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center. It was arranged by the Little Red School House, an experimental school at 196 Bleecker Street, for the benefit of its scholarship fund.

Anthony Battaglia, 39 years old, was probably fatally wounded about 9:30 o'clock last night as he stepped out of his automobile in front of 610 Crescent Avenue, near Hughes Avenue, the Bronx. With bullets in his spine, neck and mouth, he slumped back into his car, in which he had been alone.

With hotel men gathered here from all parts of the world for a series of conventions and meetings this week, the nineteenth annual National Hotel Exposition opened yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Palace.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Nov. 12. -- The slaying of Lawrence L. Lyon, University of Southern California medical student and prominent fraternity man, was confessed late today by Rush Griffin, alias George Johnson, 19-year-old Negro gunman, according to the police.

New York money market closed for holiday. Saturday's closing rate for Stock Exchange call loans, 1 per cent; for sixty-day time loans, 3/4 to 1 per cent; for prime commercial paper, three to four months, three-quarters of 1 per cent.

Less emphasis on occupational and academic training and more on new goals for non-vocational instruction are asked in a survey of adult education courses offered by 1,402 organizations in this city, made public yesterday by the community planning committee of the New York Adult Education Council.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Harold L. Stuart, president of Halsey, Stuart Co., the bond house which has marketed $2,000,000,000 worth of Insull securities during the last twenty-five years, testified today that the profit from these transactions was not more than 1 per cent, or $20,000,000.
LEWISTON, Me., Nov. 12 (AP). -- Bates College displayed a powerful offense to defeat Colby, 13 -- 0, today and clinch second place in the State series race for 1934.

The songs and the music, the color and the enthusiasm and some of the sadness of the World War were recalled yesterday morning as 10,000 persons, many of them former soldiers, gathered around the Eternal Light in Madison Square to commemorate the signing of the armistice sixteen years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Infused by the President with a spirit of reverent emulation, most of his New Deal executives have gone in for frequent and at least apparently candid press conferences. When General Hugh S. Johnson was running the NRA, the audiences he gave to the press at times rivaled those at the White House.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 11. George J. Smith, chairman of the Board of Examiners of the Board of Education, is reported to have commented on the lists of more than 5,000 candidates awaiting appointment in the elementary schools by stating that it was "unfortunate that the life of the lists had been extended by the Legislature."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Maintenance of existing tariff barriers against Spain, and in some instances increasing of duties, were urged today by representatives of the cork, olive oil, wine and barytos ore industries at a hearing on a proposed reciprocal tariff treaty with that country.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- It was learned today that the insistence of the American naval delegation on maintaining the 5-5-3 ratio for Britain, the United States and Japan had been strengthened all along by the unequivocal attitude of France and Italy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Authorizations and commitments by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation from its establishment in February, 1932, to Oct. 31, reached $8,415,514,137.85, the corporation reported today in a summary of its operations.

Difficulties of administration growing out of the depression face Harry Miller Lydenberg, new director of the New York Public Library, who has assumed office this month with the retirement of Edwin H. Anderson.

New York money market closed for holiday. Saturday's closing rate for Stock Exchange call loans, 1 per cent; for sixty-day time loans, 3/4 to 1 per cent; for prime commercial paper, three to four months, three-quarters of 1 per cent.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Pollard's 3-year-old Chance Line, carrying 108 pounds with Jimmy King up, won the $2,500 added Fort Worth Handicap today, beating Crout Au Pot by a head. The Pelican finished third.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (AP). -- Paul Pirrone, Cleveland middleweight, checked Mickey Walker's come-back campaign tonight, defeating the Rumson Bulldog in ten bristling rounds at the Arena. The Cleveland fighter won the decision of both judges and Referee Tommy Reilly before 8,500 fans. Pirrone weighed 161 pounds, Walker 164.

With the announcement of the 1934 All-Boston and All-Boston Reserve field hockey elevens yesterday, the line-ups of the major teams to compete in the Northeast tourney at Garden City, L.I., next Friday, Saturday and Sunday are complete. Boston has selected the same team as last year with the exception of the left wing and inner positions filled by Miss Catherine Snyder and Miss Betty Neilson, respectively.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12. -- The ninth Pan-American Sanitation Conference opened here today for a ten-day session with delegates from nineteen American republics. Only Bolivia and Haiti were absent.
VIENNA, Nov. 12. -- One of the most famous beauties of the old Austro-Hungarian monarchy, Baroness Louise Poglodowska, has just died destitute in a Vienna hospital.
The City A.C. first team, defending titleholder in the metropolitan Class C squash tennis tournament, registered a 3-2 victory over the Essex Club of Newark yesterday on the City A.C. courts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Closer cooperation with the administration was promised to President Roosevelt today on behalf of Pennsylvania, in which the Democrats won control in last Tuesday's elections for the first time in more than fifty years, and of New York, where the Democrats have a majority in the Assembly under the two-party system for the first time in the memory of living members.
Helen Hackett, formerly of the Hackett Galleries, has opened studios in the galleries of P. Jackson Higgs, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Prompt construction of two giant airships, an aircraft carrier and a "flying-deck" cruiser unlike any other ship now afloat was proposed privately today to the President's Aviation Commission.

In addition to putting through a reapportionment of the Congressional and Senatorial districts by the next Legislature, leaders of the Democratic party will seek a change in the State Constitution to remove the limitations which make it difficult to elect a Democratic Senate and almost impossible, except in a landslide, to elect a Democratic Assembly, it was learned yesterday.

The deans of five medical schools in the city, at a conference yesterday with Dr. S.S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, approved of the commissioner's plan for a general city hospital for the chronic sick, to be conducted in cooperation with the medical schools.
Columbia directed its attention yesterday toward game with Pennsylvania, an opponent regarded by the Lions as a very serious threat to their highly successful come-back efforts.
LOWELL, Mass., Nov. 12. -- A powerful Providence College team swamped Lowell Textile today, 34 to 0.

Armistice Day's ceremonies included none more impressive and suggestive than the international broadcast in the cause of peace. The sentiments and aspirations expressed were in themselves apposite and moving, but the thing to appeal to the imagination was the fact that they passed back and forth between the nations swifter than the wind.
LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Elswyth Thane, the American playwright, who is Mrs. William Beebe, wife of the author, had her second play, "Young Mr. Disraeli," produced at the Kingsway tonight.

The modernization phase of the National Housing Act already has created 1,750,000 days of work in New York State, Julian M. Gerard, New York State Director of the Federal Housing Administration, said yesterday. He spoke at the thirtieth annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, which, began a three-day convention In the Hotel Astor.
For nearly a week Alfred E. Distelhurst, Tennessee representative of a publishing company, has been waiting at a hotel in this city for word from the supposed kidnappers of his 6-year-old daughter.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 12. -- A.E. Distelhurst Sr., father of Dorothy Ann, 6 years old, who disappeared here on Sept. 19, is the son of the late H.E. Distelhurst, a retired real estate operator. The younger Mr. Distelhurst was born at Montclair, N.J., and served in the Canadian army during the World War.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 12. -- Leslie Ragan, New York artist, and his wife and Robert Velie, Chicago illustrator, were rescued early this morning off Cape Romain when the Clyde Mallory liner Henry R. Mallory took them off their sinking thirty-foot auxiliary sloop, the Departure.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Nov. 12. -- All attendance and pari-mutuel records for thoroughbred racing in New England were broken today when more than 56,000 persons wagered close to $750,000 on the final day of the Fall meeting at Narragansett Park.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 12. -- The University of Maryland football team gained an easy victory over Virginia Military Institute in the Municipal Stadium today, 23 to 0.

Air pollution during October was close to the low mark for the month since 1930, it is recorded in the monthly report of David R. Morris, in charge of the New York Meteorological Observatory in Central Park.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The official summary of the report of the New York Power Authority to President Roosevelt on the Cost of Distribution of Electricity follows:

A tax in wartime of 98 or 99 per cent on all incomes in excess of $10,000 a year was advocated by Senator Gerald P. Nye, head of the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry, in a speech last night at an armistice meeting at the Hotel Astor.
Modern Merlins in tails and starched fronts stood along the walls of the darkened grand ballroom of the Hotel McAlpin last night and criticized one another's technique.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP). -- President Roosevelt is keeping close watch as the House Speakership race rapidly shapes up. The candidacy of Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas was made more clearcut by the withdrawal of Representative Marvin Jones, also of Texas.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13. -- Some of the pictures bought by Andrew Mellon came from the famous collection gathered by the Czars of Russia and placed in the Hermitage at St. Petersburg before the revolution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP). -United silver stocks have advanced more than 200,000,000 ounces since enactment of the Silver Purchase Law, but the government still holds less than half the huge total of more than 2,000,000,000 ounces needed to establish a 25-75 ratio with the gold monetary stock.

The New York University football squad spent more than an hour of its practice session yesterday in an extensive blackboard drill in the locker rooms at Ohio Field. Coach Mal Stevens and his staff reviewed the newly devised defensive tactics and plays which will be used against Rutgers on Saturday when the twoelevens clash at New Brunswick in the thirty-second game of a series which commenced in 1890.

DUBLIN, Nov. 13. -- Whatever political or economic difficulties he may yet have to face in working out his policies, President Eamon de Valera has the satisfaction of feeling that he has behind him one of the strongest political organizations this country has had for many years.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- To beat back the tide of rising prices Dr. Karl Goerdeler, Reich price commissar, today issued a decree that puts the hitherto all-powerful cartels under his control and makes him arbiter over the life and death of the individual merchant.
Mrs. Annie Ide Cockran of 1,136 Fifth Avenue is planning to give to some one else the birthday that Robert Louis Stevenson deeded to her forty-three years ago.

Another case of thugs preying on elderly women in the tenement districts in the hope of finding hoarded cash was recorded yesterday by the police with the finding of the body of Mrs. Fannie Agannoe, 72 years old, in her bedroom on the top floor of a five-story building at 109 Thompson Street.

VIENNA. Nov. 13. -- It was announced here officially that on a warrant from Austrian police, Czechoslovak police today arrested in Prague on a charge of slander a young Viennese lawyer, Dr. Fritz Kreisler, who has just published in Prague a book entitled "Who Murdered Dollfuss?"

Directors of the Procter Gamble Company voted yesterday to declare an extra dividend of 20 cents on the common stock, payable on Dec. 15 to stock of record of Nov. 23. Action on the regular quarterly dividend on that stock will not be due until the middle of January.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. -- Compulsory increase of 5 per cent in the working forces of every employer in order to absorb all the unemployed of the country under 30 years of age was suggested by Roger Babson in a speech before a luncheon of the Advertising Club of Boston today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13. -There is an old Japanese proverb to the effect that "He who rides a tiger dare not dismount." As Princeton today continued preparations for the game with Yale here on Saturday the football Tigers made ready to turn on the Elis should they take the dare.

Renewal of the strike of building service and elevator employes in office buildings in the garment district was again postponed last night, following a meeting of officials of the Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32B, and real estate operators.

The city's suit to reopen the $2,569,909 Bergen Beach land award case was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward J. Byrne in Brooklyn. The court held that the city's petition, in which former Mayor James J. Walker and officials in his administration were charged with collusion and fraud, was contradictory and failed to support the charges.

Another of the College Art Association's group exhibitions, organized as a traveling show, has just opened at the Weitzner Galleries, 6 East Fifty-seventh Street. It is called "Figure Painting From American Ancestors to Our Day."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- An assertion that all newspapers might be advised to withdraw from NRA codes if the Labor Relations Board accepted jurisdiction in a dispute between The San Francisco CallBulletin and one of its former employes was expressed today before the board by Elisha Hanson, counsel for the newspaper and also the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

HSINKING, Manchukuo, Wednesday, Nov. 14 (AP). -- While British and American diplomats were marking time in the oil controversy, Japanese officials connected with the Manchukuoan Government moved steadily today toward the institution of a monopoly.

A friendly action to determine whether all judgments against stockholders and other legal documents involving the liquidation of the Bank of United States filed in the County Clerk's office by Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, are to be accepted without the payment of fees, was decided yesterday against County Clerk Albert Martinelli and in favor of the Superintendent of Banks.

Federal Judge Julian W. Mack, who held recently that security holders of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, $700,000,000 public utility holding concern, had filed a petition for reorganization in good faith, reserved decision yesterday on an action brought by George M. Le Pine, counsel for the company, for a reargument of the motion to dismiss the petition on the ground that the reverse had been true.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The belief that there are impending developments in transatlantic air routes has been created by the visit of John C. Cooper Jr., vice president of Pan American Airways, who is carrying on discussions here.

If there is a recount of the vote cast for Controller at last Tuesday's election, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick will be elected, Benjamin Howe, city chairman of the City Fusion party, declared last evening.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--Proposals expected to serve as a basisfor a comprehensive program foreconomic security to be presentedto Congress in January by President Roosevelt will be discussed tomorrow at general conferences andgroup meetings of nearly 200 experts and representatives of industry and labor.

VIENNA, Nov. 13. -- That Austria regards the question of her State form, whether monarchical or otherwise, as a matter for herself alone was among the items of information extracted by questioning from Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg today at a luncheon of the Vienna AngloAmerican Press Association.

After an early advance had carried March and May contracts above 12 1/2 cents a pound the first time in several weeks, prices on the Cotton Exchange fell back 10 points yesterday and ended unchanged to 3 points lower on the day.
Money market was featureless. New business was at a minimum, replacements making up the bulk of the turnover. Quotations for all classifications remained unchanged.

The campaign of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross to raise $400,000 for its relief and educational work was started here yesterday. A Roll Call desk was opened in the Broad Street lobby of the Stock Exchange and about 100 traders were quickly enrolled.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13. -The consecration of Samuel Seabury of Connecticut in Scotland as the first Episcopal Bishop of the United States was tonight pronounced one of the most important events in the history of the church by the Rt. Rev. Frederic L. Deane, Bishop of Aberdeen, chief guest of honor at the opening nation-wide exercises of the celebration of the 150th anniversary of the consecration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- President Roosevelt's efforts to maintain public confidence in the crisis of the depression were praised today by Cardinal O'Connell of Boston, dean of American Catholic priests, who declared after a visit to the White House that the "psychology" of the country had improved.

Madison Square Garden will be the scene of several outstanding basketball games this Winter, according to the twenty-one game schedule of St. John's University released yesterday by Director of Athletics James A. Freeman. The Brooklyn five will play its four leading games in the Garden.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- The Chamber of Deputies, after having heard former Premier Gaston Doumergue charged with aspirations to dictatorship, tonight voted overwhelmingly its confidence in the new government of Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin.

A bitter legal fight over the custody of Constance Starr Brock, 9 years old, loomed yesterday after Mrs. Helen Starr Josephson of 975 Park Avenue, mother of the child, obtained a warrant for the arrest of her mother, Mrs. Libby Starr of Mamaroneck, N.Y., on a charge of kidnapping the girl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Reduction of transportation costs by coordinating the operation of rail, highway, water and air carriers was advocated before the National Association of Railroad and Utility Commissioners today by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation.

The post-holiday bond market showed considerable irregularity. On the Stock Exchange yesterday domestic corporation bonds and some of the leading foreign loans were weaker, while United States Government long-term issues finished generally higher.

Settlement by arbitration of the long-standing controversy between wholesale and retail fresh and salt water fish dealers in the city has been agreed to by all factions involved, it was announced yesterday afternoon by Mayor LaGuardia.

Mayor LaGuardia's search for $50,000,000 to finance relief for one year moved forward a step yesterday when he discussed possible new taxes with leaders of the Board of Aldermen, but ran into a snarl when the same leaders attacked the legality of the 1935 budget.

Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt finished her testimony yesterday in the Supreme Court after ten days on the witness stand behind closed doors, defending her character and her fitness to recover her 10-yearold daughter, Gloria.
Both of the seeded players participating in second-round matches yesterday in the amateur tourney of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association turned in victories at the New York A.C.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A new and more determined movement among private business interests to shove the country further out of the depression is understood here to be taking form, largely as a result of the vote of confidence given the Roosevelt administration at the election.

The choice of a minority leader of the Assembly apparently had narrowed yesterday to Herbert Brownell Jr. of Manhattan and Irving M. Ives of Chenango County, with James J. Wadsworth of Livingston County, son of the former United States Senator, as a possibility.

TRENTON, Nov. 13. -- United States District Attorney Harlan Besson announced today that Carl M. Hansen was taken into custody at Butte, Mont., last Saturday on an indictment charging use of the mails to defraud in connection with his activities as president of the International Reinsurance Company of Delaware and the Insurance Management Corporation of Pennsylvania.

Benno Moiseiwitsch, the pianist, making his reappearance after three years' absence and round-theworld tour of exotic climes, was warmly greeted last evening as soloist of the National Orchestral Association's second concert in Carnegie Hall.

TEMPLETON, Mass., Nov. 13. -Landlords' Inn, operated for eight years by twenty-five New York and New England hotel men as their composite idea of the last word in modern country resorts, today went under the auctioneer's hammer. Building, equipment and land is to be knocked down to the highest bidder either piecemeal or in toto in a three-day sale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--Federaldemands upon Andrew V. Wrellonfor the payment of $8,075,103 inadditional income taxes, penaltiesand interest, were described as"impertinent, scandalous and improper'' today ina reply filed beforethe United States Board of TaxAppeals to the Internal RevenueCommissioner's answer to a petition' for relief from the deficiencyassessment.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The London foreign exchange market noted with interest today Washington's removal of the restrictions on the export of capital, and, according to The Daily Mail, the effect of this re-established freedom is likely to be manifest on the dollar if further talk of devaluation becomes prevalent in the United States.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13. -Two hours of indoor dummy scrimmage in the Coxe Memorial Cage today opened Yale's preparation for the Princeton game Saturday.

FRANK WALSH, chairman of the New York Power Authority, loves to sit in a golden chair and "splash at a ten"league canvas with brushes of comets' "hair." Only ten leagues is not wide enough for his canvas. It must cover the country, from the tumbling waters of the Columbia and the floods of the Colorado to the rapids of the St. Lawrence and the falls of the Tennessee.
Although most of the fishing captains are in agreement that the codfishing to date has been pretty spotty, there are indications that conditions will improve within the next week or so.
RENO, Nov. 13. -- Divorces were granted here today to two New York women, Mrs. Bernadine B. Slade from John Slade Jr., and Mrs. Dorothy C. Kelland from Thomas S. Kelland.

The principal over-the-counter dealers would welcome rather than oppose Federal licensing by the Securities and Exchange Commission, leading members of the Unlisted Security Dealers Association asserted yesterday. Their comment was evoked by dispatches from Washington stating that the commission contemplated creating a licensing system and by the remarks of Commissioner James M. Landis, who was quoted as saying in New Orleans yesterday that "over-thecounter manipulations of stocks must go."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The Home Owners Loan Corporation announced today that no more applications would be received until further notice.

When the British Parliament reassembles after the Autumn recess, there is always a great bustle over the legislation to be taken up. The Government announces many plans and introduces many bills. Private members give notice of their intention to press certain measures which they deem of the highest importance.

Dr. John F. Condon, the "Jafsie" of the Lindbergh case, declared last night at a dinner of the Franklin Simon Post, American Legion, that "on Jan. 2 I'll do my duty by the State of New Jersey." The dinner, which marked the installation of officers of the post, was held in the auditorium of the Franklin Simon store at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street.

Permit me to make a correction of your editorial "Limiting Machine Hours." You state in effect that about two weeks ago the National Industrial Recovery Board had reached the conclusion that the code provisions limiting the hours of machine operation in certain codes were a mistake.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13 (AP). -Asserting that "every one was crazy" in the 1929 era of stock speculation, William A. Lockwood, counsel for the New York Curb Exchange, said here today that America's investing public could be assured that adequate safeguards had since been thrown around security operations.
Neither President John A. Heydler nor Ford C. Frick, who will succeed Mr. Heydler as the National League head on Dec. 11 next, had any advance knowledge of the proposed sale of the Cardinals.

The State's case in the firstdegree murder trial in General Sessions of Mrs. Catherine Phelan, 52 years old, in the slaying of Douglas Sheridan, 68, a broker, on the night of last Dec. 30, took another unusual turn yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 13. -- King Leopold and Dave Hennen Morris, United States Ambassador to Belgium, were created doctors by the University of Brussels today during the celebration of the university's centenary.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13. -- Another victory fell to George D. Widener of Philadelphia when his Sickle colt Kawagoe easily won the featured Monumental Purse at Pimlico today from five of the best sprinters which could be mustered against him.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- An admission that Insull units bought and sold Insull stocks at the same time was drawn today from Fred H. Scheel, one of the defendants in the mail fraud case, as the government turned again to "rigging" and "wash sales" transactions.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 13 (AP). -- Edward Bermingham, former Long Island police judge and business man, was held in the Laramie County jail today on orders from New York State authorities. The former resident of Lynbrook and East Rockaway, N.Y., was known here as Thomas B. Edwards.

While some plan of unemployment insurance seems certain to be enacted in the coming session of Congress, it would be unfortunate if extravagant hopes were entertained regarding precisely what such a plan could do. Some are evidently under the strange impression that it would provide a substitute for relief.
All Speakers Stress Human and Civic Value of Expert Care for the Sick Poor.

ISYRACUSE Nov. 13.--A.rthur 1.Lauterbach, chief of the AAA. DairySectidn, and Fred H. Sexauer, president of the Dairymen's League Co-!operative Association, told the annual convention of the NationalCooperative Milk Producers' Association today that coordination ofthree factors, cooperative marketing, State control and Federal assistance, was necessary to bring themilk industry back to a normallevel.

Removal of the existing governmental restraint on foreign exchange transactions, as announced from Washington yesterday, means more than would at first glance appear. As matters have stood since the first "emergency legislation" of March, 1933, all but minor transactions in foreign exchange were forbidden except by official license.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Organization of the Town Hall of Washington, a non-partisan, non-sectarian and non-profit organization patterned after the New York institution of similar name, was announced today, with plans for a series of forum discussions on economic and social aspects of national and international problems of government.

The contract bridge team of the Four Aces, playing a bridge system perfected by its five members, swept through the last session of its final match yesterday afternoon at the Ritz-Carlton to win the Vanderbilt Cup for 1934 by a margin of 7,760 points.

Back in 1873, when the echoes of another war had just begun to fade into the background of time, the football teams of Yale and Princeton began playing each other. In that first game Princeton scored three goals to Yale's none.

Encouraged by a brisk opening, Wall Street looked for a much more active market yesterday. That the trading pace slackened was apparently due to the fact that selling of the utilities dampened speculative enthusiasm somewhat. The market was fairly active when the first break occurred in that group, but it was low and unexciting at the close.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- The Boerse was slightly firmer today without any significant change occurring. Heavy industrials opened weak but closed somewhat stronger. Lignites were irregular in slow trading and potashes again were stagnant. Machineries and electricals were stronger, Berlin Karlsruhe gaining 2 1/2 points and A.E.G. advancing 1 point.

The wide use of psychiatry in the administration of justice was favored and opposed by authorities representing medicine and law before an audience of more than 1,000 persons at the Academy of Medicine last night. The meeting was held under the auspices of the New York Neurological Society together with the Section of Neurology and Psychiatry of the Academy of Medicine.

Dr. Stephen S. Wise, rabbi of the Free Synagogue and honorary president of the American Jewish Congress, appealed to President Roosevelt yesterday to halt the negotiations by which the AAA seeks to exchange 500,000 bales of American cotton for German goods.

Lester R. Stoefen, tennis star of Los Angeles, relinquished his amateur standing yesterday and signed a professional contract to play in sports promoter Bill O'Brien's barnstorming troupe over a nationwide circuit in 1935, The Associated Press reports.

The State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration announced yesterday that at the request of the Federal Surplus Corporation it would buy with Federal funds about 50,000,000 pounds of cabbages from the surplus crops in New York State for distribution this Winter to the needy in this and other States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP). -Andrew W. Mellon said today that his large collection of paintings eventually "would be made available to the public." He described as "entirely unfounded," however, reports that he had "arranged to build an art gallery at Washington."

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Members of the British Cabinet held a two-hour meeting with all the Dominion High Commissioners today to inform them of the course of the recent naval discussions with Japan and the United States.

As Speaker for the years 1925-33 JOE MCGINNIES holds the record for length of service in that office. That is glory enough. He wanted to throw off the cares of office and be no more even a member of the body which he has ruled so long with such skill, shrewdness and humor.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13 (AP). -- A new Bolivian offensive in the Chaco has recaptured about 1,600 square miles of territory in the northwest of the disputed area, reports reaching Buenos Aires said.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Stanley H. (Bucky) Harris, who as baseball's "boy manager" led Washington to a world championship ten years ago, tonight was given a one-year contract as the Senators' pilot for 1935.

A fight in a dimly lit tunnel under Bellevue Hospital between two policemen and a powerful 170pound prisoner ended yesterday with the foiling of what the police said was a well-planned attempt to escape.
A favorable straw in the economic Iwind appears in .tabulations of ex-1pendltures for expansion of out- 1standing major industries, largely1expenditures of idle cash.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13. -- The Senate has authorized its meat industry investigating committee to use the police to force packers to submit their books for examination.

Temperatures that dipped below the freezing point in the early morning hours, frequent snow flurries and a chilly southwest wind that reached a maximum velocity of forty miles an hour all gave this city yesterday a sample of the Winter weather that prevailed down the Atlantic seaboard from Maine to Florida.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 13. -The first round of the fifteenth annual mid-South professional golf championship today demonstrated that upsets can occur in Scotch foursomes match play as well as in any other type of medal or match competition.

ARLINGTON, Texas, Nov. 13. -Jockey C. Parvin booted home five winners before a crowd of 7,000 at the Newspaper Day program at Arlington Downs today. Included among them was the winner of the featured Dallas News Purse, H. Massey's Motley.

NASHVILLE, Nov. 13. -- Similarity between dental work of missing Dorothy Ann Distelhurst and that of a child whose body was discovered in a shallow grave today was reported tonight, but a definite check was delayed until tomorrow.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The government's bill on incitement to disaffection, designed to enable law officers more easily to prosecute persons organizing assaults on the loyalty of the armed forces, was passed by the House of Lords tonight and awaits only royal assent to become law.

Taking the most drastic disciplinary action in the history of the college, the City College faculty expelled yesterday twenty-one students, and disciplined sixteen others in various degrees for the student riot in the Great Hall Oct. 9, during the visit of a party of Fascist students.
Five Manhattan properties and three in the Bronx were bid in in foreclosure auctions yesterday. Three scheduled sales were postponed. The Manhattan results were as follows:

The "urgent need" for reduction of the burdensome taxes now borne by real estate was stressed yesterday at the annual convention of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York in the Hotel Astor.

Record-breaking track stars, led by Blazin' Ben Eastman and Bill Bonthron, dominate the list of nominations made so far in the contest for the James E. Sullivan Memorial Medal, awarded annually by the National Amateur Athletic Union to the country's outstanding amateur performer.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Two comparatively modern transatlantic liners, the Minnewaska and the Minnetonka, each about 22,000 tons gross and probably the largest cargo carriers of any ocean-going vessels in the world, are to be broken up.

ALBANY, l?ov. 13.--The UtopianSociety of America (East), Inc.,has obtained a New York Statecharter under the Membership Corpora*'ns Law. Its purposes are"the formation of a social, cultural, fraternal and educational organization which has for its purpose the promotion of social welfare, cultural advancement, fraternal spirit and educational facilities among its members andothers."

HELSINGFORS, Nov. 13. -- A Russian war chest, which is believed to contain a fabulous sum and is said to have been sunk in the Gulf of Finland west of Helsingfors by Bolsheviki in the last stages of the World War, is being hunted by expeditions from six countries.

The drama's guests from Dublin, in Abbey Theatre repertory at the Golden, submit a Lennox Robinson festival today. The matinee is Mr. Robinson's comedy "The Far-Off Hills"; the evening brings his "Drama at Inish," seen here last year about this time under different auspices as "Is Life Worth Living?" . . .

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP). -Cottonseed crushed in the period from Aug. 1 to Oct. 31 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 1,236,655 tons, compared with 1,399,976 in the same period a year ago.

PARKER DAM SITE, Calif., Nov. 13 (AP). -- A threat of "war" over Parker Dam site vanished suddenly tonight when the Federal Reclamation Bureau stopped construction work on Arizona territory, and Governor E. B. Moeur of Arizona announced that he would withdraw his martial-law proclamation upon receipt of official word of the bureau's action.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 13 (AP). -- Miss Esther De Lee, 21, school teacher dismissed last week by a rural trustee of Pompey Hollow who said she would not display the American flag where he ordered it to be hung, remained in her 12-pupil school today determined to continue teaching "until I am evicted by State police."

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 13. -- Lew H. Wentz, Oklahoma oil multi-millionaire, with a desire to own a major league baseball club, is seeking to purchase control of the Cardinals and their minor league "farms" from Sam Breadon.

BUFFALO, Nov. 13. -- The social chaos which has driven women of Central Europe "back into medieval drudgery and made of them mere breeding machines" can never have its counterpart in this country so long as women wisely use their ability and capacity, Rabbi Joseph L. Fink of Temple Beth Zion of Buffalo told the State Federation of Women's Clubs today in an address.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- France's new truce government under the leadership of Pierre-Etienne Flandin received a handsome majority of 423 to 118 in the Chamber of Deputies this evening. These figures undoubtedly represent a sufficient margin of confidence to carry the Cabinet along until after the budget is passed and perhaps until after the Saar plebiscite is held on Jan. 13.

A memorial service for the late Charles E. Wry, executive director for many years of the National Retail Clothiers and Furnishers Association, will be held in the auditorium of the Chanin Building tomorrow afternoon at 4:45 o'clock.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13. -- The ninth Pan-American Sanitation Conference devoted today to arranging its committees and hearing reports on public health progress since the last conference, held in Lima in 1927.

One of the masterpieces of engraving -- Albrecht Duerer's "The Knight, Death, and the Devil" -was sold for $2,500 last night at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., when the etchings and engravings by early masters collected by the late Frank H. Bresler of Milwaukee was dispersed to close his estate.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13. -- Bolivia's recent sweeping victory in Northern Chaco was one of the major operations in the Chaco war. Bolivian and Paraguayan communiques disagree as to the losses inflicted upon Paraguay but agree in describing the engagement as Bolivia's most energetic offensive since the war started.
Police Commissioner Valentine demanded yesterday that District Attorney Dodge investigate rumors that policemen were accepting graft from motorists to overlook violations of parking rules.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- How the late Earl of Minto, former Governor General of Canada, was unable to obtain an official reception by the late Lord Curzon when he succeeded Lord Curzon as Viceroy of India, was revealed in a book published today by the Dowager Countess of Minto.
BRUSSELS, Nov. 13. -- The de Broqueville Cabinet resigned today because of the members' inability to agree on retaining the present gold value of the belga.

THERE seems to be some political confusion in Louisiana due to the fact that "State Senator" Abe Mickal of the Louisiana State back field refused to be seated. He is better at running than at sitting down. But the general idea is fairly clear. Huey Long, the strong, silent man of the sleepy bayous, has a new system of natural selection for public office.

Emily Dickinson, whose shade was haunting "Allison's House" a few years ago, appears as the chief character in "Brittle Heaven," which was put on at the Vanderbilt last evening. If she does not appear in person, she appears in the person of Dorothy Gish, which is considerable consolation.

Revised water rates, giving small home owners a lower water tax and large property holders higher levies than they now have, will be ready for submission to the Board of Aldermen in January, that body was informed yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
Realty market activity yesterday centred in the suburban zone.

Frank W. Clarke, vice president of the Anglo-Canadian Pulp and Paper Company, Ltd., said here yesterday on the way South for a vacation, that the newsprint prices of his company would be moved up by the decision of the International Paper Company to increase its 1935 newsprint prices from $40 to $45 per ton.

The contention of the Power Authority of New York State, in a survey given out at the White House on Monday, that present electric rates could be virtually halved "if schedules were adjusted to the cost of service," brought yesterday heavy selling of the shares of utility holding and operating companies on the markets here.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 13. -While the silk and rayon dyers' strike was deadlocked today with little immediate hope that the 25,000 workers would go back to the shops, representatives of 8,000 broadsilk workers indicated a walkout was inevitable in that branch of the industry unless conditions as to wages and hours were corrected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Confidence was expressed today by Senator Borah that Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, would conduct his investigation of relief expenditures in a satisfactory fashion, but there were indications that Republicans in Congress might take up relief distribution as an issue.

DUBLIN, Nov. 13. -- Daring and originality marked the brilliant settings and costumes provided by James Bould for the production of Moliere's "School for Wives," which opened at the Abbey Theatre here last night. Utilizing only blank and white, Mr. Bould gave a striking effect of fantastic extravagance and unreality, well matched to the mood of the Moliere piece.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The annual concentration of politicians in Washington has begun, and their chief topic of conversation is the future of the Republican party. Many Democrats, some Republicans and practically all radicals seem convinced that the Republican party is dead.
Jackie, a pet fox terrier, saved the lives of his three little girl playmates in Brooklyn ]ast night.

The American Jewish Congress moved last night to obtain the cooperation of leading groups which have differed with it on fundamental questions of policy in the matters of the forthcoming national elections to the 1935 assemblage of the congress and of the proposed world Jewish congress.

The price movements of staples developed considerable irregularity on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. Sugar, silk and hides were stronger and coffee and rubber eased. In the cash markets wheat, corn and rye advanced, and cocoa and rubber declined.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The Treasury's action yesterday in granting a blanket license authorizing all transactions in foreign exchange, transfers of credit and exports of currency except gold is expected by observers here to prove of material aid in keeping the dollar stable in terms of foreign currencies and to stimulate to some extent investments in foreign equities.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Corn led the grain markets here today, and a rush of commission house and local buying toward the last swept prices up about 2 cents a bushel from the early low marks and to new high figures since early in September. The strong cash situation was generally given as the main factor.

Comparing the Little House on Park Avenue with model housing on the Tennessee Valley project, we find that commuters' homes in the vicinity of New York come much cheaper than workingmen's homes on the Norris Dam.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Application for registration of the following securities under the Securities Exchange Act has been received by the Securities and Exchange Commission:

The liability of the State of New York for the death of three persons, injuries to two others, and damage to an automobile as a result of the landslide on the Storm King Highway, north of the West Point Reservation last Spring, is to be decided as the result of hearings begun in the county courthouse yesterday before Judge Joseph A. Murphy of Albany, member of the State Court of Claims.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- A convention to provide effective control over the traffic in and manufacture of arms and other munitions and to be negotiated through the general disarmament conference at Geneva, as a separate treaty, is being urged by the United States on the principal arms manufacturing countries for immediate consideration and action.

BASLE, Nov. 13. -- The governors of all the big European central banks and other bankers have scattered again to London, Paris, Berlin, Rome, Amsterdam and other money markets after spending the last three days here at the monthly meeting of the Bank for International Settlements sizing up future prospects.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Plans for accelerating private building under Title II of the Housing Act are being pushed by James A. Moffett, administrator, in the hope of obviating another huge Federal building outlay at the hands of the new Congress.

Commissioner William Hodson of the Department of Public Welfare and chairman of the City Emergency Relief Bureau revealed yesterday that in the last month the number of persons applying for relief had been balanced by the number of those taken off the relief rolls.

Younger members of society headed by Miss Louise Whitehouse are assisting at the bazaar and tea in behalf of Hope Farm which will open today at the Savoy-Plaza and will continue there tomorrow. A variety of articles suitable for Christmas gifts will be offered for sale, including handbags, Indian print dresses, and costume jewelry, as well as honey, jellies and marmalade.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -Harvard's football holiday was extended to almost all of the first team today, only a few of the regulars being on the field. Captain Gundlach did not report, nor did Dubiel, Keely, Comfort, Haley and Knapp.

Before a brilliant gathering of 12,000 enthusiasts, France's army officers last night captured the International Military Perpetual Challenge Trophy, the leading event of the National Horse Show which was concluded in Madison Square Garden.

A pair of vegetarian porcupines (syntheres prehensilis) which came by air from the headwaters of the Amazon River -- express prepaid -created a mild sensation yesterday in the customs division of the Railway Express Agency, at 403 Tenth Avenue.

October production of new life insurance was 5.7 per cent greater than that of the same month last year, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents announced yesterday. Volume for the first ten months of 1934 shows an increase of 10.5 per cent over the corresponding period of 1933, it was said.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. -- With the 1934 New England pari-mutuel betting crop, which totaled $41,957,209, safely gathered in, the racing interests that shared in this bountiful harvest as well as scores of others that hope to next year, today turned their attention to Massachusetts, which voted overwhelmingly in favor of horse and dog wagering just a week ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Asserting that the National Labor Relations Board had no jurisdiction in the disputed case of Dean S. Jennings, chief re-write man on The San Francisco Call-Bulletin, Elisha Hanson, counsel for the newspaper, declared at a Labor Board hearing today that the case rightfully belonged before the Industrial Relations Board created under the Daily Newspaper Publishers Code.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that the ticker abbreviation for Pennsylvania-Dixie Cement Corporation will be changed tomorrow from PXC to DXC.

A great silvery monoplane drifted down to a landing on Newark Airport at 11:27 last night with sixteen persons aboard. The Florida Flier, which left Newark for Miami yesterday morning at daylight, had completed the round trip of 2,400 miles in less than fifteen hours' flying time.

An agreement not to publish any more anti-Jewish attacks in the Deutsche Zeitung, organ of the Friends of the New Germany, was signed yesterday by William L. McLaughlin, editor of the English section of the weekly, as a condition for suspension of a one-year prison sentence for libel imposed on him by County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn.

Deterred by the chill weather and a water-soaked field Fordham's football forces reverted to the college gymnasium yesterday. The Rams worked under shelter for more than three hours and reviewed their plays, learned two new formations and studied those of its next opponent, Purdue.

GENEVA, Nov. 13 (AP). -- Paraguay sent another note to the League of Nations tonight asking it to stop the Chaco war by using its powers under Article XI of the League Covenant. The note from Asuncion, the second within two days, said the League must either use its powers to safeguard peace "or suffer a grave loss of prestige."

One month of Federal regulation of the New York Stock EXchange has convinced Richard Whitney, its president, that government supervision will neither destroy the broker's business nor disrupt the traditional free and open market, he said yesterday in an interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES.
In THE TIMES of Nov. 8 I read that Margaret D. McClelland objects to my letter which appeared in a previous issue.

The Steamboat Inspection Service turned yesterday to the engine room staff of the Ward liner Morro Castle in its investigation of charges of laxity on the part of a group of five officers during the fire that wrecked the ship the morning of Sept. 8.

Possible changes in the methods now employed by Code Authorities for serial registration of NRA labels for garments and allied merchandise loom up as a result of charges that such serial marking enables competitive retailers to discover the manufacturing source of a store's merchandise.

The site of the Rialto Theatre, at Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street, has been leased for twenty years by its owners, the Gerry Estates, Inc., to Rialto Times Square, Inc., which plans to destroy the present structure and erect a new two or three story building, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Almost every topic of national interest came before President Roosevelt for at least cursory consideration today as he worked to clear his desk to depart Thursday to be absent three weeks.

Store space was one of the featured items in the commercial leases reported yesterday by Manhattan realty brokers. New retail quarters were taken by druggists, bakers and hardware dealers. Loft buildings also figured in the renting activity.

The first volume of what his publishers describe as Will Durant's"life work" will be brought out bySimon Schuster on May 15, 1935,the ninth anniversary of the publication of "The Story of Philosophy.'' This volume will be knownas The Story of Civilization; Part1."

Forcing their way into a garage at 956 Dean Street, Brooklyn, police on the staff of Chief Inspector John Seery of Manhattan found yesterday an elaborate whisky-making plant under construction. They discovered three vats of 20,000-gallon capacity each and a 2-500-gallon still connected with a huge copper coil set in a pit fifteen feet deep.
The last night of the Horse Show, after a triumphant week, was attended by a representative gathering of society. The grand finale socially was almost as resplendent as the opening night.

A special meeting of stockholders of McLellan Stores Company has been called for Nov. 28 to elect a new board of directors. Working control of the company was obtained last month by G. K. Morrow and his associates. It is expected that the Morrow group will obtain representation on the board.

Talk of a compromise on the soldiers' bonus is being heard in Washington. The chairman of the House Committee on Appropriations suggested yesterday a plan for immediate payment in the case of veterans now on the relief rolls, estimating that this would cost only a third or a quarter of the entire amount needed to pay off all of the certificates outstanding.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- The prices for hogs weighing 220 pounds or more for packing sows were steady in the trading here today, but the demand for lightweights was slower and prices were off as much as 10 cents a hundredweight. Today's arrivals were the largest for any Tuesday since Jan. 30.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 13 (AP). -- Following Senator Long's demand for swift action, the Legislature tonight suspended its rule and passed his forty-four bills to third reading for final passage tomorrow. There was not a flurry of opposition.

Giulio Gatti-Casazza will hold his annual press conference at the Metropolitan Opera House this afternoon and will announce the season's opening opera for Dec. 22 as well as other details for the coming fourteen-week period, his twentyseventh and final year as the opera's general manager.

Mr. and Mrs. Witherbee Black gave a dinner last night in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for Lieut. Commander A. Stanton Merrill, U.S.N., and Mrs. Merrill; Mr. and Mrs. Karl B. Smith, Mr. and Mrs. John Wolfe and Mr. and Mrs. William J. Ryan.

The study and treatment of mental diseases, which are as prevalent as all other diseases combined, have kept pace with the increased demands of modern life, according to the report of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, issued in conjunction with the twenty-fifth anniversary of the organization.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- One of the most important discoveries relating to the ancients since the finding of the Rosetta Stone in 1799 is a key to the shorthand of ancient Greece brought to light by H. J. M. Milne, assistant keeper of the Department of Manuscripts of the British Museum, which the Egypt Exploration Society is publishing in book form on Saturday.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 13. -- "I'll give Pittsburgh nothing except that it is a good team, and we have a good team too," Head Coach Tom Hamilton of Navy said today concerning the football game with the Panthers here Saturday. He added: "We'll go into this game just as we did into the others this season -to win."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Three Jersey City (N.J.) youths were sentenced today to prison and reformatory terms totaling nineteen years in connection with the shooting of two Darlen policemen.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- The exchange market had an extremely agitated day today with the entire gold bloc reacting unfavorably to the Belgian political crisis. Even the French franc, which is essentially independent of the other members of the bloc and which, in the view of competent observers here, will continue at the present parity no matter what happens to the belga, weakened today.

The Manhattan football team opened preparations for its final game of the season, with Villanova at Ebbets Field on Saturday, in a two-hour drill at Innisfail Park yesterday. It was the first workout of the week for the Jaspers.

Pressure against the utility stocks, resulting from the publication of a report by the Power Authority of the State of New York which suggested a downward readjustment of rates for electricity, had an unsettling effect on the share market yesterday after a promising advance had taken place in the early dealings.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- Trading in British Government funds continued active on the Stock Exchange today, but owing to profit-taking the best prices were not held. At one time the war loan reached 107, a new high record. Elsewhere the stock market's feature was early weakness in the Kaffir mines on heavy Cape selling, but the group recovered slightly in the afternoon.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

While the recent election returnsrevealed that the country as awhole is in accord with PresidentRoosevelt's national policies a casual survey made yesterday afternoon along Forty-second Street between Fifth. and Eighth Avenuesshowed that an overwhelming majority of shop owners have stoppeddisplaying the Blue Eagle, oncepowerful symbol of the NationalRecovery Act, in their store windowS.

PARIS, Nov. 13. -- Marshal Henri Petain, whose withdrawal from the Cabinet terminated his government and military activities, by Presidential decree today was reinstated permanently as a member of the Superior Council of National Defense and other military bodies.

ALBANY, Nov. 13. -- Governor Lehman today opened the prison doors for ten men who have served portions of the sentences originally imposed on them. One, Miguel Gomills, convicted of arson in New York City and sentenced June 30, 1930, to ten to twenty years, is to be deported to Spain and was released for that purpose only.

The Musical Art Quartet, consisting of Sascha Jacobsen, Paul Bernard, Louis Kievman and Marie Roemaet-Rosanoff, began its ninth subscription season at the Town Hall last night. There were only two compositions on the program: Mozart's ineffable Quartet in B flat (K. 458) and Reger's Quartet in E flat, Op. 109.

DALLAS, Nov. 13 (AP). -- Directors of the American Petroleum Institute described gasoline taxation today as an exclusive function of the State and urged the elimination of Federal, county and municipal levies on the motor fuel.
Harold G. Hoffman, Governorelect of New Jersey, told last night in a radio address from Station WHN how he planned to "rehabilitate" the State.

Warner Brothers' film version of Lajos Zilahy's play "The Firebird" replaces "The St. Louis Kid" tonight at the Strand. The players are Ricardo Cortez, Verree Teasdale, Anita Louise and Helen Trenholme.

CANADA COCHABAMBA, Bolivia, Nov. 13. -- The Bolivian army's recapture of Fort 27th of November in the Chaco territory has blocked Paraguay's efforts to capture the rich Bolivian oil fields, the general staff announced today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- Four railroads sought an injunction today to prevent Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator, from enforcing his order that Louisville and Nashville trains on the "Dixie" route continue to be routed over the Chicago Eastern Illinois tracks between Chicago and Evansville.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- More iron and steel scrap was exported from the United States during the first nine months of 1934 than ever before, either on a nine months or annual basis. Of the total 61 per cent went to Japan, according to an analysis today by the Commerce Department.
LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP). -- Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald and Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, moved today to block any efforts to bring the war debts question up for reconsideration.

Net profit of Montgomery Ward Co. for the nine months ended on Oct. 31 was $7,182,452, after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equivalent, after allowing for nine months' dividend requirements on the $7 Class A stock, to $1.37 a share on 4,467,240 no par shares of common stock.

A sale of oil paintings, drawings and water-colors mainly by modern artists attracted one of the season's largest auction audiences last night to the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., where the collection of the Chester H. Johnson Galleries of Chicago was liquidated.

Modernization work was an important factor in realty deals announced in Manhattan yesterday. Apartment houses which have been renovated or are to undergo improvements figured in the trading. Most of the new owners are investors.

Creation of a new school in Columbia University where an "educational elite" can be trained to provide leadership in American education is advocated by Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university.

The sale of the Atlantic Transport liners Minnetonka and Minnewaska to Glasgow ship brokers, announced Tuesday in London, was accepted yesterday in shipping circles as marking the end of the Atlantic Transport Line. The service between New York and London has not been functioning for two years, and the line has only two freighters, the Montauk and the Montana, remaining in its fleet. Both of these ships have been tied up here for three years.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of October: Total imports, 68,990,000; exports of British products, 36,740,000; re-exports, 4,000,000; total exports, 40,740,000; excess of imports, 28,250,000.

Maxie Rosenbloom remained a 7-5 choice over Bob Olin yesterday after both battlers had completed their heavy training in preparation for tomorrow night's fifteen-round fight for the world's light-heavy-weight championship at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- Receipts of hogs here continue heavy. Today's arrivals were the largest for any Wednesday since May and curtailed demand to some extent. Light hogs were as much as 10 cents a hundredweight cheaper early, while weighty kinds were steady to 5 cents lower.

Among nine Manhattan properties offered at foreclosure sales yesterday was a parcel consisting of seven buildings at 361-363 West Forty-second Street through to 352-360 West Forty-third Street, which were bought in by the Bankers Trust Company in an action against the Noybar Realty Corporation.

Although labor was 10 per cent more expensive and taxes and the costs of raw materials also increased, the General Foods Corporation earned almost as much in the third quarter of this year as in the corresponding period of last year, C.M. Chester, president, said in the corporation's pamphlet report issued yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 14. -- With Senator Huey Long sitting on the Speaker's dais directing action, his House of Representatives in three hours this afternoon passed his forty-four bills designed to "share the wealth" and further clinch his control of the Louisiana State Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- October cotton consumption was placed today by the Census Bureau at 520,310 bales of lint and 57,412 bales of linters, compared with 295,960 bales of lint and 54,690 bales of linters during September this year, and 504,055 of lint and 64,473 of linters during October last year.
PARIS, Nov. 14 (AP). -- Princess Alexis Midivani, her Prince and 120 guests celebrated her twenty-second birthday tonight in princely style.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 11. -- Henri Jaspar, Foreign Minister in the previous Belgian Cabinet, was selected today by King Leopold to form a new ministry after long consultations with political leader. M. Jaspar on leaving the palace indicated that he had not yet given his consent but would announce his decision tomorrow after conferring with his friends.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP). -- A many billioned expansion of the public works program, designed eventually to absorb all direct relief rolls, was strongly hinted today by Secretary Ickes.

When Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney completed their cases yesterday in the Supreme Court, Justice John F. Carew announced from the bench the principle on which he would decide today their struggle for the custody of Mrs. Vanderbilt's 10-year-old daughter.

Scrimmaging was the order of the day at Baker Field yesterday as Columbia reached the peak of its training for its encounter with Penn at Philadelphia on Saturday. It was cold and windy along the Harlem River, but that did not deter the Blue and White from working for more than two hours.

The interim statement of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., for the nine months ended with September shows earnings of $14,017,808 after expenses, provision for taxes and other charges, equal to 86 cents a share on 14,584,025 no-par common shares after dividend requirements on preferred stock.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- Efforts of local bulls to advance prices of corn today on the Board of Trade met fair success, as futures at the extreme were the highest since late in August. Profit-taking was too heavy, however, for the limited outside support, and toward the last some operators who had bought yesterday started to sell.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- Samuel Insull Jr. took the witness stand in Judge James H. Wilkerson's Federal court late this afternoon to defend himself from the government's accusation that in 1929 he entered into a scheme to defraud the public in the sale of Corporation Securities Company stock.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14. -- Bolivia reports important advances on two roads thirty miles apart, pushing back the Paraguayans from positions in the northwestern Chaco where they were threatening the Bolivian oil fields. The Bolivians captured Fort Senator Long on the southern road and Fort Piquirenda on the northern road.

Stanford's Indians, now on the warpath on Pacific Coast gridirons, replaced Alabama's Crimson Tide as the runner-up to mighty Minnesota yesterday in the national ranking list of college football teams, compiled by The Associated Press from more complete returns in a poll among the country's leading newspaper observers.

The bulk of a collection of 1,358 paintings which Jonas Lie, president of the National Academy of Design, calls "quite the most important collection of American art from the standpoint of history and chronology" has been deteriorating in the darkness of a storehouse for nearly thirty years because its owner, the National Academy of Design, does not have adequate funds or gallery facilities to display it.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- The Boerse was quiet and slightly weaker today. Heavy industrials moved lower, Kloeckner losing 3/4 point. Potashes again were stagnant. Machineries were fairy strong at the opening, but closed weak, Orenstein Koppel losing 2 1/2 points.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Norman H. Davis and the other American naval delegates went to the House of Commons today for another inconclusive talk with the British concerning the deadlock precipitated by Japan's demand for equality and prolonged by Britain's manoeuvring to satisfy her on terms that the United States continues to oppose.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- While Attorney General Wilentz in Trenton was denying a request that Bruno Richard Hauptmann's sequestered funds be released to his lawyers, Prosecutor Anthony M. Hauck Jr. rejected another request here today that the Hauptmann guard in the county jail be eased.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, Nov. 14. -- The report of the German Dye Trust for the third quarter of 1934 indicated continued favorable development of home trade, but admits exports are meeting growing difficulties and in some sections have shown substantial declines.
It develops that Gifford Beal, well-known American artist and a member of this year's prize jury at the Carnegie International, has gone in for ship figureheads, and on a rather ambiguous scale.

IT must be, as they say on the Waterbury, Winsted and Woonsocket circuit, "nigh onto Winter." Hockey players have been sighted in the offing, venturing out on thin ice. They have kept very quiet since the ice went out last Spring, leaving the field to baseball players, the track and field men, the prizefighters and, lately, the heroes of the gridiron.

The press dispatch that the government is contemplating "a bold move to spur recovery" is very welcome news to all those who believe that the time may now have arrived when powerful governmental action is advisable to initiate a genuine recovery.
STOCKHOLM, Nov. 14. -- Professor Gustav Cassels, financial expert, writing in the Svenska Dagbladet today, criticized the economic policies of countries having dictators.

Forty-two promotions were made in the Police Department yesterday, the first since Lewis J. Valentine became commissioner two months ago. Two deputy chief inspectors, two inspectors, four deputy inspectors, four captains, fourteen lieutenants and sixteen sergeants were created.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 14. -- The unclad body of the child found yesterday in a shallow grave in the grounds of a hospital on the outskirts of the city was positively identified today, after a night of doubt, as that of Dorothy Ann Distelhurst, who disappeared on Sept. 19 while on her way home from kindergarten.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- Within a few months Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Executive Council, will be in a position legally to declare an Irish republic, and the first to recognize her as such will be Germany.

Clarence C, Drake, manager of a Brooklyn chain grocery store, who made a vow a year ago that he would never again submit to a holdup, was shot and killed by two robbers yesterday in a struggle to protect company funds. The killers escaped without loot.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was less active yesterday, but prices were higher in most sections of the market. Bonds were fairly steady, with a tendency to sag. The agricultural staples were weak at the end of the day. Foreign exchanges were steady except for sterling, which fell 1 1/8 cents to $4.99 1/8.

If the Fordham University seismograph noted any unusual earth tremors yesterday the explanation is quite simple. It merely was the ponderous Chicago Bears working out at the Polo Grounds for their all-important game with the New York Giants on Sunday.

BERLIN, Nov. 14. -- The impact on the German shipping lines of the continued decline in world trade in general and Germany's foreign trade in particular, coupled with the increased control over their management exerted by the Nazi regime, has given new momentum to reorganization plans long debated but thus far left in their initial stages.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Twenty-six national banks, whose frozen deposits had amounted to $31,493,000, were licensed in October, the Treasury announced today.

" The Gay Divorcee," RKO-Radio's film version of the Broadway musical farce of '32, begins an engagement this morning at the Radio City Music Hall. Fred Astaire, who appeared in the original: Ginger Rogers, Alice Brady and Edward Everett Horton top the cast.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The Princeton football squad today drove with vigor through its last hard practice for the Yale game here Saturday.
Quotations for all classes of credit -- on call loans, maturity money and business paper -- remained unchanged in a quiet market. Routine requirements only engaged the attention of the borrowers.

Verdi's "Aida" will open the Metropolitan Opera season on Saturday evening, Dec. 22. Kirsten Flagstad, a Norwegian soprano, has been engaged to replace Frida Leider in leading Wagnerian roles. Cimarosa's "Il Matrimonio Segreto," previously announced for its first Metropolitan production, has been abandoned and in its place two masterpieces of Italian opera-buffa, Pergolesi's "La Serva Padrona" and Donizetti's "Don Pasquale," will be presented.

ROUSES POINT, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP). -- A couple who said they were Rabbi and Mrs. David Katzman of New York City were arrested on an international train today and charged with attempting to bring gold into the United States from Canada.
Members of the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique closed yesterday the sixty-sixth salon held under its auspices, in conjunction with the national hotel exposition at the Grand Central Palace.

A major committee to study and make recommendations regarding the master Retail Code for presentation in Washington was named yesterday by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at a meeting in its offices here.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14. -- The need of support of privately maintained charities is urgent despite the activities of the government in the field of relief, said Newton D. Baker, chairman of the 1934 mobilization for human needs, and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who heads the women's committee of that organization.

Pirate a treasure bobs up on Blackbeard's Island off the Georgia coast. There an exploring citizen has discovered a subterranean wooden chamber in which he believes are deposited the famous buccaneer's life savings.

The Board of Education voted yesterday to seek a PWA loan of $1,500,000 to build and equip a combination elementary and junior high school within the area of the proposed city housing development in the Williamsburg district of Brooklyn.

Melvin C. Eaton, Republican State chairman, intends to call a conference of twenty or twenty-five of the leading Republican members of the Assembly, at which the question of the minority leadership and a legislative program will be discussed.

Stimulated by cold weather, retail trade both here and out-of-town has scored sharp gains this week, reports here yesterday indicated. Current increases are running appreciably larger than during the first ten days of the month and an excellent showing for November as a whole seems in prospect.

Weakness was the rule yesterday in most of the commodity futures markets here, but sugar, cocoa and copper futures were slightly firmer in the face of heaviness centring particularly in hides, rubber, silver, silk and coffee. In the cash markets cocoa advanced and lard and dairy products went to new high levels.

Samuel L. Rothafel, better known as Roxy, will take over the management of the Mastbaum Theatre in Philadelphia, a Warner-operated house, on Christmas Day, according to an announcement yesterday by H.M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc.

T.J. White, a member of the newsprint committee of the Hearst newspapers, took issue yesterday with a statement of Frank W. Clarke, vice president of the Anglo-Canadian Pulp and Paper Company, Ltd., regarding the effect of the decision of the International Paper Company to increase its newsprint prices $5 a ton in 1935.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 14 (AP). -- An Ohio woman's letter to President Roosevelt resulted in the round-up of seven persons in a conspiracy ring which had fleeced 2,000 investors of $133,000 in eighteen States, Ambrose Epperson, Assistant United States Attorney, said tonight.

The directors of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company voted yesterday to retain Samuel Untermyer as special counsel to represent the company's stockholders in negotiating with the city for rapid transit unification. The law firm of Cromwell Sullivan will be associated with Mr. Untermyer.
