WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Denials that evidence showed Negroes to be systematically excluded from Alabama juries where the Scottsboro attack cases were tried were made by Thomas E. Knight Jr., State Attorney General, when he filed a brief in the Clarence Norris case in the Supreme Court today.

Mme. Maria Jeritza, operatic and concert singer, about whom rumors have been current that she was going to be divorced from Baron Leopold Von Popper de Podragi of Vienna, virtually admitted yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis that there was a good foundation for the report.

Nathan Machlowitz, labeled "All-American substitute" by those who have followed his career as a ball carrier through the past two seasons, was chosen unanimously to lead the New York University football team next Fall at a meeting of the Violet lettermen yesterday.

Domestic speculative markets remained dull yesterday and price movements were uncertain. Bonds were steady with the exception of some of the foreign loans, in which there was active selling. The Italian issues were conspicuously weak, a reflection of the Italian Government's new foreign-exchange policy.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- A $50,000 fire wrecked St. Bonaventure Monastery in Ramsey Street today, after eighty Franciscan fathers and friars had made their way to safety. Three of the friars, who fled to the roof of the three-story building, were in danger of suffocation by smoke when firemen arrived and led them down ladders to safety.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 10 (AP). -- Getting a smart ride from Jockey G. Arnold, Sandwrack, a 7-to-1 shot, accounted for the feature race today at Epsom Downs, the $800 Beaumont claiming purse. He returned $16 for $2 straight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The following seventy-three organizations and public offices were among those listed as represented at the Attorney General's conference on crime which opened here tonight:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Salaries of executives of large corporations were shown today in registration statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to have increased in some instances by 200 per cent this year, but on the whole they remained stationary or increased less sharply.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- A capacity audience -- rare for the nation's capital -- greeted and cheered Ina Claire tonight in "Ode to Liberty," produced by Gilbert Miller. Those present, who included the political and social dignitaries who emerge in force only for stars of the first magnitude, greatly enjoyed Miss Claire in a light comedy role from Michel Duran's "Liberte Provisoire," adapted freely by Sidney Howard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Thomas N. McCarter, New Jersey public utilities official, appeared before a District of Columbia grand jury today to testify in the government's inquiry into activities of income-tax "experts" who are alleged to have asserted that they could "fix" contested claims.

A move to recommend that the totalizator be adopted as the betting medium at all race tracks was held in abeyance yesterday by racing representatives who met at the offices of the New Jersey Racing Commission in Jersey City.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The text of President Roosevelt's address at the opening session of the Attorney General's Crime Conference tonight was as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Two attacks on the constitutionality of the NRA came before the Supreme Court today, one relating to the Oil Code on which oral argument was heard, and the other on used-car price fixing in which the court noted probable jurisdiction.

Barron G. Collier, the only honorary deputy Police Commissioner in the department, has resigned from his position, it became known yesterday afternoon at police headquarters. Mr. Collier, who had the title of Special Deputy Police Commissioner, had served for many years as liaison officer between the New York and foreign Police Departments.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 10. -- The importance of recapturing foreign markets as a means of restoring national prosperity was emphasized today in a message from President Roosevelt and an address by Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, at the opening session of a convention of the American Farm Bureau Federation.

LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The United States has "ridden out the tempest and a fairer future than ever spread before it," Professor Allan Nevins of Columbia declared today in the last of his six lectures on the New Deal at University College here.

Former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer denounced last night the organized world Jewish boycott of Germany and the proposed world Jewish congress as elements of a "doctrine of destruction for American Jewry."

The listed bond market continued to move irregularly lower yesterday in quiet trading. Italian issues were the weakest of the foreign group as the aftermath of the move made on Saturday by the Italian Government to halt the flow of gold from Italy by requisitioning foreign credits of its nationale.

The New York County grand jury began yesterday an investigation of alleged violations of Section 120 of the Penal Law by persons who have been soliciting clients for Mexican lawyers in one-day divorce proceedings in that country, in which the fees run from $25 to $750.

Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, won a sweeping victory at a meeting of its executive committee last night when by a vote of 65 to 5 the district leaders upheld his choice of David B. Costuma, leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District, for a two-year term as a member of the election board. Four members did not vote.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Henry G. Bugbee Jr., '36, of New York, was the recipient of the Coaches' Cup for his victory in the single sculls championship of Princeton University, at the fifth annual rowing dinner tonight at the Nassau Inn.

DETROIT, Dec. 10. -- Automobile workers affiliated with the American Federation of Labor will not participate in the forthcoming plant elections announced by the Automobile Labor Board, F.J. Dillon, general organizer of the A.F.L., said today.

A large gathering attended Mr. Bagby's 375th Musical Morning yesterday in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Mme. Grete Stueckgold and Emanuel List of the Metropolitan Opera and Alberto Salvi, harpist. Coenraad V. Bos and Arpad Sandor were at the piano.

Baseball men were trooping into the city from all sections of the country yesterday for the annual major league Winter conventions, which swing into action today, but at a late hour last night baseball was still being only remotely discussed. Instead, every one seemed to be wrapped up entirely in arguments relating to dog racing.

Contributions totaling $112,437.27 have been received by the Young Women's Christian Association in this city toward the $200,000 needed to balance the 1935 budget, Mrs. Frank C. Munson, campaign chairman, announced yesterday. She made public, gifts of $100 and over received in the last two weeks, as follows:

The penthouse of Samuel M. Goldsmith, broker, atop the Hotel Beekman at 575 Park Avenue, was robbed last Saturday of $51,000 worth of jewelry, it became known last night. The robbery occurred while Mr. and Mrs. Goldsmith were spending the week-end at their Summer home in Deal, N.J.

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 11. -- Fire swept through the Hotel Kerns here this morning, leaving fourteen known dead, of whom six were State legislators, about fifty persons unaccounted for and forty injured.

The weekly listing of "indecent and immoral" motion pictures as well as of approved pictures, which was started Sunday in Catholic churches of the New York archdiocese, probably will not be uniformly followed elsewhere, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- A possible shift of the line-up in the contest for reorganization of the House appeared today, with many Northern Democrats insisting that Representative Bankhead withdraw from the Speakership race to seek the floor leadership.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 11 (AP). -- Despite the "disastrous drought," Chester C. Davis, administrator of the Agricultural Adjustment Act, said today that "supplies in all commodities for which control programs were carried out are still ample."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 1. -- The City Council here adopted the 1935 budget today setting a tax rate of $3 for each $100 of assessed valuation. The rate is eighteen points under the 1934 levy and about twelve points less than the rate fixed by the budget originally proposed by City Manager Irving C. Brewer.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 11. -- Providence College opened its basketball season tonight by defeating Harvard, 45 to 21. Providence was in front from start to finish, leadnig 20 to 9 at half time, then continuing at a furious pace in the second period.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- Harvard's hockey forces opened the college season at the Boston Arena tonight with a field day on the ice. The Crimson overwhelmed Coach George Owen's M.I.T. six, 10 to 0, while the Crimson freshman sextet defeated Framingham High School, 13 to 0.

BELGRADE, Dec. 11. -- While the resolution of the League of Nations Council in the dispute with Hungary was being acclaimed here as a victory, rumors were circulating concerning impending Cabinet changes.

The probability, that the coming New York racing season would open on April 20, 1935; the prediction by Algernon Daingerfield that 1935 would be a banner turf year, and praise from William Woodward for the racing commissioners and secretaries meeting in Jersey City were developments in local racing circles yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Some specific suggestions for standards in the contemplated nation-State unemployment insurance laws were made today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.
A press dispatch from Washington tells us that the world's efforts to translate the expression "The New Deal" have proved a failure.

Started for the purpose of recording in permanent form material of interest about the World War, the magazine Current History marks today the twentieth anniversary of its first publication. From an exclusively war history, the magazine has developed into a month-by-month record and discussion of events throughout the world.

The application of the Department of Sanitation for permission to extend the area of Riker's Island in the East River, to provide a dumping ground for ashes and other incinerator residue, was opposed by shipping and civic groups of the Bronx, Queens and other sections of the port, at a hearing yesterday morning before Colonel Gustave R. Lukesh, district engineer, at the Army Building, 39 Whitehall Street.

William B. Nichols, chairman of the reorganization committee of the Celotex Company, announced yesterday a modification of the reorganization plan whereby it will receive the endorsement of the debenture holders' committee as well as the bondholders' committee.

AS an aftermath to the fireworks of the final game of professional football's most successful season, there was the annual meeting of the club owners held in New York as echoes of the Giants' uproarious last period against the Bears receded into the background. Held in a hotel, the meeting in its procedure was just like the time-honored gatherings of professional baseball.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Dissatisfaction with the way government records are kept was expressed by members of the Supreme Court today as they listened to arguments on the constitutionality of the National Recovery Act as it applies to oil production.

More than 200 claims totaling about $1,250,000 had been filed yesterday by survivors or relatives of victims of the Morro Castle diaster. Charles W. Hagen of 111 John Street, who has been appointed special commissioner in the case by Federal Judge Alfred W. Coxe, is receiving the claims.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 11. -- The Romanies, amateur choral group, entertained with an informal reception tonight at Holy Trinity Parish House after rehearsal. The guests included members of the board of directors, their wives and a few others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Privately owned utilities and their holding companies were accused by the Federal Trade Commission today of having issued securities "almost without limit" in the boom years of 1928 and 1929, with the result that the losses to investors ran into billions of dollars when the market crash came.

HAMBURG, Wednesday, Dec. 12. -- Miss Isobel Lillian Steele, young American music student, who was held in custody in Berlin for four months on charges of espionage and escaped trial for her life before the People's Tribunal only through the intervention of United States authorities, was aboard the liner President Harding this morning bound for New York and freedom.

Mrs. Glora Morgan Vanderbilt filed her notice of appeal in the Supreme Court yesterday from the decision of Justice John F. Carew dismissing her habeas corpus proceedings for the custody of her 10-year-old daughter, Gloria. Justice Carew awarded part-time custody to her and Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, the child's aunt.

PARIS. Dec. 11. -- The Bourse was firm today, but despite the good news from Geneva of the settlement of the Balkan problem, transactions remained scarce. The fact that trading is still confined to professionals, with the public abstaining, is proving highly disappointing to the government and financial circles generally.

ALBANY, Dec. 11. -- Colonel Walter G. Robinson, who has been assistant adjutant general since 1926, today succeeded Major Gen. Franklin W. Ward, retired. His appointment was announced by Governor Lehman. Colonel Robinson is a graduate of the adjutant general's course, Army War College at Washington.

" The underlying spirit of angling should be that it is a sport in which the skill of the angler is pitted against the instinct and strength of the fish, and that the latter is entitled to an even chance for his life."

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- British commercial creditors of Germany will begin this week to receive 1,200,000 [the pound was quoted yesterday at $4.95] which has been made available by the Reichsbank under the terms of the Anglo-German exchange agreement for liquidating outstanding trade debts to Britain.
LANSING, Mich., Dec. 11. -- A dramatic eye-witness account of the fire at the Kerns Hotel was given by State Senator John W. Reid of Highland Park, who made his way to safety.

HAMBURG, Dec. 11. -- A definite decision to break up the German shipping trust, as represented by the Hamburg American-North German Lloyd union, which up to last year, controlled 70 per cent of the entire German merchant fleet, was announced here before a conference of several hundred shipping men by John T. Essberger, "leader" of German shipping.

Zealous and unselfish reformers, entering politics in an attempt to establish a system of good government, have "little chance of success" because of the existing political organization of the two major parties, Controller Joseph McGoldrick asserts in a series of essays on "Redirecting Education," published yesterday by the Columbia University Press.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Codified regulation of industry to relieve the employer of the necessity of invoking strong-arm methods to preserve his interests against unfair competitors was suggested to the Crime Conference today by Attorney General Bennett of New York as a weapon more effective than reform of legal systems in dealing with commercial racketeering in large cities.

The Sanitation Department's plan to displace 400 employes on snow work this Winter by substituting machinery for their services was attacked by the Board of Aldermen yesterday, but the department was finally authorized to make the change.

A major consideration of welfare workers during the past four years has been the effect of bad times on the children. Among the Neediest are many who are already showing the disastrous results of too little food, insufficient clothing, wretched sleeping quarters.

Bitter cold beset the metropolitan area yesterday for the fifth consecutive day. It extended as far south as Florida, where Tampa had its first snow in twenty-eight years, and as far west as the Plains States. The official thermometer here registered from 12 to 22 degrees above zero, and the day's average of 17 was 19 degrees below the normal for Dec. 11.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Bobby Buxton, chestnut 2-year-old gelding, took the lead at the break and withstood every challenge in the mile long featured fifth race at Epsom Downs today.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 11. -- Following protest by the Yale chapter of the National Student League, Dr. Richard Sallet of the German Embassy in Washington spoke this afternoon on "The New Foundation of the German Commonwealth." The protest was widely circulated on the Yale campus.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 11. -- In the presence of Bruno Richard Hauptmann his attorneys moved today before Supreme Court Justice Thomas W. Trenchard at the opening of the December term of the Hunterdon County court for a bill of particulars in the State's case against the alleged slayer of the Lindbergh baby.

Annunziato Vaccaro, 53 years old, owner of a waste paper packing business at 178 South Street, was burned to death yesterday afternoon in a spectacular three-alarm fire which swept the building. Vaccaro's body was found in the ruins four and a half hours after the fire began.

The "rebuilder" of the oldest school of science and engineering in any English-speaking country, the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, is the distinction that belongs to PALMER C. RICKETTS, a graduate, a member of its faculty for fifty-nine years and its president for thirty-three years.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- The resignations of Curtis Bok as president and a director of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association and of his mother, Mrs. Mary Louise Curtis Bok, as a director were added today to those of Arthur Judson as business manager and Leopold Stokowski as conductor and music director of the orchestra.
BREMERTON, Wash., Dec. 11. -- Rear Admiral John Halligan was 58 years old and a veteran of the Spanish-American and World Wars. He took command here five months ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Legislation seeking to curb a "racket" in handling of estates for incompetent veterans will be presented early in the new Congress, Representative Patman, Chairman of the Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Hospitalization and Guardianship, said today.

Directors of Loew's, Inc., declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share. Both dividends are payable on Dec. 31 to stock of record of Dec. 21.

Out of all the trade-winds that swirled around the National and American League meetings yesterday only one deal actually was completed. Manager Bill Terry of the Giants swapped young Johnny Salveson to Manager Pie Traynor of the Pirates for Leon Chagnon.

Visiting buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a gain over those registered in the previous week and in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES. For the week the arrivals numbered 610, as against 408 in the preceding week and 529 in the same period last year.

Application blanks for the registration of motor vehicles for 1935 will be available beginning today at offices of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles in the five boroughs of the city. For the present at least, the blanks will not be obtainable at police stations, as in previous years, it was announced by I. James Brody, Deputy Commissioner of the bureau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- The largest order for new military aircraft in several years was awarded today to the Northrop Corporation of Inglewood, Calif., the War Department contracting to pay $1,896,400 for 110 new-type attack planes.

A young woman who knew the difference between a thug and a philatelist thwarted a hold-up of the Hoffman Stamp Company at 29 West Thirty-fourth Street yesterday and caused the arrest of two armed men. Hundreds of excited Christmas shoppers gathered as the police, with revolvers and rifles ready, charged into the building, which is across the street from the Empire State Building and is flanked by department stores.

The Board of Health adopted yesterday an amendment to the Sanitary Code requiring that every dog on the public highways of the city be either muzzled or confined on a leash not exceeding six feet in length. The new regulation modifies the old provision that dogs be muzzled even though leashed and will be followed with an effort to force compliance.

Scores of theatregoers on their way through Times Square last night saw detectives with drawn pistols arrest Joseph Somsky for the slaying of Patrolman John P. Monahan in Brooklyn last month. Nearly ten minutes elapsed before the detectives could push their way through the throng and get their prisoner into an automobile, in which he was taken to Brooklyn.

New York University honored eighty-seven of its representatives in Fall athletics with letters and numerals, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon. Thirty-three football players, members of the undefeated freshman football team, varsity and freshman cross-country teams are included on the list.
CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N.J., Dec. 11. -- The entire City Commission of Wildwood was indicted by the Cape May County grand jury today on charges growing out of the recent four months' investigation.

With a strike meeting of the Grocery Chain Stores Executives and Employes scheduled for tonight, the Regional Labor Board will continue negotiations this afternoon with representatives of the union and the James Butler Grocery Company to avert a threatened strike of the company's New York City employes.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- Six million pounds of cabbage without an ounce of corned beef was the gift of the Federal Government to Massachusetts through an error made by the Surplus Commodities Corporation in Washington last week.
The fund for New York's Neediest cases was increased to a total of $81,656.07 yesterday by 437 contributors who gave $17,354.39.

What would be the precise word to describe the offense for which the National Academy of Design has just expelled one of its associate members? He is accused of having exhibited in the last two years two pictures that are nothing but copies of works by another Australian artist. In one instance the reproduction is almost photographic.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 11. -- The Montclair Athletic Club scored its sixth consecutive victory in the Class B division of the New Jersey Women's Squash Racquets Association today, defeating the Essex County C.C., of West Orange, 5 to 0.

Dr. Allan Roy Dafoe of Callendar, Ont., family physician of the Dionne quintuplets and about 1,400 other North country young folk, devoted yesterday to a diversity of affairs. In the morning he visited the American Museum of Natural History and discussed the family problems of whales with Dr. Roy Chapman Andrews and Director George H. Sherwood.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- Much has happened in the last few clays bearing on that well-debated problem, the future of peace in Europe. Most of the happenings have been favorable. Some are merely promising and some not so good, but on the whole the horizon is not so cloudy as it was.
GENEVA, Dec. 11. -- The League of Nations Council completed today arrangements for the League army in the Saar Basin territory and ended its most productive session in years.

Retailers will urge on Congress next month continuance of the general principles in title 1 of the NRA, according to action taken yesterday by the board of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at a meeting here. The organization represents 5,000 retail stores throughout the country.

The President's address at the Attorney General's conference on crime was a refreshing contrast to those outbursts of ostentatious moral indignation on this subject that we are so accustomed to hear from many of our politicians and police officials. Instead of a treat-em-rough speech, which would doubtless have drawn easy applause, the President chose to put before the conference a thoughtful presentation of what he recognized as "an "interrelated problem of immense diffi-"culty."

MANILA, Dec. 11. -- Babe Ruth, apparently optimistic concerning his chances of becoming a pilot for some American League club, said tonight: "I won't sign a player's contract, and will quit baseball if I fail to land a manager's job."

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 11 (AP). -- The Boston Bruins, after outplaying the New York Americans by a wide margin during the first two periods, started coasting in the third frame and just managed to turn back a determined rally by the star-spangled players to register a 4 to 3 hockey victory tonight before 7,500 fans in the Boston Garden.

In an effort to save the life of 12-year-old Stanley Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Walker of 1,080 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx, who is believed dying of a strange blood disease in the New York Hospital, persons who have recovered recently from blood infections of several types were appealed to last night to donate blood.

The boys at Dannemora have run into difficulties; are in Clinton Prison has struck a temporary snag. With the work that is being done in the inmate art classes there, readers of this column are already familiar. It has been commented upon many times in the last few years, particularly in connection with shows, held in New York, that contained pictures sent from the up-State prison and from various other penitentiaries and institutions of correction.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 11 (AP). -- The radio station of the General Electric Company stated today that a radiogram from Little America said the Byrd Antarctic Expedition intended to leave for New Zealand and New York the last week in January, 1935.

An Ohio-Pennsylvania woman's team of four, headed by Mrs. Anne Rosenfeld of Cleveland, won the Charles E. Coffin trophy yesterday afternoon in the second day of the American Bridge League's Fall tournament at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

They keep on shifting. "The O'Flynn," which was to arrive on Friday night at the Broadway Theatre, has postponed until some evening during Christmas week. It needs cutting. . . ."Slightly Delirious" will open on Christmas night instead of Christmas Eve.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 11. -- The 6-year-old gelding A la Carte showed a return to his best form when he scored easily in the mile-and-a-sixteenth of the featured Algiers Claiming Purse at the Fair Grounds today.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey today will advance the price of gasoline in New Jersey to approximately normal levels, thus ending the gasoline price war that has been going on in that State for more than two months. The independent distributers selling unbranded grades of gasoline will advance prices to within 1 cent a gallon of those of the major companies.

The trial of a suit against the Actors Equity Association for $100,000 damages because of the closing of the play, "Right of Happiness," in 1931, began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Daniel V. McNamee and a jury. The suit is brought by Du Roy Lemaitre, Inc., producers of the play, on the ground that the closing of the production was uncalled for.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 11 (by cable). -- Quick thinking by Captain Mattheis Oran saved the liner Vestvangen when she struck a submerged rock off Matelot Point, on the northern coast of Trinidad.

Detectives investigating a wife's complaint that her husband was missing found him dead yesterday in a vacant office on the sixth floor of 83-85 Canal Street. He had been murdered and robbed of about $6,000 worth of diamonds he was carrying as samples.

Most tape watchers were puzzled yesterday by the last-hour decline on the Stock Exchange, and Wall Street scanned the news from Washington and elsewhere for some explanation. Late in the day it seemed to be the general conclusion that the mild upset had been caused by one of those selling flurries that occasionally occur spontaneously, without outside impulses.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Grief-stricken over the death of her mate, the nudist philosopher Dr. Friederich Ritter, Dore Koerwein, one of the group of Galapagos colonists, was on her way back to civilization today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Condolences on the death of Manuel Marquez Sterling, Ambassador of Cuba, were sent by President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull today.

A gift of $1,000 from a former Negro slave was announced yesterday as the first contribution in a nationwide campaign to raise $400,000 for the expansion and improvement of Lincoln University, near Oxford, Pa.

BASLE, Dec. 11. -- The principal Central European bank governors dispersed today after their regular monthly meeting as members of the board of the Bank for International Settlements, leaving behind the impression that they are concerned now chiefly about the situation in Italy and Belgium and above the continued flow of gold to the United States and to France.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Receipts of hogs here were in heavy volume again today, but there was an active demand for offerings weighing more than 210 pounds and prices advanced 10 cents a hundred pounds. Closing prices were the best of the day.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The government tonight announced the terms on which after Jan. 7 it will shoulder the burden of relief for all the able-bodied unemployed who have been out of work too long to receive insurance benefits.

The Bangor Aroostook Railroad Company has offered to holders of three issues of 5 per cent extension bonds a par-for-par exchange for a like principal amount of the company's stamped convertible consolidated refunding mortgage 4 per cent bonds due in 1951, it was announced yesterday.

ALTHOUGH Quincy Howe's "World Diary: 1929-34" (McBride, $3.50) is a month-by-month chronicle of the depression years, it differs from the usual factual compilation. Mr. Howe believes in a thorough marshaling and airing of the evidence, but he doesn't follow the American sociological tradition, which stresses gathering the facts, but puts very little emphasis on thinking about the facts after they have been gathered.

The New York Athletic Club shut out the Bayside T.C., 5 -- 0, and registered its second victory in as many starts in Group 2 of the Eastern Squash Racquets Association tournament yesterday on the Winged Foot courts.

An all-Lieder program, wisely chosen and skillfully contrasted, was sung in the Town Hall last night by Florence Easton, who brought to groups of Schumann, Schubert, Brahms and Wolf the intelligence, the grasp of style and the exceptional diction that are familiar characteristics of her art.

The undertone of the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange showed improvement yesterday. United States Government long-term issues were up 1-32 to 8-32 point with the exception of the Treasury 4s, which sold off 1-32, and the First Liberty 4 1/4s and the Federal Farm Mortgage 3 1/4s, which held unchanged.

The New York County grand jury which had conducted an investigation since last June into the loss of millions by the city in the purchase of the wrong coal for departments under preceding Tammany administrations, handed up a presentment on its findings yesterday to Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions and was discharged.

With the city of New York accepting the check for $60,923 in payment of franchise taxes the investigation into the financial affairs of the Eastern Parkway, Brownsville and East New York Transit Relief Association was officially closed yesterday.

OSSINING, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- The Republicans made a clean sweep in the village elections here today, but the voters turned down a proposition to pay small salaries to the Village President and Trustees. The latter plan lost by 499 to 459.

Your editorial "The Bond Subscription," commenting on the oversubscription to the three Treasury offerings, said: "What it does prove unmistakably is the belief of the financial community that the danger of wholesale inflation of the currency has passed."

OTTAWA, Dec. 11. -- Canadian Mounted Police are seeking Allan Harry, Sam and Abe Bronfman, leaders in the liquor industry, on warrants connected with charges that the Dominion Government has been defrauded of $5,000,000 revenues by liquor smuggling operations.

Two hours of the Equity Council's regular weekly meeting yesterday were devoted to discussion of a petition presented by a delegation appearing in behalf of the Actors' Emergency Association. The petition asked Equity to reconsider the case of the "Baby Mine" company, which has charged unfairness in the suspension of the production by the Department of Welfare.

F.R. Hanson Jr. and E.G. McLaughlin of the Columbia Club and L.A. Strasser of the City A.C. gained the semi-final brackets yesterday in the invitation squash tennis tournament at the Princeton Club. E.R. Larigan of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, third seeded player, remained a round behind the field.

MOSCOW, Dec. 11. -- The total of persons executed in the round-up of "terrorists" following the assassination of Sergei Kiroff on Dec. 1, rose today to seventy-five. Nine of the twelve persons arrested last Friday in White Russia were convicted today of committing terroristic acts against Soviet officials and were forthwith shot by a firing squad.

The City of New York should employ the best talent available for its architectural work. In this connection it should be remembered that architects work on a uniform financial basis; among them there is no competition of rates, but only in the quality of their service.

A committee has been formed to protect the interests of holders of all equipment trust certificates of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company following the default on Dec. 1 in payment of the principal maturities on the Series L and Series Q certificates and the proposed abandonment by the bankruptcy trustees of their plan under which the payment of $4,067,000 of certificates was to be deferred for three years.

Inducting their newly elected president, Ford C. Frick, officially into office, the eight club owners of the National League opened their annual two-day Winter conclave in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. While they conducted voluminous business pertaining to constitutional baseball law, they decided not to mar an otherwise pleasant afternoon and so gingerly sidetracked their most perplexing problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- A declaration that until political pressure on law enforcement agencies disappeared and cooperation of all agencies of the law was established there could be no permanent suppression of crime was made today by J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Justice Department's division of investigation, before the conference on crime.

A second series of Sunday evening symphony concerts, which will bring to the microphone distinguished conductors and soloists representing the musical centres of the United States and Europe, will be inaugurated on Jan. 6 by the sponsor of the present WJZ networks concerts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Pricing regulations in the code for the lumbermen's industry are "making an army of scofflaws and lawbreakers," according to the testimony of lumbermen before A.C. Dixon, deputy NRA administrator, at a public hearing today on the question of abandoning price-fixing in the Lumber Code.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee's campaign to raise a minimum of $2,000,000 for the support of the city's leading private family welfare agencies enters its final week this morning, with the women's division already past its goal of $500,000.
PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 11. -- The Princeton basketball team staged a last-minute rally to defeat the Lafayette quintet by a single point in the university gym tonight. The score was 27-26.

New York Lodge of Elks, the Charity Fund of the Queens Kiwanis Club and THE NEW YORK TIMES Hundred Neediest Cases fund each will receive nearly $100 as the result of a decision yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Lockwood which was agreed to in Jamaica by representatives of the New York Lumber Trade Association, administrator of the lumber-trade code.

HONOLULU, Dec. 11. -- A week's search for Charles T.P. Ulm and his two companions was officially closed tonight when the destroyers which had been hunting far north of Oahu Island returned to Pearl Harbor. Admiral Harry E. Yarnell, naval commandant, announced this morning that the Coast Guard cutters Tiger and Reliance were returning from a search of the ocean west of Kauai Island and the Itasca was expected back late tonight or tomorrow morning.

At a season of the year when steel production usually declines, activity at the mills has increased for eight consecutive weeks. The present rate of operations is estimated at about 33 per cent of capacity, compared with 18 per cent in the early Autumn. Various factors have contributed to the present upturn.

A supper party and musicale were given last night in the Grill Room of the Ritz Tower for the benefit of the relief fund of the Russian Nobility Association, of which Prince Alexis Obolensky is president. The organization was formed recently to provide relief for destitute Russians of noble birth and their children.

Epidemiologist the world over will mourn the passing of Dr. THEOBALD SMITH. He looms large even beside PASTEUR and KOCH. Indeed, there is a curious similarity between him and the great German. Both were practicing physicians; both had an unquenchable thirst for the kind of knowledge acquired only by research; both forsook medicine for the laboratory; both made discoveries that strengthened PASTEUR'S famous dictum; "

Quick sale, with a heavy over-subscription, characterized the offering yesterday of the new issue of $6,100,000 Chicago Western Indiana Railroad Company first and refunding mortgage 5 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, due on Sept. 1, 1962, priced at 102 1/2, to yield 5.34 per cent.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale price at New York:
Miss Helen Keller was guest of honor yesterday at the Christmas sale for the blind of the New York State Commission for the Blind at 527 Fifth Avenue. She made several purchases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Breaking down of the barrier preventing ascertainment of the truth, created through the constitutional provision against self-incrimination, was urged upon the Crime Conference tonight by Ferdinand Pecora, former acting District Attorney of New York County.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 11. -- There is every indication that Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, will be confronted with strong opposition tomorrow at the conference of members of the 1935 Assembly when he opens his fight for the selection of a young Republican progressive for floor leader of the Republican minority in the lower house at Albany.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 (AP). -- Abandonment of the National Industrial Recovery Act was recommended today by Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, economist, as one of three steps he believes will clear the path for a return of widespread prosperity.

The Black Decker Manufacturing Company, makers of electric tools, reported yesterday for itself and subsidiaries a net profit of $325,533 for the year ended on Sept. 30. This was equivalent, after dividend requirements on the $25 par value 8 per cent preferred stock, to 182 cents a share on 298,355 no-par shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Great Britain's decision to withhold payment of $117,670,765 due next Saturday on her war debt to us and not to participate in conferences regarding her debt was contained in correspondence made public at the State Department today.

Thousands of assorted animals, fowls and fish will be placed on exhibition today at the fifth annual Pet, Poultry and Tropical Fish Show, which opens in Madison Square Garden at noon. The formal opening of the five-day show will take place at 8 P.M., with Mayor La Guardia officiating.
Emil Goldstein, City College fencer, last night won the junior foils competition at the New York A.C. and was awarded the Dr. Graeme M. Hammond foils.

PARIS, Dec. 11. -- Speaking quietly from his place at the front bench of the Chamber of Deputies, Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin startled that Assembly today into the full recognition that a new force has come into French politics by announcing that if it did not behave itself he was quite ready to call a new election.

OSLO, Dec. 11. -- Arthur Henderson, winner of the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize, addressed a large and interested audience at the Festival Hall of Oslo University today on the need of the creation of a world commonwealth as the only alternative to world war.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- An interesting sidelight on last night's Geneva achievement of patching up the dispute between Yugoslavia and Hungary over the assassination of King Alexander was revealed today in London diplomatic quarters. It was in the form of a story purporting to explain why the Italian representatives at the League of Nations had withdrawn their support from the intransigeant attitude taken by Hungary.

Many dinner parties will be given at the pre-view opening celebration which will take place tomorrow night at the Boeuf Sur Le Toit, a new dinner and supper club at 57 West Fifty-seventh Street, for the benefit of the Post Contagion Unit of the Speedwell Society and the Social Service Department of the Roosevelt Hospital.

Removal of the extension over Park Row into City Hall Park of the Brooklyn Bridge terminal of the I.R.T. and B.M.T. elevated lines has been decided upon by Frederick J.H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, it was announced yesterday.

HAVANA, Dec. 11. -- Rescuers of the four injured in the crash of a plane of the Cuban Aviation Company which occurred yesterday morning twenty-four miles southwest of Falmasoriano have not yet succeeded in bringing the victims out of the brush owing to the heavy rains making travel almost impossible, according to a dispatch tonight.

Frederick Buldrini plays Beethoven's concerto with the Civic Orchestra at the Natural History Museum at 2 P.M. today. Arthur Hartmann conducts his "Balkan Sketches" with the Brooklyn Symphony at Abraham Lincoln High School at 8:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- A White House conference on the advisability of helping Italy build a poison gas plant, arranged for the du Pont Company by ranking army officers, was disclosed today by the Senate Munitions Committee.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11. -- In a cold wind that hampered play, Olin Dutra, national open champion, carded a 74 today for a 36-hole score of 144 to top the field of 300 at the half-way mark of the 72-hole $12,500 Miami Biltmore Open Golf Tournament.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Angrily charging there had been intrigues behind his back, Lord Chief Justice Lord Hewart declared in the House of Lords tonight that political pressure had been applied to prevent Lord Justice Sir Henry Slesser, member of the Labor party, from becoming president of one of the courts of appeal.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Pre-holiday dullness developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade. Sentiment was more bearish than of late and pressure was sufficient to lower wheat about a cent a bushel at the extreme, several houses with Eastern connections selling rather freely on the way down.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Premier of Prussia, who organized and led the fight for the extermination of communism in Germany when the National Socialists took over the government on Jan. 30, 1933, asserted in a public address tonight that Adolf Hitler's party had not needed the Reichstag fire to rouse the consciousness of the German people.

ROME, Dec. 11. -- Although official quarters declare themselves highly satisfied with the way in which the Yugoslav-Hungarian incident was solved at Geneva, it created a certain disappointment among the public. Italian newspapers had been so strongly committed to the defense of Hungary as to give almost the impression that Yugoslavia and not Hungary was the defendant.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- President Roosevelt was quoted at a London dinner tonight by Admiral Sir Lewis Bayly of the British Navy, retired, as having told the latter that it was necessary for the American and British fleets to work together to keep world peace.

Your comments upon the shocking wholesale executions in Russia last week deserve the earnest commendation of all believers in justice and human rights. But the Stalin "purge" raises a number of issues affecting not only Russia but America as well. May I be permitted to call attention to a few of these points?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Moving toward the goal set by President Roosevelt for Federal, State and local cooperation to suppress criminals, the Attorney General's conference on crime worked on a broad program today.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 11. -- It was with great relief that the Hungarian public learned today of the settlement of the Yugoslav-Hungarian conflict at Geneva. Despite the assured tone of Hungarian official statements and newspaper articles, Hungary was well aware of the seriousness of the situation.

There were many declines on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. The volume of trading was light. In the cash markets cotton and raw sugar advanced, while declines occurred in wheat, corn, rye, cocoa, eggs, tin, rubber and silk.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,386.850 barrels, compared with 2,372,700 in the preceding week. an increase of 14,150, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A rise of 47,000 barrels in California was largely offset by declines in Oklahoma, Kansas and Texas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, declared tonight that the "spell" of regimentation and planned economy had been broken and that America now had a future of "tremendous opportunities" under a system of free enterprise.

The practice of luring nickels and pennies from the pockets of New Yorkers through slot machines has developed into a flourishing industry that has municipal sanction. This was indicated yesterday in the disclosure by License Commissioner Paul Moss that from 10,000 to 12,000 slot machines are being operated here under city license.

Stocks were driven downward yesterday in a late selling movement which Wall Street failed to explain satisfactorily. The market was easy most of the day, but its stamina was tested rather severely just before the close. The setback in prices, as measured by the index of averages, was the widest since Oct. 25.
Mayor La Guardia celebrated his birthday yesterday -- but said there was some doubt on whether it was his fifty-second or fifty-third.

A British Admiral was heard to speak contemptuously of the League of Nations as "a fancy organization." Many military authorities and not a few public men and newspapers have for some time been assuming a supercilious attitude toward the League. A common saying has been that, as an agency for peace, it is useless or even moribund.

TOKYO, Dec. 11. -- The settlement of the Chinese Eastern Railway deal came definitely in sight last right when Foreign Minister Koki Hirota offered the Japanese Government's guarantee of the purchase money.

Dr. Harmon Smith, 62 years old, a well-known nose and throat specialist, and his wife, Janet, 42 years old, were found stabbed to death last night in the library of their four-story home at 150 East Sixty-second Street. The police said the physician had killed his wife and then committed suicide.

Abram Haitowitsch, violinist, and Max Panteleieff, baritone, the one a blind fugitive from Russia in wartime and the other escaping from the later revolution, gave a joint recital last night in the ballroom of the Hotel Plaza, where Mr. Haitowitsch has appeared annually for the last decade or more.
Every woman in the city police force will carry a revolver in her handbag, under orders issued yesterday by Chief Inspector John J. Seery.

The New York Rangers held the Toronto Maple Leafs even in the first period of their game at Madison Square Garden last night, but there the equality ended. For the rugged, high-flying skaters from the North opened up with a burst of speed and power in the next two sessions and went through to bury the blue-jerseyed New Yorkers under a score of 8 to 4.

Four Atlantic liners, which have been delayed by the heavy storms in mid-ocean, are arriving today with 2,136 passengers, many of whom are coming home for the holidays. On the Italian liner Conte Di Savoia, coming from Mediterranean ports, are Harry Bacharach, Mayor of Atlantic City, with Mrs. Bacharach; Gaston Jaccard, Consul for Switzerland in New York; Mrs. George E. Roosevelt and:

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- Defense of poison gas as the most merciful of all forms of warfare was made last night by Dr. Herbert Levinstein, an eminent chemist, addressing the Institute of Chemistry at Bristol.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Since 1923 the War and Navy Departments of the United States have approved efforts of the E.I du Pont de Nemours Company to sell explosive-making machinery and military powders to Japan, the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry revealed today in a continuation of its hearings.
Charles M. Bayer of The New York American was elected president of the Inner Circle yesterday at the annual meeting of the organization, held in the Aldermanic Chamber at City Hall.

About $11,000,000 more gold has been engaged abroad for shipment here, bringing to about $179,000,000 the total bought abroad for American account since Nov. 1. Of this amount about $136,000,000 has been imported, while approximately $43,000,000 is en route or awaiting shipping facilities.

A campaign to force the removal of illegal or dangerous electric signs, overadorned theatre marquees and other encroachments on streets and sidewalks was announced yesterday by Samuel Fassler, Man hattan Superintendent of Buildings.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved 3 to 7 points yesterday under a steady demand from foreign and domestic sources coincident with less selling by houses doing business for the government.

Judge and Mrs. Abram I. Elkus gave a dinner last night in their apartment at the Ambassador for Mrs. Harold A. Rosenbaum (Hulda Lashanska), mother of Miss Leonore Rosenbaum, whose engagement to James Hess Elkus, son of the hosts, has been announced.

Mr. MELVIN C. EATON, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, seems to have been greatly misunderstood by his predecessor in that office. Mr. MACY spurned his successor. The chosen of the Old Guard must necessarily be a hunker with his back turned to the morning of the new day.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 12. -- A committee of the Privy Council decided last night to approve termination of the Washington naval treaty. The decision will be reported to a plenary council on Dec. 19 and immediately thereafter it is expected that Ambassador Saito will notify Secretary Hull.

Reporting that volume this year is running 38 per cent ahead of 1933, members of the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers, holding their annual convention at the Hotel Astor, predicted yesterday further substantial gains next year.

The Astor Theatre, which has been dark since "The Merry Widow" ended its run on Nov. 11, will reopen tonight with "Babes in Toyland." Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's film of the Victor Herbert operetta. Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy and Charlotte Henry head the cast.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 11. -- The Rev. and Mrs. J.C. Stam, American missionaries, and their 10-week-old daughter were captured today by Communist bandits in Southern Anhui Province.

Three matches were played yesterday in the Metropolitan League Class B, Group I, squash racquets tournament, two of which resulted in clean sweeps for the victors. In Group II four matches produced only one 5-0 triumph. All the matches were in the New York division.

In the wake of the championship football game between the New York Giants and Chicago Bears and the rule changes adopted by the National Football League Monday, came the news yesterday that at least two clubs will have new coaches next year.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The Stock Exchange was more cheerful today as a result of the Yugoslav-Hungarian agreement, but business remained restricted because of the approaching end of the account. Britsh Government funds were firmer.

Harper's report the best November in three years. They have sent an eighth edition of Edna St. Vincent Millay's "Wine From These Grapes" to press, and say that last Friday they received orders for 2,500 copies. They report high sales figures also for "Lamb in His Bosom," by Caroline Miller; "English Journey," by J.B. Priestley, and "The Native's Return," by Louis Adamic.
Arthur Brisbane will be seventy today. Not 70 years old. Just seventy. It is reported only because it was the reason for calling on him yesterday. Otherwise the seventy is misleading. He seems fifty.

With the great majority of retail stores reporting such widespread popular acceptance of the new city sales tax that Christmas shopping was running more than 10 per cent ahead of last year, the Board of Aldermen decided yesterday to postpone until next Tuesday action on the various amendments to the law that have been proposed.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- The Boerse was weak gain today. Activity in stocks was limited to professionals and the reaction in bonds continued. lIeavy industrials were dull, with a downward tendency, Rheinstahl losing 1 point. Potashes were quiet and weak, Aschersleben losing 1 ponts and Westeregeln 1,.

HAVANA, Dec. 11. -- Constitutional guarantees were again suspended for sixty days in the provinces of Havana, Santa Clara and Camaguey by a Presidential decree signed late this afternoon. The government is taking this action to combat terrorist and bandit activities, which have increased alarmingly in these provinces, according to the preamble to the decree.

Three matches were played yesterday in the Metropolitan League Class B, Group I, squash racquets tournament, two of which resulted in clean sweeps for the victors. In Group II four matches produced only one 5-0 triumph. All the matches were in the New York division.

In the wake of the championship football game between the New York Giants and Chicago Bears and the rule changes adopted by the National Football League Monday, came the news yesterday that at least two clubs will have new coaches next year.

CHICAGO Dec. 11 (AP). -- Federal Judge John P. Barnes ruled today that two oil-cracking process patents held by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana are invalid and ordered dismissal of a suit by that company against the Globe Oil and Refining Company for alleged infringement.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Prices for heavy hogs advanced today 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight to the highest level since Oct. 9. Light-weight hogs were firm early, but some late sales were regarded as 10 to 20 cents lower than yesterday. The day's top was lifted 10 cents to $6.35, while the average was unchanged at $5.75.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Sharp increases during November in imports of all types of alcoholic beverages, including liquors and cordials for entry into warehouses, were reported today in preliminary figures of the Department of Commerce.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Youth sang its song to Leopold Stokowski tonight at his farewell concert for youth. Stokowski is leaving the Philadelphia Orchestra, which he has conducted for twenty-two years. Tonight at the conclusion of the third consecutive season of the concerts for youth-youth from 13 to 25 -- he said not good-bye, but au revoir.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Acclaimed the "outstanding American woman" foe 1934, Mrs. Fronklin D. Roosevelt tonight received the Gimbel national award for her achievements. She accepted it modestly at a dinner in her honor held in the Gimbel Brothers store and attended by 1,000 persons.

A non-political solution of the problems of the Jews through affirmation of their spiritual heritage was urged last night by the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, in an address at the first annual congregational dinner in the Isaac Mayer Wise Memorial Hall.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12. -- Aided by the abatement of a cold wind that knocked the scores of earlier finishers into a cocked hat, Abe Espinosa of Chicago and Mike Turnesa of Elmsford, N.Y., romped home late today to tie at 219 and lead the field at the 54-hole mark in the $12,500 Miami Biltmore open golf tournament.

HAVANA, Dec. 12. -- Eight men armed with machine guns tonight invaded the editorial offices of the morning newspaper Accion, official organ of ABC, revolutionary organization, and kidnapped six members of the Staff.

With the "upward trend in iron and steel demand still gathering momentum." the rate of operations has shown the eighth consecutive weekly gain, says The Iron Age, which, in its current review, estimates that production has risen to a level of 33 per cent of ingot capacity.

Breaking down a barrier which they themselves had set up against the innovation several years ago when it became the rage among the minor leagues, the club owners of the National League yesterday voted to admit night baseball on a limited scale.

In a decision criticizing the Superintendent of Insurance for the manner in which the F-1 issue of guaranteed mortgage certificates, aggregating $27,463,985, sold by the New York Title and Mortgage Company, has been administered since the mortgage company went into rehabilitation, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler directed yesterday an immediate vote by the certificate holders on the reorganization of the issue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Treasury tonight announced the allotment of $967,863,000 of the cash subscriptions turned in for the recent offering of about $900,000,000 of eighteen-year 3 1/8 per cent bonds and eighteen months' 1 1/8 per cent notes.

Since the beginning of the depression two of the most popular proposals for restoring prosperity have been the raising of wage rates and the lowering of weekly hours. Both were adopted in the NRA codes. Though the results achieved were disappointing, the agitation has continued for a still further raising of wage rates and a still further lowering of weekly hours.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The government favors interstate crime compacts to tighten up law enforcement, but the government will not relax its own fight against all interstate and "national" crime, Joseph B. Kennan, Assistant Attorney General, told the Attorney General's Crime Conference tonight.

Howard Coonley, president of the Walworth Company, was re-elected president of the American Standards Association at the annual meeting of the organization in the Hotel Astor yesterday. Frederick E. Moskovics, representing the Society of Automotive Engineers, was again chosen to serve as vice president.

Today's free concerts include the State Symphonic Band, 3 P.M., Brooklyn Museum, and 8:30 P.M., Julia Richman High School; Greenwich Sinfonietta, 4 P.M., Columbia University, and Empire String Quartet, 8:15 P.M., Educational Alliance.

The special meeting of stockholders of the Republic Steel Corporation scheduled for Dec. 17. at which action was to have been taken on the proposed consolidation of Republic and the Corrigan-McKinney Steel Company, has been postponed until Feb. 5, it was announced yesterday by T.M. Girdler, chairman of Republic.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Dec. 12 (via Mackay Radio) (AP). -- The geological sledging party of the second Byrd Antarctic expedition has discovered coal fields and plant-bearing sandstone holding numerous fossils.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- In the peaceful setting of an old English manor house at Knowle Park, Cranleigh, Surrey, a conference began over teacups today that is expected to determine the fate of the throne of Siam.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 12. -- Mrs. E.B. Shipp's Irene's Bob showed an amazing streak of speed in the five and a half furlong Lake Charles Handicap, which featured the program at the Fair Grounds today, to triumph by five lengths and shatter an 8-year-old track record.

A highly interesting exhibition has been installed at the Downtown Gallery, 113 West Thirteenth Street. It is called "Practical Manifestations in American Art," and opens today, remaining current until the first of the year.

Committees have been appointed by the Authors League and the Newspaper Guild to settle details of their proposed association. The Newspaper Guild committee is made up of Heywood Broun, Carl Randeau and Paul Fredericksen. The Authors League committee consists of Elmer Davis, Homer Croy, Arthur Richman, Sidney Howard, Ralph Block and John Howard Lawson.

Special holiday sales are being held by various thrift shops throughout the city which are maintained for the benefit of various charitable organizations. Several are making appeals at the Christmas season for donations from individuals of useful articles suitable for resale later at the shops.

OTTAWA, Dec. 12. -- Mackenzie King, former Prime Minister of Canada, called on the National Liberal Convention here today to press for an empire-wide investigation into the operations of arms manufacturers. His proposal was based on revelations at the Washington munitions inquiry, and drew from Colonel Herbert Mackie, a former Member of Parliament, a denial that he had had any communication with the du Pont interests since 1922.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A jolly little Canadian doctor, who chuckles like Santa Claus, talked babies today with President Roosevelt.

A plan for promoting cooperation between commercial banks and the Export-Import Banks was announced yesterday by the American Bankers Association, following conferences recently between George N. Peek, president of the Export-Import Banks, and the association's advisory committee to the Export-Import Banks.

Lew Brown's revue, "Calling All Stars," a large entry in this town's current race for musical show honors, arrives at 8:30 o'clock this evening to take its opening salute at the Hollywood Theatre. It arrives, to be exact, from Boston and the adventures of its tryout there, with the names of Lou Holtz, Phil Baker and Everett Marshall at the head of its titular list of stars.

There is good Republican precedent for Mr. ROOSEVELT'S demand yesterday that profits be taken out of war. President HARDING advocated this, and virtually took the position that in wartime wealth should be drafted as well as men. COOLIDGE and HOOVER echoed him. Since then we have had the proposal that no arms or implements of war should be manufactured at all except by the Government.

PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Paris dressmakers indulged today in their annual pastime of looking over the field of their customers and naming the women they regarded as the most elegantly gowned in the world.

BERLIN, Dec. 12. -- The Boerse was weaker today. Heavy industrials and lignites were lower and electricals lost 1/2 to 1 point. Chemicals were resistant, although I.G. Farben lost one-fourth point. Textiles were slightly weaker and quiet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- An effort to settle the long-standing dispute over competition between prison-made goods and those of normal industry was begun by President Roosevelt today with the creation of an organization known as Federal Prison Industries, Inc.

Miss Janet St. Clair Mullah gave a dinner last night at the home of her mother, Mrs. George V. Mullan, 25 East Eighty-third Street for Archibald G. Macdonnell. The other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Hubert Strange Dunning, the Misses Mary Lawrence Swift, Elizabeth Watts Englar and Jean Swartz; Russell Tucker, Frederick Geller Duncan and Charles Notebaert.

The advisory council of the New York Stock Exchange received a definite role in shaping future policies of the Exchange last night in a five-hour conference with Richard Whitney, president, and other Exchange officials. The council of ten "outsiders," some of whom previously were not content with the routine character of their duties, were guests of Mr. Whitney at dinner at the Links Club.

The Manhattan basketball team, functioning with smoothness and precision, sent Seton Hall College down to a 38-to-21 defeat at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. The victory was the second of the season for the Jaspers and preserved their undefeated record.

The pleasure of giving often lies partly in choosing the gift. From the search through busy stores for the thing that will be most appreciated on Christmas morning, the weighing of alternatives, the question of deciding whether stockings or gloves, a book or a picture, will be most welcome, the giver himself derives keen satisfaction.

Placards protesting the treatment of Catholics in Mexico were carried into the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Guadaloupe, in Fourteenth Street west of Seventh Avenue, yesterday afternoon by 300 students who had just come from picketing the Mexican Consulate General at 225 West Thirty-fourth Street with about 350 others.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- A movement for new and stronger laws against subversive activities, defined generally as any attempt to overthrow by force our present form of government, has been started in the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

HAMBURG, Dec. 12. -- Progressive break-up of the Hapag-Lloyd (Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd Lines) into more than a dozen smaller lines and operating units, announced yesterday, represents Germany's effort to master the shipping crisis and meet a changed world situation, John T. Essberger, "leader" of German shipping, told this correspondent today.

The proposal to merge the Metropolitan Opera and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was abandoned yesterday. Arturo Toscanini's opinion, received by cable from Milan, that the combination would not be to the artistic advantage of either organization was the decisive factor.
Business in the credit market was small, representing chiefly routine requirements. Quotations for all classifications remained unchanged.

MILAN, Dec. 12. -- Arturo Toscanini is opposed in theory to the amalgamation of the New York Metropolitan Opera and the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, his son, Walter, told The Associated Press today.

THE invitations stated flatly that it would be an honor to have the pleasure of the recipient's company at the ceremony attendant on the laying of the cornerstone of the Jack Dempsey restaurant. There would be a buffet luncheon first and His Honor, Mayor La Guardia, would officiate.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The Westchester County Park Commission announced today the retirement of Jay Downer as chief engineer. It was under Mr. Downer's personal direction that the entire Westchester park system, including the Bronx River Parkway and its extension, was constructed at a total cost of more than $90,000, 000.

Peter Fick of the New York A.C. swam an excellent race last night to beat his team-mate, Ogden Woodruff, in a 100-yard free-style match race at the N.Y.A.C. The winner was clocked in 0:51.9, only nine-tenths of a second behind the world's mark held by Johnny Weissmuller.

Written with the same crispness and clarity that has characterized his books and essays, the annual report of the Secretary of Agriculture is both a claim of gains achieved and an examination of problems that lie ahead. AAA has taken some hard knocks. It has been accused of destroying potential wealth, of subsidizing inactivity, of regimenting the hitherto unregimented farmer.
The list of the President Johnson of the Dollar Line, leaving today for the regular round-the-world voyage via the Panama Canal, includes:

William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, is to be commiserated on his lack of perception. Five days after a severe cold snap envelops New York City he announces that he hopes to have a number of armories opened next week as recreation centres for the homeless. Arrangements will be made to hand out hot coffee and sandwiches to the 10,000 unfortunates housed in the Municipal Lodging House and other institutions.

With the subsidence yesterday of selling, the share market began to orient itself. At the close of a day in which there were several "constructive influences," the main body of stocks on the Stock Exchange rested not far from the last price level of Tuesday; the combined averages were off 17 cents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Organized labor took issue with commerce and industry today by announcing that its legislative program included several proposals denounced by the nation's leading commercial and industrial groups.

The eight-story building at 247-259 West Fifty-fourth Street, formerly the home of the Automobile Club of America, was leased yesterday to Joseph E. Ferguson, owner of the Fergus Motors Company, which will occupy the property as a garage. Rentals in excess of $200,000 ,will be paid for the use of the building, which has a frontage of 131 feet, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

LIVERPOOL, England, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The floor of a concert hall where nearly 500 parents and children were gathered at the St. Clement's School here collapsed with a roar tonight, injuring about 150 of them, many seriously.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The Scarsdale Woman's Club, which attracted nation-wide attention last year with its campaign for the improvement of radio programs generally heard by children between the hours of 4 P.M. and 8:15 P.M. announced today the results of the survey made of programs during those hours.

Tribute to Arthur Brisbane was paid yesterday at a luncheon in the Warwick by leaders in the professional and business life of the nation. The occasion was his seventieth birthday anniversary and the completion by him of fifty-one years as a newspaper man.

The Fox film version of the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical show, "Music in the Air," opens today at the Radio City Music Hall. Among the players are Gloria Swanson, John Boles, Douglass Montgomery and June Lang. On the stage will be "Varieties," a divertissement in three scenes, staged by Leon Leonidoff.

Ernest Schelling, pianist and conductor of the Young People's Concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, returned yesterday on the Paris. He will begin his Saturday morning concerts the first week in January. During the Summer he climbed mountains in Switzerland and later made a concert tour of Holland.

As a result of the NRA the cost of equipment and repairs for school buildings has increased 20 per cent, it was noted yesterday after the Board of Education had voted to request Budget Director McGahen to approve revised estimates for the work.

Prices of commodities on the various exchanges here were generally higher yesterday, although cotton seed oil futures dropped sharply on profit taking. The volume of trading was light. In the cash market, rubber was higher, but all grains, butter, lard and tin were lower.
Trading on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to reflect buying power sufficient to absorb government selling, so that the list closed a point higher to a point lower than on Tuesday.

The suspected rum-runner Mary Kenney disabled and drifting off the Atlantic Coast, had eluded a Coast Guard cutter in a snowstorm, it was admitted yesterday by Coast Guard officials. Captain William H. Shea, commander of the guard in this area, said that on Monday the cutter Champlain was replaced by the cutter Icarus and that later, during a northwest blow, the two boats became separated.

Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, came to New York yesterday to tell banking, business and industrial leaders once more that recovery had been retarded by their "lack of willingness to accept the New Deal as a necessity and follow the leadership of the President."

ALBANY, Dec. 12. -- Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer gave his chewing gum a thorough workout in the County Court building here today while nine attorneys, seven representing the government and two for the defense, argued over him for almost two hours in removal proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Cotton seed crushed during the four months from Aug. 1 to Nov. 30 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 1,767,722 tons, as compared with 1,983,047 tons in the same period a year ago, and cotton seed at mills on Nov. 30 was 1,232,067 tons, as compared with 1,353,691 a year ago.

Detectives on the staff of Deputy Chief Inspector John J. Seery raided the top floor of a twelve-story loft building at 19 West Twenty-first Street early last evening, seized $600,000 in counterfeit sweepstakes tickets and arrested three men.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- The conference of Republican Assemblymen adjourned without a showdown today when those attending refused to vote on a recommendation of the State chairman that some one besides Joseph A. McGinnies be elected minority leader of the 1935 session of the Assembly.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Without waiting for Japan to terminate the Washington Naval Treaty, the British Cabinet virtually decided today to adjourn the three-power naval discussions after three months of inconclusive talk.
Leading from the opening jump, Fordham's basketball team scored a 37-to-20 victory over St. Peter's College of Jersey City last night.
NORRIS, Tenn., Dec. 12. -- Three youths, burned to death after midnight by fire which swept the Clear Creek Civilian Conservation Corps Camp, were identified today. They were:

Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown, retired Chancellor of New York University, who died on last Nov. 3, provided for division of his estate into twenty-four parts, it became known yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

A spending program by industry for replacement and modernization of equipment is now under way as the one quick method of giving a stimulus to employment this Winter, James A. Moffett, Federal Housing Administrator, announced here last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- An intention to negotiate a reciprocal trade agreement with the Netherlands and its possessions, the third largest colonial empire in the world in respect to population, was announced today by the State Department.
LONDON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for November:

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade and found support lacking, with the result that wheat closed 1/4 to 1/2 cent a bushel lower on the December and 1 1/8 cents down on the distant future, making the sixth day of a straight decline.

Lewis W. Douglas, speaking publicly for the first time since he resigned from President Roosevelt's administration as Director of the Budget, took sharp issue last night with the Federal recovery program.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- The depression will end in about six months and the nation will emerge into a year of full business prosperity, General Charles G. Dawes, chairman of the board of the City National Bank and Trust Company and former Vice President of the United States, predicted today at a luncheon of the Chicago Association of Commerce.

BOSTON, Dec. 12. -- Four motion picture houses in New England were bombed early today at almost the same hour, and as a result police guarded every theatre in Boston tonight. Two of the bombs were exploded here, one in the Tremont, facing Boston Common, and one in the Majestic.

PARIS. Dec. 12. -- The Bourse continued dull today, with the public showing no interest in the market and speculators waiting to see the outcome of the wheat debate in the Chamber of Deputies. Yesterday's firmness turned to heaviness, although the differences in prices were slight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Continued flexible control of agricultural production, decentralization of industry to provide employment in new locations and a lowering of industrial prices that have advanced too far were recommended by Secretary Wallace in his annual report to President Roosevelt today as the soundest program for economic betterment of urban and rural populations.

Subscriptions of $100 and more received by the bankers and brokers committee of the United Hospital Fund thus far total $57,585, it was announced yesterday by James Speyer, the committee's chairman. The contributors total 271.

In the last of the women's Class A squash racquets team matches, the Junior League yesterday emerged the victor in the New York division by a 5-0 defeat of the Heights Casino team at the latter's court in Brooklyn.

Governor Lehman will confer with a group of representative up-State Democratic chieftains in Albany tonight to seek their cooperation in the enactment of the program of legislation he offered in his campaign for re-election.

Quiet trading in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with intermittent rallies, left closing prices irregularly higher on the day. United States Government bonds were up 6-32 point to 2-32 lower. Domestic corporation bonds were generally steady, and foreign loans showed rather wide irregularities.

The Columbia Club's team scored a 3-to-2 victory over the New York A.C. squad on the letter's courts yesterday for its sixth straight triumph in the Metropolitan League Class A squash tennis competition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Frowns by Justices of the Supreme Court at the uncorrelated profusion of emergency law-making by Executive Fiat prompted a presidential study today of how to systematize the issuing of executive orders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- In a ruling taking issue with Donald Richberg, director of the National Emergency Council, and Blackwell Smith, acting general counsel of the NRA, the National Labor Relations Board announced today its adherence to the decision of Dec. 3 in the case of Dean S. Jennings, rewrite man of The San Francisco Call-Bulletin.

Reports here agree that retailers are having considerable success in increasing the sale of better grade merchandise during the present holiday period as compared with the last three years. While most customers have definite restrictions on the total amount of money they are going to spend for gifts, they are spreading it among better quality items.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Thursday, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Her hold afire, the steamship Pan Atlantic, 7,000-ton freighter owned by the Atlantic Line of Mobile and loaded with general cargo, made for port here early today.

:BUDAPEST, Dec. 12. -- Answering attacks by Father Grieger, a legitimist Deputy, in Parliament on the government's alleged Germanophile foreign policy, Premier Goe.mboes emphasized today that it was ira-! possible to ignore the existence of !the 70,000,000 C-ermans in Central EUrol.

The support of the public for the Musicians' Emergency Fund was urged yesterday by Dr. Walter Damrosch, chairman of the campaign for $400,000, at a luncheon attended by representatives of these groups and their guests at the Hotel St. Regis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- While official and unofficial reports indicate a steady upward climb in general business, Secretary Roper warned today against any sudden business inflation.
