WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Charges by the Dominion Government against officials of a Canadian distillery, alleging a $5,000,000 fraud through smuggling operations were followed by the disclosure here today that United States customs agents are in Ottawa checking records to determine how much liquor was smuggled into the United States prior to prohibition repeal.

With the fund-raising campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee within $105,000 of its original goal of $2,000,000, James G. Blaine, chairman, urged 250 workers at a report luncheon at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday to push on until they had passed the $3,000,000 mark.

The six-day cold wave here reached its peak at 12:01 A.M. yesterday with a temperature of 11 degrees, a record low for the date, and then the mercury mounted steadily to a maximum of 33. The Weather Bureau reported that today would be cloudy and warmer.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Sweeping Light, beautiful 5-year-old horse from the Eskay Stable, showed a great burst of speed in the final furlong to capture the $1,000 Regatta Handicap at Epsom Downs today. Mrs. R.T. Flippen's Chinese Empress, beaten a scant head, landed the place, with Biff, owned by Lundy and Ryan, taking show honors, three lengths behind. The time for the six-furlong dash was 1:12 2-5.

Among the various species of water or marsh loving birds occurring regularly in the United States few are more picturesque and colorful than the roseate spoonbill, often called "pink curlew" by the natives of the Southern States.

Clashes between Frank J. Prial, president of the Civil Service Forum, and Albert L. Marvin, assistant corporation counsel, enlivened a hearing yesterday before the Municipal Civil Service Commission on a motion to cut exempt attorneys jobs in the Corporation Counsel's office from 104 to 87.

The Regional Labor Board continued yesterday its conferences with representatives of the James Butler Grocery Company and the Grocery Chain Stores Executives and Ernployes Association in an effort to avert the threatened strike in the company's stores in this city.

Barnard College should strike a medal in honor of Mr. GEORGE A. PLIMPTON after the pattern of the old English gold coin called the "angel-noble," bearing as its device the figure of Mr. PLIMPTON (instead of St. MICHAEL) "standing upon and piercing the dragon" -- for he has overcome that most destructive of modern dragons -- a continuing deficit.

Topping a field of thirteen bidders, a syndicate composed of Brown, Harriman Co., Inc.; Kelley, Richardson Co. and L.F. Rothschild Co. won yesterday the award of a new issue of $1,000,000 city of Rochester, N.Y., general obligation bonds.

ESSEN, Germany, Dec. 12. -- The "business integrity" of Hugo Stinnes Jr., heir to the industrial realm left by his father, will be made the subject of a formal investigation following an attempt to exclude him from membership in the Essen Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 12. -- A detailed account of the slaying of John F. Gorrell Jr., dental student, on Thanksgiving night, was given for the first time today by Philip Kennamer, who has confessed to the killing and is held on a charge of murder.

Alexander Phillips gave a luncheon yesterday at Le Coq Rouge for Princess Viggo of Denmark. Other guests were Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Warren Jr., Miss Helen Rives, Miss Louise Iselin, Lawrence Smith Butler and Frederick Godwin.
Completing a day's trip to Washington by air, Dr. Dafoe landed at the Newark airport at 6:45 P.M. last night in an Eastern airliner.
A $2,000 check given by an anonymous contributor "In Memory of My Sons" was the largest gift received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund.
VIENNA, Dec. 12. -- Jewish supporters of the Fatherland Front, which the late Chancellor Dollfuss founded, are indignant at the treatment that that organization has just meted out to Jews.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The Democratic "freshmen" of the Congress will have a chance to express their ideas directly to President Roosevelt.

The Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore, manufacturer of military planes and flying boats, announced yesterday that it had completed what it believed was the first major reorganization consummated under Section 77B of the Federal act to help corporate reorganizations.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- There was increased strength in British Government funds on the Stock Exchange today. The new South African loan helped to infuse more life into the market, although prices were irregular. German bonds were less active in the foreign section.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick made public yesterday regulations governing the city's new inheritance tax, which became effective on Dec. 5. This tax, one of the three measures designed to raise relief funds, calls for payment to the city of 40 per cent of the amount of the State inheritance tax.
Transactions reported in the Bronx yesterday showed a demand for apartment houses in that borough.

It must be a source of nation-wide satisfaction that no less than three out of the twelve best-dressed women in the world, as designated by the Parisian dressmakers, are American-born, though only two apparently continue to make the United States their home.

The New York Board of Trade adopted resolutions yesterday opposing the adoption of "any and all" forms of Federal and State unemployment insurance, urging laws to outlaw strikes and lockouts and legislation to compel the licensing of spokesmen for capital and labor in industrial disputes.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12. -- Legal action has been taken against two more prominent British-owned corporations here today, making three now engaged in litigation with Argentine Government agencies.

The Shippers Conference of Greater New York went on record yesterday at its monthly meeting as opposed to the proposal of the trunk line railroads and roads serving New England to assess a charge of 50 cents a ton for the service of loading and unloading freight handled at piers, lighters or ear floats at North Atlantic ports.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The American Farm Bureau Federation adopted resolutions today urging that "gold certificates be issued against the profit accruing to the government in the revaluation of gold."

At a meeting of the board of trustees of the Middle Atlantic Outboard Association at the Hotel Lexington last night it was decided to conduct the seventh annual Albany-to-New York race next Spring on a handicap basis as has been the system in past years.

With the annual meetings of the two major leagues going into their final stages yesterday it appeared that player trading at these conclaves would reach a new low. For out of all the conversation, the sustained lobby-sitting and the seemingly earnest debates between rival managers, Just one lone deal developed.

Quarters for the central jury part of the Municipal Court were leased yesterday by the Sinking Fund Commission, which approved the lease of four and a half floors at 2 Lafayette Street at a rental of $80,000 a year for five years.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (AP). -- The nation's twelve Federal Reserve Banks have approved 857 applications for industrial loans totaling more than $42,000,000, it was announced tonight following a two-day conference at the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland.

Paul Musikonsky, 11-year-old Brooklyn violinist, appeared in recital at Carnegie Hall last night. His program consisted of Handel's Sonata in E, Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole" and shorter items by Mendelssohn-Achron, Joan Manen, Gluck-Kreisler and Bloch.

GENEVA, Dec. 12. -- During the League Council session just ended the writer had a private talk with a statesman who in the past has spoken very frankly and informatively. The views he expresses at this time include the following:

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 12. -- Now that I have returned from the Galapagos Islands, where, on Marchena Island, I found two dead men, I can tell the facts surrounding the discovery and the true situation on Charles Island, the modern Garden of Eden.

Lord Chief Justice HEWART, who so stoutly defended the independence of the judiciary against the encroachments of the bureaucracy, is now defending it against what he deems the invasion of politicians. Tuesday he startled that chamber of repose, the House of Lords, by a denunciation of what he called "a disgraceful bill."
LANSING, Mich., Dec. 12. -- Firemen and relief workers were laboring tonight at the task of removing the bodies of those who perished yesterday when the Hotel Kerns was destroyed by fire.

Charges that the courts and the District Attorneys' offices had failed to cooperate with the Home Relief Bureau in the prosecution of persons defrauding the relief administration were made yesterday by Edward Corsi, director of the bureau.

The directors of the Evans Products Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable on Jan. 2 to stock of record of Dec. 24. This will be the first dividend for the company since April 1, 1920, when 62 1/2 cents a share was distributed.
The bidding in by a large insurance company of a tall apartment house in Yorkville was the outstanding transaction in the auction marts yesterday.

The editorial "Peace Demanded" again hits the international nail on the head. It is a perfectly fair and comprehensive comment on the wholesale expulsion of peaceful and inoffensive Hungarians from their homes, without a moment's warning and in the midst of scenes of unparalleled disorder, hardship and horror, so graphically described in the press dispatches.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Election of Representative Byrns as Speaker of the House in the new Congress was virtually assured tonight with the withdrawal of Representative Rayburn from the contest.

The New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the listing of 748,592 additional shares of the Callahan Zinc-Lead Company, which intends to offer the new issue to stockholders at $1 per share in order to obtain working capital. By agreement with the Exchange, subscriptions will be returned by the company unless sales aggregate 250,000 shares.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Sir John Simon, the Foreign Secretary, revealed in the House of Commons today that Yugoslavia had stopped her expulsion of Hungarians after intervention by Great Britain.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- With the belga weakening under heavy attacks, the Belgian Finance Minister, Camille Gutt, came to Paris today for a long conference with Louis Germain-Martin, French Finance Minister.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 12. -- Something awe-inspiring and terrible is happening in the Copan zone, residents of that quake-devastated district have wired the government here.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 12. -- Champion Max Baer is really in earnest, it now appears, in his proposal to meet Art Lasky and Steve Hamas, both on the same night, with his heavyweight title at stake.

The New York Stock Exchange has approved the listing of 400,000 additional capital shares of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, making the total amount on the Exchange 26,340,965. The shares will be sold to employes of the company in connection with its stock acquisition plans.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 12. -- Sandy Loam Farm was the setting today for a luncheon with which Hugh Dillman entertained, having as guests Mr. and Mrs. Marion Sims Wyeth, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Rutherford, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Sears Jr., Mr. and Mrs. John Colgate Jessup, Mr. and Mrs. William Royster Johnson, Mrs. George Alexander McKinlock, Mrs. Chalmers Woods, Mrs. William Seward Webb, Mrs. Quentin F. Feitner and Miss Ross Williams.

A judgment for $145,986 plus interest against August Heckscher in favor of Frederick Goess, as receiver for the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, was granted yesterday by Federal Judge John C. Knox, who dismissed at the same time counterclaims filed by Mr. Heckscher.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Members of the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry, particularly Senator Nye, the chairman, and Senator Vandenberg, both Republicans, expressed resentment today on learning of President Roosevelt's step toward ending war profits.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- An official ceremony was held at the United States Embassy today when Ambassador Jesse I. Straus accepted from William N. Cromwell a copy of a portrait of the late Myron T. Herrick painted by Mrs. Ellen Emmet Rand from the original by Sir William Orpen.

When the new sales tax is amended to remedy defects caused by its hasty adoption, a clause may be added specifically making it illegal for any vendor to absorb the tax instead of passing it on to his customers.

Price advances of 2 to 3 cents a pound on several viscose process rayon yarns and of 5 to 7 cents a pound on some acetate yarns will be put into effect today by the Viscose Company, it was announced here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12. -- Miss Wyeth explained her Christmas fantasy as "an expression of my personal reactions to Christmas Day in our home: a weaving together of the solemn spirit of Christ's birth day with the festivities of a family holiday."
Transfer of thirty-two former Steneck holdings featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Envisioning a day when the largest of ocean-going vessels may reach the Great Lakes, district engineers of the War Department recommended today a $336,462,000 rivers and harbors development program, including the $175,000,000 St. Lawrence waterway and hydroelectric project.

LONDON, Dec. 12. -- By a vote of 410 to 127 the House of Commons tonight gave the government permission to introduce a bill on the lines of the recent joint committee report, which outlined a vast and complex system of limited self-government for India.

Nineteen of New York's largest hotels took in a total of $5,514,648 through the sale of alcoholic beverages during the first year of repeal, according to a report made public yesterday by Harris, Kerr, Forster Co., accountants. The largest monthly total, $552,536, was reported for last month, which ran $25,029 ahead of December, 1933, the first month of repeal.

The Princeton Club, defending champion, registered its second victory in a row in Group 1 of the Class C Metropolitan League squash racquets tournament yesterday, blanking the Heights Casino team, 5 -- 0, in Brooklyn.

The life of 12-year-old Stanley Walker of 1,080 Anderson Avenue, the Bronx, may be saved by a blood transfusion performed at 1 o'clock this morning after a twenty-four-hour city-wide search for a blood donor whose blood might lend the boy help in his fight against a strepticoccal septicemia.

The freedom of American radio news from commercialism and propaganda was discussed last night by Elisha Hanson, Washington attorney for the American Newspaper Publishers Association, in a broadcast over an NBC network. Mr. Hanson spoke from the studios of WRC in Washington.

With the extremely serious financial questions facing the city administration, and at the same time the vital problem of sewage treatment to be solved, it would seem that the public should be informed as to what plans are to be followed for the disposal of our sewage.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 12. -- The St. Nicks hockey team defeated Princeton, 3 -- 2, in a fast, rough game tonight in Baker Rink. Playing furiously in the final period to overcome the early 3 -- 0 margin of the victors, Princeton held the visitors scoreless and Ken Willis tallied twice.

Stocks moved unevenly yesterday in much less active trading. The volume on the Stock Exchange was about 790,000 shares, compared with 1,281,000 on Tuesday. The undertone was generally firm, although the price averages fell a little. Wall Street attached no significance to the idle movements beyond the fact that speculators seemed to be regaining their confidence after the abrupt decline of the preceding day.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Major Gen. John E.S. Brind, commander of the Saar International Force, is leaving London tomorrow for Saarbruecken, which will be headquarters of his force.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- For his work in promoting friendliness and cooperation of American countries President Roosevelt received today the medal of the Pan-American Society.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- General Douglas MacArthur, who has been chief of staff of the army longer than any other officer, was continued in that office indefinitely today by informal order of the President.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Here are some of the recommendations of the War Policies Commission, submitted to the White House in March, 1932, upon which President Roosevelt's commission to draw legislation for stripping war of profits expects to concentrate study:

A field of twenty-four contract bridge teams of four, including experts of the United States and Canada, vied yesterday afternoon in the first round of competition for the Chicago Trophy of the American Bridge league at the Hotel P ennsylvania.

Fellow artists of the Metropolitan Opera were among those who applauded Hans Clemens, for several years a valued member of the German wing of Mr. Gatti-Casazza's company, in his first New York song recital, given yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall.
DENVER, Dec. 12 (AP). -- Two Colorado convicts today apparently had won their gamble with science for their lives and provided new hope for success of a tuberculosis preventive.

Welfare Island, centre of a controversy between the Hospital and Park Departments as to which shall inherit land to be vacated there by the Department of Correction next year, was visited yesterday by the Mayor's Committee on City Plan, which has been charged with the duty of settling the dispute.

A recommendation that all silk and rayon manufacturers, converters, , operating under the Silk Textile Code, should voluntarily close on Dec. 24 and on Dec. 31, and operate instead on Saturday, Dec. 22 and 29, was issued yesterday by Peter Van Horn, president of the National Federation of Textiles, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Legislation to "take the profit out of war" was placed by President Roosevelt today on the program which he will present to the new Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Whether the President's newest commission is a red herring across the trail of the Nye committee, as some Senators seem to think, or just another step in the orderly progress of the New Deal, the subject before the commission has been prominently before the American public for more than fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Turning to the chemical industry and the part it plays in war, the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry sought to reveal today the international ramifications of chemical groups involving, according to the committee, the United States, Great Britain and most of Continental Europe, with principal bases of operation in Wilmington, London and Berlin.
BELGRADE, Dec. 12. -- There is reason to anticipate big changes in the internal political situation in Yugoslavia now that conditions after the assassination of King Alexander have been regularized.

The Metropolitan Jockey Club, which conducts racing at the Jamaica track, yesterday followed the move of other New York associations and increased the value of the stakes which will feature its 1935 meetings. The Wood Memorial, earliest 3-year-old event in this area, has been doubled in value and will be worth $10,000 added next season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- Declaring that the requirement of a license to sell guns is only a "halfway measure." J. Weston Allen, former Attorney General of Massachusetts, today urged the Attorney General's Conference on Crime to demand that the Governor of every State support legislation to compel purchasers to obtain a license "as prerequisite to lawful possession, with certain identification to hold the possessor to strict accountability."
VIENNA, Dec. 12. -- The widow of the man who composed "The Dollar Princess" music was at home again today.

Hundreds of odd creatures not to be classed as pets, poultry or tropical fish added yesterday to the din that marked the opening of the annual Pet, Poultry and Tropical Fish Show in the basement at Madison Square Garden. There were tigers and porcupines, a group of pythons that tied themselves into knots, and infant monkeys that flew to their mothers' arms, screaming, at the sight of visitors.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Mrs. Henry Place Marshall of Hillside Avenue and Mrs. William L. Strong Jr. of Kensington Avenue, at a tea given this afternoon at Mrs. Marshall's home, introduced to society their niece, Miss Elsie Burke Foster, daughter of Herbert H. Foster of Plainfield.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12. -- The Paraguayan War Office today reported the capture of Fort 27th of November in the Northwest Chaco. It is situated thirty miles north of Fort Senator Long or Loma Vistosa, which the Paraguayans captured Saturday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 12. -- Because of lack of student demand for beer and ale, the service of the brew will be discontinued in the Harvard College undergraduate dining halls when the present licenses expire on Jan. 1, it was announced here tonight.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP). -- Stanford University's football team, after extended time out for study for the coming examinations, reopened practice today in preparation for the game with Alabama New Year's Day.
The New York Giants, champions of the National Football League, had the most effective forward-passing attack in the circuit, according to the final statistics of the season released yesterday.
I read in THE TIMES that an educator objected to fighting hymns, especially for the younger generation. As one of the younger generation may I disagree?

Thirteen Christmas trees will be erected by the Park Department in parks throughout the city for the holiday season, it was said yesterday. The trees, each forty-five feet tall, will be dedicated Friday, Dec. 21, with ceremonies in City Hall Park which will be broadcast to the other parks.

Many dinner and supper parties were given last night at the pre-opening celebration held at Le Boeuf Sur Le Toit, a new dinner and supper club, at 57 West Fifty-seventh Street, for the joint benefit of the Post Contagion Unit of the Speedwell Society and the Social Service Bureau of the Roosevelt Hospital.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 13. -- The taxpayers of Westchester County had the first opportunity in the history of the county today to express publicly their views on a county budget. About 100 taxpayers appeared and twenty-six persons spoke at a three-hour hearing this morning in the supervisors' chambers.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 13. -- Making his first start of the meeting, Hammel, 3-year-old chestnut gelding owned by H.G. Shoemaker, today captured the Shrewsbury Purse, feature attraction over six furlongs at the Fair Grounds. The races were run over a fast track and the splendid weather brought out a good crowd.

The Netherlands has been added to the list of countries with which the United States is seeking to negotiate a reciprocal trade agreement. A dozen other countries are already there. They include Belgium, Sweden, Switzerland, Spain, Brazil, Colombia and several Central American nations.

A field of twenty-four contract bridge teams competing for the Chicago Trophy of the American Bridge League was cut to thirteen yesterday afternoon in the semi-final round of play in that event at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Four favored entries were eliminated, but the Cincinnati team now holding the trophy came through the elimination round by a scant margin.

Members of the local Kiwanis must now find themselves torn in two. On the one hand, a handsome compliment has been paid them. On the other is the financial burden involved. Kiwanis members must pay the sales tax on their weekly luncheon tickets because they sing at their meals.
The number of contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund declined again yesterday, and the total amount received for the day was only $6,786.83.

The special features of the concert that Bruno Walter gave last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall were the first American performance of Kurt Weill's symphonic fantasy, "Three Night Scenes," and Bronislaw Hubermann's appearance for the first time in some seasons in this city, playing the Beethoven violin concerto.

SINGAPORE, Dec. 13. - Large-scale army, navy and Royal Air Force manoeuvres began today when eighteen destroyers, the aircraft carrier Eagle, with twenty-four planes aboard, and the cruiser Cumberland left for somewhere in the China Seas to open an "attack" on Singapore.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Detroit's Red Wings surpassed their own high scoring record by defeating the St. Louis Eagles, 11 to 2, in a National League hockey game tonight.

It was by no accident that the appeal for the Neediest Cases all these past years was published in the three weeks before Christmas. The deliberate plan was to place this charity within the traditional period of good cheer and good-will. It has been supported by many in that spirit.

At this time, with the opening of the Crime Conference in Washington and all the best minds of the nation's police officers and prosecutors bent on our crime problem, it is particularly heartening to read that the annual Sing Sing musical show is being given this week before a cheering audience of friends and admirers of the inmates of that much-publicized institution.

Net profit of the International Business Machines Corporation and subsidiaries for the ten months ended on Oct. 31, amounted to $5.611,701 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. This was equal to $7.98 a share on 703,345 no par shares of capital stock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Southern railroads will be permitted, under a decision made by the Interstate Commerce Commission today, to reduce rates on export and import traffic from interior territory to South Atlantic ports.

Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, in his address at the Republican mass meeting in Mecca Temple last night, demanded that the Republican party be reorganized on a basis of "constructive liberalism," divorcing itself from control by big business and becoming a party of agrarians and laborers, producers and consumers.

A total of $307,321.75 raised to date by workers for the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Fund, for which the goal has been set as $550,000, was announced yesterday at a luncheon for group chairmen of the men's division held in the Luncheon Club of Wall Street, 40 Wall Street.

HAVANA, Dec. 13. -- All persons detained for any reason may be kept in jail without a hearing for a period during which constitutional guarantees are suspended, according to a decree law modifying the provisional Constitution which was adopted by the Cabinet this afternoon.

A news item stating that the Forstmann Woolen Company of Passaic, N.J., would re-employ 500 additional workers as a result of obtaining a temporary exemption from the wool code restrictions on their worsted spindle operations is of vital interest to industry and the public in general.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest H. Rice of Montclair, N.J., gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. Roderick Tower, Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Hutton, Mr. and Mrs. Dickson B. Potter, Mr. and Mrs. John R. Hearst, Mrs. Earl E.T. Smith, Miss Muriel Johnson, Miss Elinor Bronaugh, Bradley Dresser, John H. Claiborne and Peter Van Brunt.

The committee of holders of defaulted bonds of the township of North Bergen, N.J., announced yesterday that it had filed suit in the United States District Court in New Jersey for $372,159, representing payments due, plus a judgment for interest to time of settlement.

It is always interesting to watch artists engaged in adventurously changing their style. The week has brought to our galleries several shows in which embarkation upon voyages of experiment is revealed.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Indian Salute came from behind to win with a rush in the feature race today at Epsom Downs, the mile-long Gus Arnheim claiming purse.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 a consolidated net income of $1,457,398 after all charges, minority interest and other deductions. This was equal to nearly 23 cents a share on 6,339,002 shares of stock. For the same period last year the company reported a net loss of $239,223.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13. -- The B Minor Mass of Johann Sebastian Bach was given tonight by the Philadelphia Orchestra and the Westminster Choir before a capacity audience of 1,500 persons in the chapel of Princeton University in connection with the day's ceremonies in dedication of the new buildings of the Westminster Choir School here.

A basic monthly wage of $57.50 has been adopted by conferees representing American ship lines and their sea-going personnel, it was learned yesterday. After several weeks of discussion by committees of both groups this wage has been accepted as a compromise and, unless complications develop in the next few days, will become effective by Jan. 1.

E.G. McLaughlin of the Columbia Club, seeded No. 4, reached the final of the invitation squash tennis tournament yesterday at the Princeton Club. He advanced by turning back L.A. Strasser of the City A.C., 10 -- 15, 15 -- 4, 18 -- 17, 15 -- 12.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A critical situation appeared to be developing today in the relations between the National Recovery Administration and the National Labor Relations Board as a result of reiteration by Chairman Francis Biddle of the Labor Board that his organization was empowered to assume jurisdiction over Section 7a cases where "special facts warranted such action," even though an industrial board might exist to handle labor disputes.

Ten days ago The London Times ended the war of letters which has been waged hotly in its columns since the appearance of the latest volume of Mr. LLOYD GEORGE'S "War Memoirs." He has answered his critics, military or civilian, cleverly and often tartly. His side of the controversy has had airing enough.

Asserting that he had not "made a cent out of the war." Vincent Astor last night issued a statement expressing resentment over intimations at the Senate munitions inquiry that he benefited to the extent of more than $1,000,000 a year from wartime profits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- "Substantially the unanimous support" of the New York delegation for Representative O'Connor of New York City as Democratic leader of the House was announced tonight by Representative Martin J. Kennedy.

Jack Menders and Beattie Feathers, both of the Chicago Bears, smashed two National Football League records during the 1934 season, according to the figures announced yesterday. Manders, former Minnesota ace, set a mark in individual scoring by making 79 points.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 13. -- The Rev. and Mrs. J.C. Stam, young American missionaries, have been slain in Anhwei Province by Communist bandits and their bodies have been found abandoned on a battlefield, according to telegrams received today by the China Inland Mission headquarters here.

The Annalist index of business activity shows a slight increase for November, rising 0.3 point over October. The preliminary index is 70.9, compared with 70.6 for October; 66.4 for September, the low for the year, and 80.2 for May, the high for the year.

After four days of operation of the 2 per cent sales tax imposed by the city for unemployment relief purposes merchants indicated yesterday through their trade organizations growing dissatisfaction with the effects of the levy, particularly as to its effect on out-of-town sales.

Commander Hjalmar Frederik Gjertsen of the Royal Norwegian Navy, on leave to pilot the ships Jacob Ruppert and Bear of Oakland of the Byrd expedition out of the January ice floes from Little America, will leave New York for Dunedin, N.Z., today on the twenty-third aniversary of the discovery of the South Pole by Roald Amundsen.

Two new films are scheduled to be shown today in Broadway theatres: "Wednesday's Child," from the play by Leopold Atlas, with Frankie Thomas, Edward Arnold and Karen Morley, at the Roxy, and First National's screen version of Sinclair Lewis's "Babbitt," with Guy Kibbee and Aline McMahon, at the RKO Palace.
The mystery of the disappearance six years ago of Grace Budd, 10 years old, was solved last night.

The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service covers all of Manhattan and the Bronx and most of Queens. The nurses of its 21 centres make 553,000 visits to more than 100,000 patients annually. One-third of all the mothers in the three boroughs depend on Henry Street nurses for maternity care. One in every four pneumonia cases is cared for by a Henry Street nurse.
The Alton Railroad, a subsidiary of the Baltimore Ohio, reported yesterday an increased deficit in November. Its statement follows:

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Chiefly because of the Napoleonic Association's remarkably good prices. Sotheby's sale today of a collection of French works of art, the property of Princess Furstenburg, including various objects that Napoleon presented to his adopted daughter, Stephanie Beauharnais, realized a total of 3,533. (The pound is currently worth about $4.95.)

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade fluctuated today in an erratic manner, but within relatively narrow limits. An early upturn was followed by a recession, and then a rally toward the close, with wheat finishing unchanged to 1/8 cent a bushel higher and corn 1/4 to 1/2 cent better.

The State of South Carolina announced yesterday that it would offer for award on Jan. 4 a new issue of $4,312,000 highway certificates of indebtedness, the proceeds of which would be used to redeem highway notes of like amount on Feb. 1, 1935.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Negotiations leading up to a wartime contract between the du Ponts and the government, of which the Delaware munitions company received about $2,000,000 without investment by itself, were disclosed today in the Senate munitions investigation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Caustic criticism from the Supreme Court of the way in which the New Deal keeps its records today focused attention on the fact that NRA has produced 10,269 administrative orders, an output of more than 200 a week, in 1934 to set an unparalleled record of law making by executive authority.

The appeal of THE NEW YORK TIMES for the Hundred Neediest Cases brings to pass in a great metropolis the seemingly impossible -- neighborly help that conveys genuine friendliness, help that has not lost its spirit by becoming impersonalized.

At the suggestion of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Produce Exchange suspended dealings yesterday in Como Mines $1-par capital stock of which the commission has been conducting an investigation for the last week. The suspension was ascribed to the fact that part of the issue which should have been registered under the Securities Act of 1933 had not been registered.

In the last few months Belgium has been frequently referred to as the weakest member of the gold bloc. The belga has had several sinking spells; the de Broqueville Cabinet fell on Nov. 13 as the result of a reputed disagreement between advocates of devaluation and advocates of deflation and retrenchment.

An unseasonal decline of $13,000,000 from the previous week in the amount of money in circulation took place in the week ended on Wednesday, it was shown in the report of the Federal Reserve System, published yesterday. The amount in circulation on Wednesday, the report showed, was $5,532,000,000, which was $77,000,000 higher than the figure for three weeks ago and $241,000,000 above the low point of last Summer, reached on July 25.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 13. -- Recovering from shock after he and a dozen spectators were plunged into a canal when a bridge collapsed under their weight, Olin Dutra, national open champion, today won the $12,500 Miami Biltmore open golf tournament with a seventy-two-hole score of 292. His prize was $1,200.

Except for a loft building and a few vacant parcels, auction mart activity yesterday was confined to foreclosure sales of housing properties. Auctioneers struck down to plaintiffs six properties in Manhattan and seven in the Bronx.

The medical work of the Protestan denominations which belong to the Medical Missions Conference of North America was commended by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the Methodist Episcopal Church, who spoke at a luncheon yesterday in the Parkside Hotel, 18 Gramercy Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- President Roosevelt held today the first of a series of conferences devoted to writing of the budget message, which must be ready for presentation, according to custom, on the second day after the new Congress convenes on Jan. 3.

The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its monthly list of companies and their reacquired stocks, accompanied by explanations of the changes in most cases. Other than the purchase by the Barnsdall Corporation of 18,000 of its common shares and a large reduction in treasury holdings by the Standard Oil Company of Indiana, the changes were of a routine nature.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Vast profits made in "the World War years" by some American corporations, along with 181 individual annual incomes of a million dollars or more for one or more years from 1915 to 1920, were listed today by the Senate Munitions Committee as a sequel to President Roosevelt's announcement yesterday that "the time has come to take the profits out of war."

George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago, generally recognized as the world's greatest doubles player, definitely left the ranks of amateur tennis yesterday when he signed a professional contract with Bill O'Brien for a nation-wide tour this Winter with William T. Tilden 2d, Lester Stoefen and Ellsworth Vines Jr.

Integration of companies into larger units, with increased stability in times of stress and with progressive merchandising methods resulting in profitable selling operations, "is the next step toward a return to profits for the silk and rayon industry," according to a survey entitled "Production and Distribution of Silk and Rayon Broad Goods," issued yesterday by the National Federation of Textiles, Inc., in cooperation with the Textile Foundation of Washington.

Effective today, the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company will reduce the price of gasoline 1 cent a gallon in Brooklyn and Queens. This will be the sixth reduction within ten days, five cuts of 1/2 cent each already having been put into effect. The new price for the regular grade will be 13 1/2 cents a gallon at service stations, including 4 cents in taxes.
BERNE, Switzerland, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Rudolf Minger, reorganizer of the Swiss Army, was named president of the Swiss Confederation for 1935 by the Federal Assembly today.

A collective agreement affecting 6,000 drivers and pasteurizing and distributing plant workers was ratified yesterday between the Borden's Farm Products Company and Local 584 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers at a meeting in Mecca Temple.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- Newspapers published in this country and Canada numbered 129 more this year than last, according to the 1935 edition of N.W. Ayer Son's Directory of Newspapers and Periodicals, which will be issued on Jan. 1.

A "year of fruitful services" was reported to members of the New York Association for the Blind at the twenty-seventh annual meeting of the organization at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon. Dr. John H. Finley, president of the association presided,

VIENNA, Dec. 13. -- The open revival of Nazi anti-Semitic propaganda with the full permission of the government, which was signalized by the publication today of the newspaper Deutsche Arbeiter Presse, has caused jubilation among the Nazis and consternation among those who believed the policy of the late Chancellor Dolfuss and his successors was to build Up a bulwark in Europe against Nazi doctrines.
The Harvard Club and Princeton Club continued to set the pace in the Class A. squash racquets competition of the Metropolitan League yesterday, each winning by 4 -- 1.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 13. -- The Stradivarius Quartet of New York appeared this morning in the second of the series of concerts arranged by the Greenwich Member Society of the Chamber Music Society of America at the home of Mrs. George W. Davison, Dublin Road, Greenwich.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- The Hitler Cabinet's final meeting for the year today produced a series of laws calculated to make more elastic the application of various aspects of the government's program this Winter.

Gold valued at $1,000.000 was reported yesterday as engaged abroad for shipment here, bringing to $185.000,000 the amount bought in foreign markets by this country since Nov. 1. Of this total all but $29,000,000 has been received. The bullion en route here includes $13,000,000 from India, $7,000,000 from France, $6,000,000 from England, $2,000,000 from Mexico and $1,000,000 from Holland.

For the third consecutive week bank clearings exceeded those of the corresponding week last year. In the principal cities throughout the country, clearings totaled $4,769,049,000, an increase of 15.7 per cent over the $4,121,069,000 a year ago, according to Dun Bradstreet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- The kind of a team coaches dream about, but never get to carry on the glory of their master-minding fame, will represent the East in its annual all-star charity football duel against the West at San Francisco New Year's Day.

Recovery, despite the best efforts of industrialists, will not become a fact "in six months or even six years" unless the government clears up uncertainties which force business men to hesitate about future commitments, W.B. Bell, president of the American Cyanamid Company and a director of the National Association of Manufacturers, said yesterday before the Sales Executives Club of New York, Inc., at the Hotel Roosevelt.

When Lew Brown starts "Calling All Stars" into a musical revue, which opened amid a general hubbub at the Hollywood Theatre last evening, Lou Holtz and Phil Baker are the first to appear. If you have an inexplicable weakness for music hall skittishness you are likely to prick up your ears at the mention of these two buffoons.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, Dec. 13. -- Sensational charges of a plot to take a part of Lithuania by armed force for Germany will be revealed in the mass trial of 126 Nazis in the Memel district. The trial of the accused, among whom are several former German officers, will begin here tomorrow before a court-martial.
Sales and leases of dwellings in Manhattan featured realty trading in the city yesterday.

The Lenox Picture House, 52 East Seventy-eighth Street, a non-profit-making theatre for children, will open today at 2:15 P.M. under the sponsorship of a group of prominent women, including Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt. The theatre, catering exclusively to juvenile tastes, will be used as an experimental laboratory to determine children's reactions to films and, in some respects, to serve as a guide to motion picture producers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- With all the ceremony of a nation-wide political contest, about 2,000,000 cotton growers in the sixteen States comprising the Cotton Belt will go to the polls tomorrow to vote for or against continuance of the Bankhead Cotton Act.

The New York Americans were forced into overtime by the Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night, but Joe Simpson's courageous skaters succeeded in registering a triumph over the once mighty Hub sextet, nevertheless.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Friday, Dec. 14. -- Patrick Downey, 31 years old, of Central Islip, a carpenter, was found guilty early this morning of murder in the first degree in connection with the assault and strangling of Rita Lazarri, 7, in Islip last Sept. 23.

Carrying their fight against Old Guard leadership of the Republican party right into the heart of its Eastern stronghold, Senators William E. Borah of Idaho and Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota demanded in public speeches here last night that young and liberal Republicans get together, oust the "diehards" from control of party machinery, set up liberal leadership and break the control of "big business" and monopoly upon the party.

The first contact for a cooperative arrangement between the Metropolitan Opera and Great Britain's ranking opera company, Covent Garden in London, has been established during the last week, it became known yesterday.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.
Following is the text of the address delivered by Senator Borah at Mecca Temple last night on the liberalization of the Republican party:
LONDON, Dec. 13 (AP) . -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

With the completion of two player deals, both involving the Giants to make a grand total of three for the three-day convention, the sixteen club owners of the National and American Leagues decided at their joint concluding session before Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt to make no drastic changes in their administrative affairs.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 13. -- Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Kroger entertained tonight with the second of a series of dinners, followed by contract, at Villa Sueno. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Ernest G. Howes, Mr. and Mrs. Harry Oakes, Mrs. James H. Kennedy and Miss Margaret Crowley.
The Bronx Symphony playa tonight a Wagner-Weber program at Theodore Roosevelt High School, assisted by Thelma Votipka in airs from "Lohengrin" and "Der Freischiitz."

Retail prices held unchanged during November, according to the Fairchild retail price index, issued yesterday. The composite index as of Dec. 1 stood at 87.4, the same as on Nov. 1, but for the first time since July, 1933, is lower than on the corresponding date a year ago, when the figure was 88.

A national poetry centre was opened formally yesterday afternoon on the forty-fourth floor of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Cen ter, with Anita Browne as director. The centre is an outgrowth of the Poetry Week Fellowship and American Poetry Week founded by Miss Browne in 1927 and will be open to the public daily as a clearing house for information about poets and their works.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Wholesale commodity prices continued to show an upward tendency last week, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today, the bureau's index increasing to 76.7 per cent of the 1926 average. The index on Dec. 1 was 76.5, and on Dec. 9, 1933, it was 70.9.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange failed to develop a definite trend yesterday. After moderate strength most of the day's prices turned irregular near the close. Trading was slightly more active than on Wednesday, totaling $11,899,300, of which $2,443,800 was in United States Government issues, which ended easier 4-32 point down to 3-32 up.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Such anti-spenders and budget-balancers as there are in this country may as well realize that, to the possible costs of a compromise on the veterans' bonus demands, they should tentatively add a large sum for old-age pensions. This does not mean to imply that the President has come to any definite decision on either project.

What opera-lovers may expect this season at the Metropolitan in the way of lighting effects was demonstrated last night by Jacob Buchter, chief electrician, who showed the new $250,000 illuminating system of the opera house to 200 members of the New York chapter of the Illuminating Engineering Society.

Dry goods jobbers confined their activity in the primary markets this week to fill-in orders on seasonal goods, the demand for which was spurred by the cold weather. They reported a stronger tone in the market and found that efforts to clear goods by mills before inventory taking were not as numerous as in previous weeks.
A woman is among the seventeen persons who have applied for permission to take the examination for postmaster at New York City.
Thornton Wilder's new novel, "Heaven's My Destination," will be the January choice of the English Book Society as well as of the Book-of-the-Month Club here. It will be published by Harpers.

Plans for the early reorganization of the Crime Prevention Bureau as the Juvenile Aid Bureau were discussed yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine before 100 women at a forum of the Women's City Club. Under the new plans division commanders will be held responsible for crime prevention.
Support of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee in its $3,000,000 drive was urged last night upon the citizens of New York by former Governor Alfred E. Smith.

Lack of cooperation among city, State and Federal relief agencies which resulted in the spoiling of 1,400,000 pounds of potatoes and tied up the distribution of large quantities of other foodstuffs brought sharp criticism of the Welfare Department and the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration yesterday from the Aldermen's committee investigating relief.
Resale of a Jersey City parcel recently in foreclosure featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

The Association of Life Insurance Presidents, representing $22,000,000,000 of current assets and 65,000,000 policy holders, met in its twenty-eighth annual convention yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to consider fundamental problems of the economic and social system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 12, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,462,000,000, an increase of $3,000,000, compared with the preceding week, and a decrease of $205,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 37 1/2 cents, placing the stock on a $1.50 annual basis against $2 paid previously. It is payable on Jan. 2 to stockholders of record of Dec. 18. The reduction was forecast by I.

British authorities announce that the discussion of naval plans will end at London next week. It is admitted that no agreements have been reached. For some time it has been evident, even from the unofficial reports, that the informal exchange of views would be fruitless.

Mrs. August Egerer, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, presents a picture of the work of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures which is not in harmony with the facts as they are known to us. It apparently impugns the integrity of this organization and the work of the more than 300 men and women who, as volunteers, regularly give their service in reviewing the films.

The frequency of fatal fires in old-law tenements suggests several explanations -- combustible halls and stairs, defective electric wiring, unsafe chimneys, defective heating apparatus, incendiarism. But if the exact causes could be determined one of the most prolific would be a pest whom we may call the Firebug Cigareticus.

MONTREAL, Dec. 13 (AP). -- The high-flying Toronto Maple Leafs strengthened their hold on first place in the National Hockey League's international division tonight by defeating the second-place Montreal Maroons, 4 -- 2, in an overtime struggle.

BERLIN, Dec. 13. -- Stocks on the ]oerse were weaker today. Financial commentators hold the weakness almost entirely due to virtually complete public indifference to the market, so that the relatively small i volume of offerings finds no takers. Heavy industrials were quiet and closed without significant losses.

Dr. Allan Roy Defoe, the Canadian backwoods physician who woke up one morning to find himself the world's best-known obstetrician, went through another breathless round of adventures yesterday, following his vist to the President the day before, his first airplane flight, and a visit to a night club.

Additional funds to finance the special work projects being conducted by the Architects Emergency Committee were announced yesterday at a tea held under the auspices of the women's division of the committee, at the home of Mrs. A. Stewart Walker, 823 Lexington Avenue.
PARIS, Dec. 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

George Schoenich, a retired police lieutenant who was appointed to the force when Theodore Roosevelt was head of the department in 1896, was run down and killed by an automobile last night as he was crossing Sedgwick Avenue, at the corner of Cedar Avenue, in the Bronx.

Traders continued yesterday to approach the speculative markets cautiously. Nowhere was there any very positive trend or any great amount of activity. Stocks, bonds and commodities were fairly steady at the close of an unexciting day.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Twenty-five hostesses of the Rosebud Ballroom, 212 West Forty-second Street, carried picket signs among the crowds in front of the ballroom last night in a strike to protest recent dance hall reforms, including the abolition of "sitting-out privileges."

Coming from Philadelphia, where she received the Gimbel national award as "the outstanding American woman" for 1934, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent most of yesterday here Christmas shopping. Among her purchases were some neckties for the President.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- David Lloyd George, former Prime Minister, advised his countrymen today not to boast so much of their prosperity as long as their government had not paid its war debt to the United States.

A committee formed at the instance of twelve of the country's largest insurance companies announced yesterday that it had retained counsel to determine whether legal proceedings should be started "and, if so, against whom," as a result of the Missouri Pacific Railroad's disbursement of its funds in purchases of its own stocks and bonds when they were dropping in the depression stock markets of 1930 and 1931.

PARIS, Dec. 13. -- Clarification by official sources of the reasons for the visit of Camille Gutt, Belgian Finance Minister, to Paris yesterday resulted in the recovery of the belga on the exchange market today. The Belgian currency closed at 3.5425, which puts the belga once again above the gold-export point to Paris.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 13. -- The Nassau County police broadcast descriptions today of three armed men who entered the home of Harry Johnson at 22 Primrose Lane, Valley Stream, at 5 P.M. yesterday, bound Mrs. Johnson, her daughter, Gloria, 10 years old, and her maid, Bertha Pankoffer, with picture wire and ransacked the house.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- Arrivals of hogs here today were in excess of expectations and were the heaviest for any Thursday since January. Prices dropped 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight compared with the top levels made yesterday. Many of the smaller packers refused to operate freely owing to the failure of the fresh pork demand to be stimulated by the colder weather.

Although the turnover on the New York Stock Exchange increased sharply from 787,330 shares on Wednesday to 997,450 yesterday, the market failed to develop any definite trend and closed irregularly lower. The industrial price average declined 79 cents, while the combined rail-industrial average was 42 cents lower on the day.

Following is the text of the address delivered yesterday by S. Clay Williams, chairman of the National Industrial Recovery Board, at a joint meeting of the American Arbitration Association, the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and the Merchants Association of New York:
Plans for the formation of a State-wide Sportsmen's League in New Jersey are outlined in a letter sent to this column by Robert R. Edge of Asbury Park.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 13. -- The defense of Bruno Richard Hauptmann scored a point in a pre-trial hearing today when Justice Thomas W. Trenchard in the court of Oyer Terminer here directed the prosecution to state the manner in which Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was murdered.

Trends of prices were mixed on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. The activity was light in most instances. Hides were strong in a record-breaking market. Silk and some of the metals were higher. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye and oats were stronger, and butter, lard, cotton and rubber eased.
EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 13 (AP). -- Richard E. (Dick) Hanley probably will not coach the Northwestern University football team in 1935, it was indicated tonight.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith will head a council of Catholic laymen appointed here to aid in the drive of the Legion of Decency against objectionable motion pictures, it was announced yesterday at the chancery office of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, 477 Madison Avenue.
New York enjoyed a respite yesterday from the first severe cold wave of this season, but a return of cold weather was forecast for today and tomorrow.

PARIS, Dec. 13. -- Trading on the Bourse was stagnant again today, with business virtually non-existent. The inertia into which the market has fallen is just as complete as it was toward the close of the Doumergue government's tenure. The fact that Premier Flandin now seems certain of getting his wheat bill through the Chamber of Deputies did not help.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A contention that processing taxes to pay farmers for controlling production represented an increase in the cost of living of less than 1 per cent was advanced today by the Farm Administration.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 13. -- Something almost new is going to take place in this State tomorrow when thousands of Negroes will go to the polls, cordially invited and earnestly urged to do so by their white neighbors.

The modernization program of the Federal Housing Administration has increased the business of building material and equipment manufacturers and distributers as high as 500 per cent in ninety days, James A. Moffett, Federal Housing Administrator, reported yesterday at a luncheon of the Advertising Club of New York.

The importance of radio in public education was discussed last night by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and several other speakers in a half-hour broadcast devoted to "Economics in a Changing Social Order." The occasion marked the 100th presentation in this series.

PARIS. Dec. 13. -- Overcoming the most powerful opposition he has yet met. Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin pushed his wheat bill through a disgruntled Chamber of Deputies today, winning a handsome majority of 387 to 175.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of last week totaled 325,970,000 barrels, a decrease of 787,000 barrels from the total of 326,757,000 barrels on hand at the end of the preceding week, Secretary Ickes announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A comprehensive and "practical" eight-point program for permanent suppression of crime in the United States, designed to tighten up poilcing, legal processes, and the handling of convicted prisoners, was approved today by the Attorney General's Conference on Crime.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 13. -- The great, endowed universities of the United States are being menaced by "sinister consequences" of the depression, Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University, declared in his annual report, made public today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- A total of 4,161,006 families were "on relief'' in this country in October, as against 3,010,516 last year, but November showed a much smaller increase this year than last, Harry L. Hopkins, Relief Administrator, stated today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13. -- Yale exhibited brilliant basketball tonight in defeating Providence College, 41 -- 26, in a game in which both teams displayed mid-season form in shooting and defensive work.

More dates, shows, theatres, in various combinations: the premiere of "Accent on Youth" (nee "Old Love") is now listed definitely for Christmas Night at the Plymouth. . . . "Baby Pompadour" (it used to be "True to the Marines") plans to open on Dec. 27 at a theatre yet to be announced. . . .

A group headed by Brown, Harriman Co., Inc., and Edward B. Smith Co. and including Kidder, Peabody Co., Field, Glore Co. and the Lee Higginson Corporation will offer today at 102 1/2 and accrued interest to date of delivery, to yield 5.32 per cent to maturity, $1,658,000 Chicago Western Indiana Railroad first and refunding mortgage 5 1/3 per cent Series C bonds due in 1962.

Four years have passed since Winifred Christie first introduced to an audience in Carnegie Hall the double-keyboard piano invented by her husband, Emanuel Moor. In that time, discussion has waxed and waned as to the advantages and possibilities of the instrument, without otherwise disturbing the even tenor of the concert world.

The electric power and light industry had gross revenues of $155,811,500 from sales to ultimate consumers in October, compared with $150,390,400 a year ago, an increase of 3.6 per cent. For the twelve months ended on Oct. 31 the revenues were $1,822,895,600, compared with $1,777,731,600 in the preceding year, a gain of 2.5 per cent.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 13 (AP). -- Jose Santos Chocano, a Peruvian poet, was stabbed to death today in a street car. Police arrested Martin Bruce, the father of eight children, who had been suing Senor Chocano, alleging a treasure hunt swindle.

The Jewish Labor Committee, which says it represents more than 300,000 Jewish trade unionists, announced yesterday that it would not participate in the movement for the creation of an enlarged American Jewish Congress.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange was influenced yesterday by a statement from Senator Bankhead that government loans on cotton at 12 cents a pound might not be made next season, and slightly easier prices left the list unchanged to 7 points lower on the day.
So far as the Long Island Golf Association is concerned the 1935 golf season could start tomorrow, for its house is already in good order for the coming year.

Although yesterday was "Bird Day" at the Pet, Poultry, Pigeon and Tropical Fish Show in Madison Square Garden, the spotlight was stolen early in the afternoon by a pair of cats boxing with small, leather gloves in a "ring" of rubber tubing on a tea table.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, called at Downing Street today and assured Prime Minister Ramsay McDonald that the American delegates were not leaving England Saturday, so would be available next week for such naval conversations as the British might think useful.

Stanley Walker, 12-year-old Bronx boy, seriously ill of a streptococcus infection at New York Hospital, was holding his own last night. About 1 o'clock yesterday morning Leon Zaskevich of 360 Riverside Drive gave a transfusion of a half-pint of blood. He is prepared to give as many more as may be needed.
Barring moderate activity in commercial paper, interest in other sections of the money market was small. The little business involved was done at prevailing quotations.

Sammy Fuller, the veteran Boston lightweight, and Eddie Cool, clever Philadelphia battler, will meet in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. In the semi-final, also slated for ten rounds, John Henry Lewis of Tucson, Ariz., will oppose Tony Shucco, Boston light-heavyweight contender.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 14. -- The newspaper Asahi annouces that in accepting adjournment of the naval conversations Foreign Minister Koki Hirota will also present concrete details of the program Japan proposes to follow if her claim to parity in the form of a common upper limit is allowed.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 13. -- Miss Rhoda Christmas's Worthington captured the featured Charles Town Jockey Club Purse today, finding little trouble in leading home G.L. Hamilton's Tight Wad and Miss Betty J. Christmas's Triolet, which finished in that order.
ALBANY, Dec. 13. -- Governor Lehman's legislative program was discussed this evening at a conference of Democratic leaders from up-State counties at the Executive Mansion.
PRINCETON, Dec. 13. -- The Princeton basketball team scored its second victory in three starts by defeating Lehigh, 44-23, in the university gym tonight.
The elimination of price-fixing provisions in the NRA of the future was forecast yesterday by S. Clay Williams, chairman of the National Industrial Recovery Board.

The directors of the American Iron and Steel Institute unanimously elected Eugene G. Grace its president yesterday. Mr. Grace is president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. Tom M. Girdler, chairman and president of the Republic Steel Corporation, was elected vice president to succeed Mr. Grace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Application of Darragh A. Park et al, voting trustees, for registration on the New York Curb Exchange of voting trust certificates and scrip for 77,181.3 shares of capital stock of the Properties Realization Corporation has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, was authorized today by the Detroit District Council of United Automobile Workers to notify President Roosevelt that the Federation, on behalf of its affiliated automobile labor unions, had decided to withdraw from the settlement negotiated by the President in March.

In his letter to THE TIMES our friend Tavityan shows by the trend of his thoughts on the subject of "hour-pounds" of clothes-carrying what comes of the departure from ancestral custom in bathing as frequently and as reflectively as he says he does.

The Western Air Express Corporation has declared a liquidating dividend of $2.50 a share in cash and 11-3 shares of stock in Transcontinental and Western Air Inc., on each share of Western Air's capital stock outstanding. The declaration was in compliance with the new mail law, which makes it unlawful for a corporation holding an air mail contract to have an interest in any other corporation directly or indirectly connected with commercial aviation.

Edward J. Reilly, chief defense counsel for Hauptmann, said at his office in Brooklyn yesterday he regarded the reply of the State of New Jersey to his request for a bill of particulars as complying with his request.

A dinner dance was given last night at the Central Park Casino by Mr. and Mrs. Barton G. Collier for Miss Mary Dewart, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Dewart, who will give a dance for her at the Ritz-Carlton on Dec. 28.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Federal-State unemployment insurance, administered by the States and providing for a Federal subsidy to States adopting plans which comply with certain national standards, is the form of insurance approved by the President's Advisory Council, it was learned today.

Speyer Co. and the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, as American fiscal agents for Kingdom of Bulgaria 7 per cent settlement loan of 1926 and 7 1/2 per cent stabilization loan of 1928, announce that they have received the following communique from the League Loans Committee of London:

Officers of the Como Mines Company, who were attending a stockholders' meeting in Dayton, Nev., on Thursday when the New York Produce Exchange suspended dealings in the company's stock, issued a statement yesterday through Charles P. Franchot, counsel for the concern. The statement follows:

Charles H. Meyer, an attorney and chairman of the Stock Exchange Committee of the Trade and Commerce Bar Association, recommended yesterday at a meeting of that committee the adoption of a single standard of margin for all registered securities to displace the triple standard now embodied in the rules governing margins. He would substitute a specified percentage irrespective of previous market prices of the securities.
C.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:
NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 14. -- The Federal grand jury today indicted Seymour Weiss, treasurer for Senator Huey Long's political organization, on charges of attempted evasion of income tax payments.

Leaving in their wake a high wind, which was rather cold, whereas only a short time before it had been pretty hot, practically all the invading major league club owners who had been churning the air with their three-day convention this week had departed the city yesterday.
General Hugh S. Johnson has chosen as the title for his account, of his command of the NRA "The Blue Eagle From Egg to Earth." Doubleday, Doran will publish it in March.

The annual dinner and dance given by the Service Club of St. Thomas Church, in aid of its charitable activities, took place last night at the Maytown Club. The rooms given over to the entertainment were decorated in keeping with the holiday season, with banked evergreens as the predominating features.

Holiday shopping made good headway during the week, with some leading stores showing gains in dollar volume in excess of 12 to 14 per cent over the same period a year ago. In some instances the increase was described as substantially better than these figures.

The board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange sent yesterday a letter requiring every clearing member who has an open position in sugar in December, 1934, contracts to appear before it on Monday "in regard to the situation existing in connection with December, 1934, contracts."

Following the issuance yesterday of a statement by the State TERA denying that it had glutted New York City with surplus foodstuffs, Mayor La Guardia said an investigation directed by him had shown that the TERA was not at fault in the handling of relief foods.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Viscount Sankey, Lord Chancellor and supreme head of the British justiciary, snatched his wig from his head to mop his perspiring brow this afternoon as he stood, or rather strode, before the historic woolsack in the House of Lords in passionate anger when rebutting Lord Chief Justice Hewart's charges of "rigging the judges' bench."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 14. -- Mrs. Frederick C. Havemeyer 2d entertained tonight with a dinner at Jungle Nest for her house guest, Mrs. Harry S. Black of New York, taking the party later to El Studio.

George Sheinberg, City College swimming star, broke two college records and won three first places last night as the C.C.N.Y. varsity natators opened their season by triumphing over Fordham, 41 -- 30.

The criticism of my letter by Messrs. Wallis and Stigler suggests that the future of economics lies in the hands of the so-called mathematical economists. But significant contributors to recent economic thought do not incline in that direction.

Albert H. Fish, 65-year-old house painter who confessed that he had kidnapped and slain Grace Budd in 1928, will be surrendered to Westchester County for trial on murder charges as soon as the evidence against him is completed, it was announced yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Wilbur T. Clemens, who has been associate general secretary of the Greater New York Federation of Churches for seven and a half years, announced yesterday his acceptance of the office of general secretary of the New York State Council of Churches and Religious Education.
The worst North Atlantic storm of the year brought death to eight seamen yesterday as the British steamer Usworth foundered about 850 miles east of St. Johns, Nfld.

More large trout and fewer small trout are to be released in Connecticut streams in the future. Announcement of this new policy is one of the high lights of the 1932-34 biennial report of the State Board of Fisheries and Game, which was made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Receipts of 31,000 hogs here today were the largest for any Friday this season and, with the liberal arrivals earlier in the week and a slow demand for fresh pork, prices dropped 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight, with light kinds leading the decline.

Ray Morrison, coach of the Southern Methodist University football team for the past twelve years, is slated to succeed the veteran Dan McGugin as Vanderbilt University gridiron coach for 1935. This was learned last night at a dinner given by the Vanderbilt Club of New York at the Hotel Lexington.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 14 (AP). -- Stanford's casualties were still in evidence today as Coach Tiny Thornhill sent his Indians through a brisk workout for the Rose Bowl football clash with Alabama at Pasadena New Year's Day.

TRENTON, Dec. 14. -- Announcement was made today that subscribers of New Jersey Bell Telephone Company who had paid the monthly charge for hand-set or French type telephones for thirty-six months would be relieved of the assessment under a tariff to be filed by the company with the Public Utility Commission.

SEVERAL hundred years ago on some Asiatic plain, according to the theories of most historians, a group of sturdy horsemen, having placed some sort of a ball in the middle of a field, rode to either end, turned, charged at each other in a race for the ball, and the sport of polo was born. It was, according to these same theories, somewhere in Tibet.
S.S. JEAN JADOT, Dec. 14 (by Wireless). -- Sorry, I'm too tired to write a long story.

Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, who resigned last May as chairman of the American Iron and Steel Institute, is praised as a "wise and inspiring leader, a great American and a citizen of the world" in the resolutions adopted at that time by the directors of the institute but not made public then.

The Christmas list of books recommended by the literature committee appointed by Cardinal Hayes contains 118 approved works in biography, fiction, history, philosophy, poetry and other fields of writing.

United States Government bonds held by life insurance companies of this country will total $1,468,000,000 at the end of this year, according to O.J. Arnold, president of the Northwestern National Life Insurance Company of Minneapolis.

The City of New York is asking proposals for the purchase of $42,900,000 of its serial bonds dated Dec. 15, Joseph D. McGoldrick, Controller, announced last night. He said he would receive sealed proposals for the purchase of the bonds until noon on Tuesday, when they would be opened publicly. Offers for all or part will be received.

Yesterday was "tropical fish day" at the Fifth Annual Pet Show, Madison Square Garden, and eleven out of the thirteen major awards for tropical fish were won by members of the Greater City Aquarium Society of Brooklyn. Today will be "most unusual pet day," and Sunday, the fifth and final day of the show, will be "hero dog day."

New State and municipal bond financing schedule for offering next week amounts to $10,227,289, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with a revised total of $27,164,390 for this week and a weekly average for the year to date of $18,639,678.
MONTREAL, Dec. 14. -- A fast skating McGill sextet turned back Yale by 5 -- 1 tonight in the first international college hockey contest of the season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14. -- Recapitalization of Wilson Co., the country's third largest meat-packing concern, which will eliminate preferred dividend accumulations of $26.25 a share amounting to $12,000,000, was approved today by the directors. The plan will be submitted to stockholders at their annual meeting on Feb. 19.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Although six foreign governments today notified the State Department they would default tomorrow on war debt payments, President Roosevelt declared he expects future payments under existing funding agreements.

Reports that cotton growers throughout the South were voting overwhelmingly in favor of the Bankhead Act stimulated trading yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, and prospects of continued crop control caused a sharp upturn in contracts for next October delivery.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Japan emphatically dissents from the American assertion that under the present naval ratio she has equality of defense with Britain and the United States, says Captain Tamon Yamaguchi, Japan's naval attache here, in a statement issued today as a preliminary to Tokyo's announcement of termination of the Washington Naval Treaty.

Francis Rockelein tossed a field goal in the last minute of play to give the Long Island University freshman quintet a 42-41 victory over the James Madison High School team in a free-scoring contest yesterday on the losers' floor.

HAVANA, Dec. 14. -- Dr. Manuel Marquez Sterling, late Cuban Ambassador to the United States, who died in Washington Sunday, was buried with national honors in Colon Cemetery this morning. The cortege passed along streets where intensive preparations were being made to cope with violence, which it is feared may break out at any moment.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for saving banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

Mrs. Harrison Williams, recently designated by the dressmakers of Paris as the first on a list of the twelve best-dressed women in the world, arrived yesterday from Europe on the Bremen of the North German Lloyd Company. She learned of the action of the French designers by radio while crossing from Cherbourg.

Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, made public yesterday a letter in which he declined to confer with delegates of the Transport Workers Union regarding negotiations for a new contract covering hours and wages of the company's employes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- A conciliatory attitude by utility companies toward the administration's power program, promising far less difficulty in working out a plan than the President's advisers have expected, was noted in White House circles today.

Sammy Fuller, the little "strong boy" from Boston, turned in another winning performance last night. The Hub veteran easily out-pointed Eddie Cool, the clever Philadelphia lightweight, in the feature bout of ten rounds in Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 8,000, of which 7,522 paid.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Trading on the stock market here was irregular today, with a fair amount of selling, this being the last day for settlement of accounts. British funds were fractionally easier. Japanese loans were supported and German issues recovered further in the foreign market, the latest political advices being more favorable.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP). -- Rear Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, one of the Japanese naval delegates, secretly visited Admiral William H. Standley of the American delegation today and urged that the Americans abandon their intention formally to terminate the conversations on naval limitation the day Japan announces termination of the 1922 Washington Naval Treaty.

BREMEN, Dec. 14. -- The first large merchant vessel built under the National Socialist regime, the 18,000-ton North German Lloyd steamer Scharnhorst, was launched here today amid the cheers of half Bremen's population and in the presence of Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, General Werner yon Blomberg, Defense Minister, and navy chiefs and other high government and party officials.
