PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 16 -- Blue and orange lights illuminated the patio of their villa on El Brillo Way for the dance with which Mr. and Mrs. Gail G. Grant entertained tonight after dinner indoors. The affair was in compliment to T. Howard Kelly of New York, their house guest.

Committees for holders of bonds of the Missouri Pacific Railroad which were formed soon after the company entered bankruptcy, are criticized for failure to take action on a $20,000,000 terminal deal affecting the company in a statement issued yesterday by a committee headed by Charles A. Beard, former Professor of Politics at Columbia University.

PARIS, Dec. 15. -- The French Parliament again had occasion to declare itself on the measures enacted in Italy to deter capital exports and to prove Premier Mussolini's firm determination to maintain the lira. In reality none of the gold countries runs any risk at present of being forced to abandon the gold standard.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16. -- Three Paraguayan columns are advancing steadily against Fort Villa Montes from three directions. And Paraguayan public opinion, led by the unanimous editorial opinion of Asuncion newspapers, is vigorously opposed to the acceptance of any peace proposal that might halt the advance of these columns before the capture of Villa Montes.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 16. -- Out-gained on rushing plays, the Brooklyn Dodgers, the first National League eleven to face the Memphis Tigers this season, struck through the air today to annex a 20-to-7 victory.

The greatest need for God in the world today is in the home, the Rev. Joseph B. Bernardin, assistant rector of All Angels Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue at Eighty-first Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Again this week more than a score of new exhibitions face the gallerygoer. With those which opened over the week-end, and those for which announcements have been belated, the number probably will reach thirty eventually.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 16. -- Edmund Krull, 19 years old, of 34 Laurel Place, whose arrest was brought about last night by quick work on the part of his intended victim, pleaded guilty today to a charge of attempted extortion before Police Recorder Charles E. Tindell and was remanded to the county jail to await action of the grand jury.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Albert Handley, 19-year-old Central High School senior, captured the first annual five-and-a-half-mile handicap road run staged by the La Rabida Council of the Knights of Columbus today. This was the initial A.A.U. road test for the victor, who holds the New Jersey State interscholastic cross-country championship.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- The outstanding fact in the health record of the State for October was the exceptionally low maternal mortality, the bulletin of the State Department of Health, which is to be made public tomorrow, announces.

A statement analyzing the cotton situation was issued yesterday by Harriss Vose, members of the New York Cotton Exchange, in connection with Friday's referendum on the Bankhead Cotton Act, in which the South's cotton farmers by a vote of about 9 to 1, recorded themselves as favoring compulsory crop control in 1935.

THE publication of "The Mighty Barnum," by Gene Fowler and Bess Meredyth (Covici-Friede, $2), is something of an event. For it marks the first time that a motion-picture scenario, or "shooting script," has been published in book form. In his introduction Mr. Fowler says "The Mighty Barnum" was meant to function "wholly inside its own medium"; it was written for Hollywood, and for nothing else.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 17. -- The latest formula announced by the vernacular press for solving the London naval impasse would dilute Japan's demand for parity by introducing "a period of attainment," during which Japan would not exercise the parity she would theoretically achieve.

Religion was the essence of the Huguenot tradition, which was characterized by emphasis on the authority of a commanding conscience, the Rev. Dr. William H. S. Demarest, president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary and vice president of the Huguenot Society of America, told 400 persons who attended the first memorial service of the society in the Protestant Episcopal Church of Saint-Esprit, 229 East Sixty-first Street.

Andrew Thomas Merson, 27 years old, a part-time worker for the Standard News Association in Brooklyn, was killed almost instantly last night when he plunged down a flight of stairs in the balcony of the St. James Theatre at 246 West Forty-fourth Street.

LEXINGTON, Va., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Fire destroyed Tucker Hall, Law School building at Washington and Lee University, early today. College authorities set the loss at $85,000. Three students and a Lexington resident were injured.

Evidence in refutation of recent allegations of religious and racial discrimination against Jewish students in American medical colleges was presented yesterday by Dr. Harold Rypins, secretary of the New York State Board of Medical Examiners, before the Congregation Rodelph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street.
LONDON, Dec. 16. -- According to The Daily Herald's Saarbruecken correspondent, he was a witness to several incidents immediately proceeding Captain James H. Justice's accident today.

WUHU, China, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Mothers of this little missionary community were lavishing care and attention today upon little Helen Priscilla Stam, 3-month-old daughter of the murdered American missionaries, Mr. and Mrs. J.C. Stam.

The Rev. Francis X. Kelly, rector of St. John's Roman Catholic Church, Kingsbridge Avenue and 230th Street, celebrated a high mass yesterday in observance of the golden jubilee of his ordination and the silver jubilee of his pastorate. Cardinal Patrick Hayes, who was expected to preside at the mass, remained only a short time, as he had to "hasten away to another important engagement."

Domestic cotton consumption in November was fairly well maintained, although lower than in October, while exports continued small in comparison with recent years, according to the New York Cotton Exchange Service. It continues:

Plans to make the benefit parties that are to be held on President Roosevelt's birthday, Jan. 30, a greater success than the first national observance last January were announced yesterday by Henry L. Doherty, chairman of the national committee of the 1935 Birthday Ball for the President.
GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. Dec. 16. -- Four CCC workers were killed and eight of the twelve other passengers were injured today when a truck taking them to church skidded on the State highway near here.

A 22-year-old robber, who was released from Sing Sing prison last year, was "mussed up" by a patrolman early yesterday after he had been captured in a chase while fleeling from a delicatessen store he had robbed at 883 Columbus Avenue, near 104th Street.

Attacking the concept of the authoritarian state as "far below the level of established human knowledge," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia warned yesterday in his annual report to the university's trustees of the dangers inherent in a too-great extension of governmental powers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Six amendments to the National Industrial Recovery Act to assure that labor shall share fully in the "economic democracy" contemplated by the law were urged upon the Recovery Board by the Labor Advisory Board tonight.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 16. -- Ken Strong came here today with the New York Giants, champions of the National Football League, played in an exhibition game against the Paterson Panthers for less than three quarters, scored a touchdown, kicked the point after, booted a field goal and then was content to call it a day.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 16. -- A further and more definite indication of what private enterprise may do in the coming months to aid the administration in speeding economic recovery -- and in so doing to help avert the possibility of a "wild" Congress -- is expected to come from a meeting of business and industrial leaders which opens here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Dr. Otto F.H. Vollbehr, whose collection of incunabula and a rare and valuable copy of the Gutenberg Bible were purchased by the Library of Congress a few years ago for $1,500,000, has since spent nearly all of his personal fortune in the circulation in this country of pro-German and anti-Jewish propaganda, according to his testimony before the House Committee on Un-American Activities, it was announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- Sterling is showing a renewed but moderate weakness. The dollar rate on London this week touched $4.93 3/4 to the pound, against the recent high point of $4.96, but is now $4.94 3/4, while the franc rate has receded since a week ago from 75 1/4 francs to the pound to 75.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- Speculation concerning the prospect of a cut in the Reichsbank's discount rate at the New Year continued this week. Although there has been no official utterance, banking circles believe that a reduction is unlikely, and their attitude has induced on the Boerse a reaction in bond prices for which the big rise of preceding weeks had provided a basis.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 16. -- The congregation of St. James Episcopal Church waited this morning for their pastor, the Rev. Philip M. Kerridge, to conduct the 8 o'clock service. As he did not appear, two church members, Henry Holt Smith and Philip K. DeWire, were dispatched to ascertain the cause of the pastor's delay.

Sportsmen and bird lovers deplore the rapid disappearance, approaching extinction, of our waterfowl. In this connection may we call attention to the recent publication of the United States Biological Survey: Status of Waterfowl in 1934? It states the facts concerning the shortage of waterfowl and removes all discussion of the cause of this shortage beyond the realm of controversy.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16. -- The German-Americans today eliminated another of their foes in the race for the American League soccer championship by defeating Brookhattan, 2 -- 1.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Twenty Grand, a winner of the Kentucky Derby, stepped the full mile on the Santa Anita track today in a time trial of 1:43. The Greentree Stable entry in the $100,000 handicap was not let out by his handlers at any time.

As an individual who has a relatively moderate interest in the electric light and power industry, acquired in part during the years 1928 and 1929, I wish to express my appreciation of THE TIMES'S efforts -- particularly the editorial "Will They Pay?" -- to point out the disastrous possibilities of the various power yardsticks which are being established by the Federal Government.

A concert of compositions and adaptations by Lazare Saminsky will be presented tonight at the French Institute. The assisting artists will be Emily Roosevelt, Nadia Reisenberg, Mildred Dilling, Felix Salmond, Moses Rudinov, Edna Sheppard, Joseph Yasser and the Emanu-El Choir.

If compulsory crop control is "regimentation," a great many Southern farmers are apparently willing to be regimented. They cast a heavy vote in favor of the Bankhead Act, which authorizes the Government to allot to each producer the amount of cotton he may market and to impose a stiff penalty tax on all ginnings in excess of the quota thus established.

The National Industrial Conference Board, Inc., announced yesterday the results of a survey among 226 industrial executives that showed that 60 per cent of them have discovered no change in employer-employe relations since NIRA became effective.

The Save the Children Fund, which maintains a welfare program for underprivileged children in the Southern mountain regions, will benefit by a dramatic travelogue, entitled "The Romance of Oberammergau,'' to be given by Mark Haight on the morning of Jan. 5 in the ballroom of the Plaza.

BERLIN, Dec. 15. -- The November foreign trade figures showing a small excess of exports, amounting to 10,000,000 marks, indicate that the government has attained a permanent approximate equilibrium of imports and exports. The last four months, in which the balance in either direction fluctuated within the narrow limit of 25,000,000 marks, contrasted sharply with the first seven months of the year, in which the balance fluctuated 85,000,000 marks.
Foreign exchanges showed an upward trend against the dollar last week. While the improvement was limited in range, it disclosed a reversal of the sagging tendency in the Europeans in previous weeks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- In letters sent today to each member of the Senate and House, Henry H. Curran, director of the National Economy League, urged Congress not to yield to demands for immediate payment of the soldiers' bonus.

In preparing to produce a pageant of the Regency Period in England -- that of George III -- the committees for the Beaux Arts Ball, to be held on Feb. 1 at the Waldorf-Astoria, already have begun to assemble a cast, draw up a fitting scenario for the production and plot out a decorative setting.

Resolutions protesting against the anti-religious program in Mexico as "a serious blow aimed at both religion and human liberty" were adopted last night at a mass meeting of 1,800 Jews, Protestants and Catholics in the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

SOFIA, Dec. 16. -- More than forty high school pupils were arrested today in Southern Bulgaria, charged with being implicated in a Communist conspiracy discovered in Haskovo, where 500 persons, including 100 soldiers, had previously been arrested.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP). -- With the forward line of Howie Morenz, Johnny Gottselig and Mush March doing all the scoring the Chicago Black Hawks came from behind twice tonight to defeat the Montreal Maroons, 3 to 2, and regain the undisputed leadership of the National Hockey League's American Division.

The sale by the Hoboken Trust Company to the Martin New York Tent and Duck Company, Inc., of New York of part of the Naumann-Bove lumber yard property in North Bergen was the outstanding realty transaction in New Jersey over the week-end.

The complete city sales tax bill, containing amendments to the measure under which residents of the city paid the tax all last week, will be presented to the Local Laws Committees of the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen today at a joint meeting in the Mayor's office at City Hall.

Finding the net in each period despite the stiffest of defensive opposition, the Cities Service team yesterday afternoon downed the fast-skating St. Nicholas Hockey Club, 6 to 2, in a game packed with thrills.

Life insurance presidents in session the other day wondered what kind of a world it will be with fewer young people and more old people in it. The head of the Equitable Life was interested in the social consequences that may follow "the transfer of the balance of voting power from those under 40 to those over 50."

Serious doubts concerning the exemption from Federal taxation of any bonds issued by a Board of Transit Control as part of a plan to finance rapid transit unification have arisen to perplex the city's representatives in their negotiations with the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company, it was disclosed yesterday.

Two armed and masked men held up William Breit, 45 years old, address goods manufacturer, and his wife, Sarah, in the driveway of their home at 291 Beaumont Street, Manhattan Beach, at 2 A.M. yesterday as they were returning in their automobile after visiting friends.

Congratulations on your forceful defense of Latin and Greek contained in the paragraphs of Topics of The Times. When we investigate and find, as the years go on, fewer and fewer students enrolled in the field of the classics, we begin to wonder on whom the reflection should fall. Can we in all fairness except our colleges and universities?

I attended the luncheon given yesterday by the Arbitration Society and heard S. Clay Williams speak. Mr. Williams preceded his formal address with a statement that what he was about to say was to be confined entirely to the NRA and not to any other features of the New Deal.

With many of the old, the crippled, the dying, the suffering and the abandoned still unhelped, the Neediest Cases Fund enters the third and most critical week of the appeal today, lagging almost $6,000 behind the 1933 total for the corresponding date.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 16 (AP). -- A hodge podge of thirty-five bills, including measures increasing the corporation tax by one-third to provide additional revenue for Louisiana State University and forbidding New Orleans Police and Fire Department appropriation slashes were thrown into the Louisiana Legislature tonight by Senator Huey P. Long as his "mystery" special session opened.

Argentina will close the current year with its budget virtually balanced, according to a statement made yesterday by the Minister of Finance, Dr. Federico Pinedo, and received by cable by the Argentine Information Bureau here. After meeting all expenditures the deficit for the year will amount to only 19,400,000 pesos [$6,400,000].

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Assets of the 5,466 licensed national banks in the United States, Alaska and Hawaii on Oct. 17, the date of the last call for statements of condition, amounted to $24,811,390,000, an increase of $909,798,000 over the total reported by 5,422 banks on June 30 and a gain of $3,612,741,000 over the total reported by 5,057 banks on Oct. 25, 1933, J.F.T. O'Conner, Controller of the Currency, announced today.

William Baxter, secretary of the Beach Haven Tuna Club, sends word that there will be a public hearing at Atlantic City next Friday on the desirability of modifying regulations governing fish pound nets in the Atlantic Ocean from Montauk to Cape Charles, Va.

DETROIT, Dec. 16. -- The Detroit Red Wings came from behind tonight to gain a 2-to-2 overtime tie with the New York Americans in a National Hockey League match featured by hard-checking in all periods.

Republican women of State-wide and national prominence will receive opportunity to express their views at a series of Republican forums on the course the party should follow, Chase Mellen Jr., New York County chairman, announced yesterday.

Nathan Platkin was known in Harlem as a patient and considerate landlord by his tenants in the building at 1922-24 West 143d Street. He always waited for his rents and had been satisfied to collect them in small instalments. Yesterday he was shot dead as he entered the building to make one of those small collections.

Jeremiah D. Maguire, president of the Federation Bank and Trust Company, which was reorganized in October, 1932, announced yesterday that an initial dividend would be paid on the stock of the bank. The stockholders, he said, included President Roosevelt, Senator Copeland, Senator Wagner, Governor Lehman, former Governor Alfred E. Smith and William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

A call to New York Protestants -- admittedly in the minority as compared with Roman Catholics and Jews -- to organize so that they will have a united voice in the city's affairs was sounded yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church.

FRED J. PERRY of England, world's No. 1 singles tennis player, who won the Wimbledon championship this year, held the Davis Cup for the British with the help of AUSTIN, and then came over here and took the American championship with ease, has been getting some bad beatings in Australia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- A Housing Advisory Council composed of twenty-five building authorities was created today by James A. Moffett, the Federal Housing Administrator, to bring representative men in the building trade into more direct contact with the administration and through their technical knowledge speed up the housing program.
Numerous realignments in the "Golden Horseshoe" appear in the list of box-holders for the coming Season of the Metropolitan Opera Association made public yesterday.
Hoffman Co. have admitted Frank J. Adams as a general partner, and the name of the firm has been changed to Hoffman, Adams Co.

Denouncing social inequality yesterday in his sermon at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, the pastor, ridiculed the type of individual who goes through life "high-hatting people."

MOSCOW, Dec. 16. -- The Commissariat of Heavy Industry announced today the ten millionth ton of pig iron for the year had been poured. The program for 1934 under the second five-year plan was 10,000,000 tons. Thus, according to announcement, heavy industry has completed its allotted task in iron for the year with fifteen days to go in which overfulfillment will be recorded.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday a letter to John McKenzie, Commissioner of Docks, asking him to notify the steamship companies leasing city piers that the city administration does not approve of the holding of public dinners and entertainments on their ships while in port.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Spanish Ambassador and Senora de Calderon and members of the staff of the Chilean Embassy, representing the Ambassador, who is ill, entertained box parties at the concert given today in Constitution Hall by the National Symphony Orchestra in tribute to Manuel de Falla and to Mme. Blanche Renard, Chilean pianist, the guest artist, who played de Falla's fantasy, "Nights in a Garden of Spain.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16. -- Some steel producers made an effort to swell operations last week on account of Christmas payrolls, and the rate of steel ingot production rose 3 points to 33 per cent of capacity, making a total advance of 9 points in eight weeks.

BELGRADE, Dec. 16. -- Yugoslav army reservists, comprising the entire able-bodied population of this exceedingly virile country between the ages of 21 and 55, took the oath of allegiance today to their boy King. Their leaders thereby provided not only the cities but also thousands of villages with a most impressive spectacle.

A pageant portraying the history of Jewish philanthropy in New York City was presented yesterday at the Roxy Theatre, Seventh Avenue at Fiftieth Street, by 165 pupils of Jewish religious schools of the city.

Butch Keeling's dash down the ice and his pass to Cecil Dillon, who caged the puck in 18:19 of the third period, enabled the New York Rangers to turn back the hard-fighting Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16. -- Playing much more competently and with greater spirit, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club hockey team routed the Baltimore Orioles, 5 to 0, tonight. The Orioles played listlessly and were hopelessly outclassed throughout.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 16. -- State highway patrolmen hunted a motor car theft suspect tentatively identified as John Hamilton, fugitive member of the John Dillinger gang, in the Flint hills of Kansas tonight.

The penchant of Patrolman Ambrose Moore for using his service pistol otherwise than in the line of duty caused his arraignment yesterday, for the second time in less than four years, on a charge of felonious assault.

Three men invaded the home of Louis Rose, manager of the Jamaica Sporting Arena, at 84-26 Avon Road, Jamaica, yesterday morning. They bound the maid who answered the bell, bound Rose and his wife to their bed with twine and escaped with $5,500 worth of Jewelry.

Despite hisses, boos and catcalls from a minority element of about forty Communists, more than 2,000 persons took part yesterday in a meeting at Cooper Union to protest the recent mass executions in Soviet Russia following the assassination of Sergei Kiroff.

ALBANY, Dec. 16. -- No new records for stock corporations will be made this year, according to a report made today by the Division of Corporations of the Secretary of State's office. The number of new concerns up to Dec. 1 totaled 17.058, including 1,466 for last month, while the total for the same period a year ago was 20,930.

A committee headed by the Right Rev. Mgr. Francis Wakim, and with the Right Rev. Mgr. Gallue Bruder as honorary chairman, has been organized here to welcome the Most Rev. Francis Janssens, Abbot General of the Cistercian Order, on his arrival tomorrow from Rome on the Holland-America liner Statendam.

United States Senator W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey, speaking last night over Station WOR, advocated "a strict Federal licensing system governing exportation of domestic products that must become part of the essential implements of war."

The annual report of President BUTLER has usually something -- and usually several matters -- of wider interest than the events, problems, achievements, honors in the immediate life of the university. This year's report is no exception. Three or four matters of more than academic concern are discussed in his masterly fashion:
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 17. -- The Foreign Office spokesman today said that from the standpoint of Japanese-American friendship, the plan of Chairman Vinson for a Nicaraguan canal "is most untimely."

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Brooklyn's $427,950 armored truck robbery apparently came a step nearer solution today with the arrest here of Joseph Burns, one of the last of the John Dillinger gang. A paper found in the flat where he was seized indicated a twelve-way split of $427,000, which was believed to have come from the Brooklyn raid.
This afternoon's meeting of Actors Equity Association at the Hotel Astor is expected to take up the question of Sunday shows.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public nine new securities registration statements, representing proposed issues amounting to $10,606,960.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- A Federal-State unemployment insurance program, with the imposition of a 3 per cent tax on payrolls, beginning in 1936, is recommended in the report of the Advisory Council to the Committee on Economic Security, the text of which became available tonight.

Pledges and contributions in the United Hospital Fund's campaign to raise $500,000 toward paying for the free service given by its fifty-six affiliated voluntary hospitals now total $265,975, it was announced yesterday by David H. McAlpin Pyle, its president.

In the Supreme Court last week the Chief Justice and Associate Justice BRANDEIS sharply criticized the haphazard way in which Executive and administrative orders with the force of law are distributed. "If these are "Executive Orders having the effect of "laws," said the Chief Justice, "why "aren't they included in the laws of "Congress? I don't see any reason for "exclusion."

BURLINGAME, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Two army aviators, one of them Lieut. William C. Reeves, son of Admiral Joseph M. Reeves, commander of the United States fleet, were killed when their plane plunged nose down onto a highway and burned near here today.

Mrs. Jane Heinme, 38 years old, of 36-41 208th Street, Bayside, Queens, was killed at 5:40 A.M. yesterday when the automobile in which she was riding left the roadway of Northern Boulevard at 205th Street, Bayside. The car capsized after hitting a fire hydrant and careening off into a tree.

Bishop William T. Manning's recent declarations on the heritage of apostolic succession in the Protestant Episcopal Church were attacked yesterday afternoon as an "extravagant claim of authority and privilege" by the Rev. Dr. George C. Foley.

Seventy-nine awards for members of the City College varsity and junior varsity football squads of 1934 have been approved by the Athletic association, according to an announcement yesterday by Professor Walter W. Williamson, college manager of athletics.

Only one show will light the local dramatic Christmas tree this evening. It is "The Sky's the Limit!" Pierce Johns and Hendrik Booraem wrote it and the doctrine has something to do with the radio advertising field. Smith and Dale of vaudeville renown are present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Measures to strengthen the army and increase its efficiency were recommended by George H. Dern, Secretary of War, in his annual report to President Roosevelt today for the fiscal year which ended June 30, 1934.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices this week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 78.6, which compares with 78.7 a week before, 79 two weeks before, 78.9 three weeks before and 79 four weeks before.

Liberalization of the Republican party within two years was predicted yesterday by David W. Peck, chairman of the board of governors of the New York Young Republican Club. He spoke from Radio Station WINS in reply to questions asked by Paul A. Shinkman.

Albert H. Fish, house painter who confessed last week to the kidnapping and murder of Grace Budd in 1928, has been placed within seven blocks of the neighborhood in which William Gaffney, 4-year-old Brooklyn boy, disappeared in February, 1927, detectives announced yesterday.

Outside the crime of being steady and outstanding earners at continually declining rates, I question whether there is any justification for the present leadership in the attack upon operating utility companies.

Last week's testimony before the aldermanic committee regarding an alleged breakdown in the services of supply was given the most sensational interpretation by officials conducting the inquiry. The public got the impression not only that vast quantities of veal, potatoes, cabbage and other foodstuffs intended for the suffering were going to rot, but that responsible public agencies were sitting by, callous and indifferent.

A report covering the first sixteen months of operation of the Cotton Textile Code under the Cotton Textile Code Authority, made public yesterday by George A. Sloan, chairman of the Code Authority, found that, with the exception of cases involving only twenty-three employers, all code violations investigated were adjusted satisfactorily without reference to NRA or other governmental agencies.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16. -- Charges that "gentlemen attached to intelligence services of several Western powers and one Eastern power are not above undertaking subversive activities in Soviet Ukraine" were made editorially today in Izvestia, the government organ.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Developments in the corn market on the Board of Trade were bullish early last week but became more varied toward the close of trading. High cash premiums and light offerings in the country, with corn in most markets higher than wheat, has induced liberal buying of futures by outsiders as well as local traders, who base their operations on the expected shortage in corn and feed crops.

MOREHEAD, Ky., Dec. 16 (AP). -- Twelve National Guardsmen, under command of Lieut. Col. Jesse Lindsay of Frankfort, were on their way to Haldeman, in Rowan County, tonight to quell a threatened labor uprising at the plant of the Kentucky Fire Brick Company there.

As was to be expected, Senator HIRAM JOHNSON does not agree with Senator BORAH that the Republican party ought to be reorganized. When Senator NORRIS is heard from, and also Senator LA FOLLETTE, it will doubtless appear that each of these Progressive Republicans is "contrary-minded" as regards all the others.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- In spite of the apparent firmness of the Continental European gold currencies in terms of sterling, it cannot be said that their future is regarded with any greater confidence. Italy's action to mobilize Italian foreign credits in defense of the lira and Belgium's recently concluded credit with Dutch bankers are regarded here as confessions of weakness.

PARIS, Dec. 16. -- French opinion is beginning to follow that of the United States and England in demanding that the profit be taken out of war, and that the manufacture of and traffic in arms should be a national, not a private business.
Mrs. Theodore Greenbaum and Richard W. Kahn of New York took the mixed-pair championship of the American Bridge League yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
The State Department of Education's new certificate regulations, which will become effective Sept. 1, will be fought by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations, it was announced yesterday.

The final rush for holiday merchandise, heavy purchases for January promotions and hurried calls for cold weather apparel combined to create unusual activity in the wholesale markets here last week. Large quantities of goods were moved from all departments featuring gift merchandise and manufacturers in many lines were hard pressed to keep up with the demand.

An application to the Federal Government for a $17,000,000 loan to enable the razing of the Criminal Courts Building and the Tombs prison, and the erection on their combined site of a monumental structure housing practically all the criminal courts and associated departments of New York County will be made early in the new year, it was disclosed yesterday.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 16. -- Time Supply moved into the lead at the head of the stretch to capture the $25,000 added Bay Meadows Handicap today. Dark Winter was second and Fleam third. The time was 1 minute, 53 and 4-5 seconds for the mile and one-eighth.

DETROIT, Dec. 16. -- Spokesmen for skilled tool and die makers today objected vigorously to the President's joint NRA-Labor Department inquiry into employment stabilization when they were prevented from airing their grievances concerning alleged violations of Section 7a, and from giving their objections to the further continuance of the National Automobile Labor Board headed by Dr. Leo Wolman.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- Four thousand men and women athletes, representing the reserves from which the German Olympic team of 1936 will be selected, today took the oath of loyalty and obedience at public ceremonies held at forty different points of the Reich.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Twenty-eight State Federations of Labor were called upon today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, to urge State Legislatures to approve the child labor amendment to the Constitution of the United States.
BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 16. -- Peacemakers were busy tonight trying to patch up a quarrel between Senator Huey P. Long and Captain Lawrence (Biff) Jones, football coach of Louisiana State University.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Theodore G. Bilbo, Senator-elect from Mississippi, may "raise more hell than Huey Long" eventually but thus far the capital has found him modest, shy and retiring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Protest against proposed amendments to the Men's Clothing Code, scheduled for a hearing on Jan. 3, was made today by the Industrial Recovery Association of Clothing Manufacturers in a telegram to the National Recovery Administration denouncing them as a menace to "those elements not enjoying the favor of the Code Authority."

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 10. -- In a successful defense of the laurels it captured last year, the New York team made a clean sweep of three matches with the Tuxedo-Long Island combination today on the court of Mrs. Payne Whitney's Greentree estate to retain the Payne Whitney Memorial Trophy for court tennis doubles.

Eighty-six Columbia students will receive insignia for their participation in football and cross-country activities last Fall, it was announced yesterday by Reynolds Benson, graduate manager of athletics.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Argentine oats are in a measure making up for the shortage in the crop in the United States, this extending from the Gulf of Mexico to the extreme Northeastern States and along the Pacific Coast, and in some parts of the Middle West.

Any attempt by public utility companies to transfer the burden of new city taxes to the shoulders of their customers by means of rate increases will meet with bitter opposition from the city, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- From all parts of the Reich come reports of a warning given by provincial authorities to officials of the established Protestant church that the government is ready to withdraw its financial support and to disestablish the church if it does not cease quarreling.

PARIS, Dec. 15. -- The Bank of France return, as of Dec. 7, shows a decrease of 589,000,000 francs in circulation and a rise of 971,000,000 in private deposits, but as treasury and caisse amortisement deposits fell 750,000,000, while the gold reserve rose 217,000,000 the cover ratio improved to a record figure of 80.83 per cent.
The following table gives the high and low prices for 1934 as well as last prices for all stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange that were not traded in last week:
PARIS, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin, addressing a conference of French Mayors tonight, announced the Cabinet will propose measures to reform the Constitution early next year.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Dec. 16. -- A British officer attached to the Saar International Volunteer Police Force, who had been driving in an automobile accompanied by the Earl of Aylesford and another friend, a Fraulein Braun, was beaten by an infuriated crowd after a street accident here early today.

The first of three Wagner programs by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Bruno Walter at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon was devoted to examples sufficiently generous in size and scope to illustrate adequately aspects of the man's enormous genius.

Max Reinhardt's production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream," with Mendelssohn's music, is expected to open in New York about Feb. 15, it was said yesterday. There is a possibility that it may use the Center Theatre of the Rockefeller group now occupied by "The Great Waltz," but in the event that it does not, the spectacle will open at some other large house.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Twenty-six registration statements involving issues amounting to $67,617,529.14 became effective during November, bringing the total effectives registered under the Securities Act of 1933 since that law became operative in July of that year to 875 issues for an aggregate of $1,309,618,245.68.

Contributions from Federal employes totaling $13,000 to the relief fund of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee were announced yesterday. The contributions from this source are now 11 per cent larger than those received in the campaign last year, according to T.B. Randles, chairman of the division canvassing Federal employes.

SAARBRUECKEN, Dec. 16. -- Witnesses of today's automobile accident involving Captain James H. Justice and the subsequent attack by an irate crowd said that after Captain Justice's car had hit the woman victim he got out and apologized.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 16. -- President Lazaro Cardenas initiated his nationalistic program today with a decree giving Mexicans complete preference in the bestowal of concessions. The decree takes effect immediately.

LONDON, Dec. 9. -- By a startling coincidence, the autograph diary kept by the Empress Marie Louise has come to light at a time when the collecting world is filled with excitement over the forthcoming sale at Sotheby's in London on Dec. 17 of the letters written to her by Napoleon during some of the most momentous stages of his career.

New York's grand opera "family," soon to open a new season at the Metropolitan, met last evening at a reception and supper given by Giovanni Martinelli at the Beethoven Association Clubhouse, 30 West Fifty-sixth Street, in honor of the new Italian opera conductor, Ettore Panizza, and Mme. Panizza.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Incomes of individuals and corporations in New York State took dominant place in final statistics of income for the calendar year 1932, issued by the Internal Revenue Bureau today.
Milton Hanauer, New York State chess champion in 1926, yesterday administered the first defeat sustained by David Polland in the annual tournament for the championship of the Marshall Chess Club.

The International Seamen's Union has obtained recognition of two demands that seamen consider important in a new wage agreement adopted by committees representing the union and thirty-eight ship lines, it was announced yesterday. The lines have agreed to give preference to union members in employing seagoing personnel and to grant agents of the union access to ships in port to confer with seamen on matters pertaining to working conditions.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16. -- A scientific secret, hitherto concealed by the clam, was made public at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- Grain markets of the world are regarded by many speculators and cash handlers as in a position where constant buying and injection of bullish sentiment into the trade to sustain prices at high levels are necessary. Bulges run into selling and are comparatively short-lived, while fair buying develops on all price recessions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Disclosure that President Roosevelt is planning to recommend a neutrality policy to Congress for possible application in case of another war to which we are not a party has raised sharply the question of whether the administration is veering from the support it has previously given to the Kellogg-Briand pact for the outlawry of war.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Dr. Clarence W. Lieb, a New York stomach specialist, has been confined to his Pound Ridge Road estate here since Tuesday, when he was bitten by a poisonous black widow spider, it was learned today. Although a serum arrived today by airplane from Denver, Colo., it will not be used if Dr. Lieb continues to improve at the present rate.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Seven hundred United States marines sailed for home today, completing a tour of service at Shanghai, but three of their fellows who expected to depart with them were left behind in Shanghai hospitals.
Housing sales in the Bronx and Brooklyn and various leasehold deals in Manhattan were reported yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 16. -- Frank Campbell's Class B one-design boat, Felix, edged out Bill Inslee's Smoke in the frost-bite dinghy regatta off the Larchmont Yacht Club today. Every race was a drifting match, with the lightest of southwest winds barely filling the sails.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- A permanent public works program, intelligent planning of the use of land, water and mineral assets of the country and a rejuvenation of the agricultural technique of the nation were recommended in the report of the National Resources Board to President Roosevelt, made public today.

ROME, Dec. 16. -- The Italian Government in a formal report to the League of Nations today refused arbitration of the bitter quarrel with Abyssinia over troop clashes and insisted on an apology from the Abyssinian Government.

Postmaster General James A.Farley, Aldermanic President Bernard S. Deutsch and other officials attended last night the annual dinner of the Home of the Daughters of Jacob at the Hotel Astor. The institution, founded thirty-eight years ago by a small group on the lower East Side, now occupies a $1,250,000 building at 167th Street and Findlay Avenue, the Bronx.

Increased rates for public liability insurance affecting apartment, boarding and rooming houses in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn have been approved by the State Insurance Department and are affective today, the National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters pointed out yesterday.

The message of Christmas to the world today is that, amid conditions of desperate need. Christianity brings to men a new power of God and a new way of life, the Rev. Dr. Raymond C. Knox, chaplain of Columbia University, declared yesterday.

In the last of a series of Sunday night radio talks on education Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared last night that "we have made too much of a fetish in this country of what is known as white-collar work."

Doubleday, Doran ennounce the l organization of what they. call Heyday House, a new department that will be devoted to entertainment. It v-ill be under the direction of Jerome S. Meyer, who produced "Mental Whoopee" and "Mind Your P's Q's," and will publish puzzles, games and some books of humor.
No group trend was noticeable in commodity futures trading here last week, and while the volume in some of the staples was large, the changes in price were small for the most part.
Dr. T.Z. Koo, vice president of the World's Student Christian Federation of Peiping, preached the sermon yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-Fourth Street.
New York had no alarm out for a Jospeh Burns in connection with the Brooklyn armored car robbery in August, officials said last night.

Z.G. Simmons and J.H. Wantling tied for the High-Over-All Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. Each finished with a card of 97 out of 100 targets. In the 25-target shoot-off, Simmons triumphed by 24 -- 23.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 16. -- Demanding a share in its benefits to balance the burdens of the New Deal, Puerto Rico's Civic Reform League, a non-partisan organization including many of the island's most prominent persons, has cabled to President Roosevelt, asserting that mere promises are no longer of avail.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 16. -- William A. Carlile Jr. '36, of Columbus, Ohio, will be chairman of the 1935 board of The Daily Princetonian, campus newspaper of Princeton University, it was announced here today.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 (AP). -- Attacking munition manufacturers as "merchandisers of murder," the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin charged in an address today that "we actually equip our potential enemies among the world powers, and out of fear of offending Japan our navy, our army, our State Department all approved a sale of a secret process to Japan."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 16. -- With more than 500 in attendance, the ten winners of the annual New Jersey State exhibition received medals today at the Montclair Art Museum. About 700 entries were received for this year's competition, of which 316 were accepted.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 17. -- Mrs. Frederick D. Sherman of Greenwich, Conn., and her daughter, Miss Betty Sherman, who are at La Solana, were honored by Mr. and Mrs. Pierre L. Willis at a dinner tonight in their Brazilian Avenue villa.

Stocks showed an inclination yesterday to advance, if somewhat timidly, but they did not get far. By comparison with Saturday's quotations, the price averages at the close were only a trifle higher. The volume of trading was monotonously close to the recent daily average, so much so, that it excited no comment.
An exchange of factory properties in Jersey City valued at $100,000 featured the New Jersey trading reported yesterday.

Lovers of irony will find a choice morsel of it in a recent decision of the Indiana Supreme Court. In November, 1930, the Democratic candidate for a superior court judgeship was elected, on the first count, by nine votes. On a recount, granted at the demand of his Republican opponent, the latter was shown to have been elected by twenty-one votes.

Award of a new issue of $500,000 Kenosha County, Wis., 3 1/2 per cent poor relief bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1935, and due serially from 1936 to 1955, has been awarded to a syndicate comprising Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.; R.W. Pressprich Co. and Pipe, Jaffray Hopwood of Minneapolis.

The local regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission completed yesterday its investigation of the Como Mines Company and recent dealings in its stock on the New York Produce Exchange. An extensive report was forwarded to John J. Burns, general counsel for the commission, in Washington by John P. Callahan of the legal staff of the local office.
WASHINGTON Dec. 17. -- The text of the statement issued by Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, in reply to the memorial of Thomas N. McCarter to President Roosevelt follows:

The proposed heavyweight battle between Steve Hamas, American contender for the world's title, and Max Schmeling, German boxer who formerly held the crown, will be waged in Germany, according to an announcement yesterday by Charles J. Harvey, manager of Hamas.

Evidence on which New York County plans ultimately to file an indictment against Albert H. Fish, 65 years old, who confessed to the abduction and murder of Grace Budd in 1928, was submitted to the grand jury yesterday. The District Attorney's office previously had indicated that the kidnapping case against Fish would be completed, as a precautionary measure, although plans have been made for trying him in Westchester County, where the charge would be murder.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- Mrs. Helen Starr Josephson, 33 years old, of 975 Park Avenue, New York, testified before official Referee Joseph Morschauser this afternoon that her mother, Mrs. Libby Starr of Mamaroneck, always had been irritable, and never affectionate nor patient.
Restaurant checks of $1 or perhaps $1.25 a person will be made subject to the city's 2 per cent sales tax under an amended tax bill to be acted upon today by the Board of Aldermen in City Hall.

Approval of the contract affiliating the recently formed Screen Actors Guild, Inc., with the Actors Equity Association was voted at the regular quarterly meeting of Equity members yesterday afternoon in the Hotel Astor. Only two or three dissenters registered objections.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 17. -- The State refused today to grant the request of Bruno Richard Hauptmann's counsel for permission to examine exhibits in the Lindbergh murder case. This was announced by Attorney General David T. Wilentz after a conference with his prosecution staff.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club swept its matches with the Princeton Club yesterday to maintain its lead in the Metropolitan Class C squash tennis league. The New Mooners now have eight victories and no defeats. The City A.C. first team, however, remained in a virtual tie for first place by winning by default from the New York A.C. second team.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Captain Jones has made no request to the Adjutant General's Department for relief from duty at Louisiana State University and transfer elsewhere, it was said today.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Stocks were irregular today, with the volume of business small. British Government funds weakened fractionally, while most of the foreign bonds were dull. Firmness in brewery shares was a bright spot among British industrials.

The Federation Bank and Trust Company announced yesterday its first dividend since reorganization two years ago, and a cash bonus to all employes. The dividend amounts to 20 cents and is payable on Jan. 3 to holders of record of Dec. 22.

The estate of Mrs. Elizabeth A. Mekeel, widow of Isaac A. Mekeel, founder of the United Publishers Corporation, was appraised yesterday at $842,165 gross and $311,846 net. Because she was a resident of Montclair, N.J., the only part of the estate taxable in New York State was $30,000 in real estate in the town of New Castle, Westchester County.

The artists at Albert Morris Bagby's Musical Morning yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, at which a large audience was present, were Mme. Lily Pons of the Metropolitan Opera, Chase Baromeo and Albert Spalding. Edwin McArthur, Arpad Sandor and Andre Benoist were at the piano.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Operatic stars, in person, sang with a synchronized radio reproduction of a full orchestra and chorus for the first time tonight in a condensed version of Gounod's "Faust" before an invited audience of musical notables in the Whitehall Theatre.

Testimony of delays in the distribution of relief coal before the Aldermanic committee investigating relief embroiled city officials in another dispute with the State TERA yesterday, with the result that both sides agreed to meet tomorrow morning to discuss the general relief problem.
Opposition to the proposed 2 per cent sales tax on food checks was expressed in a resolution adopted last night by the Society of Restaurateurs, of which Paul Henkel is president.

The Student Council, undergraduate self-governing body at City College under suspension for the last two months, was reinstated yesterday with two minor qualifications. The council was suspended by the faculty Oct. 11 for its part in the anti-Fascist demonstration in the Great Hall during the visit of an Italian student delegation to the college Oct. 9.
LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The naval discussions will adjourn Thursday without a date for resumption being fixed or conditions for resumption being stated.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Dec. 17. -- Two lawyers were under arrest tonight, indicted on charges of complicity in the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, Oklahoma oil operator, in 1933. Both appeared as defense counsel at the trial and conviction of abductors of Mr. Urschel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- There was neither affirmation nor denial at the White House today of a report that Mrs. Anna Dall, daughter of the president, will marry John Boettiger, former member of The Chicago Tribune staff.

Younger members of society are taking an active interest in the plans for the Christmas party and dance which will follow the annual Christmas Song Festival to be given by the People's Chorus of New York tomorrow night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to augment the maintenance fund of the chorus.

The formal protest of the government of the United States to Germany over the matter of defaulted interest payments on bonds held in this country was cited yesterday by George N. Rosenberg, counsel for the Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for the International Match Company, at a hearing before Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Clearly, the President's purpose, when he asked the State Department to survey the body of laws and conventions governing neutrals in wartime, was to keep the United States from being drawn into the next conflict in which it has no direct or immediate interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Nine changes of assignment in the high command of the army were announced today by Secretary Dern, the War Department explaining that they had been planned for some time but awaited final decision as to the tenure of General Douglas MacArthur as chief-of-staff, which now has been extended for an indefinite period.

Space on the ocean liners left from Christmas mail seems to be taken up by the theatrical people going back and forth. Setting them forth in proper order, these travel notations 1ook something like this:

The Alabama Great Southern Railroad, controlled by the Southern Railway, reports for the ten months ended Oct. 31 net income of $296,136, after charges and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 81 cents a share on 156,600 shares of common stock,

Roscoe H. Hupper, counsel for the Ward Line, announced last night that he would submit today to the Postoffice Department inquiry into steamship mail subsidies a brief characterizing as "inaccurate" reports that the Ward Line made a $263,000 profit on insurance on the Morro Castle.

United States Government bonds were bid up 1-32 to 9-32 point on the Stock Exchange yesterday, showing the best strength of any of the groups in the listed market. Four of the Federal issues closed unchanged on the day. Domestic corporation bonds moved irregularly higher, while foreign loans were lower.

Two nation-wide syndicates have been organized to submit bids today for the new issue of $42,900,000 New York City serial bonds, one headed by the Chase National Bank and the other by the National City Bank. Each banking group consists of about forty members.

The report submitted by the Public Service Commission on the original cost of the Rochester Railways system was "tainted with vice." Henry W. Kileen of Buffalo declared yesterday at a hearing before the commission. The hearing was on a petition to reorganize the company.

In a decision yesterday Supreme Court Justice Collins took notice of charges that Harry Gerguson, self-styled "Prince Michael Romanoff," had been hired to compromise Mrs. Wilma E. Gould in an alleged conspiracy to enable her husband, Edward B. Gould, to divorce her.

The Newspaper Industrial Board of the Newspaper Code Authority started a hearing in the Hotel Warwick yesterday in the case of Alphonse Tonietti, who contends that he was discharged from the Italian language newspaper Il Progresso because of his activity as head of the chapter of the Newspaper Guild of New York.

The 1935 nominating committee of the New York Stock Exchange, whose duty it will be to propose names for a president and ten new members of the board of governors, was chosen yesterday by the old nominating committee of the Exchange.

The Regional Labor Board cited yesterday S. Klein, dress store proprietor of Union Square, before the National Labor Relations Board in Washington for "appropriate action" on alleged violations of the collective bargaining provision of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

Only two more days remain before the closing of the campaign of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which set out to raise a fund of at least $2,000,000 to help the private welfare agencies meet the demands upon them. The final report is to be made on Wednesday.

Retail collections during November showed an increase of 1.92 per cent, according to the index of twenty local key stores, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc. The average collection percentage last month was 48.35.

The board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday advised holders of long or short contracts in December sugar that unless their positions were liquidated on or before Dec. 20, it proposed to suspend all trading in December contracts and to require the liquidation of the contracts.

William F.J. Piel, president of Piel Brothers, brewers, and chairman of the Third Regional Board of the Code Authority for the brewing industry, declared yesterday that breweries financed through stock promotions since repeal had been "signally unsuccessful" as a class.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- The Budget Committee reported to the Westchester Board of Supervisors today that it had added $8,250 to the proposed 1935 budget. It now totals $10,027,169 gross. The increases were $750 for rent of county judges' quarters in Yonkers, and $7,500 for plans for a parkway bridge at Fleetwood.

The New York Conference for Unemployment Insurance Legislation has taken over the mezzanine of the Roxy Theatre for the evening showing of "Anne of Green Gables" on Friday night. Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, heads the list of sponsors.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- In just three and one-half minutes a hitherto unknown collection of 318 letters which Napoleon wrote to his second wife, the Empress Marie Louise, fell under the auctioneer's hammer at Sotheby's today for 15,000 (the pound is currently quoted at $4.94).

With Christmas just a week away, and children straggling home for the holidays, the proprietors of puppet shows and other juvenile enticements are planning their entertainment. Most of them will manage to give three or four performances in the mornings or afternoons of Christmas week, and at the moment the schedule looks something like this:
A new and still nameless party has plunged into the American political arena under the generalship of two young officials of the Museum of Modern Art. Its members wear gray shirts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The text of a memorial on power handed to President Roosevelt today by Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Edison Electric Institute, read as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- That celebrated song dear to the heart of railroad men -- "The Wreck of Old 97" -- was held today by the Supreme Court to be the property of David Graves George of Detroit, the author.

Ray Miller of Essex Prep, the New Jersey State heavyweight champion, knocked out Paul Jones, unattached, in the second round of the heavyweight special bout that featured the amateur boxing show at the New York A.C. last night.

Filling the vacancy caused by the death of John Wanamaker, the American Power Boat Association council elected General J. Leslie Kincaid of New York City treasurer of the organization at a meeting last night at the Hotel Lexington. The position is one of the five elective offices of the A.P.B.A.

Audits of banks by certified public accountants at regular intervals to supplement those of Federal and State examiners was advocated last night by George W. McLaughlin, president of the Brooklyn Trust Company and former State Superintendent of Banking, in an address before the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

Harry A. Buck, who for the past twenty-five years has been the secretary of the United Hunts Racing Association, resigned from that post yesterday on account of ill health. He will go to California shortly to spend the Winter. He will continue his association with the Turf and Field Club of which he is secretary, and his other interests, however.

DETROIT, Dec. 17. -- The Automobile Labor Board completed today arrangements for the primary election of a collective bargaining committee by employes of the Cadillac Motor Car Company on Wednesday. The final election of the men nominated will be on Dec. 28.

The grand jury that for about eleven months had been investigating widespread operation of policy rings and the police methods in dealing with them handed up a presentment to Judge Corrigan in General Sessions yesterday and was discharged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Holding that America's economic recovery was dependent largely on liberalization of credit policies by commercial banks and the government, so that billions of dollars in reserves might be utilized, Dr. Jacob Viner of the University of Chicago and Charles O. Hardy, of the Brookings Institution, in a report today to Secretary Morgenthau, advocated the concentration of the government's direct lending operations in a single Federal agency.

DUBLIN, Dec. 17. -- Negotiations for a trade agreement between the Irish Free State and Germany were resumed in government buildings here this afternoon following arrival in Dublin today of three envoys of the Hitler government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- This country's definition of neutrality, and its probable line of conduct in case of a war in which it is or is not involved will be set forth as an official pronouncement as soon as studies, now going on at the State Department, are concluded, Secretary Hull said today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 17. -- Establishment in Washington of an all-business board to act in a liaison capacity between private enterprise and the administration in planning further recovery efforts was revealed today as the first practical objective of about ninety business leaders gathered here to seek ways and means of ending the depression.
The Home Owners' Loan Corporation in New York State has closed loans on 57,330 dwellings and the amount advanced has passed $300,000,000, Vincent Dailey, State manager, announced yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 17 (Canadian Press). -- Harvey Jackson and Charlie Conacher are more firmly entrenched as leaders in scoring in the National Hockey League as a result of their play during the past week. Both starred for the Toronto Maple Leafs in three decisive victories and tonight were far ahead in the race for Individual honors.

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- Arrests in con nection with a morals clean-up have now been going on in Germany for a fortnight, and although nothing about them is published in the German press they are no longer denied.

Nothing in the annual catalogue for 1934-35 of that seasoned and excellent school, the Worcester Polytechnic Institute, indicates it, but the undergraduates are profoundly discouraged. They make no complaint about minor matters such as the courses of instruction and the proficiency of professors.

PARIS, Dec. 17 (AP). -- France, watching with keen interest the futile naval conversations in London, laid plans today to boost her naval ratio above the present 1.75 in capital ships at any conversations that might follow Japan's termination of the Washington naval treaty.
CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 17. -- A Santa Claus without whiskers but a real Santa Claus just the same came today to the Dionne quintuplets.

The horse that does not drink will be led to the trough again. Acting jointly, the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation have reduced from 3 to 2 1/2 per cent the maximum rate of interest that may be paid on time and savings deposits by the nearly 14,000 banks which are members of the FDIC.
CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 17. -- Sweep Vestal galloped to victory in the first race today without a single ticket on her to win.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- Dave Smukler, Temple's star fullback, was taken to the Temple University Hospital today suffering with a heavy cold and grip.

Lady Hardwicke, actress, and her sister, Miss Marjory Pickard, actress, are among the passengers due today from Liverpool via Queenstown on the motor ship Georgic of the Cunard White Star Line. Others on the ship include Mr. and Mrs. Melville Cooper and Edmund Gwenn.
BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- Soviet Russia now has a fleet of fast modern submarines at Vladivostok, her eastern seaport nearest Japan, it was learned here in well-informed naval circles.

Al Casimini, Corona lightweight, hammered his way to the decision over Johnny Bonito of the Bronx in the feature bout of eight rounds at the benefit show held last night at St. Nicholas Palace. About 4,000 persons saw the bouts held in the interest of County Clerk Al Marinelli's Christmas basket fund.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 17. -- The Louisiana State Tigers, plucky little band of football players, were sitting in the middle tonight of the heated row between their coach, Biff Jones, and Louisiana's boss politician, Huey P. Long.

PARIS, Dec. 17. -- Even though there was no longer the same uncertainty and cause for uneasiness in the French internal and foreign political situations as existed in many past months, the stock market continued unsatisfactory today. There was little business and the atmosphere remained heavy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- A material falling off today in the movement of hogs, receipts at leading Western markets being less than two-thirds of the number received a week ago, brought all classes of buyers into the market, and prices advanced 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight from those of Friday, with some light hogs up as much as 40 cents.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, houses with Eastern connections selling wheat futures while longs were disposed to get out of their holdings of December oats and rye.

In one of the wildest meetings ever held by the New York County Republican organization. County Chairman Chase Mellen Jr. won a sweeping victory last night on the vote for his candidate for Commissioner of Elections, David B. Costuma, leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District.

Japan is said to be swinging around to a compromise by which she is to be granted naval parity and in return will promise not to build up to it. This may seem to be a rather childish subterfuge for grown-up nations to resort to, but national prestige has been known to act like that.

Narrowly missing several children as they were playing in Central Park near East Sixty-second Street at 3:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a steel pear-shaped object, about four inches long and weighing between ten and fifteen pounds, fell out of the sky and imbedded itself six inches in the ground.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Dec. 17. -- A tense situation has been left here as a result of yesterday's incident. This developed when Captain James H. Justice of the Saar Valley International Volunteer Police Force, and the Earl of Aylesford, another Briton, were beaten severely after a woman had been run over by their car.

TORONTO, Dec. 17 (AP). -- A band of organized arsonists was sought tonight by police following an incendiary fire at the Thorncliffe racetrack today that destroyed three stables and burned to death twenty valuable race horses.

Prynne Lee Hoxie, 20 years old, of St. Louis, a Princeton student, was killed yesterday morning when an automobile in which he was riding with four fellow students struck an elevated pillar at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. The impact forced his head through a window of the car.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 17. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-one leading cities on Dec. 12 shows increases for the week of $33,000,000 in total loans and investments, $127,000,000 in net demand deposits and $17,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

Free programs under the auspices of the city's concert activities will be given tonight in Brooklyn by the Stuyvesant String Quartet at the Central Branch Y.W.C.A., Knickerbocker Dance Orchestra in the Prospect Park Picnic House and the Metropolitan Dance Orchestra in the Willoughby Settlement House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Beginning with a premise that price fixing in the codes of fair competition has not operated in the best interest of the nation's industrial structure, the National Industrial Recovery Board, administrative arm of the NRA, stated today that it would establish a new procedure by opening public hearings on Jan. 9 to collect material on the operation of major code provisions.

The B.M.T. made public yesterday results of the annual election of employes' representatives on its lines and pointed to these results as an indication that the workers were satisfied with the relationship under the employes' representation plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Led by the four Cabinet officers whose duties include supervision of some phrase of aviation, the capital paid tribute today to the late Wilbur Wright and his brother, Orville Wright. The speeches of the four were broadcast over a National Broadcasting Company network.
Price movements on the local commodity futures markets were mixed again yesterday. The volume of trading was moderate in most instances. Copper and cocoa were the only staples to show any firmness.
ROMSEY, England, Dec. 17 (P). -- Sir Charles Greenway was elevated to the peerage in the King's honor list of 1927, when he became a baron.

Mayor LA GUARDIA is fond of wandering about the streets of this city, like HAROUN, seeing that the laws are obeyed. On his rounds he must observe much that is gratifying to his pride as chief magistrate. The condition of the streets themselves, for example.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 17. -- In a report submitted to the Legislature today, the Passaic Valley Flood Control Commission proposed creation of a lake twice the size of Lake Hopatcong in the valleys of the Rockaway and Whippany Rivers if the necessary funds can be obtained from the Federal Public Works Administration.
CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 17 (AP). -- Federal Judge John Boyd Avis ruled today that persons holding stock in closed national banks were liable to assessment although the stock was part of a trust fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- A proposal made to President Roosevelt today by Thomas N. McCarter, president of the Edison Electric Institute, that the government cooperate with the power interests for an early Supreme Court decision on the validity of the Tennessee Valley Authority, was rebuffed tonight by the Federal Power Commission, to which Mr. Roosevelt had referred the matter for consideration.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 17. -- With Senator Huey P. Long cracking the whip, the Louisiana House today advanced to the last step before final passage thirty-four of the thirty-five edicts he presented last night when his own special session of the Legislature convened.

It would be impossible to consider in detail all the proposals in the grandiose planning scheme just outlined to the extent of about 75,000 words by the National Resources Board headed by Secretary ICKES. Some of the suggestions looking toward the conservation of our natural resources are obviously sound and embody policies that should have been adopted by our Federal and State Governments long ago.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 17. -- Dr. Edward T. Devine, executive director of the Nassau County branch of the TERA, resigned today from that position, because of "differences with the bureau." His position paid a salary of $6,500 a year, and he held it for more than three years.

The hearing on the petition by George W. Wickersham and Thomas B. Gilchrist, co-guardians of the $2,800,000 estate of 10-year-old Gloria Vanderbilt, to be eliminated from the habeas corpus proceedings brought by Mrs. Vanderbilt for the custody of her daughter was adjourned yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Valente until May 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Early settlement of the dispute between the government and the railroads over the constitutionality of the Railroad Retirement Law to pension retired employes, was assured when the Supreme Court today granted the plea of the Department of Justice for a review of the case.

Several developments interested the speculative markets yesterday, but most importantly the announcement on behalf of the National Resources Board that a permanent public works program was being worked out. That there was no emphatic response indicated that market interests were more or less skeptical, having in mind previous projects that had been received initially with great enthusiasm in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Asserting that the development of chemistry and chemical knowledge was not only the basis of all national defense but would eventually end all war, Francis P. Garvan, head of the Chemical Foundation, opposed today before the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Information Committee any agreement that might affect adversely the chemical industries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP). -- The second Roosevelt social season, differing from the first by two light wines, and minus the precedence talk of seasons still further back, will open with the Cabinet dinner tomorrow night.
Miss Sally Perot gave a luncheon yesterday in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for Miss Carol Prichitt, debutante daughter of Mrs. James T. Houghton. The other guests were:

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- The resignation of Dr. Gustav Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach as president of the so-called Reich Estate of German Industry, actually in effect for several months, was officially announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- The tense situation on the frontiers of Abyssinia, British Somaliland and Italian Somaliland was the subject of a statement today by Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon in the House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- A recommendation that the Federal Government be permitted to limit arbitrarily the oil production of States is put forward in a comprehensive legislative program to conserve petroleum resources submitted privately by Secretary Ickes to the oil subcommittee of the House Interstate Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Army plans for industrial mobilization in time of war were taken up today by the Senate committee in a continuation of its inquiry into the operations of the munitions industry.

The Hotel Association of New York City announced yesterday that copies of a resolution assailing as unfair the operation on city tax-exempt property of "restaurants such as the Tavern on the Green in Central Park" had been sent to members of the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen.

The Terrace Contract Club's team of four won the Chicago Trophy of the American Bridge League at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night. The team, made up of H.S. Dinkelspiel, Bernard Rabinowitz, Lou Jaeger, Murray Seiler and W. Mason Lichtenstein, captured a thirty-two board play-off for the title by 17 1/2 matches to 14 1/2.

Art has made tremendous strides in industry in recent years, Alon Bement, executive director of the National Alliance of Art and Industry, declared last night at a dinner of the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street.

The Modern Library sends in some statistics on its sales. During the first eleven months of this year more than 1,000,000 of its books were sold, a larger total than for all twelve months of 1933. The greatest percentage gain was in the "Giant" series, but the pocket-size editions showed a marked increase also.

The Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, who will be 70 years old today, was the guest of 200 members of the Men's Club of the Central Congregational Church, of which he has been pastor for thirty-one years, at a birthday dinner in the church, Hancock Street near Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, last night.

In the spirit of artistic fraternity," which is the Beethoven Association's purpose in bringing together established artists for its concerts, Jascha Heifetz joined Edwin Bachmann, Nicolas Moldavan and Josef Schuster for an evening of chamber music at the Town Hall last night.

It should be as true today as it was when SHAKESPEARE wrote it, that the one who "hath a tear for pity" has also "a hand open as day for melting charity." More than 3,000 open hands have given to the Neediest so far this year, but that is not so many as on the corresponding day last year.

The bids of nine public utilities for the city's 1935 requirements for street lighting, and light, power and steam in public buildings were opened and rejected yesterday by Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

GENEVA, Dec. 17. -- Strong British pressure is being exerted to settle peacefully the Italo-Abyssinian dispute over an armed clash on the Somaliland border, according to information received today by League of Nations officials.

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Sir John Simon, British Foreign Secretary, disclaimed today any governmental responsibility for the volunteer police force in the Saar, one of whose British members was attacked by a mob at Saarbruecken yesterday.

Dr. Fred H. Albee, internationally known bone surgeon, will be reinstated to full membership in the Medical Society of the County of New York on Jan. 1, and all litigation in the case brought by Dr. Albee against the society has been dropped.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Al Watrous, Birmingham (Mich.) professional, turned in a par-breaking 65 today to lead the field practicing for the $5,000 British Colonial open golf tournament starting tomorrow, His 30 -- 35 clipped three strokes from perfect figures of 68.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Communist activities in this country are not now a menace to its institutions, but if unchecked will inevitably develop to a danger point, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, testified today before the House Committee on un-American Activities. His view was backed by other witnesses.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 17 (AP). -- Jockey L. Machado and Judge Primrose, 5-year-old gelding owned by W.C. Morris, proved a winning combination in the Lafayette purse, featured five-and-a-half-furlong dash at the Fair Grounds today.

Fordham and Columbia will meet for the first time under the new coaching regimes of Vinnie Cavanagh and Paul Mooney tonight when the Rams and the Lions clash at the Columbia gymnasium at 8:30. This game will mark the start of a week of important clashes involving local quintets.

The De Witt Clinton High School basketball team triumphed over the Erasmus Hall quintet, 23 to 14, on the victor's court yesterday. Joe Kaplowitz and Bill Lewis led the winners' attack with seven points apiece.
