PARIS, Dec. 19. -- The Bourse improved considerably today both in level of quotations and volume of trading. Opening hesitant, the whole list soon strengthened and closed not only at the best prices of the day but with appreciable gains over yesterday. Rentes led the way.

The third annual exhibition of early. American Genre Paintings, which opened yesterday at the Ehrich-Newhouse Galleries, is even better than its two predecessors. That is high praise. But not only is there greater variety of subject matter and a wider selection than in the other two shows: there has been an even more considered arrangement and use of contrast in the examples shown.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Twenty-four fireproof, unsinkable lifeboats, each with a carrying capacity of 145 and easily the largest ever constructed in Great Britain, are now being built for the liner Queen Mary.
The Princeton Club scored its third consecutive triumph in the Metropolitan League's Class C squash racquets play last night, vanquishing the Yale Club at the latter's courts by 5 to 0 in Group 1.

The story of how a New York game protector, combining a little pleasure with business, brought down a legal-sized buck with a revolver during the recent deer season was told yesterday by an official of the New York State Conservation Department.

There was no feature about the trading in the credit market except that of continued activity in commercial paper, where the demand for short date, prime name bills exceeds the supply. Prevailing discount of 3/4 was maintained. Business in Stock Exchange call loans, maturity money and acceptances was small.

UNIVERSITY, Ala., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Every member of Alabama's team that participated in the march of triumph through Dixie football today was designated to make the trip to the Rose Bowl. Thirty-five players were chosen.

An article written by your correspondent C.H. Calhoun in Panama, C.Z., and published in THE TIMES issue of Nov. 18 exposes various desires of the people of Panama for modifications in the Hay-Bunau Varilla treaty of Nov. 18, 1903.

One world's record was broken and another equaled last night at Columbia University's first annual water carnival in the Morningside pool. Peter Fick of the New York A.C., shattered the 75-yard free style mark for a 75-foot pool when he swam the distance in 0:37 1-5. Fick's mark clipped three-fifths of a second from the old mark.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 19. -- Professor Karl Barth, noted Swiss theologian of Bonn University, who will be tried for insubordination at Cologne tomorrow, has offered to swear the unamended civil service oath of fealty to Chancellor Hitler if the government would recognize the primacy of the Christian conscience over the Nazi totalitarian principle.

Free concerts engage the State Symphonic Band this afternoon at Brooklyn Museum and this evening at Julia Richman High School. The Greenwich Simfonietta plays at 4 P.M. at Columbia University and the Amsterdam Trio appears tonight at the Educational Alliance.
A driving rain swept by a southeast wind that reached a velocity of 42 miles an hour lashed the city yesterday, forcing pedestrians to seek shelter and causing an interruption of holiday shopping.

Our recovery from the depression seems to be steadily progressing. There are still, however, some handicaps to be overcome. The most serious one now is the smallness of our export trade, caused, largely, by the recent increase in wages under the NRA policy, which has so raised the prices of commodities that it is becoming increasingly difficult for them to compete successfully abroad.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- C. Lloyd Fisher issued a statement today in support of the contention of Edward J. Reilly, chief defense counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, that the Lindbergh case prisoner had been brutally beaten after his arrest in New York.

The Government's crop-reporting bureau estimated yesterday that, while this country's production of the "field crops" during 1934 decreased 22 per cent from 1933 in quantity, their market value increased 42 per cent. The bureau recognized that the corn and oats crops were the smallest since 1881, the wheat yield the smallest since 1894 and the rye harvest since 1872.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Dec. 19. -- Preparations for the New England Intercollegiate Model League of Nations committee in March at Holyoke College were begun this week at a meeting of the executive council of the league at Smith College.

SHELBYVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 19. -- The way a mob marched against bullets and bayonets in an effort to seize a Negro here today was described by Deputy Sheriff John E. Gant as "one of the most pitiful sights I ever saw."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- Prompt reorganization of the board of directors of the Philadelphia Orchestra Association was agreed upon tonight at a conference of more than three hours' duration, attended by members of the administration committee and Leopold Stokowski, who recently announced his resignation as conductor and music director.
THE visitor was well dressed and reserved but very direct in his approach.
The Kansas City Southern reported yesterday a decreased net operating income in November despite increased revenues. Its statement follows:

SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 19. -- A statement that "it is time the country woke up to the fact that the road we are traveling leads directly to progressive and uncontrolled inflation," was made by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury under President Hoover, in an address before the Century Club here tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Paul Robeson, American Negro actor and singer, will leave for Russia tomorrow to pass several weeks at the invitation of Sergei Eisenstein, noted Russian film producer.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 19. -- The report of the "Joint Conference for Business Recovery," issued here today, was as follows:

These are trying days for the utilities. At Washington the Federal Trade Commission is attacking them on one flank and the Federal Power Commission on the other, while the Tennessee Valley Authority continues its drive on their centre and the PWA harasses their rear with loans and grants to competing municipalities.

Directors of the Iowa Southern Utilities Company declared yesterday dividends of $1.75 on the 7 per cent preferred stock, $1.62 1/2 on the 6 1/2 per cent preferred and $1.50 on the 6 per cent preferred, all payable on Jan. 19, 1935, to holders of record of Dec. 31.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- The Boerse was irregular today, but showed a tendency toward recovery, the market being dominated by professional interests. The turnover, however, remained small. Heavy industrials were fractionally higher. Ilse Lignite gained 3 1/2 points, and other brown coals averaged 1 point higher.
The Columbia University Club's Class A squash tennis team is gradually making it harder and harder for its rivals to prevent it from winning the season's honors in the Metropolitan League.

DETROIT, Dec. 19. -- About 80 per cent of the eligible voters at the Cadillac Motor Car Company plant had cast their ballots at 8 P.M. tonight when the polls closed in the first official election held by the Automobile Labor Board for employe representation on the projected bargaining agency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Federal funds for construction of a power plant by New York City to supply electric current to municipal and Federal buildings and for other public purposes were tentatively promised to Mayor La Guardia today as he carried to the White House his controversy with public utilities.

The hope that Samuel Dewey Byrd, the young man from Birmingham, Ala., who is rated one of the best golfers in baseball, would some day fill the yawning gap in right field when Babe Ruth definitely steps down ended yesterday with the announcement that the Yankees had sold the outfielder outright to the Cincinnati Reds for cash.

The old maxim that "when men have "arrived at the goal they should not "turn back" has been splendidly observed by the Family Welfare Committee under the chairmanship of Mr. JAMES G. BLAINE. The total contributions in cash, pledges and other promises have exceeded by a million the minimum of $2,000,000 and are marching toward still another million.

The police would like the unidentified intoxicated man who, valuing his liquor more than his other property, belittled their aid in recovering $18 and a gold watch which was stolen from him by three hold-up men in Central Park early yesterday morning, to know that three arrests have been made in the case.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange failed yesterday to hold the gains made on Tuesday and finished irregularly lower. In the United States Government group, prices closed off 5-32 to up 4-32 point in quiet trading.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 19 (AP). -- S.T. Bledsoe, president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company, looks for an upward trend in business and agriculture in 1935, he said today in his annual survey of conditions in the road's area.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 19. -- Turning from his capture of the city of New Orleans to a new objective of political conquest, Senator Huey P. Long announced today plans to subjugate the parish of East Baton Rouge, a citadel of his foes, and make it the seat of his "imperial" government through legislative act.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Treasury figures showed today that gold held by the government on Dec. 17 totaled $8,195,367,244.33 on the basis of the price of $35 an ounce adopted when the dollar was devalued on Jan. 31, as compared with $4,034,000,000 just before devaluation, when holdings were calculated on the basis of $20.67 an ounce.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Dec. 19. -- The general situation in Croatia -- apart from the new government crisis -- tends to resume the aspect that it wore before the assassination of King Alexander.
SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Dec. 19. -- A Christmas truce to preserve tranquillity in the Saar over the holiday was declared today by the League of Nations' Plebiscite Commission.

CARMEL, Calif., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Under strange circumstances Mrs. Eliot Boke Schaffner, 36. Chicago matron, was missing here tonight. Sheriff Carl Abbott ordered an airplane search of the Monterey Bay vicinity after trained dogs had twice picked up her trail and followed the scent to the ocean beach.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A stop order of Oct. 30 against registration of the Haddam Distillers Corporation under the Securities Act of 1933 was continued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, although at its insistence property valuations had been so reduced that total assets were cut from $315,890 to $139,658.76.

Federal regulation of transportation lines operating in interstate trade was recommended yesterday in a report submitted to the directors of the Maritime Association by its committee on steamship affairs. The report was based on a study of legislation that was introduced at the last session at the suggestion of Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator of transportation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19. -- Five members of the Temple University football squad were absent from practice today because of illness as Coach Pop Warner prepared the team for the Sugar Bowl game with Tulane.
The Dartmouth College basketball teach tonight will begin its annual Christmas holiday tour which brings the Big Green quintet from New Hampshire to Connecticut and then to New York.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 (AP). -- Irene's Bob, 5-year-old gelding, running in the silks of Mrs. E.B. Shipp, chalked up his third straight victory today when he scored easily in the Mandeville Handicap for all ages at the Fair Grounds.

The sports writer was hailed as the greatest contributor to the up-building of modern American youth yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, former Police Commissioner, speaking at the reopening ceremonies of the Catholic Boys Club of the Bronx, 290 East 153d Street.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The stock market was quiet today, with pre-holiday profit-taking in evidence, but the general tone Was good and there were some bright features. There was renewed demand for British funds. Outstanding in the foreign section of the market was recovery in Brazilian issues.

The Neil H. Swansons (Mr. Swanson, a Baltimore newspaper executive, wrote "The Judas Tree" and "The Phantom Emperor") are back from South America with notes for future Stories. They report 200 or more filing cards covered with scribbling that they may or may not be able to read and more than 300 photographs.

PARIS, Dec. 19. -- The difficulties of the Citroen Company are approaching a climax and it is learned the company has filed an application with the Tirbunal of Commerce, which is expected to be heard tomorrow.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- A hockey stick once used by the Princeton player, Hobart A.H. Baker, who was killed in the World War, has been 'established as a unique perpetual trophy to be contested for annually by the St. Paul's School and Princeton freshman hockey teams.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- The Marquess of Londonderry, British Secretary for Air, paid a generous tribute to American aviation at tonight's Royal Aero Club dinner welcoming home C.W. Scott and T. Campbell Black, winners of the air race to Australia.
Mr. and Mrs. William J. Elias gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza for Mme. Pierre Colombier of Paris. The other guests included:

The Flanagan-Nay Brewing Corporation, which obtained a license in June of 1933 to take over the old Phoenix Brewery, a violator of the prohibition law, filed a petition in Federal court yesterday for permission to reorganize under Section 77B of the Bankruptcy Act.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 19. -- The crowd at Tropical Park got more than its share of thrills today as tight finishes developed in each of the seven races on the program.

HAMBURG, Dec. 19. -- The Hamburg-American liner New York, which rescued the crew of the sinking Norwegian freighter Sisto in a storm on the Atlantic last night, will receive a festive reception when it makes port here late Friday or early Saturday.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced slightly yesterday as daily trade demand disclosed a limited supply of contracts and the list ended unchanged to 8 points higher than on Tuesday. Following an easier tone in the spot month earlier in the week.

A score of Manhattan properties went under auctioneers' hammers yesterday. Included in the list of forced sale offerings were several large holdings, such as two office buildings in Fifth Avenue and a nine-story apartment building in East Ninety-third Street.

Prejudice against attorneys at law, strong in all the American Colonies in the seventeenth century and lingering far into the eighteenth, would naturally be extreme in the Puritan settlements, where "Moses His Judicials" was the supreme textbook of law. In "Revolutionary New England" (1923) Mr. J.T. ADAMS writes that "in Connecticut "in 1698 they [lawyers] were legis- "lated against in company with drunk- "ards, keepers of disorderly houses and "other people of ill fame."

A recent item in THE TIMES relating to the postmastership examination for New York City showing that only seventeen persons had made application for the office, brings forcefully to light the farcical arrangement under which postmasterships are filled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- A request of the Erie Railroad for a three-year RFC loan of $3,179,000 to meet a like amount of taxes, equipment trust obligations and sinking fund payments during December, January and February was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

General Alberto Herrera, member of the Cuban Cabinet during President Gerardo Machado's regime, was arrested yesterday at the French Hospital, where he had been a patient since Friday, on an extradition warrant issued here last May at the request of the Cuban Consul General.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- A blunt answer to the question, "What's the matter with Cornell football" coming rather frequently of late, it seems, from certain "enraged groups," has been sent to graduates of the university throughout the world through the medium of the latest issue of The Cornell Alumni News.

A meeting of stockholders of Translux Daylight Picture Screen Corporation was adjourned yesterday until 3 P.M. tomorrow to permit counting of votes in the proxy contest for control of the company. Before the adjournment both the stockholders' committee, which is seeking to change the present management, and Leavitt G. Hunt, counsel for the management, claimed sufficient votes to control the meeting.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Following is the text of the communique issued mament conversations:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Hearings on the petition of thirty-one cotton garment manufacturers for a permanent injunction to restrain enforcement of wages and hours provisions of the NRA Code for the cotton garment industry closed in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today with a plea to Justice Jesse C. Adkins by counsel for the government that he hasten a ruling.

All except about $6,000,000 of the $40,000,000 issue of New York City 3 3/4 and 4 per cent long-term serial bonds, offered yesterday by a syndicate headed by the National City Bank, have been sold out of syndicate account, the bankers reported at the close of business yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- An intensive campaign to enforce the President's executive order which makes illegal the discharge of employes for reporting hour and wage violations of codes, is under way, the 'NRA compliance and enforcement director, Sol A. Rosenblatt, made known today.

No legislation is needed for the rehabilitation of the mortgage situation in this State, according to Richard M. Hurd, chairman of the board of the Lawyers Mortgage Corporation, who was questioned yesterday by a joint legislative committee at the Bar Association.

With almost $29,000 deposited in five banks in Union City, Miss Margaret Enders, 51 years old, and her brother, Michael Enders, 62, received emergency relief from the Union City Charity Department. When arraigned before Recorder A. Michael Lepore yesterday on charges of fraud they explained that despite their small fortune they were afraid of insecurity in old age.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area of New York, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, showed the largest gain over a year ago in the first half of this month to be registered in several years. There was a sizeable gain in the first half of last March but the comparison was made with the period of the bank holiday.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 19. -- Huey Long looked in all directions today for some one to fill the shoes of Captain Lawrence (Biff) Jones, who resigned last night as head football coach at Louisiana State University after a dispute with the Louisiana dictator.

On any list of this theatrical season's important events would be Katharine Cornell's first New York appearance tonight as Juliet. She presents the Shakespearean play in her own arrangement at the Martin Beck Theatre, with Basil Rathbone as Romeo, Edith Evans as the Nurse, Brian Aherne as Mercutio and Charles Waldron as Friar Laurence.

Newark Airport, it was indicated yesterday, would continue to be the Eastern air-mail terminal for many months, perhaps for years. Moreover TWA, Inc., which flies the mail between New York and Los Angeles and which Mayor La Guardia recently announced had agreed to remove to New York's municipal field in South Brooklyn, expects to continue at Newark for the present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- If the United States is again drawn into war, a system now being worked out contemplates a machine which, so far as mobilization of man power, material resources and finances are concerned, will be ready to "start from scratch," Colonel T.C. Harris, director of mobilization plans in the War Department, today told the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry.

The projected Jewish republic in Biro-Bidjan, Russia, constitutes no menace to the Zionist movement, E.Z. Goldberg, associate editor of The Day, who recently returned from the Soviet, declared yesterday. He was interviewed at 285 Madison Avenue, the office of the American Committee for the Settlement of Jews in the U.S.S.R., of which he is a member.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 19. -- Returning to basketball competition after a fine season on the gridiron, Hugh MacMillan led Princeton's varsity basketball team to a 25-18 victory over the Harvard team in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game in Harvard's indoor athletic building tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The Federal Reserve Banks will press their efforts to promote advances to industries under the Loans to Industry Act, despite the fact that a Treasury committee headed by Dr. Jacob Viner has recommended that this work be concentrated in the future in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation or a new government agency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The doctor says President Roosevelt is in better physical shape than at any time since entering the White House, and is ready for the Congressional session ahead.

Commodity futures contracts were generally lower on the local Exchanges yesterday in quiet trading. In the cash market all the grains. tin and silk were lower, while cocoa, butter and hides were higher.
WUHU, Anhwei Province, China. Dec. 19. -- Helen Priscilla Stare, 3 months old and an orphan, ate and slept contentedly today in the Wuhu General Hospital.

Albert H. Fish, confessed kidnapper and murderer of Grace Budd, it developed yesterday, was about to fall into a net spread for him by postoffice operatives when the city police stepped in last Friday and captured him.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee, which has been engaged since Nov. 19 in an effort to raise funds to help recognized family agencies meet the relief demands upon them this Winter, has exceeded its minimum goal by more than $1,000,000.

James O'Neill of the Actors' Equity Association, who has been a trouper for more than forty years, has a two-a-gay pigeon-feeding act that would be a success on any circuit. The setting is the sidewalk in front of the association's offices at 45 West Forty-seventh Street.

BERLIN, Dec. 19. -- Despite the general armament race and other not exactly Christmas-like developments in Europe, Germany is buoyed up by the hope of bringing France to direct negotiations with herself after all, thereby obtaining more elbow room than was left her in her present isolation.

Slow to hit its stride but moving fast in the closing stages, the Manhattan basketball team experienced little difficulty in overwhelming Cooper Union, 34 to 13, at the Manhattan gymnasium last night.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

Following is the text of a letter sent by W. Kingsland Macy, then Republican State Chairman, to George B. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company, asking lot a contribution to help pay off the party's indebtedness. It was introduced yesterday at the hearing of the utility investigating committee:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- With an increase of $68,977.503 in income tax receipts for the first five months of the present fiscal year to Nov. 30, over the total for the same period last year, a report of the Internal Revenue Bureau today gave evidence of a general advance of recovery throughout the country.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- A holiday market prevailed today in grains on the Board of Trade and prices averaged lower. Scattered liquidation in wheat attributed to Eastern Interests disclosed a lack of aggressive support and weakened all quotations.

A "purging" of the Friends of the New Germany through the expulsion of insurgent members and their leader, Anton Haegele, was decided upon last night at a four-hour meeting in the New Yorker Turnhalle, Lexington Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, attended by about 1,000.

With only five days remaining before Christmas -- the day of all the year when men most wish for peace on earth and good-will toward their fellow men -- the Fund for the Neediest Cases is $14,814.10 behind the total on this date a year ago.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- An improvement in tax collections for 1934 is indicated in a statement of current finances of municipalities issued today by Walter R. Darby, State Commissioner of Municipal Finance. The statement includes collections up to last Sept. 30 and shows that 48 per cent has been collected.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 19. -- Forging to the front as the wave of sub-par golf subsided. Jack Thompson of Youngstown, Ohio, today took a two-stroke lead over the field at the half-way mark of the $5,000 British Colonial open tournament with a thirty-six-hole score of 132.

Theatricalism of the motor-cycle-escort variety, red-baiting and political favoritism were declared to be "out," as far as the present city administration is concerned, by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday. The commissioner, speaking at a luncheon of the Broadway Cheese Club in the Friars Club at 1,657 Broadway, added that his statements were not meant to reflect on previous commissioners.

A prediction that the Spring of 1935 will bring an upturn in building activity, concentrated chiefly in alterations, was made yesterday by Kenneth M. Murchison, formerly an architect, and now vice president of the Central Savings Bank.

Charges of mismanagement and inefficiency in the administration of unemployment relief, coupled with the accusation that the officials responsible were trying to "cover up" defects were made yesterday by Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen and chairman of the Aldermen's committee investigating relief.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- All interests were in the market today for hogs and prices advanced 10 to 25 cents a hundredweight. The top was $6.40, the highest since Oct. 9. Light weights led the upturn. A further falling off in receipts in the West had some effect on the market, as did the forecast for colder weather.

Steel operations have risen 2 1/2 points this week to 35 1/2 per cent of ingot capacity, according to The Iron Age, which emphasizes that the "approach of the holidays has failed to halt the dual advance of production and scrap prices, which has now lasted for nine consecutive weeks."

The selection of Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean, spectacular righthanded pitcher of the world's champion St. Louis Cardinals, as the outstanding athlete of the year, in any sport, gives the game of baseball and the State of Oklahoma something resembling a monopoly of honors in the four-year record of The Associated Press sports poll.
The following statement was issued to the press last night by Bernard M. Baruch:

Only fifteen theatre ticket agencies in this city were designated last night by the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority as having qualified to do business, beginning today, under the provisions of the revised Legitimate Theatre Code. Yesterday was the final day on which brokers could apply for certificates to do business under the new code while maintaining their privileges under the old licensing provisions.

The co-guardians of 10-year-old Gloria Vanderbilt told Surrogate James A. Foley yesterday that they had been informed that Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney would bear all the expenses of the child's upbringing and education as long as the girl was in her custody.
LONDON, Dec. 19. -- In his radio broadcast tonight Sir John Simon expressed the "firm hope" that the naval conversations might be resumed "in two or three months' time."

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- About 500 Princeton students voted against the NRA and indicated their approval of a more closely integrated international system, it is shown by a campus questionnaire sponsored by The Nassau Literary Magazine, the results of which were announced today by Minor C. Morgan Jr., '35, of Greenwich, Conn., chairman of the magazine.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- Jay Berwanger, the University of Chicago's one-man football and track team, is the outstanding athlete of the Big Ten for 1934. The 19-year-old star from Dubuque, Iowa, won the honor with votes to spare in the second annual poll conducted by The Associated Press.

Amendments to the city's 2 per cent sales tax measure were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly with the likelihood that concurrent action would be taken by the Board of Aldermen today.

The preference given by the State Labor Law to residents and voters of the State in the award of jobs in public construction work was up held as constitutional yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore Cotillo in dismissing a suit brought by seventy-six members of the Dock and Pier Carpenters Union of Greater New York.

PLANDOME, L.I., Dec. 19. -- Martin W. Littleton Sr., prominent New York lawyer, a former Representative in Congress and former Borough President of Brooklyn, died at his home here tonight after an illness of about a week. He was in his sixty-third year.

Arguments for municipal power plants, to serve as "yardsticks" for electric rates in big cities, were presented yesterday to the legislative committee investigating public utilities, at the second hearing held in the County Court House on Foley Square.

TRENTON, Dec. 19. -- About thirty public schools in New Jersey were closed today because of the spread of grip and influenza, particularly among pupils in the southern counties. Dr. Charles H. Elliott, State Education Commissioner, informed school superintendents of all counties to use their judgment whether to close schools tomorrow instead of Friday, depending on conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Official, diplomatic and resident society turned out in full force today to welcome and applaud Miss Kathryn Meisle, contralto, and Richard Crooks, tenor, both of the Metropolitan Opera Association, at the opening concert of the series given annually under the direction of Mrs. Lawrence Townsend at the Mayflower Hotel.
The list of the Italian liner Vulcania, due today from Mediterranean ports, includes:

GENEVA, Dec. 19. -- Foreign Minister Hercui of Abyssinia answered Italy's note today by strongly maintaining his stand on every point and making Great Britain's position in the dispute even more important by citing her representative in Abyssinia's support.
QUEBEC, Dec. 19. -- Newsprint men and government heads conferred this afternoon, but failed to reach an agreement on the question of newsprint prices.

BOSTON, Dec. 19. -- Asserting that the "destructive influence of outside agitators" had caused such repeated labor troubles, accompanied by intimidation and violence, that successful operation was no longer possible, the directors of the Hamilton Woolen Company, Inc., of Southbridge, Mass., voted today to liquidate the company.
Duncan MacInnes, veteran chief accountant of the Department of Finance, will be named first deputy controller on Jan. 1, Controller-elect Frank J. Taylor announced yesterday.

The resignation of Robert T. Paine, for forty years a director of the General Electric Company, was announced yesterday by Gerard Swope, president. Mr. Paine was elected a director in 1894, two years after the company's formation and in its worst business year. He resigned because of ill health.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19. -- Dr. William H.S. Demarest, president of the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, announced today he would resign Dec. 31, after holding the office exactly ten years. The seminary's board of directors, in accepting the resignation, elected Dr. Demarest president emeritus. He is 71 years old.

CHARLES TOWN, W. Va., Dec. 19. -- Worthington carried the silks of Miss Rhoda Christmas to an easy two-length victory in the featured Parkersburg Purse at the Charles Town track today. Dona Dulcin was second and Postponement third in a field of six.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Unemployment insurance, which has won a definite place on the agenda of Congress, belongs to the reform -- as contrasted with the recovery -- section of the New Deal. The purpose behind it is to prevent the recurrence of some of the evils of the depression.

TULSA, Okla., Dec. 19 (AP). -- The third Tulsa youth to dies from violence in three weeks, Carl Pulliam, 17, was shot to death today in a vacant house where police said several boys were flourishing pistols.

Following closely upon the sale of its 237-year-old holding comprising a Hudson Street blockfront, the Trinity Church Corporation yesterday figured as the buyer of a large property in the Holland Tunnel Plaza section. The corporation has extended its realty holdings in the area with the purchase of the fourteen-story commercial and industrial building at 145 Hudson Street from the Park-Colony Corporation.
With Captain Sidney Gross and Willie Rubenstein in excellent form, the New York University basketball team had little trouble defeating its first intercollegiate opponent, Lafayette, last night.

Charles J. Lynn of Indianapolis was elected chairman of the executive committee of the Drug Institute of America, Inc., to replace Dr. William E. Weiss, at the annual meeting at the headquarters here yesterday. Albert C. Fritz, also of Indianapolis, was chosen vice chairman.

PARIS, Dec. 19. -- French foreign trade figures for November, issued today, show a slight improvement in exports over October, while imports held their own. However, in comparison with November, 1933, and taking the first eleven months of 1934 as a whole, the figures show a heavy slump and indicate the severe strain to which high prices and world monetary disorder are subjecting France.

A walk in early twilight of a December afternoon, on Fifth Avenue north of the Park Plaza, was tinglingly cold and exhilarating. Seen across the Winter aspect of the park, to the south, the clear bluish-pearl sky above the city lights, just flashing into their night array, was gemmed with the first faint stars.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 19. -- TWO hundred and two Princeton students have been awarded athletic insignia for their work in varsity and freshman Fall sports, it was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Prime Minister J. Ramsay MacDonald told the House of Commons at question time today that while he did not think any Minister held shares in companies that are arms contractors to the government, he would consider whether such practice is undesirable if the question is asked again later.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 19. -- Fire of undetermined cause destroyed three small frame buildings at Harbor Hill, the estate of Clarence H. Mackay, at 4 o'clock this morning. Mr. Mackey and his wife, the former Anna Case, have been occupying a Colonial cottage on the estate rather than the large mansion at the hilltop, but they were not at home at the time.

SNOW HILL ISLAND, Weddell Sea, Dec. 19. -- At last my airplane, the Polar Star, has flown above the Weddell Sea and a successful trial has been made. It is just sixty days since she was first landed on this side of the Antarctic and with one or two exceptions during these two months there has not been a period of six hours of cloudless sky within our vision.

GENEVA, Dec. 19. -- League of Nations quarters attach much importance to Washington reports that the State Department favors authorizing the President in certain cases to drop neutral rights and proclaim American ships enter a blockaded zone at their own risk.

EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 19 (AP). -- Twenty-two Eastern college football stars reported to co-coaches Andy, Kerr of Colgate and Dick Hanley who recently resigned his position at Northwestern, for uniforms today and then entrained for the Pacific Coast, where they will meet the Western All-Stars in the annual charity game New Year's Day.

BELGRADE, Dec. 19. -- Boske Jeftitch accepted at noon today a mandate from Prince Paul, head of the regency, to form a new Cabinet on a broad national basis. In the afternoon M. Jeftitch received Milan Stokadinovitch and Dr. Milititch, former Ministers of the Serbian Radical party in parliamentary days, and Father Anton Koroschetz, Slovene leader.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The contention that plans prepared by the War Department for use in the event of war would give the government "absolute control" of the press was advanced before the Senate Munitions Committee today by Senator Clark.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Continuing its activities on a restricted basis, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in November authorized $195,752,908.01 in new loans and commitments, of which $110,000,000 represented an advance made to the Federal Emergency Relief Administration.

The city and county of San Francisco, Calif., announced yesterday that it would be in the market on Jan. 7 with a new issue of $1,050.000 of 4 per cent bonds. The issue will be dated as of Dec. 1, 1933, and due serially from 1935 to 1963.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 20. -Mrs. Henry Clinton Hood was a tea hostess today at her residence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Efforts to avoid a naval building race after the Washington and London naval treaties terminate on Dec. 31, 1936, are expected to centre on auxiliary rather than capital ships, as in the latter category the issue does not promise to become acute for several more years.

So wordy became an argument between Magistrate Overton Harris and three lawyers for fourteen persons arrested for mass picketing at S. Klein's garment store, 6 Union Square, that the case was adjourned in Yorkville Court yesterday when the court stenographer announced he was too tired to go on.

Mrs. James Danahy, wife of the managing director of the West Side Association, was discovered dead in the street in front of their apartment at 305 West Forty-fifth Street. after a six-story fall from the roof where she had gone to smoke a cigarette early yesterday morning after a restless night.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Mrs. Mary Colucci, 43 years old, who is being tried in General Sessions for the slaying of her husband, Joseph, last June 12 in a Third Avenue elevated train at the Ninth Street station, told her story of the shooting yesterday to Judge Koenig and the jury.

COLOGNE, Germany, Dec. 20. -A disciplinary court after a fourhour secret session today directed the government to expel Dr. Karl Berth, noted Protestant theologian, from his professorship at Bonn University.

UNIVERSITY, Ala., Dec. 20 (AP). -- Alabama's eleven ended two weeks of hard work today with a scrimmage that lasted until dusk. Tomorrow the Crimson Tide will start its fourth invasion of the Rose Bowl.

A spirited exchange of words between Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals, enlivened a hearing in City Hall yesterday before the Mayor's Committee on City Planning at which the prolonged controversy was aired over which commissioner shall obtain the thirty-five-acre tract on Welfare Island, to be vacated next year by the Department of Correction.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 20. -Bobby Cruickshank of Richmond, Va., came back to win the $5,000 British Colonial open golf tournament today with a score of 267 after being 5 down to Tony Butler at the turn on the final round.

Despite the reluctance of Eastern college athletic leaders yesterday to discuss publicly Cornell University's blunt, though unofficial challenge to the "hire and fire" system of conducting the varsity football business, it is known that the subject is under more serious consideration now than at any time since the Carnegie Foundation delivered its blast against the subsidizing and recruiting of athletes five years ago.

According to the abstracts of the report of the Carnegie Corporation contained in THE TIMES, unfavorable comments are made concerning the function and efficiency of the small college in our educational scheme.

The Princeton freshman hockey team and the St. Paul's School sextet of Concord, N.H., will meet in their annual game at Madison Square Garden this afternoon. The net proceeds of the encounter, which will start at 3:30 o'clock, will be donated to the two charities conducted by St. Paul's -- the Coit House, an orphanage, and the Summer camp for boys.

Francis Hackett has finished inserting 10,000 words into the galley proofs of his new biography, "Francis the First," Doubleday, Doran report. He took several years to write the book and was well enough pleased with the manuscript when he turned it in last Summer.

Six hundred East Side boys, between the ages of 6 and 12, cheered wildly when Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt took the stage at their annual Christmas party yesterday afternoon in the Tompkins Square clubhouse of the Boys Club of New York, at Avenue A and Tenth Street.

Bank clearings in the twenty-two leading cities throughout the United States for the week ended on Wednesday amounted tO $6,160,688,000, the highest figure for any week in nearly three years, and an increase of 32.5 per cent over the $4,650,696,000 reported in the corresponding week of 1933, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 20. -Youthful Emory Zimmerman today shattered par by two strokes with a 69 to lead the field of first-round qualifiers for the Pasadena $4,000 open golf championship.

A report that Soviet Russia has changed her buying policy and in the future will refuse to deal extensively with any country where interest or other charges on longterm credits exceed the rates charged to other buyers caused widespread discussion among exporters here yesterday.

ROME, Dec. 20. -- Prince Jaime, second son of former King Alfonso of Spain, who relinquished his claim to the fallen Spanish throne because he is a deaf mute, has won the hand of an Italian noblewoman, it was disclosed today.

BAGHDAD, Friday, Dec. 21. -- Airplanes of three nations, including twenty-four British military machines, are starting at dawn from various points in Transjordan to search the Syrian Desert for the famed Douglas airliner Univers, known as the "flying hotel," which finished second in the recent England-to-Melbourne air race.

After a four-hour conference with holders of December short and long sugar contracts, the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange announced last night that it would not make public its course of action in the present technical "corner" until this morning at 9:50 o'clock.

To "so affrighted" Ophelia, Hamlet's hatlessness was one of the signs of his madness. Times and indicia change. For some years the bareheaded brigade has been a familiar sight in the streets. Thumping fuller pockets, the happy hatters say that it is dwindling.

While the Fire Department and the National Association of Commercial Organization Secretaries were issuing warnings yesterday of the hazards caused by the use of lighted candles on Christmas trees, it was disclosed by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt that the President, personally, prefers candles to electricity.

The Harvard Club team improved its grip on first place in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association race for Class A teams yesterday when it defeated the Princeton Club, 3 to 2, on its home courts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 19, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,471,000,000, an increase of $9,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $216,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

Joseph Milner, real estate broker and adviser to the New York Housing Authority, and Joseph P. Day, real estate auctioneer, engaged in an informal debate yesterday at a luncheon at the Town Hall Club attended by about 100 members of the apartment house group of the Real Estate Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Calling upon corporations to make public detailed information on their capital structures and operations which is expected to supply all pertinent data to the investing public, the necessary forms and rules for permanent registration of securities on the country's Stock Exchanges under the Securities Act of 1934 were issued today.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Abolition of December as a contract month in wheat futures trading on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange is proposed by John I. McFarland, head of the Canadian Government wheat agency and general manager of the Canadian wheat pools, in a statement alleging excessive charges at terminal elevators at the lake head.

James J. McCormick, former Deputy City Clerk in the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building and up to 1933, for twentytwo years Tammany leader of the Twenty-second Assembly District in West Harlem, was released on a suspended sentence in General Sessions yesterday on his plea of guilty to an extortion indictment.

United States Senator Warren R. Austin of Vermont charged that the New Deal discriminated against New England for the benefit of other sections of the country in an address at the annual dinner of the New England Society in the City of New York at the Hotel Plaza last night.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 20 (AP). -Woodruff Randolph, secretary of the International Typographical Union, stated tonight that 781 locals of the organization would be affected by a referendum decision, effective Jan. 1, to prohibit subordinate unions from making a work contract in excess of forty hours a week.
Activity in the credit market was confined to commercial paper, other sections ruling quiet and rates unchanged for all classes of accommodation.

The public bequests made in the will of Frank Lusk Babbott, Brooklyn philanthropist and art patron, amounted to $3,478,476, according to a report filed in Brooklyn yesterday by David F. Soden, transfer appraiser.

A national freight-car pool, which, it has been estimated would save the railroads $100,000,000 annually, is nearing completion, J. J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, said yesterday, The association's executive committee spent all yesterday in discussing the pool and will present methods for establishing it at a meeting of the full board today.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 20. -Leslie Howard delighted an audience that filled Parsons Theatre here tonight at the world premiere of Robert E. Sherwood's latest play, "The Petrified Forest," presented by Gilbert Miller and Mr. Howard in association with Arthur Hopkins, who was responsible for the staging.

The directors of the National Lead Company declared yesterday a dividend of fourteen shares of common stock for every 100 shares held. The dividend represents treasury stock acquired in the open market in the last few years. It will be paid on Jan. 15 to stock of record of Dec. 31.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A World War profit of more than $250,000,000 by the du Pont Powder Company, after expenses and taxes had been deducted, was detailed today before the munitions committee.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- An indication that the lessons of the EnglandAustralia air race are bearing fruit is seen in an announcement in the House of Commons today by Sir Philip Sassoon, Under-Secretary for Air, of a far-reaching scheme for the development of the British Empire air services.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- As the time for the President's budget message approaches, some members of Congress have been restudying the old proposal that Congress once more take over the purse strings of the nation, as envisaged in the Constitution. These members do not expect any early move in that direction.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- An official communique to which a big display was given in the German press this morning announces that the conversations between German and French front fighters, upon which the Germans are now pinning their hopes for separate direct negotiations with France, continued here today.

RENO, Nev., Dec. 20. -- A divorce was granted here today to Mrs. Katherine Swift Warburg from James Paul Warburg, banker, adviser to the United States at the London economic conference and song writer. The charge was cruelty.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- The critical situation in the large French automobile company, the Citroen Corporation, which has filed a demand for liquidation, was the subject of active negotiations between the government and industrial and banking circles throughout the day without definite action being taken.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) Henry Ford says his unsuccessful "peace-ship" venture in 1915 taught him something "that most of the world is just now finding out -- that war was a profit-making business."

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday just about matched, in volume, those of the previous day. All markets were more or less irregular in their price movements. The averages for stocks were some cents higher at the close; the bond market index was a trifle lower.

E. S. S. Carroll won the Harry Cline Memorial Class B 18.2 balkline tourney, defeating Joseph R. Johann, 200 to 111, in 25 innings, as the competition was concluded last night at the Amateur Billiard Club. Carroll's high run was 41 and Johann's 27.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20. -- Coming within three-fifths of a second of the track record, Cary T. Grayson's Hope to Do covered the five and a half furlong distance of the featured Coconut Grove Purse in 1:04 3-5 to score at Tropical park today.
LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Word has been received here that Gregory Zinovieff and Lev Kameneff, who were once high in Soviet councils, have been arrested by the Moscow government.

A painting by Rembrandt, "Christ Washing the Feet of His Disciples," one of the few group scenes by the great Dutch master in this country, has been bought by the Institute of Chicago, through its Robert Alexander Waller Memorial Fund, from the E. A. Silberman Galleries, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

SHELBYVILLE, Tenn. Dec. 20. -Shelbyville citizens today began formation of a vigilante committee to protect their town from further disorder after the withdrawal of 600 National Guardsmen sent here to prevent further riots as the result of thwarted attempts to lynch E. K. Harris, a negro accused of attacking a white girl.

As editor of a magazine that has published about a dozen exposes of the arms traffic during the past four years and that helped to pave the way for the Nye investigation, may I point out a vital omission in the President's proposal to take the profit out of war and in your own editorial "War Profits"?

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- Justice Bleakley in Supreme Court here denied today an application by Gordon Weil for a writ of mandamus compelling the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board to issue a license for Weil's liquor store here even though Weil had a connecting door, in violation of the board's regulations, between his liquor shop and his furniture store adjoining.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP). -The Federal Trade Commission was told today that the Cities Service Power and Light Company, a Henry L. Doherty interest, recorded the sale of a subsidiary's property in such a manner that the profit of more than a million dollars was not subject to Federal income tax.

Representatives of Eastern seaboard ports conferred yesterday at the offices of the Merchants Association here on the freight-rate situation, which, it is feared, will cause diversion of Middle Western import and export freight to Southern harbors. Most of this movement now is through Atlantic coast terminals.

The City Emergency Relief Bureau, of which Commissioner William Hodson of the Department of Public Welfare is chariman, struck back yesterday at critics of the administration of relief in New York, including the Aldermen's inquiry committee, headed by Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- American business leaders tonight were determined to proceed with development of their program for economic recovery despite a shower of criticism by Washington and other officials.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20. -- Great Britain and Argentina have appointed an international mixed commision to investigate the meat packing business. The investigation will include the activities of four American-owned companies in Argentina -- Armour, Swift, Wilson and La Blanca.

One publishing firm says that it has sold in the course of two years no less than 20,000 copies of GIBBON'S "Decline and Fall." This must be only a part of the total distribution. There are other publishers, and GIBBON, like MACAULAY and other classic historians, circulates largely in second-hand editions going back half a century and more.

Total contributions of $353,173.75 to the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Fund were announced yesterday at the final report luncheon of the campaign workers held at the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Administration Building, 99 Park Avenue. The campaign goal was $550,000.

Sweetness and good-will spread like a mantle over the deliberations of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, leading the members to exchange compliments, forgive old scores and paint a rosy future for themselves as they ended their sessions for the year.

The National Board of Review made public yesterday its selection of the ten best American-made motion pictures of this year, the five best foreign films and another list of ten films chosen for "outstanding entertainment qualities." The latter were chosen by vote of the board's review committee, numbering more than 300 persons.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- A bandit gang armed with shotguns held up a branch office of the Philadelphia Electric Company, Twenty-third and Market Streets, this morning and escaped with about $48,500 in cash.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP). -Brass Buttons, a 3-year-old filly by Light Brigade -- Torpedo, racing in the colors of B. Hernandez and ridden by Jockey L. Turner, scored her second straight victory of the Fair Grounds meeting today.

A check for $80,000 representing contributions made by city employes to the relief fund of the Citizens Family Welfare Committee will be presented at City Hall this morning by Mayor La Guardia to James G. Blaine, chairman of the committee.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Detroit battled to an overtime 1-1 tie with the Montreal Maroons in a fast, well-played National Hockey League match tonight.

Dr. Willis R. Whitney, organizer of the research laboratory of the General Electric Company at Schenectady and former president of the American Chemical Society, will receive the Edison Medal for 1934 of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, it was announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Dec. 20. -- The agenda of the League Council's session opening Jan. 11, under the presidency of Tewfik Rushdi Bey, Turkish Foreign Minister, was published today. It includes twenty-seven items.

At a hearing yesterday before Special Master James G. Moore in the Federal Building in Brooklyn plans for reorganization of the Seneca issue of $930,000 put out by the Prudence-Bonds Corporation were presented to more than 400 persons holding participation certificates by Frederick J. Powell, attorney for the corporation.

In the question of socialized medicine, two sides are vociferous: the laymen, reformers at heart, who wish to change existing methods, and a certain class of physicians. The people, who must pay for this, who will have this plan worked on them, are silent.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- With AngloAmerican cooperation directed toward a policy of world arbitration, peace is assured, Sir Norman Angell, Nobel Peace Prize winner, told the American Chamber of Commerce today.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Dec. 20 (AP). -- Unless an unknown youngster breaks into the circle of winners, it looks as if veterans again will battle for the Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championship here New Year's Day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Many Governors, noting the suggestion by the business men's conference that the relief burden should be returned to the States, said the time for that has not yet arrived. Some assailed the proposal. Governor Bryan of Nebraska called it "unfair and unpatriotic."
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 21 (AP). -Emperor Hirohito today affixed the imperial seal to the documents concerning Japanese termination of the Washington Naval Treaty.

Miss Virginia Van Wie's all-conquering march through the golfing year, including her third successive women's national title, yesterday brought her the added distinction of being voted 1934's outstanding feminine sports star.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A virtual ultimatum was given by President Roosevelt today to the two major telegraph companies to accept the code for their industry which has been pending for more than a year or present one of their own.

J. LESLIE MITCHELL, who has written the life stories of nine of the great explorers in "Earth Conquerors" (Simon Schuster, $3.50), is himself, if not exactly a conqueror, at least one of the few living romantics who never feels at home without a passport in his pocket. When he is not traveling in Persia or Iraq, he sinks into the pseudonym of Lewis Grassic Gibbon and writes novels in his native Scots dialect.

The city's credit is looking up again. With the end of his term of office less than two weeks away, Controller MCGOLDRICK has just successfully negotiated the sale of $42,900,000 in serial bonds at a net interest cost of less than 4 per cent. All things considered, that is a satisfactory and even gratifying rate.

An active day in the wholesale dry goods district and the largest exports in several weeks strengthened prices on the Cotton Exchange again yesterday. While pre-noticeday liquidation in January contracts supplied demand for near deliveries, both May and July rose above 12.60 cents a pound and the closing quotations were 3 points lower to 3 points higher on the day.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 20. -- The Silver Jubilee Winter Carnival, marking a quarter of a century of Winter sport fetes at Dartmouth College, will be held Feb. 8 and 9, the Dartmouth Outing Club announced today.

Albert H. Fish, 65-year-old house painter held for the murder of Grace Budd in 1928, was picked from a line-up in the Tombs yesterday as the man seen in the company of a child resembling William Gaffney on the day the boy disappeared from his home in Brooklyn.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Dec. 20 (AP). -- Major Gen. John E. S. Brind, British commander-in-chief of the League of Nations military forces that are to guard the Saar for the coming plebiscite, opened general headquarters today in a two-story villa on the Saar River from which all operations of the troops will be directed.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 20 (AP). -- Huey P. Long tonight had tightened his dictatorial reins over Louisiana by grasping, through a submissive Legislature, power to displace elected municipal officials, levy a general manufacturers' tax and select the State's 15,000 school teachers.

LONDON, Friday, Dec. 21. -- The Daily Express today carried a dispatch from its Moscow corespondent saying Gregory Zinovieff and Lev Kameneff, another former leader of the Communist International, were arrested at the Kremlin gates yesterday and placed under "house arrest."

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The probability that if the Saar votes to return to Germany France will immediately clap down heavy quotas and tariffs upon Saar products was fore-shadowed in a measure adopted by the Chamber of Deputies today. It prolongs the special powers voted to the Doumergue government by which quotas and tariff regulations may be imposed by decree until February.

Having avoided Shakespeare until she believed herself ready to play him, Miss Cornell has hung another jewel on the cheek of the theatre's nights. Her "Romeo and Juliet," which she put on at the Martin Beck last evening, is on the high plane of modern magnificence.

Indications that the New York municipality will press a program of publicly supported power production, to compete with existing enterprises, were weighed carefully and critically yesterday in Wall Street. While skeptical, that community took into account all the possibilities.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Dec. 20 (AP). -Some of the costs and fundamentals involved in building a winning football team for "big time" collegiate competition were disclosed today by President Ralph C. Hutchison, young, energetic president of Washington and Jefferson College.

Two schools of opinion will clash in the Saar Basin Territory on Jan. 13, the day of the plebiscite, Professor Sidney B. Fay of Harvard declares in an article entitled "The Fate of the Saar" in the January Current History, which will be published tomorrow.

George Harris caged a foul goal in the closing minutes to give the De Witt Clinton High School basketball team, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, a 27-to-26 victory over the school's Alumni quintet yesterday in the Clinton gymnasium.

Trading was mixed and generally narrow and light on the local commodity futures markets yesterday. On the cash markets butter sold at a new high level and coffee and cocoa advanced, while wheat, corn, rye, lard and rubber declined.
PARIS, Dec. 20 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company today will advance gasoline prices 2 1/2 cents a gallon in Brooklyn and Queens and 1/2 cent in Manhattan and the Bronx and in Westchester and Nassau Counties. In Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, the new price for regular grades of gasoline at service stations will be 16 cents a gallon, including 4 cents in taxes.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 20. -- The largest airplane ever constructed in the United States and the largest transport airplane in the world tried its mettle successfully here today for the first time in both the elements for which it was designed -- water and air.
Lack of funds forced the suspension yesterday of the Aldermanic committee investigating relief, which has asked the Board of Estimate for $25,000 to continue its investigation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20. -- Fullback Dave Smukler and the other four ailing members of the squad were aboard the Temple University football train when it pulled out of North Philadelphia station tonight, bound for the New Year's Sugar Bowl game with Tulane in New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Federal loans to municipalitles such as the one tentatively promised to New York City yesterday for the construction of a municipal electric plant will be confined exclusively to those cities where rates are not "reasonable," according to Secretary Ickes.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- Recovery continued today in the Boerse. Gains ranged up to 2 points, although there were individual losses up to 4 points. Heavy industrials rose fractionally, but lignites were rather weaker, Bubiag losing 4 1/8 points.

Regulation of minimum wages, shorter working hours, elimination of the sweat shop and of child labor, together with protection of honest business and of the rights alike of employers and employes were cited last night by Senator Wagner as guiding principles of the New Deal which should be embodied in permanent legislation.

Many boxes and seats have beenpurchased for the performance cfi"Romeo and Juliet," starringKatharine Cornell, tomorrow nightat the Martin Beck Theatre, whichhas been taken over by membersof the Smith College Club of NewYork to augment its scholarshipfund.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 20. -- The Presbytery of New Brunswick, at an executive session that lasted three hours, voted this afternoon to place the Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen of Philadelphia on trial on nine charges growing out of his alleged defiance of the church authorities.

With a view toward aiding the development of basketball players of Olympic caliber, the Metropolitan A.A.U. plans to stage a metropolitan basketball championship tourney this season among both college and amateur club teams.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Without mentioning the word "recognition," but painting a glowing picture of British trade prospects in Manchukuo, a long-awaited report was issued tonight by the mission that spent four weeks in the Far East last Autumn on behalf of the Federation of British Industries.

In a letter printed in THE TIMES Mrs. Rosalie Edge, chairman of the Emergency Conservation Committee, appeals to sportsmen to put aside their guns for a few years to give the ducks a chance to recover in numbers. I wonder if she has given any thought to where this increased number of birds will feed?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Jack B. Tate, acting NRA division administrator, will be "glad" to make arrangements for an open conferfence between representatives of the American Newspaper Guild and officials of the NRA concerning wage and hour amendments to the code for the daily newspaper publishing business.

This country is showing a keener interest in the conservation of the nation's wild life resources than ever before, speakers agreed last night at the annual Winter camp dinner of the Camp Fire Club of America at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Louisiana indictments against the AnheuserBusch Company were said by officials of the Department of Justice here today to be one more step in the administration's drive, started more than a year ago when the liquor codes were drawn, to balk any attempt by brewers to return to the pre-prohibition "tiedhouse" system, whereby brewing companies acquired financial control over saloons and other retail outlets.

The Legion of Decency Council of the Archdiocese of New York held its first meeting yesterday in the Empire State Club and agreed on at least two points as a basis for its drive against objectionable movies.

BELGRADE, Dec. 20. -- Boske Yeftitch's efforts to form a concentration government broke down this evening. The Serbian radical party leaders withdrew from the negotiations, Father Anton Koroschetz, Slovenian leader, thereupon withdrew, and the Moslem leader, Dr. Spaho, declined to consult with the former Foreign Minister and did not even come to Belgrade.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20. -- An indictment has been returned in Federal District Court at Lake Charles against Anheuser-Busch, Inc., of St. Louis, invoking the provision of the brewery industry's code which forbids the pre-prohibition practice by big brewers of subsidizing saloons to sell their beers.

! TEWTOWN FORBES, Irish FreeState, Dec. 20 (P).--To the rejoicing of the whole countryside, pretty!Lady loira Forbes, 24-year-oldgranddaughter cf the late OgdenIMills, t0dy became the bride ofIComte Louis de Brantes of France.

Offering will be made today of $18,000,000 of ten-year 5 per cent convertible collateral trust bonds of the Chesapeake Corporation by a banking syndicate consisting of Edward B. Smith Co., Brown Harriman Co., Inc.; the First Boston Corporation and the Lee Higginson Corporation.

Package deliveries made in the metropolitan area by the United Parcel Service, Inc., for the week ended Dec. 15 showed an increase of 19 per cent over the corresponding week last year, officials of the service announced yesterday. The comparison covers deliveries for approximately 250 identical stores.
The Neediest Cases Fund dropped back again yesterday, and the hope for a happy Christmas grew dimmer for scores of those who most need happiness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Despite the largest planted acreage since 1931, the Winter wheat crop yield for 1935 is put by the government Crop Reporting Board at only 475,000,000 bushels, an increase of but 75,000,000 over the short crop last year and 157,061,000 bushels below the average for 1927-31.

Receipts from merchandise sold in New York City and delivered to any point out of the city are specifically exempted from the city's 2 per cent sales tax under an interpretation of the tax law made last night by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Proposed expenditures approaching half a billion dollars for plant improvement and replacement in 1935 have been reported by a group of large industrial companies in reply to inquiries of the Federal Housing Administration, James A. Moffet, housing administrator, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Wholesale violations by bituminous coal operators of the minimum price provisions of the Soft Coal Code have resulted in the last ten days in a crisis in the industry, according to John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Evidence viewed as giving the "birthplace and birth-time" of the American Liberty League, nonpartisan critic of some New Deal policies, was uncovered today by the Senate munitions inquiry in the form of some correspondence in which John J. Raskob figured prominently.
BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- A new effort to end the conflict within the German Protestant Church was initiated at a meeting of all Bishops of the Confessional Church in Berlin tonight.
"Fishermen are always crying for more fish. We are going to find out if they mean it."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at thc close of the week ended Dec. 15 totaled 324,260,000 barrels, a decrease of 1,710,000 barrels from the total of 325,970,000 on hand at the end of the preceding week, Secretary Ickes announced today.
At this moment when an unbalanced budget perplexes thoughtful Americans, the remarks of P. W. Wilson in his delightful book on the younger Pitt are interesting.

All the more deplorable and discouraging must appear the latest attempt to lynch a prisoner for coming so soon after President ROOSEVELT'S appeal to the nation to rally every energy against the prevalence of crime. Bar associations, together with various committees and agencies formed to deal with the subject, have at the same time appealed to the American people to start a "revolt" against crime in the United States.

Robert Miller will sing airs from "Tannhaeuser" and "Rigoletto" tonight with the Bronx Symphony under Franco Autori at Theodore Roosevelt High School. The Brooklyn String Trio also will play a free program tonight at the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

Carrying out the new Federal policy of substituting, where feasible, government-owned postal stations for branch offices previously rented from private property owners, the Federal authorities have acquired fifteen branch postoffice sites in Manhattan and the Bronx and expect to own within a short time perhaps a dozen more parcels.

Net profit of the Caterpillar Tractor Company for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30 was $3,459,064, after interest, provision for Federal income tax, depreciation, expenses and other charges. This is equivalent to $1.84 a share on 1,882,240 shares outstanding.

Jumping into the lead with two goals in the first few minutes of play, the world's champion Chicago Black Hawks handed the Rangers another defeat last night. Playing a strong, forceful game, despite the fact that they were always ahead, they triumphed by 4 to 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A national survey with a view to eliminating overlapping Federal, State and local taxation will be made by the Treasury, under instructions from President Roosevelt.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP). -- The State Board of Conciliation and Arbitration tonight moved to prevent the permanent closing of the Hamilton Woolen Company's Southbridge mill or liquidation of the plant, which was indicated yesterday by the vote of the board of directors to recommend to stockholders the final settlement of the business.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- That a husband shall no longer be liable to be sued or made responsible for his wife's pre-marriage debts or contracts or wrongs or for any wrongs committed by his wife during marriage is among the bold and important reforms projected by the Law Revision Committee.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Plans for renovating the five-story apartment house at 2,653 Eighth Avenue, near West 142d Street, were announced in connection with the sale of the property yesterday to Hattan Estates for investment. The building is on a lot 25 by 100 feet and contains four-room apartments and a large double store.

A report by Harold T. Allen, former Deputy Police Commissioner, that policy racketeers continue to take in from $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 a month in this city because of "inadequate" handling of policy gambling cases by the Court of Special Sessions was disclosed yesterday.

With the re-election of Junius S. Morgan as Commodore of the New York Yacht Club at the annual meeting of that organization last night in its clubhouse at 37 West 44th Street, the race committee submitted its report for last Summer, including its stand on the protests of T. O. M. Sopwith in the America's Cup match off Newport in September.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Great elation was evident today at the headquarters of the United States naval delegation over the fact that, during the past two months of talks with the British and the Japanese, AngloAmerican relations had grown much closer.

A report by Harold T. Allen, former Deputy Police Commissioner, that policy racketeers continue to take in from $2,000,000 to $3,000,000 a month in this city because of "inadequate" handling of policy gambling cases by the Court of Special Sessions was disclosed yesterday.

With the re-election of Junius S. Morgan as Commodore of the New York Yacht Club at the annual meeting of that organization last night in its clubhouse at 37 West 44th Street, the race committee submitted its report for last Summer, including its stand on the protests of T. O. M. Sopwith in the America's Cup match off Newport in September.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Great elation was evident today at the headquarters of the United States naval delegation over the fact that, during the past two months of talks with the British and the Japanese, AngloAmerican relations had grown much closer.

The board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday denied a petition of members for a half-holiday on next Monday. It had denied previously a petition to close on the Mondays preceding Christmas and New Year's Day.

The twenty-fifth anniversary oil the founding of the Neurological Institute of New York, one of the leading institutions of its kind in the world, now part of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Centre, was celebrated yesterday with colorful ceremonies at the institute.

BERLIN, Dec. 20. -- Because an incautious chance remark was repeated by an American girl innocent of Nazi ways, Professor Fritz Meyer, one of Berlin's best-known physicians and for a long time house doctor for United States Ambassadors and consuls, was a fugitive from Nazi wrath today, knowing that he faces a concentration camp or prison if he is caught.

A rise of $55,000,000 in the volume of money in circulation took place in the week ended on Wednesday, the weekly Federal Reserve statements, published yesterday, showed. This gain, reflecting the seasonal increase in demand before Christmas, was of somewhat less than seasonal proportions, particularly in view of the abnormal decline of $13,000,000 in circulation which occurred in the previous week.

The Louisville Nashville Rail-iroad is expected to report a net income for 1934 of between $2,500,000and $2,600,000, according to JamesB. I-Iill, president. This would beequal to from $2.14 to $2.22 a common share.

The roaring Atlantic Ocean, after claiming two freighters, the Usworth and the Sisto, threatened to add another ship to its list of victims yesterday when the American collier Severance fell prey to its rage nineteen relies southwest of Fire Island.
DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 20 (AP). -For playing host to Homer Van Meter at a north woods resort in the Dillinger gangster's last two days, two men and two women were sentenced to prison today.
While the city yesterday was pushing its plans for municipal power plants to serve its own needs, the power companies of the State were confronted by increasing pressure for rate reduction.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Encouraged by a favorable reception to the report of Dr. Jacob Viner and Dr. Charles O. Handy on a survey of credit and banking conditions in the Chicago Federal Reserve District, Secretary Morgenthau authorized today a similar investigation by them in the Cleveland District.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler, in a decision handed down yesterday, upheld the legality of investment of trust funds in participation certificates based on group mortgages. The question affects many trust funds administered by banks and individual trustees who have invested large sums in guaranteed mortgage certificates based upon groups of mortgages.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors adopted today the county budget for 1935 in the form in which it was presented for consideration last Monday. The vote was 25 to 144. Theodore Hill, Republican, of Yorktown, voted with the Democratic minority because he objected to the manner in which the county tax would be levied on the tax districts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Correspondence between R. R. M. Carpenter of the du Pont organization and John J. Raskob, as read before the Senate munitions inquiry, was as follows:

The New York University fencing team made a successful debut last night by defeating the Saltus Fencing Club, 18 to 9, at the Twentythird Street Y.M.C.A. The Violet swordsmen scored in the foils and saber sections by 7 to 2 counts, but dropped the epse tests, 5 to 4.
DETROIT, Dec. 20. -- Detroit is different this year.
Auctioneers offered for bidding yesterday six properties in Manhattan and four in the Bronx. Two scheduled sales in the former borough were adjourned sine die.

Lest the reader of the dispatches describing Mayor LA GUARDIA'S pilgrimage to Washington get the impression that the city's shiny new $110,000,000 power plant is going to be built tomorrow, or possibly the day after, depending on just how long it takes Secretary ICKES to sign the necessary checks, it may be useful to set forth the law on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The gradual increase in wholesale commodity prices for the previous three weeks was checked in the week ending Dec. 15, and the index, based on 1926 levels, remained at 76.7, just as in the week ending Dec. 8, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported this afternoon.

The Howard Young Gallery, 677 Fifth Avenue, has assembled in its main exhibition room as a special holiday attraction a carefully selected group of paintings by six eighteenth century English artists: Gainsborough, Sir Joshua Reynolds, Raeburn, Hoppner, Lawrence and Romney.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- A bearish construction was placed by the trade this afternoon on the government report giving the Winter wheat and rye acreage seeded for the harvest of 1935. The area seeded to wheat was nearly 6 per cent above the revised figures of last year and the largest since 1930.
Auctioneers offered for bidding yesterday six properties in Manhattan and four in the Bronx. Two scheduled sales in the former borough were adjourned sine die.

Lest the reader of the dispatches describing Mayor LA GUARDIA'S pilgrimage to Washington get the impression that the city's shiny new $110,000,000 power plant is going to be built tomorrow, or possibly the day after, depending on just how long it takes Secretary ICKES to sign the necessary checks, it may be useful to set forth the law on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- The gradual increase in wholesale commodity prices for the previous three weeks was checked in the week ending Dec. 15, and the index, based on 1926 levels, remained at 76.7, just as in the week ending Dec. 8, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported this afternoon.
