Activity in wholesale cotton goods quarters and larger clearances at Southern ports than a year ago strengthened prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday for the second successive day. After a steady opening, quotations moved slowly but steadily upward and ended at the top at gains of 2 to 9 points, the May and July deliveries closing at the highest figures this month.

BELGRADE, Dec. 21. -- After further difficult negotiations, Boske Yeftitch succeeded today in forming a Cabinet, which took the oath to the Regency this evening. M. Yeftitch retains the Foreign Ministry and General Pera Zhivkovitch retains the War Ministry.

More than 200 pupils in public and parochial schools throughout the city received certificates and cash prizes, ranging from $3 to $25, from[' the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York yesterday at a ceremony marking the close of its annual essay contest.

ALBANY, Dec. 21. -- Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, alleged income tax evader, was released tonight by United States Commissioner Hubbard in $75,000 bail for his appearance before the commissioner next Thursday.

The La Guardia administration warned the stockholders of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company and the Manhattan Railway Company yesterday that it was prepared to take advantage of the pending Federal receiverships of both corporations in its efforts to include their equities in a general unification plan at a price fair to the city.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Martin J. Insull received a Christmas present of a not-guilty verdict from a jury in a State criminal court here this afternoon. The charge was embezzlement of $344,720 from the Middle West Utilities Company, which he headed, for personal stock market operations.
This morning's mail brought to this office a clipping from THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 15 consisting of a letter to the editor from A.J. Franck, entitled "Bored by Buttons."

New offerings of bonds this week were the largest of any week in nearly six months. The total was $80,728,032, the largest since the first week in July, when new issues in the amount of $88,486,000 were placed on the market. In the corresponding week last year the total was $1,880,000.

UNIVERSITY, Ala., Dec. 21 (AP). -- Shouting their confidence of victory, 2,000 townspeople and students gave Alabama's football team a rousing send-off today as Coach Frank Thomas and his thirty-five players entrained for Pasadena for their Rose Bowl encounter with Stanford.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The White House took on its customary Christmas atmosphere today as workmen hung wreaths and strung lights over Christmas trees, both for public view and for the private enjoyment of the Roosevelt family, members of which are converging on the White House.

At the head of a large army of actors disguised as citizens of early-day Nevada and California, Helen Gahagan and Melvyn Douglas will invade the Cort Theatre this evening for their first joint appearance on Broadway since "Tonight or Never." "Another Lode," a romance by Dan Totheroh and George O'Neil, is the business of tonight's meeting, which will find the silver question uppermost.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Seasonal suspension of public works projects at the end of the outdoor working period contributed to cause a decline of industrial employment in November from the level of October, Secretary Perkins said today.

Frank B. Kellogg, former Secretary of State and Nobel Peace Prize winner, who will be 78 years old tomorrow, is still optimistic about preserving world peace, for which he worked so long in official life.

many persons prominent in the civic, business and fraternal ll*fe of the city attended funeral services last nig/it for the late Edward W. Forrest, executive 'vice president of the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants Association, at the Chapel of the Riverside'Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- The recovery continued today on the Boerse, although the turnover remained small. Heavy industrials were rather buoyant, Klockner gaining 2 1/4. Lignites were rather mixed. The best showing was made by the specialties, particularly rubbers, where the raw materials situation was regarded more optimistically.

Cardinal Hayes yesterday appointed the Rev. Bernard J. Rourke, who for the last five years has been pastor of the Church of St. Joseph, Croton Falls. N.Y., to the pastorate of the Church of St. John the Evangelist, First Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Use of stainless steel in the construction of the new aircraft carriers Yorktown and Enterprise, now building at Newport News, has been abandoned by the Navy Department as a result of an unfortunate experience with such metal in the carrier Ranger's gasoline tanks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Panama Canal rules on ship measurements were urged as the sole basis for levying canal tolls in Secretary Dern's annual report today. Mr. Dern urged legislation to such an end, recalling that though the House passed a bill providing for such a basis at the last session, the Senate adjourned without acting on the bill.

A Hungarian furrier who had studied engraving for two years to cheat Uncle Sam by counterfeiting, was captured amid a burst of gunfire early yesterday in Centreville, N.J. His capture was the climax in a round-up of a family accused of circulating thousands of dollars in fake bills.

The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad management voted yesterday to accept a loan of only $3,500,000 out of a possible $4,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Originally, the railway had asked for a loan of $9,000,000, but the Interstate Commerce Commission demanded the pledging of all the collateral offered for such a loan by the company in return for a loan of only $4,000,000.
Nine survivors of the British freighter Usworth arrived yesterday on board the Cunard White Star liner Ascania, which rescued them on Dec. 14 during a terrific storm in mid-Atlantic.
PARIS, Dec. 21. -- In a steady stream, from the north and south, a four-power peace army of the League of Nations is gathering in the Saar basin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Building construction, including new and alteration work, throughout the country was larger by 24.6 per cent in number and 19 per cent in value in November than a year ago, an analysis of building permits issued in 778 cities showed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Broadening of the Federal Reserve Board's discretionary powers as to eligibility rules for the discounting of commercial paper, in order to speed the flow of Reserve money into business channels, was under consideration by high government officials today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Former Senator James E. Watson of Indiana returned today to the Senate office building for the first time since he was defeated in the Roosevelt landslide of 1932, to tell the committee investigating the munitions industry that never at any time had he lobbied for the dyestuff embargo.

One of the most representative fields in the history of the championship will seek the national junior indoor tennis title next week at the Seventh Regiment Armory courts, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.
HONGKONG, Dec. 21. -- From a mass of conflicting reports it appears that the Nanking session of the Nationalist Central Executive Council was unproductive of a Canton-Nanking political rapprochement.

Trade Here Shows Pick-Up. Retail trade here picked up somewhat during the last two days, with today's volume expected to be large and show a substantial gain over a year ago. The effect of the sales tax, merchants said, will be evident, however, in a reduction of total pro-Christmas volume to a 10 per cent increase over a year ago, against 15 per cent or more before the tax went into effect on Dec. 10.
AMSTERDAM, Dec. 21. -- The news from Baghdad of the wreck

Looking backward over a year filled with startling exploits and stunning surprises in the wide realm of sports competition, newspaper experts yesterday appeared pretty well agreed on these four points:

TORONTO, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press). -- The annual statement of the Canadian Bank of Commerce for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, issued today, shows a slight increase in total assets to $575,000,000. Quick assets rose from $306,000,000 to $315,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The cotton spinning industry was reported today by the census bureau to have operated during November at 94.0 per cent of capacity, on a single shift basis, compared with 97.1 per cent during October of this year, and 96.3 per cent during November of last year.

Several parties were given for debutantes last night. One of the large affairs of the night was the supper dance that Dr. and Mrs. Rufus Cole gave in the ballroom of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Eegeler Cole. The decorations were suggestive of the holiday season -- white and silvered Christmas trees indirectly lighted with silver and blue lights.

The question of what kind of weather prevailed in the Bronx in November, 1783, has been posed by criticism of an $8,000 mural painting in the Bronx County Court House which depicts George Washington at the Van Cortlandt mansion on Nov. 23, 1783, surrounded by flowers in bloom and trees in leaf.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Republican liberals planned today to continue demands for reorganization of the party, despite a rebuff from those in control.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 21. -- Youth again showed the way to the veterans in the Pasadena $4,000 open golf championship today as three players in their early twenties stepped out with par-breaking scores of 69 in the second qualifying division.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

Plans to poll residents of New York on whether they preferred a sales tax or a two-cent tax on transit fares were prepared yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Association and other retail groups, as the amended sales tax bill went through the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly and stood awaiting Mayor La Guardia's signature.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Emerson Whithorne, American composer whose symphony in C minor No. 1, Opus 49, was presented by the Cleveland Orchestra under Artur Rodzinski last night, says the music world is too stingy with its writers.

A payment of $3,122,000 made to Hudson County yesterday by Controller William Budd of Jersey City virtually wiped out the city's debt to the county for taxes delinquent over a period of four years. The remaining sum due is "negligible," it was reported.

Frederick J. Powell, counsel for the trustees of the Prudence-Bonds Corporation, at a hearing yesterday before James G. Moore, special master, in the Federal Building in Brooklyn, outlined a plan of reorganization for the fifteenth series of the corporation's bonds, amounting to S4,650,700 in 5 per cents on which $402,000 interest is in arrears.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Austria was removed from the ranks of the debt-defaulting nations today under an interpretation by the Treasury, an action which makes obligations of that government eligible for sale in the United States unless the Attorney General should rule otherwise.
Only light interest was evinced in the credit market, the commercial paper section excepted. Business was small and quotations unchanged for all classes.

Mayor La Guardia moved rapidly toward giving the city its first municipally owned electric power system yesterday, when he appointed a board of fourteen city engineers from various departments and directed them to draw plans for the system immediately.

Julius Forstmann, president of the Forstmann Woolen Company, made public yesterday a letter sent to the Senate Munitions Committee in connection with the publication of his name on the list of those whose incomes during one or all of the years from 1915 to 1920 exceeded $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- The mystery of the "lost" savings is engaging the attention of economists.

LITTLE AMERICA, Dec, 20 (via Mackay Radio) (AP). -- A fresh difficulty overtook the Byrd expedition's tractor party today when the last available machine was reported broken down 136 nautical miles east of here.

The new wage agreement of American seamen and their employers was signed yesterday at the offices of the American Steamship Owners Association by John E. Craig, vice president of the Clyde Mallory Line, as representative of thirty-seven of the principal American ship lines, and Victor A. Olander, secretary of the international Seamen's Union.

For the benefit of those who are anticipating a big night of fun on New Year's Eve this department has made a survey of the various cabarets, taverns and assorted caravanserai on and off Broadway to determine the scale of prices effective on that particular evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- President Roosevelt will receive in a few days the report of the Committee on Economic Security, which for six months has been working on a comprehensive program embodying unemployment insurance, old age pensions, health protection and other measures intended to minimize life's hazards for American working men and women.

Andre Citroen is credited with having adopted "American business methods, revolutionizing the European motor car industry as the result of observations while visiting this country in 1912, 1923 and 1931.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 21. -- C. Lloyd Fisher of defense counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, revealed today that a mysterious elderly man had spent forty minutes in a silent inspection of the defendant in the Lindbergh kidnap-murder case.

BOSTON, Dec. 21. -- Max Baer and two preceding heavyweight champions, Jack Dempsey and Jack Sharkey, lured 13,000 boxing followers back to the Boston Garden tonight to watch Sammy Fuller, veteran Boston lightweight, capture a close but unanimous decision from Bobby Pacho, Yuma Indian battler, in the ten-round feature of the Goodwin A.C.'s Christmas charity show.
Danny Ridge, boxing star of another generation and later a referee, was buried yesterday in Mount Zion Cemetery, with a suspension removed from his record with the State Athletic Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Hope for naval reduction and limitation by international agreement has not been abandoned here, notwithstanding the disappointing result of the London conversations and Japan's plan to terminate the Washington Naval Treaty.

Contrary to the general impression, the present terror/and executions in Soviet Russia are not reprisals for the assassination of Kiroff. The Communists have been murdering "class enemies," but have failed to reveal the slightest evidence that they were in any way connected with Nikaliaev, Kiroff's assassin.

A smooth-functioning New York University quintet that bears promise of being an even better team than the unbeaten five of a year ago, administered a 45-26 defeat to Columbia in the Lions' gymnasium last night.

Mr. KRACKE, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, is open to congratulations for having decided to do away with the extension over Park Row into City Hall Park of the Brooklyn Bridge Terminal of the Interborough and B.M.T. elevated lines. There was a time, before the modern subways were built, when this was a point of intense congestion.
Yesterday was a more hopeful day for the Neediest Cases Fund, which has been lagging far behind last year's total.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Operators in grain generally took the selling side of the markets early today on the Board of Trade and spent the rest of the session trying to cover short sales.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The War Department's statement of policy on the nationalization of industry in war time, read today to the Senate Munitions Committee, was as follows:

Investigation of the wholesale light and power rates charged by the New York Edison Company and the United Electric Light and Power Company is asked in a complaint filed with the Public Service Commission at Albany and made public here yesterday by the National Electric Service Corporation of 25 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Any idea held by the Senate Munitions Committee that the administration favored nationalization of the munitions industry was shattered today. In a communication carrying Secretary Dern's approval, the Senators were told that the War Department was convinced that private industry and not the government must produce the major part of the munitions required in war time.

" The Mighty Barnum," with Wallace Beery playing the title role, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rivoli. Adolphe Menjou, Virginia Bruce, Rochelle Hudson and Janet Beecher also are in the cast.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 21. -- The search for the missing Dutch airliner Uiver, nicknamed the "flying hotel," ended in the discovery of a tragedy this morning when the charred remains of the big American-built plane were found by British Royal Air Force fliers ten miles southwest of Rutbah Wells, a lone depot in the middle of the Syrian Desert.
CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Two deaths of influenza in Camden were reported today as many more schools in southern parts of New Jersey were closed to check the spread of grip among pupils and teachers.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21. -- While Moscow buzzed tonight with stories, still lacking official confirmation, of the arrest of Gregory Zinovieff and Lev Kameneff, former Soviet leaders, the government announced it had struck another blow against alleged terrorist plotters, this time within the ranks of the Communist party itself.

A youth with a criminal record was shot dead last night as he stepped from an automobile into the street at Washington and West Houston Streets. The victim, Thomas Adabody, was 21 years old, and lived with his mother at 18 Gansevoort Street.

The churches will begin tomorrow morning a three-days' celebration of Christmas. Cardinal Hayes has renewed his permission for a midnight mass in each of his 452 churches, and virtually all will have such a service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP). -- A recommendation that the United States buy and store thousands of tons of tin for use in the event off war was made to the House Foreign Affairs Committee today by Bernard M. Baruch.

Nordic as a character from a saga, and glistening in an aura that was partly personality, partly appearance and partly the peculiar quality of a very individual voice, Goeta Ljungberg gave her first Manhattan song recital in the Town Hall last night, on the eve of her fourth season as one of the leading dramatic sopranos of the Metropolitan.

Influenced by newspaper reports that a poll of the Republican National Committee showed that members from forty-three out of the forty-eight States were against "liberalization" and reorganization of the Republican party. Chase Mellen Jr., New York County chairman, wrote yesterday to Henry P. Fletcher, chairman of the committee, suggesting that another poll be taken by a ten-point questionnaire.

Scoring in every period, the Princeton freshman hockey team defeated the St. Paul's sextet of Concord, N.H., in the annual game between the teams at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, 3 to 2. A crowd of 2,500 persons, preponderantly in favor of St. Paul's, saw the battle, which was the twenty-first of a series that began in 1909.

DESPITE a certain amount of a difficulties of a rather imposing nature, though not necessarily deemed insurmountable, there seems to be a feeling of assurance about that 1935 is quite certain to see another one of those sporting extravaganzas styled "A battle for the heavyweight championship of the world." Perhaps "annoyance" would be more the word than "assurance."
The Bowman-Biltmore Hotels Company, which operates the Commodore Hotel, filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court asking permission to reorganize under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Act.

The proxy contest for control of Trans-Lux Daylight Picture Screen Corporation ended yesterday in a victory for the present management, headed by Percy N. Furber, president. The management's slate of fifteen directors was elected by a margin of 167,000 shares, in the case of Mr. Furber, and by slightly smaller or larger majorities in the case of other directors, according to the company's statement.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Capital totaling 17,285,000 (the pound is quoted at $4.94) has been irretrievably lost by the Royal Mail Steam Packet Company and its associated company, Elder Dempster, Ltd., it was revealed today.

A committee for voluntary liquidation of December sugar contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange was appointed yesterday, William H. English Jr., president of the Exchange, announced. It consists of Walter Murphy, H. H. Pike Jr., George Hintz, B.B. Peabody and Frank C. Russell.

While a picket line of sixty-four discharged employes paraded in front of his building chanting "Don't Buy Klein," a line of 1,200 employes filed through the office of S. Klein, Union Square merchant, late yesterday afternoon and received $80,000 in cash as a Christmas bonus from their employer. Mr. Klein distributed also a ton of candy and a truckload of cigars.

Only a comparatively small amount of new municipal bonds will come up for award next week following the activity this week. The total for the holiday week will be $4,929,477, compared with this week's total of $54,027,289 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $19,411,982.

BOSTON, Dec. 21. -- Boston College turned in the first big upset of the college hockey season by downing Dartmouth on the Boston Arena ice, 3 -- 2, in an overtime game tonight. The big Green went ahead, 2 -- 0, early in the second period, but the third period had hardly begun before the Eagles had tied the score.
Your button-conscious correspondent might cut down considerably on his worries. Permit me to offer myself as an example.

With Ernie Oeding and Dave Gotkin leading the attack, the St. John's University quintet registered its fifth straight victory when it trounced St. Peter's College of Jersey City, 41 to 29, before 500 persons at the De Gray gymnasium in Brooklyn last night.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 21. -- C.J. Bild's Band Wagon scored a popular triumph in the mile and a sixteenth of the featured Tamiami Purse at Tropical Park today when he defeated J.C. Clark Jr.'s Haggerson by a length and a half.

Directors of the United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company declared yesterday in Boston a dividend of $3 a share on the common stock payable on Jan. 15 to stock of record of Dec. 31. Previously in 1934 total dividends of $5.25 had been paid.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- The Societe Andre Citroen was placed in judicial liquidation today by order of the Seine Tribunal of Commerce, thus legalizing one of the greatest commercial collapses in the history of France.

BATH, N.Y., Dec. 21 (AP). -- Officials tonight were ready to point to Joseph Lewandowski, 44-year-old inmate of the Veterans Home here, as the alleged slayer of Mrs. George H. Parker, wealthy widow of 72.
MONTREAL, Dec. 21. -- McGill University's hockey team defeated a stubborn Harvard sextet, 6 to 1, in an intercollegiate match tonight at the Forum.

Arraigned in Homicide Court and surrendered there to Westchester County for trial on a charge of killing Grace Budd in 1928, Albert H. Fish, 65-year-old house painter, was questioned at the same time yesterday concerning the fourth child murder with which police have sought to link him.
ROME, Dec. 21. -- Italy's most prolific mothers, ninety-four of them, began their second annual celebration in Rome today as guests of Premier Benito Mussolini.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, gave emphatic warning today to the world at large and the United States in particular that Britain has no present intention of stabilizing the pound with reference to the dollar, which he described as still being on gold.

After viewing the film in which Sidney Franklin, Brooklyn-born bullfighter, was referred to as a "bull-thrower," Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew indicated yesterday that he would decide in Franklin's favor in the bullfighter's suit against Columbia Pictures Corporation, distributers of the film.

Since Ina Claire has a genius for being light-minded, Gilbert Miller has cast her in a slyly ironic comedy from the French, "Ode to Liberty," which was put on at the Lyceum last evening. When it wore its native language it was Michel Duran's "Liberte Provisoire." Since then Sidney Howard has taken hold of it in the interests of the American public.

The monetary gold stock of the United States was increased $5,834,900 yesterday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank. A total of $5,207,800 of gold arrived at New York yesterday, of which $1,971,300 came from France, $1,675,800 from Canada and $1,560,700 from England.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21 (AP). -- Zekiel, carrying the colors of F. Seremba, barely lasted to win by a head from The Immortal II, owned by M. Goldblatt, in the Pearl River Purse which headed today's program at the Fair Grounds. Mrs. E.B. Shipp's Heavy Sugar, a recent winner, was third.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

Dr. F.E. Townsend, who hopes to transform the United States into a Utopia by means of an old-age pension plan on a vast scale, arrived here yesterday to spread his movement. He said he had hundreds of thousands of adherents who constitute a voting threat to Congressmen if they fail to do something constructive in the next session.

Jean and Eric La Guardia almost stole the show from their father yesterday afternoon when the Mayor dedicated the Park Department's community Christmas trees at ceremonies in City Hall Park. Later they were the centre of attention at exercises in Thomas Jefferson Park, where the Mayor dedicated another tree and started the work on a swimming pool.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Ogden L. Mills, former Secretary of the Treasury, asserted tonight that the government is not far distant from the stage of inflationary development in which the public loses interest in its short-term securities.

DUBLIN, Dec. 21. -- During the height of the Christmas shopping rush tonight a series of startling armed raids were carried out upon a number of chain stores, known as Bacon Shops, Ltd., and owned by Alfred O'Mara, member of a well-known Limerick Bacon Company, which has been involved in a labor dispute for some days.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, assumed the role of Santa Claus in the distribution of gifts to thirty-two children of the unemployed at a Christmas party yesterday afternoon at the headquarters of the Women's Trade Union League, 247 Lexington Avenue.

Considering the nearness of the holidays, commission houses felt that yesterday's volume on the Stock Exchange -- 917,000 shares -- was more than could have been expected. It was about 40,000 shares larger than on the day before. The composite index of averages showed a net gain of 17 cents; the industrial group was up 41 cents, the rails were down 7.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- A "study by the wisest minds" to devise a practicable plan to take excess profits out of war was proposed today by Pierre du Pont, munitions manufacturer.

Dr. THORNDIKE of Columbia says that the average person must possess a minimum vocabulary of 10,000 words, but Dr. FRANKLIN of Boston University says no. Dr. FRANKLIN says that the only important thing is whether a man's vocabulary is "adequate or inadequate," and that depends on his "particular walk of life."
Auction room activity in Manhattan yesterday was confined to housing properties. Seven houses were offered at foreclosure auctions and all were bought in by the plaintiffs in the cases.

The naming of two boats to compete in the Cuban mid-Winter regatta in Havana next month and the beginning of a movement for team races next Summer were the chief developments at the annual meeting and dinner of the Western Long Island Sound Fleet of the International Star Class last night at the Cornell Club.

Trading was erratic and fairly heavy in the commodity futures markets yesterday. Cottonseed oil and copper were the only staples to maintain a firm undertone. On the cash markets butter rose to a new high level and silk and gasoline advanced, while corn, rye, oats, cocoa, tin and rubber declined.

The special committee of directors of the Radio Corporation of America appointed to consider a capital readjustment plan advised yesterday against the adoption of any plan at this time, and officers and directors concurred unanimously.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 (AP). -- New York State farmers received nearly twice as much for their crops this year as they did two years ago, according to a survey by the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- Heavy butcher hogs were weak here today, while light kinds were steady. The result was that the spread in prices narrowed to around 10 cents a hundred- weight -- the smallest in some weeks. The falling off in the movement of hogs to market of late has been mainly at the expense of the light kinds, and there were intimations the East was inquiring for light weights here today.

Oscar Mannisto, who was born in Finland but has lived twenty-two years in the United States, where he has reared two sons and a daughter, all American born, fought yesterday in Federal Court to prevent his separation from his family.

While Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, was conferring yesterday with the five New York City Democratic county leaders, Assemblyman Louis A. Cuvillier, senior member of the lower house of the Legislature in years of service, notified Mr. Farley that he would not vote for Assemblyman Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn for Speaker.

Dartmouth's basketball team refined its unbeaten record against the Seventh Regiment by defeating the National Guard quintet, 35 to 21, in the fifth meeting between the teams on the losers' court last night. A crowd of 1,000 persons witnessed the contest and the review of the guards which took place during the intermission.
Will the year 1935 bring a moratorium on the shooting of wild water fowl in the United States?
" Hansel and Gretel" will be repeated in Carnegie Hall today at 2:30 P.M. for the many children turned away there three weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The administration high command will gather around a White House table with President Roosevelt Thursday to chart definitely the legislative course it expects Congress to follow.

SHELBYVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 21 (AP). -- Fearing a fresh outbreak tomorrow, vigilantes today gave notice that they would use armed force to quell any further uprising as last Wednesday's rioting claimed its fourth death.

That blazing finish the Brooklyn Dodgers staged at the Polo Grounds last Sept. 30 apparently lighted new fires of ambition in Flatbush, for Manager Casey Stengel will put his athletes in training a full week earlier next Spring than was the case this year.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- As soon as the Washington Naval Treaty has been denounced by Japan it is expected that France will send to the other signatory powers a statement that she does not consider herself any longer bound by its ratios.

All bond groups closed irregularly easier yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Trading was the slowest for a full five-hour trading period in nearly a month, amounting to $10,294,800, compared with $13,958,800 on Thursday. United States Government bonds finished 10.32 point lower to 9-32 higher.
LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The forthcoming British investigation of the armaments industry will be carried on by a royal commission, Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald told the House of Commons today.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 21. -- The United States Government entered the railroad business here today when the Reconstruction Finance Corporation assumed control and active management of the Denver Salt Lake Railroad, commonly known as the Moffat road, which is now a connecting link in a transcontinental line.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

An international students strike will be proposed by a delegation of American and Canadian college youths, who sailed last night on the Olympic to attend the international student congress against war and fascism in Brussels next Saturday.

Welfare Commissioner HODSON ought to know that you cannot beat somebody with nobody and you cannot refute stories involving millions without quoting other millions. Mr. HODSON emphatically denies that more than 8,000,000 pounds of relief potatoes have spoiled or are spoiling, with 16,000,000 pounds of veal, 1,000,000 cans of roast beef,

Writing in the last number of Collier's, Mr. WINSTON CHURCHILL expresses the fear that President ROOSEVELT may lose his leadership. It is a strange choice for such a warning. If anybody is an authority on losing both leadership and confidence, Mr. CHURCHILL is.

The Metropolitan Opera House, which for two generations has been an index of social, financial and theatrical prosperity to the city and nation, has been sold out for the opening performance tonight and the sales for the next seven days already assure the most prospersous Christmas week since 1928.

THE TIMES, as usual, has given one of the fullest and best daily accounts of the Senate hearings on the armament industry. Why, then, the disparaging editorial "More Munition Gossip"? Permit a former investigator for the Senate committee to answer the three complaints you make against this "gossip."

An intercollegiate touch is added to tonight's indoor polo games with one of the infrequent appearances in the city of the West Point cadets. The Army team, which is highly promising this year, plays in Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, against the New York Athletic Club in an exhibition game.

GENEVA, Dec. 21. -- The Chaco advisory committee of the League of Nations decided today to bring to a climax on Jan. 14, when it meets again, the question of applying to Paraguay alone the present arms embargo against both belligerents, if Paraguay is then still recalcitrant on the peace proposals.

BOSTON, Dec. 21. -- When fifty land fire engines and two fireboats were unable to halt a fire in the holds of the Merchants and Miners liner Ontario, the ship was run onto the mud flats off Governor's Island in the upper harbor here today.

THE late Thorne Smith lived the dreams of the partially repressed. The story is that he once rode a horse up the steps of the public library, gayly saluting the lions. He made an early effort to introduce nudism in Washington Square. His New Jersey home is said to have been built around trees, which occupied most of the rooms.
Among those booked to sail on a four-day Christmas cruise to Nassau on the Canadian Pacific Line Empress of Britain are:

Those who purposed in their hearts to give something toward the Neediest Cases Fund and have not yet given wish to be reminded that this is practically the last day in which to draw checks that will with certainty be delivered in time to reach before Christmas the "Cases" not yet provided for.

Formal announcement of the dissolution of the firms of Walter J. Fahy Co. and Lapham, Holden Reimer was made yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The latter firm will be succeeded by a new one, Lapham, Fahy Co., at 29 Broadway.

Coming from behind in the final period, New Utrecht triumphed over Jamaica by 2 -- 1 in a P.S.A.L. hockey tournament upset at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Textile turned back Manual by the same count in another league contest.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 21. -- The distribution of Christmas food to persons on the rolls of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration almost created a riot at the old Centre Market Building here between 9 and 11 this morning, when 10,000 persons waiting outside the building got out of control.

A large debutante party of last night was a dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Warren Prosser Smith at the Ritz-Carlton to introduce their daughters, the Misses Fanny Jane Smith and Joan Paris Smith. It was held in the Crystal Room, where the floral decorations were appropriate to the season.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 21. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, whose trial was ordered yesterday by the New Brunswick Presbytery on charges of defying church authorities, said today that if the "policy" of secrecy was continued at the actual trial it would mean that the church was operating on "a lower standard than the civil courts."

Mr. BORAH came to New York to plead for the liberalization of the Republican party. What he meant by it, what platform he would propose, nobody could make out. Mr. NYE, kindly lending a hand to the good work, was equally cloudy. Mr. BORAH habitually agrees only with himself.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for saving banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

Charles M. Schwab, chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Company, expressed yesterday his continuing optimism as to the future of business in the United States, adding that he holds this belief even though he is not in accord with all of the present-day recovery "principles."
The Bayside Tennis Club and Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club teams are still setting the pace in the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League's class B tournament.

Former Deputy Controller John H. O'Brien was named yesterday for appointment to his former position by Controller-elect Frank J. Taylor, who has already picked Duncan MacInnes as first deputy and William R. Donaldson as third deputy.

Traffic for several blocks around Thirtieth Street and Fifth Avenue was tied up for more than an hour yesterday afternoon when Fire Department apparatus and two police emergency squads responded to three fire alarms in a five-story loft building at 5 West Thirtieth Street.

Christmas-gift buying this week has more than exceeded the highest totals which had been set for it, with reports generally indicating dollar volume greater than at any time since 1930, and, in numerous instances, ahead of the 1929 comparison, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

In its surface appearance, yesterday's share market was little different from that of the previous day. Price movements were narrow; the volume was still less than a million shares. There was scattered selling of the public utility stocks, but they offered considerable more resistance yesterday than on the preceding two or three days.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- The effort of the Protestant Bishops of both camps in the church struggle to make peace before Christmas appears to have been fruitless. A conference of leaders of the opposing groups which met yesterday is reported to have postponed further sessions until after the holiday.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 22. -- Up to an early hour this morning T.O.M. Sopwith had not made any reply to the New York Yacht Club race committee's report on the America's Cup match in which Mr. Sopwith's challenger, Endeavour, was beaten by Rainbow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Organized business replied today to critics of its new cooperative program, questioning that the "hasty commentators" within the administration who passed judgment yesterday on their plan represented the views of President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Seasonal improvement and more settled political conditions have given Japanese business a slightly better tone recently, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly Survey of foreign business.

Perhaps nobody heard sleighbells or saw a team of reindeer streak across the sky yesterday driven by a rotund, bewhiskered figure in red, but the Christmas spirit gripped the hearts of millions here just the same. Christmas parties were held, others were announced and plans to feed thousands of the needy were made known.

LAKELAND, Fla., Dec. 20. -- This is the season when Florida's social structure undergoes a change that brings anxiety as well as delight to permanent residents, for along with the several hundred thousand visitors who have wealth or only modest means come many indigent individuals who give law enforcement officers considerable trouble.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 22. -- Secretary Roper, addressing the New England Society of Charleston at its annual banquet, declared that every community in the nation must so far as possible shoulder its local relief burdens and outlined a six-point program by which the individual may aid his government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- All price-fixing provisions of the Lumber and Timber Products Code were suspended today by the National Industrial Recovery Board, a step in line with the declared policy of S. Clay Williams, chairman of the board, to end price-fixing as a recovery policy as soon as possible. Production control features of the code were continued in full force.

NEWARK, Dec. 22. -- The Essex Club stepped into the lead in the New Jersey division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League's Class B competition when it defeated the Elizabeth Town and Country Club today, 4 -- 1.

A CAMPAIGN reminiscent of the suffrage battle in England is being carried on with increasing vigor in Bermuda, where an organization of women is demanding a voice in the election of those who tax them and make the laws of the colony.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday for November a decrease of $445,650 in gross revenues, compared with the same month last year, and a decrease of $649,969 in net operating income. reight revenue decreased $326,655 to 519,675,170 for the month, while passenger revenue. vhihc in recent months had been increasing, decreased _22,213 to ,128,051. lor the eleven months ended with November. freight revenues increased $11,159,774 to $232,410,771, and passenger revenue rose $4,419,242 to S52,674,351.

With eight teams of four players participating, the annual tournament for the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League will get under way this morning at the rooms of the Manhattan Chess Club in the Hotel Alamac. The tourney will end Wednesday.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 27. -- If the present plans of the central executive committee of the Kuomintang meet the approval of the government, a decided revival of Confucianism as an unofficial national religion is to be expected.

Dr. Albert Einstein saw an anti-war film here yesterday, chuckled at a highly agitated screen representation of Adolf Hitler, decided that the picture was a "fine thing," and while waiting in the lobby for his car considered the problem of the season: Is there a Santa Claus?

THE four-year college has been squeezed and distorted by the pressure of the junior college from below and the university from above so that it no longer means much educationally. Its principal hold is traditional and because of its social status.

WE confess to a thrill on reading Leopold Stokowski's letter, partially published in this place last Sunday, to the directors of the Philadelphia Orchestra, concerning the policies he would recommend to the orchestra if he were to continue at his post as artistic director.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The Senate Munitions Committee today sought to get control of any legislation which the President's committee headed by Bernard Baruch may propose for taking the profits out of war.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22 (AP). -- A Christmas truce in the Chaco appeared little likely today, as from several directions Paraguayan columns were closing in on Villa Montes, Bolivia's central army base.

CHRISTMAS and all that goes with it is usually thought of as an indoor celebration with which the garden and the gardener are little concerned. But changes, taking place so gradually that they are scarcely realized, have somewhat altered that notion.

The first of the season's intercollegiate basketball double-headers scheduled for the Madison Square Garden will be held Saturday night, with the quintets of New York University and Notre Dame opponents in the feature contest. The other encounter will bring together St. John's University and Westminster.

In behalf of the Jones Memorial Centre of the Children's Aid Society a luncheon and children's fashion show will be held Thursday in the Tropical Garden of the St. Regis. Children of the patronesses will act as manikins in the showing. Later there will be divertissements by young stars of the theatrical and motion picture worlds.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22. -- William H. Neale, executive secretary of the Intercollege League at Yale, today announced the program in Winter sports. A total of 245 events have been arranged, leagues having been formed by ten colleges, namely: Branford, Berkeley, Calhoun, Davenport, Edwards, Pierson, Saybrook, Trumbull, Vanderbilt and Wright Hall.

A special committee representing the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., will meet with executives of the Coat and Suit Code Authority on Wednesday to formulate plans for putting into effect the fair trade practice provision authorizing the setting up of a system of cost finding and accounting to be made available for the industry as a whole.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 22. -- The recently discovered star, Nova Herculis 1934, has now reached a brilliance which puts it among the twelve brightest stars in the whole sky, according to Professor Harlow Shapley of the Harvard Observatory.

DETAILS of the interior arrangement of the first of the huge Martin flying boats, test flown at Baltimore last week, have now been pretty well settled. It will resemble rather a modern luxurious combination stateroom and lounge car on a crack overland train than any airplane which has heretofore taken to the American skies.

A suit charging alienation of affections and involving socially prominent families in this city was disclosed yesterday in the Supreme Court, with the filing of a motion on behalf of John H. Connelly of 192 East Seventy-second Street, to examine before trial M.S. Huntington Watts of 400 East Fifty-ninth Street, in an action for $100,000 damages.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Election of Representative Bankhead as Democratic floor leader in the House seemed assured today. Michigan's Democratic delegation declared that six votes would go to the Alabamian on the first ballot, and the Illinois delegation is planning to cast its twenty-one votes for him after a complimentary vote for its favorite son, Representative Sabath, dean of the next House.

COLUMBIA, from which interesting pictures are coming with increasing frequency, has announced a rather robust and intriguing program for the forthcoming weeks. Ready for preview is Edward G. Robinson's "The Whole Town's Talking," which the actor terms one of his most pleasant vehicles, and May Robson's "Mills of the Gods."

Thirty men and women are to attend a conference "to clarify the objectives of the white collar group" Friday at the American Woman's Association clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, it was announced there yesterday. The program will be based on a study of "white collar" employment just completed by the association.

BATH, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- The murder of Mrs. George H. Parker, a socially prominent widow, 72 years old, found beaten to death Monday night at her home here, was solved today by a signed confession by Joseph Lewandowski, 44, an inmate of the Bath United States Veterans' Hospital.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 22. -- Infective germs propelled in coughing and sneezing may float, alive, in the air for many hours, it has been discovered by the Harvard scientists.

The photos reproduced above were taken in the League of Nations' corridor or lobby during the recent special session of the Council which decided to send an international force into the Saar and reached a peaceful settlement of the Yugoslav-Hungarian dispute.

Two goals by Irving Olsen in the final three minutes gave Brooklyn Tech, defending city P.S.A.L. hockey champion, a 2-to-0 triumph over Erasmus Hall High at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. By the victory, the titleholders moved into a tie for first place with New Utrecht.

SCREEN stars take more than one hundred times as long to register their emotions on the screen as in real life. As recorded by the camera, an emotional reaction consumes from four to twelve seconds, whereas the same sensation in actual experience, ranges only from one three-hundredth to one-tenth of a second.

Motor boat men have a calendar all their own. Ground hogs and Candlemas Day have no part in determining when the Spring season for power yachtsmen is near. Next best to July and August for vacation cruises, the skippers rather would see January come than any other month.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- The University of Rochester basketball team handed the Cornell quintet a 46-to-33 setback tonight in a spirited court fray. After a close first half, which ended with Rochester leading, 18 to 15, the home forces drew away from the invaders.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22. -- Football foes in New Orleans' New Year's Day Sugar Bowl classic were encamped near the scene of the battleground tonight, girding themselves for the impending clash.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Farrar Bateson gave a dance last night at the Pierre to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Florence Hoyt Bateson. Several dinners were given in advance, the guests going on later to the dance.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Bruno Richard Hauptmann is facing the Christmas holidays and his trial, which is to start a week from next Wednesday, with the same stolid spirit he has shown since he was arrested and charged with the kidnapping and murder of the infant son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh.

I HAVE sometimes been haunted with a vague story about a wild and fantastic uncle, the enemy of parents and the cause of revolution in nurseries, who went about preaching a certain theory; I mean the theory that all the objects which children use at Christmas for what we call riotous or illegitimate purposes were originally created for those purposes, and not for the humdrum household purposes which they now serve.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Canadian trade with countries of the British Empire made pronounced gains in the year now drawing to a close, R.B. Hanson, Minister of Trade and Commerce, stated today. He attributed this to a large extent to the Ottawa trade agreements. In two years, he added, the entire aspect of Canada's commerce had changed.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- Professor Fritz Meyer, noted Berlin physician arrested as a result of an apparently misunderstood remark repeated by an American mother and daughter, was released today on an order issued by General Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Premier of Prussia, personally.
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The stock markets were closed today for all practical purposes until Thursday after the Christmas holidays. Although officially open on next Monday, little business is expected.

GREENOCK, Scotland, Dec. 22. -- A relative of Betty Gow, former nurse of the slain Lindbergh baby, said today she was en route to the United States under close guard because, "to be quite frank, we fear something may happen to her."

An examination of the Federal records at Washington indicates that the need for cheap power has been anticipated by our public utilities. The extensive report of the New York Power Authority states that with the present St. Lawrence development electricity can be supplied by the State at prices not exceeding 3.5 cents a kilowatt hour for an annual consumption of 600 kilowatt hours.

One of the unusual holiday events for children will be the presentation of a "Children's Holiday Carnival," a combination program of stage and screen features, at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the Junior League Players of the City of New York.
With the annual Christmas turkey shoot and the regular fixtures scheduled, forty-nine gunners came to the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday.

The corner of Fourteenth and F Streets in Washington is a noisier crossroads than Times Square in New York, according to a test of city noises made last night by Dr. E.E. Free, sound expert of New York University, in a broadcast over WABC and the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

Plans for the Bronx Federal Postoffice building have been completed, Acting Postmaster Albert Goldman said yesterday, and bids will be asked early in the year, as soon as specifications have been completed. This building, which is in addition to fifteen branch structures for the Postoffice Department already announced, will occupy the entire block from Grand Concourse to Spencer Place and from 149th Street to 150th Street.

May I express in a measure the surprise, regret and humiliation which, with many others, I have experienced in reading certain newspaper and magazine articles, listening to radio broadcasts and having my attention called through shrewdly worded advertisements to "true stories" about Haiti, by men of the Marine Corps, recently attached to the American occupation in Haiti?

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 22. -- An American Airlines Cleveland-to-Fort Worth mail plane, piloted by Russell S. Riggs, missing since early morning, was sought over a wide area of Kentucky and Middle Tennessee tonight. It was last heard from about twenty-five miles out of Louisville, on its way to Nashville, at 2:52 A. M.

The trustees of the Police Relief Fund, Inc., have adopted a resolution empowering City Chamberlain A.A. Berle Jr. to take over the management of properties held by them, or which they may acquire hereafter, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Valentine.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 22. -- Whatever course future relations between Hungary and Yugoslavia may take will -- or depend largely on the good-will -- or lack of it -- manifested by their respective governments. From the head of one of those governments, this correspondent obtained today an unqualified expression of good-will and peaceful intentions toward all his country's neighbors, which, coming at this time, is a good augury for the future.

After being buffeted by winds and waves for forty-one years in all parts of the world, Captain Robert B. Irving, new master of the Cunard White Star liner Majestic, still retains his youthful spirit and his boyish laughter, which make him appear much younger than he is.

For their tenth year of holiday visits, the Mount Holyoke College girls came down from their Massachusetts hills to the Town Hall last night, singing Christmas folksongs of ten nations in the original tongues. Dr. William C. Hammond's annual program, unique among each season's college songs, was again presented under the auspices of the Mount Holyoke Club of New York.

Banks in this city are cultivating a closer relationship with those throughout the country. The beginning of a better understanding among bankers has resulted from visits by senior representatives of New York's banking institutions to confer on investment and banking procedure.

WILLIAM A. BRADY, veteran theatrical producer, whose career in the theatre dates back to 1882 and who at various times has occupied the limelight as actor, prizefight promoter and picture producer, tonight climbs on the radio bandwagon as raconteur at WABC.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 20. -- Those who picture the average Southerner as a lackadaisical individual with little initiative or energy, and decided preference for remaining in a state of inertia, may have to revise their ideas, in view of what has happened during the depression in Virginia and North Carolina. Both States have successfully launched symphony orchestras.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20. -- One of the most distinguishing features of the annual science exhibition of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, to be held here Dec. 27-Jan. 4, will be the place of meeting. All the exhibits and sessions will be housed in a real Temple of Science, the new home of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research in the University of Pittsburgh group.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Dec. 21. -- Faced with the necessity of raising at least $90,000,000 additional revenue by taxation during the next two years, California bids a long farewell to Utopian schemes and searches for the least painful way of getting the money to pay for its present commitments.

The clash between Russian and Manchukuoan forces has taken place about fifty miles northwest of Vladivostok, Russia's chief base in the Maritime Provinces. The point is about the same distance south of the place where the Chinese Eastern Railway crosses from Manchuria into Russian territory at Suifenho, or Pogranichnaya.

THE big social fashion shows of resort wear taking place in New York put one in the going-away mood. Better still, they tell the story of the enchanting clothes that are ready and begging to be packed and whirled off to Southern climes.

There will begin today a three days' celebration of Christmas, known in the church calendar as the Feast of the Nativity of Our Lord. Many of the denominational churches will confine their celebrations to the services of today, but more of them than in previous years will have services Christmas morning.

A sharp advance in distant positions in Liverpool, due to reduced estimates of harvesting results in India, caused a further improvement in prices yesterday on the Cotton Exchange here. May, July and October contracts rose into new high ground for the month and the list closed at the best quotations since before the Thanksgiving holiday, with gains of 3 to 9 points.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP). -- Representative Hamilton Fish Jr. of New York declared here today that, "if the word 'revolution' was deleted from the Cuban vocabulary, Cuba would soon become the most prosperous nation in the world."
DUBLIN, Dec. 21. -- The Irish Free State is facing what promises to be a peaceful and comparatively plentiful Christmas.

ALTHOUGH Christmas is but two days off, one may still make a success of holiday shopping. Perhaps one is in a quandary about the friend who "has everything"; possibly the indecision about a gift has continued until the last minute.

Subject to approval of the stockholders of each company, consolidation of the National Investors Corporation, the Second National Investors Corporation, the Third National Investors Corporation and the Fourth National Investors Corporation into a new company to be known as the National Investors Corporation has been proposed, according to a letter to stockholders by Fred Y. Presley, president of all four companies.

PARIS PIQUED by reports from across the Channel of the brilliant social season following the royal marriage, Paris proceeded to plan extraordinary holiday festivities. Chic hotels, restaurants, all the "boites ou l'on s'amuse," arranged special galas to be enhanced by novel decorations and surprise attractions.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- While fully expected, Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain's reaffirmation of Great Britain's unwillingness to consider stabilization of the pound has aroused much unfavorable and even bitter comment here today.

The appeal by the committee for unemployed musicians naturally receives sympathetic response from all those who are interested in sustaining the morale of an entire group that has suffered considerably in the last years of unemployment.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22. -- A mechanical "eye" which sees, measures and identifies minute substances too tiny to be visible under the most delicate microscope has been built by the Washington University chemical department.

MAKING expert revolver shots out of policewomen is a new goal of the New York Police Department. By order of Commissioner Valentine, groups of policewomen are appearing daily at the pistol range in the basement of headquarters in Centre Street.

Details of a project in Eastern Rensselaer County which will include a large public fishing ground and a wild waterfowl breeding area were made public yesterday by the New York State Conservation Department.

BACH'S "Christmas Oratorio," with pantomime, orchestra and soloists, will be presented by Delos Chapell at midnight, Christmas eve, at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre. This performance, to be given for the benefit of the Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service and the Citizens Family Welfare Committee, will enlist the services of members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Macklin Marrow.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The naval deadlock caused by Japan's demand for equality of tonnage with the United States and Great Britain has been put in diplomatic cold storage for probably two or three months. If it is not susceptible of solution by the end of the Winter the negotiations, the three-power talks, if resumed at all, will be held under even greater difficulties than those of the last two months.

TORONTO, Dec. 22 (AP). -- A penalty to Bill Kendall with little more than two minutes to play proved fatal to the Chicago Black Hawks, Stanley Cup champions, tonight and they bowed to the Toronto Maple Leafs, 1 -- 0, in a bruising National Hockey League game before a howling crowd of 14,000.

OTTAWA, Dec. 22 (Canadian Press). -- The greatest boom in the Yukon since the famous gold rush of '98 was reported today by George Black, Speaker of the House of Commons, on his arrival in the capital for the Parliamentary session which opens Jan. 17.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Dec. 22. -- An art institute for Nassau, long a cherished project of the Art League of Nassau County, is about to become a reality, according to William F. Waltemath of Rockville Centre, an artist and member of the executive committee of the league.

SOME slackening was reported in retail holiday business here for the week, due to particular circumstances, but from other sections of the country advices continued highly optimistic. Local stores suffered from the new 2 per cent sales tax and only toward the close of the week were the regulations amended so that tax-free purchases might be made by those in the suburbs.
Christmas week -- the time of "peace on earth, good-will toward men" -- opens with the Fund for New York's Neediest Cases still lagging behind the total at this time last year.

Christmas presents in the form of promotions will go to 103 members of the Police and Fire Departments at a ceremony in Mayor La Guardia's office in City Hall at 1 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, the Mayor announced yesterday.

BELGRADE, Dec. 22. -- The unique Hungarian propaganda machine has again succeeded this week in creating a smoke screen over the deportations from Yugoslavia. By this means it has obscured the real issue as determined in Geneva -- the degree of Hungary's responsibility for the murder of King Alexander and the steps she is taking to punish the guilty.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21. -- Soviet Russia's first slapstick comedy has been completed and will soon be shown in the cinema houses throughout the Soviet Union. One may laugh at it -- and, indeed, everyone who sees it will roar -- but its production is a serious and significant event.

APUNGENT, individual tang and a frequent sparkle of humor impart liveliness and a distinctive quality to Mrs. Lockwood's book on a much bewritten subject. There is individuality too in her approach to her material and her method of using it.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 23 (AP). -- The State of Maine went into the liquor business on a large scale today as State stores in Portland, Lewiston, Biddeford and Augusta opened for trade. The store in Bangor did not open until evening, due to delay in receipt of shipments.
ANNAPOLIS, Dec. 22. -- A new personnel of regimental midshipmen officers will assume their duties with the resumption of the regular routine at the Naval Academy after the Christmas leave.

Analysis of replies furnished by exporters in a survey conducted by the National Federation of Foreign Trade Associations shows that a majority of exporters favor a program under which the Second Export-Import Bank of Washington would extend credit guarantees without recourse to shippers.

TORONTO, Ont., Dec. 22. -- Following a general meeting of representatives of the metal mining industry from all parts of Canada, an association under the name Canadian Metal Mining Association is being incorporated.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest C. Wagner gave a dinner dance last night at the River Club to introduce to society here their daughter, Miss Margaret Van Horne Wagner, who was presented at the Court of St. James's last Spring. Tall vases of red and yellow roses were used in the decorations.

IT would be more satisfactory, perhaps, if these pages could come right out this morning and say, with a fine show of authority, there will be no Christmas. To announce, soberly, that Santa Claus is practicing his reindeer for the New Deal's roofs, seems somehow remote for columns that habitually trade in the curious gossips of Broadway.

Following is the statistical comparison of the Labor Bureau's monthly general average of wholesale prices in the United States, issued for November last week. The calculation is based on 784 commodities since November, 1929, and on 550 for earlier dates, so that comparisons with months prior to 1929 are presumably affected by this change.

DR. JOEL ROBERTS POINSETT, in Van Buren's Presidency, was appointed Envoy to Mexico. He had traveled widely and was ever alert for plant novelties. His enthusiasm was aroused by the "fire flower" which painted the hills and valleys of Mexico with flaming vermilion.

IF all the evil man has done in the name of God could truthfully be ascribed to him, his lineaments and nature could not be differentiated from those of the devil. This age-old truth becomes once more manifest in Mr. Clinchy's examination of some of these manifestations in our own country, which Americans so proudly suppose to be free of religious prejudice.

The New York Americans are expected to be at full strength for the first time since the season opened when they oppose the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

HSINKING, Manchuria, Nov. 22. -- Suggestions made recently in London that Japan is building up a supplementary navy under the Manchukuoan flag are not borne out by facts here. Barring secret construction, which is unlikely, the total Manchukuo Navy consists of twenty-three small river gunboats and coastal cutters with an aggregate tonnage of 2,700.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 22. -- Through the cooperation of a group of colonists, more than 200 needy children were entertained at the annual Christmas party this afternoon at the Woman's Club. Santa Claus, arriving by seaplane, distributed toys and practical gifts.

THE first Christmas of the World War -- Christmas of twenty years ago -- found the armies gone to ground. In the west, open fighting was over, not to be resumed for more than three weary years; and the belligerents peered out at one another from trenches that scarred the shell-torn earth from the North Sea to the Alps.

NANKING, Dec. 22. -- General Chiang Kai-shek painted a black picture today of conditions in areas recovered in Kiangsi Province from Communist troops that had been in occupation for six years before being driven out this year by Nationalist troops.

Secretary HULL'S article, which we take pleasure in printing today, is eminently fitting for the time when Christendom turns its thoughts to goodwill and peace on earth. What he preaches is an old gospel, but it is wholly apposite to present needs. Mr. HULL is not for peace as a mere abstraction.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 22. -- L. Slocum captured the second annual Christmas shoot over the traps of the Climax Gun Club today. He took the event, the seventh A.T.A. registered shoot of the year, by breaking 96 out of 100 targets. In Class A the trophy went to I. Wortman with 95.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The trend of events in British political life cannot be fully understood if the existence and influence of the "radical conscience" in this country is left out of the account. For it is the most potent factor in our politics today, as it has been for generations.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- History repeated itself today when British Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon, en route to Cannes for his Christmas holidays, stopped in Paris for lunch and a long talk with Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin and Foreign Minister Pierre Laval.

Judge Robert V. Kinkead, in the Hudson County Court of Common Pleas, Jersey City, reversed yesterday the decision convicting Alfred M. Bingham, 29 years old, son of former United States Senator Hiram Bingham, as a disorderly person in connection with picketing activities last June.

G.E. Yevdokimoff, who has been arrested as a plotter against the present government in Russia, was a forceful opponent of Joseph Stalin seven years ago when the latter's leadership was challenged by Leon Trotsky and Gregory Zinovieff.

AT Christmas, when good-will and peace fill the heart, remember the Neediest! To those in deepest want, Christmas will be only another day of heartache unless man's good-will toward man reaches out to include them. Tomorrow, on Christmas Eve, when carols ring and happy homes are bright, the Neediest will be close by -- around the corner, down the street, neighbors who wait in illness and loneliness.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- No end of minor complications have arisen over the Norris lame-duck amendment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP). -- The long burning dispute between Hugh S. Johnson and Donald R. Richberg, in the course of which the former resigned as Administrator of NRA, flared out tonight in an exchange over General Johnson's forthcoming articles on the recovery administration.

Announcements last week of securities to be redeemed before their dates of maturity were fewer than in recent weeks and the total principal amount was smaller. Only two small parts of issues were listed for the remaining days of December, while those called for later months were chiefly nine entire issues of bonds.

Marked by strong popular sentiment as an occasion both of retrospect and rejoicing, the Metropolitan Opera House opened last evening for its fifty-second year at the old stand, its accustomed splendors brightened by the annual colorful display and much new provision of individual comfort and social gayety.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 23. -- The arrests of fifteen more members of the Communist party, this time in Moscow, most of whom have been prominent in Communist politics since before the revolution, became known early today. Among them are Gregory Zinovieff and Lev Kameneff, the arrests of whom had been known unofficially for four days but not officially confirmed until today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 22. -- The first of the series of junior dances during the holiday season took place this evening at the Round Hill Club. Mrs. John Jay White was in charge. About 200 persons made reservations. Members of the committee of arrangements included:

Ship lines have spent thousands of dollars in the last two weeks maintaining a tradition of the sea. Those rescues in the recent Atlantic storms have meant delays in reaching port, extra pay and the use of tons of fuel oil to abate the heavy seas for lifeboats.
Al Ciullo, Brownsville lightweight, knocked out Georgie Goldberg, a neighborhood rival, in the first round of their scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Ridgewood Grove, Brooklyn, last night.

IN recent years the owners of great estates in England have been hard pressed to meet their taxes and other charges. Hence many large estates have been broken up while others have been rented to those who could afford to maintain them.

Work relief throughout the country costs the taxpayers nearly 50 per cent more than direct relief, it was announced yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board, basing its conclusion on a study of data recently published by the Federal Emergency Relief Administration.

LONDON. FOR those who are curious about the personal appearance and vocal mannerisms of living authors the book exhibition organized by The Sunday Times has provided a rare treat. It was open to the public for thirteen days, and on each day addresses were given by three more or less well known writers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Business activity continued to increase in the first half of December without interruption in the trend visible since October, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 22 (AP). -- The State of New Jersey, it was learned today from an authoritative source, will produce four and possibly five witnesses at Bruno Hauptmann's trial to testify he was in the neighborhood of the Lindbergh estate at Hopewell on or before March 1, 1932, when the Lindbergh infant was kidnapped.
PARIS, Dec. 21. -- Very seldom has any French Government laid its cards on the international diplomatic table so openly as this one has done during the past week.

NEW HAYEN, Conn., Dec. 22. -- The need for "the lawyer of vision and of broad training" is now imperative, according to Dean Charles E. Clark of Yale Law School whose annual report was put before President Angell today.

MADRID, Dec. 22. -- Although it was supposed to have the approval of former King Alfonso and the weighty support of the Duke of Alba, the monarchist restoration program, coupled with a plan for creation of a Spanish corporative State like Italy, has already fizzled completely.

Suit against stockholders of the Central Republic Trust Company of Chicago who live within the jurisdiction of the Federal Court of the Southern District of New York for the par value of their capital stock, approximately $500,000, was begun yesterday by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

AUTOMOBILE factories are entering the period when the shift will be made from second to high gear operation in anticipation of 1935. Advance showings of new models are to continue through next week, pointing toward full disclosure during the first week of the new year and at the New York show.

Another painting formerly in the Hermitage, the Russian National Museum in Leningrad, has entered an American collection. It is the well-known portrait by Rembrandt of his son Titus, which has been a Russian treasure since it came into the possession of Catherine the Great.

ROME, Dec. 22. -- In Rome, centre of Catholicism, Christmas is preeminently a religious festival. It is a feast more for grown-ups than for children. The Christmas-present habit, although becoming increasingly popular, is not an Italian custom.
ONE day in 1887, when Will Rogers was 8 years old, he scratched his head and solemnly told his parents: "If it wasn't for my pony and my rope I might grow up to be famous."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- City Controller S. Davis Wilson announced today that he would seek the removal of all former officials of Mitten Management from any association with the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company. These include Dr. A.A. Mitten, now chairman of the board, and Ralph T. Senter, president of the company.

IN poking good-natured fun at the popular song, past and present, Dr. Spaeth does not forget that no song can become popular unless it reflects, to some extent, the thoughts and the sentiments of the people for whom it is written. He is amused by the crudity, the vulgarity and the silly sentimentality of many of these songs, but he does not think it worth while to be indignant.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 22. -- Financial aid totaling $266,920.55 has been given to undergraduates by Harvard College during the past year.

WHEN government is spending millions for unemployment relief, why should private charity ask for funds and even double its efforts to win support? "When we pay the taxes that provide the public aid, why should we dig into our pockets for contributions to charity drives?"
ON the turn of the new year the Royal Academy will throw open its doors to an exhibition of art in industry such as has not taken place in England since the great exhibition of 1851.

AT least once in every year Bethlehem of Judea comes into its own and the eyes of the world centre upon the little town with uncommonly tender interest. This Christmas the interest is keener than usual because of a strange discovery made in the ancient Church of the Nativity, which covers the hillside grotto of the Christ-child's birth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The Republican Old Guard will not surrender to the younger element's demand that a meeting of the national committee be called to discuss liberalization of party policies it became apparent today, when Chairman Fletcher gave a negative response to the plea of Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Committee.

Language requirements for admission to the majority of medical schools in the United States and Canada are not sufficient to enable students to read adequately foreign scientific literature, Dr. Howard R. Marraro of Columbia University reports after questioning deans of seventy-nine medical schools throughout this country and Canada.

UNDER pressure of requirements laid down by State Departments of Education and by regional associations for the accrediting of schools, there has been a strong drift toward making the preparation of a teacher a matter of so many "hours" in the subject he is to teach, so many "hours" in education and so many "hours" in practice teaching.

THE Bulletin of the Detroit Institute of Arts is welcomed back into the ranks of museum publications with the recently issued October number. Publication had been suspended, due to enforced economies, in May, 1932, and is now to be resumed on a monthly basis, from October to May.

THE Right Hon. Winston Churchill has said that "these memoirs will rank among the most important and authoritative testimony upon the memorable episodes of the war with which they deal." Like Earl Beatty, Sir Roger Keyes ascended the ladder of promotion at the double-quick, so to speak.

VIENNA, Dec. 11. -- The "unco guid," having succeeded in sowing Austria as thickly with "Verboten" orders as Germany itself, are seeking for new evils to conquer. No longer is that pleasant Austria alive of which it used to be said:

A ROMANTIC house overlooking the River Mersey at Rock Ferry, Birkenhead, Cheshire, England, which was occupied more than eighty years ago by Nathaniel Hawthorne, is to be converted into a block of flats.

A taking steps to terminate the Washington naval treaty on Dec. 31, 1936, Japan has acted within its legal rights, but has nevertheless precipitated a new crisis in its relations with the United States.

A CURIOUS situation has arisen in the auctions whereby comparatively cheap books and manuscripts often go begging while the expensive ones evoke the intensest rivalry. Where but two or three bidders will be found striving half-heartedly to keep one another from a twenty or thirty dollar prize, it is almost invariable that when the stakes are increased to a few hundred or thousand dollars the galleries suddenly grow alive with eager-eyed competitors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- A report on questions that have held the attention of the United States and Great Britain since he was here about a year ago will be made tomorrow by Robert W. Bingham, Ambassador to Great Britain, to President Roosevelt.
BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- Even the fairy tales of old have been invoked to sell Adolf Hitler to the German people, according to the proceedings of the annual convention of National Socialist Teachers.
