ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- The committee on athletic control tonight restated Cornell's attitude toward football and expressed itself as unalterably opposed to the "buying" of football material but left the door open for the granting of scholarships to athletes provided that "character and brains remain the primary considerations."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Senate munitions committee is expected to file a preliminary report when it goes to the Senate next week for additional investigating funds of at least $50,000. The report will make grave charges concerning the operating and selling practices of the American munitions industry.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Republican, of Newburgh, announced today that at the opening of the Legislature in January he would introduce eight bills covering a variety of subjects headed by the mortgage situation and county government reform.

PARIS, Dec. 23. -- Deputy Philibert Besson, whose parliamentary immunity keeps him out of jail, made his usual flight to Brussels today before that same immunity ends with the close of Parliament. The Chamber and Senate will be closed before Christmas, so M. Besson cannot spend that day in France.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies received $97,762 last night from the clothing and allied industries here, as their contribution to the $2,071,000 the organization is raising for the support of ninety-one charitable agencies.

It seemed fairly certain last night that Arthur Taylor has a rather painful Christmas ahead of him because he thought one touch of lion made the whole world kin. Whether Arthur will admit it or not, he's no expert on lions. Trucking's his line, with headquarters at 878 Communipaw Avenue, in Jersey City, and lions are only incidental.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Led by J. Oakley Hobby Jr. of White Plains, chairman of the American Locomotive Company, who described himself as the pathfinder, nine members of the James King Hand Walking Association today held their forty-first annual hike to the Camp Fire Club at Briarcliff Manor.

Merchant ships throughout the world will be the scene of Christmas festivities tonight and tomorrow for travelers separated from their homes. Santa Claus will use funnels instead of chimneys as his means of entry, but his pack will be as well filled as though he had not been obliged to make the long trip to sea.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP). -The Chicago Cardinals of the National League today defeated the California Giants, State pro football champions, 21 to 0, before a crowd of 7,000 fans.

Contributions from 24,445 employes in fifty-three department stores of the city to the Citizens Family Welfare Committee total $66,000 to date, it was announced yesterday by James S. Burke, president of B. Altman Co., and chairman of the committee's department store division.

In the last week before Christmas, when publishers' sales usually are lighter than in the preceding two weeks, Alexander Woollcott's "While Rome Burns" again exceeded all records by selling 5,635 copies, Viking Press reports. The new Franz Werfel novel also went over 5,000 copies and, the publishers continue, more copies of two other Viking books have been sold in the first three weeks of December than in all November.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 23. -Anthony M. Hauck Jr., Prosecutor of Hunterdon County, charged today that a deliberate, malicious attempt had been made to tamper with the prospective jurors at the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., which is to begin here in little more than a week.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Canadiens of Montreal, playing like the flying Frenchmen of old, trounced the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, tonight in a rough and exciting National Hockey League match.
PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Despite light southeast winds the Manhasset Bay Dinghy Association held three races today for both Class A and B boats.

Mankind has always refused hospitality to its saviors, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick reminded worshipers at Riverside Church in his Christmas sermon yesterday morning. He then warned that "inhospitality to new ways of dealing with our economic life, new ways of thinking about internationalism, can ruin us utterly."

The cotton futures market was quiet last week, with prices fluctuating narrowly. The German cotton barter deal continued to hang fire under the scrutiny of the State Department in Washington. Exports showed some improvement and cabled dispatches stressed the increasing scarcity abroad of supplies of desirable foreign growths.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23. -- Seven members of a family were dead tonight in what police described as a case of murder and suicide by a mother whose grief over the recent death of a son drove her to slay a sister in Dunkirk, N.Y., and then to come here to carry on the slayings.

CHATHAM, Mass., Dec. 23. -Christmas greetings flashed across 8,905 miles of space early today, establishing what is believed to be a new record for long-distance radio code conversation with an airplane in flight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- There's been a lot of talk and dispute about relatives on the payroll, but apparently it hasn't bothered some members of Congress.

GENEVA, Dec. 23. -- Under Italian pressure, the League of Nations has withdrawn from the press room a map of Abyssinia made by the Italian Geographical Institute at Bergamo and showing Ualual, where the recent Italo-Abyssinian clash occurred, well within the Abyssinian frontier according to the 1897 treaty.

Public and private social agencies began yesterday to bring Christmas cheer to those who did not receive benefits from the business upswing that distinguished this year's preholiday trade from that of other years of the depression.

The suggestions of the Joint Conference for Business Recovery, assembled at White Sulphur Springs, were embodied in a "report," because the leaders could not determine whether to call it a "program," a "plan," a "platform" or what. The motive and scope of the report are stated as follows:
Christmas programs of various kinds are scheduled for today.

God's greatest gift to mankind was when, on Christmas Day, He took on the "rags of humanity," declared the Rev. Dr. William H. Rogers, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Broadway and Seventyninth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

The Cudahy Packing Company reported yesterday for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 27 net earnings of $1,968,262, equal to $2.97 a share, compared with $1,813,766, or $2.64 a share, earned in the corresponding previous period. Total net sales increased from $124,300,000 to $151,400,000, largely, according to a statement by E. A. Cudahy, president, because of higher market prices, although sales tonnage rose substantially.

The results of President Roosevelt's New Deal have been the exact opposite of what liberals have wanted from the extension of political democracy to the economic field, Dr. Harry F. Ward, Professor of Theology at Union Theological Seminary, reported in a survey released yesterday by the Methodist Federation for Social Service.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP). -Gold production in the United States, stimulated by revaluation of the dollar, apaprently skyrocketed this year to heights untouched since pioneer days.
BOSTON, Dec. 23 (AP). -- A special meeting of the stockholders of the Hamilton Woolen Company to consider liquidation of its Southbridge mill was called today by the board of directors for Jan. 15.

Ten-year-old Gloria Vanderbilt ended yesterday her first week-end stay with her mother, Mrs. Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, under the legal dispensation growing out of the suit over her custody. The pale, calm child spent a busy day up to the time a limousine sped her through the dusk back to the home of her aunt, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney.

"When Christ came to this world on Christmas night there was no room for Him in the inn, and in some of our homes today there is not much room for Jesue Christ," Bishop William T. Manning said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Winning six of the eight events, Brooklyn Prep scored an impressive 37-25 victory over St. Augustine's High School as competition in the fourth annual Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. dual-meet swimming championship tournament got under way yesterday in the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, pool.

Commodity futures markets were uneven in price movements last week, and toward the end of the period trading fell off because of the approach of the holiday. There were no important changes for the week in either direction. In the cash markets raw sugar, butter, eggs, rye, lard, hides and gasoline advanced, while refined sugar, wheat, corn, oats, flour, Rio coffee, cocoa, tin, silk and rubber declined.

A footnote on the printed program at the Camp Fire Club's dinner the other evening stated: "The trophies over the dais are loaned by the James L. Clark Studios and were taken this Fall by the J. Watson Webb party in the Rainey Pass section of Alaska under the auspices of the Alaska Guides, Inc. They are exceptional and should be viewed at close range."

TOKYO, Dec. 23 (AP). -- Although further details were lacking concerning the reported Soviet "invasion" of the Tungning district of Manchukuo, a remote locality with infrequent communications, officials at Tokyo and Hsinking said today they did not believe anything had occurred likely to cause a serious clash.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 23 (AP). -Unwilling to let up a moment in preparation for Alabama and the New Year's Day Rose Bowl football game, Coach C. E. Thornhill sent his Stanford pigskin warriors through a snappy workout today.

VIENNA, Dec. 23. -- A first-hand examination of the conflagration that recently threatened Southeastern Europe reveals a few embers still smoldering, but harmlessly, and no present danger of their blazing up again.
ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Dec. 23. -The action of Premier Boske Yeftitch in granting amnesty to Vladko Matchek, Croatian leader, caused the greatest satisfaction today here and in Belgrade.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Limited outside interest in speculative grain markets is having its influence on price-making efforts by leading local professionals. These traders are strong believers in high prices, but they hold that until more general interest is taken in all speculative commodities by outsiders a strong up-swing is not to be expected.

Community nursing services are bearing a large part of the responsibility of caring for the chronic sick. A census made by Mary C. Jarrett, secretary of the Welfare Council's committee on chronic illness, showed 6,400 patients to be under the care of nursing services. These patients represented more than 30 per cent of all patients.

A quick thrust by Frank McGaphan, which came so unexpectedly that players and spectators alike were bewildered, gave the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club hockey sextet a 3-to-2 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles in an overtime game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The Economist's fortnightly index of commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, stood on Dec. 19 at 65.7, against 65.4 a fortnight before, 64.7 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, when the gold standard was abandoned.

There are already more than two hundred cases in the courts involving the legality of one or another part of the New Deal. This statement was made by Mr. JOHN W. DAVIS in his radio address on Saturday. He had been asked to speak from the standpoint of a lawyer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23. -- Football stars of the East and West dug their cleats into practice fields today in the first intensive workouts that will lead up to the annual charity game here New Year's Day.

In its relations with Japan, America is confronted with the challenge "to show what the coming of Christ really means to us," it was asserted by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.

To those who have been caught up in the spell of the romance of old San Francisco add the names of Dan Totheroh and George O'Neil, whose "Mother Lode" was put on at the Cort Saturday evening. Since they are two of the most poetic spirits that have been hovering about our theatre the prospects of a romantic play from their pens have been uncommonly pleasing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Bulges in prices of oats last week brought sales of Argentine grain at the Gulf of Mexico as well as at Eastern Atlantic and Canadian ports, the latter being for Spring shipment, while grain arriving at Gulf ports was distributed in various directions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public seventeen new securities registration statements representing proposed issues amounting to $30,495,375, of which $4,901,875 are listed as commercial and industrial.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Gratifying evidence of better trade and consequent public spending power is provided this week by the rise of 8,750,000 to nearly 402,000,000 in the note circulation of the Bank of England. In the first post-war years the combined note issues of the Bank of England and the treasury exceeded this figure, but the present circulation is the highest since the amalgamation of note issues in November, 1929.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- The present trend of the large international movement of gold and the expansion of export trade of the United States clearly point to the fact that the dollar is considerably undervalued, according to banking opinion here.

HAICHOW, China, Dec. 23 (AP). -Three thousand coolie laborers who for many weeks have been building one of the nation's largest air bases here were nearing the end of their task today, an accomplishment of another step toward making far-flung ancient China the closely knit republic its modernizers dream of.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The intelligence, loyalty and high morale of the National Guard were stressed by Major Gen. George E. Leach, chief of the National Guard bureau of the War Department, in his report to Secretary Dern today for the fiscal year ended June 30.

IT seems there are certain folks so peculiarly gifted that popular acclaim falls to them even if they do nothing more than stand up and take a bow. Then, again, there are others who, though right enough fellows, square as they come and regular all the way through, do contrive to manoeuvre themselves into the most outlandish positions imaginable. Not infrequently they are just shoved into them.

A bouncing puck got by Roy Worters late in the third period and gave the Detroit Red Wings a 2-to-1 victory over the New York Americans in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Two Detroit players, Lorne Duguid and Tommy Anderson, had a hand in the shot that brought about the Simpson skaters' downfall before a crowd of 11,000.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- Judging by reports of the larger cities, Germany's Christmas trade is satisfactory and probably the largest since 1931, when, however, it was helped by credit inflation following the banking crisis.

The ultimate victory of the opponents of Reich Bishop Mueller and his "German Christian" movement in the church struggle in Germany was predicted yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, former president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, when he arrived on the steamship Europa.

In The Virginia Quarterly Review Mr. WILSON FOLLETT, whose brilliant work as a critic and an editor we remember with pleasure, recounts his salvation from "ultra-specialized" reading. He styles himself a "literary exdrunkard." He was saved by the good old books he returned to.
It seems to me that your editorial "Utilities Under Fire" is misleading.

BERLIN, Dec. 21. -- The Reichsbank's return for mid-December shows the repayment of 63 per cent of the November month-end credits. This repayment, which was above normal, was caused by the large repayments of Reich Treasury bonds which, in turn, were due to a heavy shrinkage in deposits which had fallen 200,000,000 marks since the beginning of the month.
We are at a dangerous crossroads. In high schools and universities the young are encouraged to believe that the end of the so-called capitalistic system is at hand.

An endowment of $10,000 for an annual award in the interest of aviation progress has been provided by Dr. Sylvanus A. Reed of New York, the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences disclosed yesterday. The winner will ge selected by the fellows of the institute and will receive a cash prize of $250 and a certificate of merit.

Further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried May contracts above 12 3/4 cents a pound, the highest quotation since September, but the market yielded under realizing pressure and closed with the list unchanged to 7 points net lower on the day.

Influence of the holiday was evident in a reduced business in credit. Barring routine requirements there was virtually no new lines opened in any section. Quotations, therefore, were carried forward without change.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24. -- Argentina's foreign trade increased 28 1/2 per cent in the first eleven months of this year over the corresponding period last year, according to the monthly report of the Bureau of National Statistics, given out tonight.
Mr. and Mrs. Alfred J. McCosker gave a tea dance yesterday in the Petit Salon of the Park Lane for their debutante daughter, Miss Angela F. McCosker. There were divertissements during the afternoon.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 24. -- A system of unemployment, sickness and accident insurance under State law, and establishment of a permanent State-wide system of poor relief, under a completely revised poor law, were advocated today by John Colt, chairman of the Administrative Council of the New Jersey Emergency Relief Administration.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 24 (AP). -- At this season, when peace and good-will are uppermost in the minds of the peoples of the world, it is but natural that we should ask ourselves how we may further this ideal, especially in view of the fact that distress and turmoil and fears of further calamities exist.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A rapid increase in the number of States which have enacted old age pension legislation in the last two years is shown in a survey made by Dr. Marietta Stevenson, assistant director of the American Public Welfare Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Tonight, in pursuance of a custom old and honored in many other families, the President will gather his kin about him at the White House fireside and read aloud from "A Christmas Carol." He reads as well as he speaks extempore. The same clear, cultivated voice, resonant with charm and intelligence, enriches and gives full meaning to the words that fall from his lips.

PALO ALTO, Calif, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The football warrior Stanford hopes will lead the Indians to victory over Alabama -- Fullback Bobby Grayson -- began pitching passes today to make the semi-final practice here a notable one.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Members of the Senate Steering and Policy Committees were reminded formally by their leader today that there was hard work ahead for 1935.
I am one of the "inarticulate mass of people" for whom Dr. Louis L. Goldblatt, in his philippic on socialized medicine, says he speaks. May I enter a protest? Dr. Goldblatt does not speak for me.

The interest in the educational program of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is gratifying. It was thought by the authorities when the free gallery talks were announced that there would be an attendance of not more than twenty-five or thirty at any one time, but the numbers have frequently exceeded 200 for single talks, with a total attendance of more than 10,000 for the ninety-three given during October and November.

With both teams at full strength, the New York Rangers and their intracity rivals, the New York Americans, will collide in the second game of their season's series tonight at Madison Square Garden. The Americans captured the series last year and hold a one-game advantage in the current race.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Tax records indicated today that not one machine gun or sawed-off shotgun had been sold by a legitimate dealer, except for law enforcement or military purposes, since the Federal firearms control law was enacted last Spring.
Christmas services were held at midnight last night in many of the churches of the city.

Four bulging parcels -- all fresh in their tinsel wrappings and plainly marked, "Do Not Open Until Christmas Night" -- are waiting temptingly under the Broadway tree this morning for their ribbons to be cut and their contents revealed. By smoothing down the wrappers, however the names on the tops may be read and they are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The United States should enter into no engagement with a foreign power to limit its naval defenses, Senator James Hamilton Lewis of Illinois told a radio audience listening over a National Broadcasting Company network tonight.

The legal action of the Merchants Association of New York, Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce and about thirty industrial concerns, charging that union longshoremen had refused to handle freight at city piers when carried by trucks manned by non-union labor, neared its termination yesterday when Walter Gordon Merritt, plaintiffs' counsel, filed his brief with Justice Burr Jay Humphrey in Kings County Supreme Court.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24. -- This is the third Christmas Bolivia and Paraguay have been at war and it is the first Christmas they are spending fighting. Both agreed to short truces in the two previous years.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The Labor Relations Board today held the Los Angeles Railway Corporation and the Los Angeles Motor Continued on Page' Nineteen. [ Coach Company in violation of section 7a of the National Recovery Act, which guarantees labor the right of collective bargaining.

BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The Mary T. Goulart, storm battered and with one of her crew missing, came into port here today to discharge a cargo of fish. At the same time another schooner, the Arthur D. Storey of Gloucester, docked with a tale of a terrific battle with high seas for the lives and safety of her crew of twenty-three.

Mayor La Guardia expressed the hope yesterday that college graduates would take the next examination for patrolmen with the object of being appointed city magistrates after rounding out several years of experience in crime detection and prosecution.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24. -- Registrations of motor vehicles in this country in 1934 show an increase over the preceding year for the first time since 1930, it was announced today by Automotive Industries. According to a preliminary survey made by this periodical 24,952,007 cars, trucks and buses were registered during the year, compared with 23,849,932 in 1933, a gain of 4.6 per cent.

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 24. -The fate of the Bennett tariff, especially those provisions which have greatly reduced the importation of United States textiles, is admitted in official circles to have been sealed by the revelations made before the Royal Commission on Business Practices before it adjourned over Christmas.

Out of the muddled tension of the contemporary world S.N. Behrman has spun a silken drawing-room comedy, "Rain From Heaven," with which the Theatre Guild celebrated Christmas Eve at the Golden. Under the rippling of the humor and the crackle of the wit it has a few sapient words to say about Fascism, Communism and Hitler's scourge of the Jews.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- An agreement authorizing the importation of Canadian hay duty free by a new private agency to relieve drought-stricken farmers in the Northwest has been signed by, Secretary Wallace.
Game breeders and sportsmen of the East are displaying considerable interest in an experiment in the rearing of prairie chickens at the State quail farm at Pittsburg, Kan.

EDGEWATER, N.J., Dec. 24. -- There were 2,000 men in line this morning at the Ford Motor Company plant here when word spread that a wholesale re-employment plan was about to be enacted. The company hired 720 of them before the "no help wanted" sign was posted.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 24. Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt of this city, dean of woman suffrage workers, announced today her annual choice of the ten outstanding women of the year. Mrs. Cart will he 76 years old on Jan. 9.

Allegheny County, Pa., announced yesterday that it will offer $9,175,000 of bonds for award on Jan. 2. On one lot of $7,298,000 the bidders are asked to name the rate of interest at not to exceed 3 1/4 per cent. This block will consist of $5,000,000 of bonds to be issued against uncollected taxes, $1,200,000 of road bonds, $870,000 of park bonds, $150,000 of court house extension, and $78,000 of work house extension bonds.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Dec. 24. (AP). -- The grim decks of Uncle Sam's fighting craft were transformed tonight into a fairyland for the visit of Santa Claus, who will welcome thousands of children aboard the ships tomorrow.

Holders of securities of the Central Public Service System were advised yesterday of the formulation of a plan of reorganization dated Dec. 1, which provides for elimination of all debts of the Central Public Service Corporation, the Central Gas and Electric Company, the Southern Cities Utilities Company and the Southern Cities Public Service Company.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica, Dec. 24. -- With the rest of the Christian world this remote community will joyfully celebrate Christmas -- perhaps more joyfully than most because two days afterward the supply ship of the Byrd expedition. the Bear of Oakland, will sail from Dunedin, N.Z., with the mail.
LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Britons will awake tomorrow, probably in a damp fog, determined to enjoy to the fullest what is proclaimed here as the most auspicious, prosperous Christmas since the World War.

W.H. Schlichter, 50 years old, an importer of fur trimmings and feathers, committed suicide yesterday in a seventeenth-floor room of the George Washington Hotel, 144 East Twenty-fourth Street. The body was found hanging by picture wire from a hook on the bathroom door by Joseph Corney, a clerk.
TOKYO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Four French-Canadian Roman Catholic priests, who were compelled to evacuate the mission at Amami Oshima because of anti-Catholic agitation, arrived today at Kagoshima.

Dr. Goldblatt states that the class of physicians supporting socialized medicine are mediocre; anxious to escape competition with their betters thus producing a state of "no more study, no experimentation, no sweating." Dr. Goldblatt implies that once the incentive of ample remuneration is removed all other incentives will automatically disappear.

Christmas is the children's own. Few of them know anything about the depression. To them this is a beautiful world, full of friends and kindness and of older people trying for the moment to be made like a little child in simple pleasure, clumsily playing antics with the boys and girls.

Removal of production restrictions on all except a few basic industries, full national encouragement to durable goods industries, stronger selling campaigns and development of better labor relations plans are among the steps advocated by the 125 magazine members of the Associated Business Papers, Inc., to speed recovery, according to a symposium of opinion released here yesterday by the group.

Moral principle rather than force must protect liberty against compulsion, according to a message on Christmas cards which have been sent to friends by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University. The message, headed "The True Liberal," follows:

SAARBRUECKEN, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A bit of bragging about the "good old United States" was heard tonight around Saar Christmas trees from American Saarlanders enjoying an old-fashioned German Christmas Eve with the home folks.

VIENNA, Dec. 24. -- Confidential advices to the Foreign Legations here revealed today that renewed efforts were being made by high personages in Rumania to induce Mme. Magda Lupescu, the red-haired "uncrowned Queen of Rumania," to leave the country.

WASHINGTON. Dee. 24. (AP). -- A desire to provide long-term credit for industry actuated the administration in its order reducing interest on bank deposits from 3 to 2 1/2 per cent, according to the explanation in Treasure and Congressional quarters.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Dec. 24 (AP). -- The Mary T. Goulart, one of Provincetown's old fleet of the opulent fishing days, coasted into this snug harbor yesterday with one of the most hair-raising tales in this port's tales of the sea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The dove of peace, draped in holly and Christmas mistletoe, hovered over Hugh Johnson and Donald Richberg today, and the controversy over Mr. Richberg's now famous letter to The Saturday Evening Post promised to dissolve in a sea of Yuletide good feeling.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24. -- Though Christmas has no official standing in the Soviet Union it is being extensively celebrated in Moscow by foreigners, especially by members of diplomatic missions.

VaIue of Dollar in Exchange. ] / The value of the dollar on the J } local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French! Crane on the days indicated, corn-I ares as follows. Quotations are! tn cents:

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24. -- A formidable attack against pagan tendencies in present-day Germany was delivered by Pope Pius XI today in an allocution to the Sacred College of Cardinals in reply to Christmas wishes offered to him in the name of all the Cardinals by the dean of the college, Cardinal Pignatelli.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Frank N. Belgrano Jr., national commander of the American Legion, told the nation today what the Legion wanted from the next Congress -- the bonus, benefits to needy widows and orphans of dead veterans, and universal wartime conscription.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Armed with a wooden model of a gun, similar to that used by John Dillinger in breaking out of the Crown Point (Ind.) jail, Benny Wojewodski of New York City tried unsuccessfully early today to escape from the New Haven County Jail after cutting the bars of his cell.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The cheer their Christmas lacked for two years has returned to the family of awakening Patricia Maguire.

WHEN Christmas troubadours gather beneath your window, singing about the First Noel and urging the faithful to come to Bethlehem, they inevitably conjure up visions of a child resting in the manger of a conventional stable -- say a thatched barn with troughs for oats and hay. All of which suggests that the modern Germans have no need to worry about the "Aryanization" of our religion, which has already been rather completely westernized.

The pigeons and the sparrows of Greeley Square sent Christmas greetings through their spokesman yesterday to Park Commissioner Robert Moses and to Allyn R. Jennings, landscape architect. Miss Clara J. Fisher, the spokesman, said the birds wanted to express gratitude for the fountain installed last Summer in the little triangular park in the square.
VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24. -- The Pope's Christmas remarks today were addressed, according to tradition, to the twenty Cardinals of the "curia," or that group of Cardinals who reside in Rome.

ANY day now news readers of these frozen climes should find themselves regaled with glowing accounts in the public prints calculated to bring warmth and cheer into their shivering souls. Just how much benefit a story of gay activity under a tropical sun may provide for a man with his nose buried in his overcoat collar as he plunges down a subway may be debatable.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Southern California's sports followers looked forward today to Christmas Day with its promise of the glamorous return of horse racing after twenty-five years' absence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- A tentative agreement on a cane sugar production program for the Hawaiian Islands, forming a basis for conferences expected to lead to withdrawal of litigation brought against the Agricultural Adjustment Administration by the Hawaiian Sugar Planters Association was announced today.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 24. -Princeton University received, through gifts and bequests, a total of $389,984.59 in the fiscal year ending June 30, 1934, President Harold Willis Dodds announced today in a report to the board of trustees of the university. Nearly two-thirds of this amount was presented as permanent endowment, the sum for this being $236,751.87.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24. -- Bequests of about $1,000,000, made by Hugh McAfee, glass manufacturer, turned out to be Christmas presents today for fifty hospitals, charitable institutions and persons when Judge Edward C. Chalfant signed the decree of distribution in Orphans Court.

On the eve of the annual holiday week gathering of intercollegiate athletic leaders in New York, Cornell University's frank statement of football policy, coupled with a bid for alumni support along clearly defined scholarship lines, yesterday was welcomed by sports observers as a distinct contribution toward clearing the gridiron atmosphere of hypocrisy.

The heads of two large rubber companies, William O'Neill, president of General Tire and Rubber, and P.W. Litchfield, president of Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, declared yesterday the tire business stood a good chance of improving in 1935.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The Treasury's holdings of silver were unofficially estimated today at just over 1,000,000,000 ounces, or still almost 1,000,000,000 short of the amount needed for a 2575 ratio with the gold monetary reserve.

Major Ramon Franco, Spanish aviator who took part in the revolution which overthrew the monarchy and resulted in the abdication of King Alfonso XIII, arrived yesterday on the Navemar of the Garcia Diaz line from Barcelona to study commercial and military aviation in the United States.

The first eleven railroads to report for November showed net operating income of $13,230,000, against $15,924,000 in November, 1933, a drop of 16.9 per cent, and against $13,183,000. in November, 1932, an increase of 0.4 per cent. In October, their net was $18,915,000, against $21,116,000 in October, 1933, a decline of 10.4 per cent.

Prices of stocks moved higher yesterday in a market larger than usually precedes a holiday. The trading on the Stock Exchange involved a total of about 810,000 shares, against 917,000 shares on last Friday. Dullness was the rule in other speculative markets as well as in bonds.

Due to the holiday the number of visiting buyers registered in town during the week ended today showed a large decrease in comparison with the number reported for the previous week. However, the total was slightly above the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in The Times.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Tiny Tim was a guest at the White House tonight. He rode into the Roosevelt family circle on the shoulder of Bob Cratchit out of the pages of Charles Dickens's "Christmas Carol" as the President followed his Christmas Eve custom of years by reading the beloved Yuletide story.

Eighteen games have been listed for the City College varsity baseball team for the season of 1935, according to the schedule issued yesterday by Professor Walter Williamson, college manager of athletics. Eleven of the games will be played at the Lewisohn Stadium, the other seven away from home.

Slight gains were shown by commodity futures in yesterday's market. All the Exchanges which were opened for business, except the Coffee and Sugar Exchange, closed at noon. The Commodity Exchange, Inc., was closed all day. In the cash markets wheat, corn and rye advanced and lard went to a new high price level.
Mrs. Frances Heenan Browning and Bernard J. Hynes, theatre manager of Denver, were married late yesterday afternoon by Justice of the Peace Charles W. Wilson at Tuckahoe, Town of East Chester, N.Y.

Albert H. Fish. 65-year-old house painter, held in Westchester County Jail on an indictment charging him with the murder of Grace Budd in 1928, may repudiate the confession of this crime announced by the New York police, Carl J. Heyser of Port Jefferson, L.I., counsel for the accused man, indicated yesterday.

Pitchers who went to American League mounds to play a relief role in 1934 enjoyed marked success in their endeavors, according to figures just released by the junior circuit's service bureau, which cites them as having won "527 per cent of their games."
Holiday shoppers here had their final opportunity for pre-Christmas shopping yesterday, and they took advantage of it in a big way.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 24. -- The fear that charges of jury tampering would delay the opening of the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann for the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was allayed somewhat today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Thousands of persons throughout Westchester County participated in Christmas Eve celebrations tonight in various municipalities. There were nine Christmas trees in the county jail at East View and scores of others in Grasslands Hospital, the county penitentiary and the county home.

An accounting suit brought by two stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation against Charles M. Schwab and other officers and directors of the company was dismissed yesterday by a unanimous decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- About sixty of the largest banks, insurance companies and building and loan associations in New York City and Westchester County have formed an association to protect their equities in Westchester real estate, it was announced today by Louis B. Joyce, executive secretary of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Development of a superpower project in the Mississippi and Ohio River Valleys, which would place cheap electricity with modern living conveniences in every farm home of the Middle West, is contemplated in a bill Senator Shipstead will introduce in Congress next month.

The Department of Public Welfare is negotiating with the Board of Education for the establishment of a free liberal arts centre at what was formerly the American People's Theatre, 257 West Fortieth Street, by the concentration there of the principal music, arts and dramatic projects now being carried on under the works division by formerly unemployed actors, artists and musicians.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Final hearings on Canada's claim for $386,803 damages because of the sinking by an American Coast Guard cutter of the rum runner "I'm Alone," will begin before a mixed commission on Friday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 24. -- Youth in both Russia and Germany has betrayed the hopes held for it by showing itself to be ruthless and anything but idealistic, Rabbi Samuel Blumenfield, registrar of the College of Jewish Studies, Chicago, told 300 delegates to the annual convention of Avukah, American student zionist federation, here tonight.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A 61-year-old locomotive engineer, veteran of forty years of railroad service, was charged by officials of his railroad today with responsibility for the train crash near Delaware in which he and two other railroaders died Sunday.

WILDWOOD, N.J., Dec. 24. -- Two Wildwood fishermen, after suffering from exposure for two days while confined to their open skiff at sea, were rescued by a New York Coast Guard cutter late today and will spend Christmas Eve with their families.

The dramatic nation-wide drive against drug addiction being carried on by Federal law enforcement agents is being paralleled by an attack on the same problem by medical scientists, reports Science Service. If the scientists succeed, there will be no further need for the legal fight, because the scientists are pushing ahead in efforts to achieve a non-addicting substitute for morphine, says the writer.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 24. -- Fritz Thyssen, German industrialist, who recently broke with the Nazis and left Germany, has been here for several weeks. He says he made the trip to look after his private interests as well as business of the company he heads.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. James T. Terry of New York and Southampton, L. I, were hosts today at a tea in their residence on Sea View Avenue. They entertained their guests with a program of Christmas carols, sung at dusk, by a male quartet composed of Romanies, Clegg Monroe, chorus director, accompanied them. Guests included:

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Despite the absence of many members of the Stock Exchange, the market was cheerful and fairly active today, prices improving practically in every section. There was fresh support of British funds and old consols were strong.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Operators on the Board of Trade here were more interested today in merriment than in the grain markets, but the latter showed a firm undertone from the start, wheat closing 1/8 cent a bushel lower to 1/2 cent higher, while corn was 1 5/8 cents higher for December and 3/4 to 1 cent higher for the distant futures.

A counterfeiter of commemorative coins, something new in the experience of Alan G. Straight, head of the Secret Service here, came to light yesterday with the arraignment of Nicholas Derevitzkay before United States Commissioner Cotter.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Charles Klein, young Deputy Attorney General credited by Governor Pinchot with conducting the investigation "which led to the resignation of several members of the Public Service Commission," became a judge of the Philadelphia Orphans' Court today.

Winning two more matches and taking all of the seven games finished in the third and fourth rounds, the City College team maintained its lead in the annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League for the Harold M. Phillips trophy at the Manhattan Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Two Brooklyn fur dressing concerns were found by the National Labor Relations Board today to have violated Section 7a of the National Recovery Act when they closed down their plants and moved them to points outside New York City and by so doing refused to continue collective bargaining negotiations pending with their employes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Practically completing its procurement plan for the fiscal year ending next June 30, the War Department today awarded a $1,655,394 contract to the Douglas Aircraft Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., for seventy-one high-speed observation planes.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- In a statement directed to Senator Huey P. Long, Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund, said today that not a college or university in the South should be included in the first twelve of the United States on the basis of scholastic output and eminence of faculty.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24. - Alabama's powerful football team, which will face Stanford in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day, reached the battlefield today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Eastern and Western stars speeded their workouts today for the annual charity football game here on New Year's Day.

CHARLES TOWN, W.Va., Dec. 24. -- Reigh Rose. 3-year-old daughter of the famous Reigh Count, captured the Kent Mere Farms Purse, feature race today, after leading throughout the entire mile and a sixteenth run.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The administration's fight to end poverty was hailed today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, in a Christmas message to the public, which read as follows:

A large West Side apartment house and a midtown theatre were among the five Manhattan and four Bronx properties bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction yesterday. Two scheduled sales of West Side houses were adjourned.

BERLIN, Dec. 24. -- A white Christmas came to Germany today, and everywhere there is rejoicing because it makes the day complete. It is a kindly, gentle snow which seemed to fall merely in order to make Christmas trees more picturesque and bring into brighter relief the glow of candles shining through innumerable windows.

Mrs. Charles Aubrey Cartwright gave a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the Valdorf-Astoria. Her guests were Mrs. Kiliaen Van , Rensselaer, Ars. VVillard S. Brown, i Mrs. Frederick Lewisohn, Mrs. %Vi]liam 1%. Coe, Miss Louise B. Scott and Miss Lucile Thornton.

With no intention of poking an intruding nose into a private matter that should have been kept private, one may venture on this day of peace and joy, to note that the Coordinator got yesterday from the former Administrator of NRA a telegram of Christmas greeting and replied to it in a spirit worthy of the festival.

Senator GLASS, watchdog of the Federal Reserve System, has come down hard on the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for their joint announcement of a week ago ordering a reduction to 2 1/2 per cent in the maximum interest rate paid by the banks on time deposits.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Designed to make the compensation of disabled veterans go further, a plan to establish the former soldiers in low-priced country homes took definite shape today.

The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club hockey sextet, Eastern Amateur Hockey League leaders, will clash with the Lewiston Cyclones of Lewiston, Me., in an exhibition game at Madison Square Garden this afternoon.
BETHLEHEM, Tuesday, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Jubilant bells of Bethlehem and "hallelujahs" of thousands of worshippers hailed the advent of Christmas early this morning at the Church of the Nativity.

More than $150,000 was recovered by the city this year from recipients of old-age pensions, William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare, revealed yesterday. Some-had received relief fraudulently and others had been able to make refunds from money acquired through settlement of estates, he said.

Opening night at the Metropolitan Opera House, said THE TIMES reporter, did not show many young faces. The debutantes and their gentlemen friends were more interested in the holiday dances that were going on all over town.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Prices of hogs advanced 25 to 40 cents a hundredweight today to the highest level since July, 1928, the run being much below the trade's expectations. Quotations were maintained to the close. The top was $6.65. Most sales were at $5.85 to $6.60.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Louis Brock, 42 years old, a Los Angeles motion picture director, wants the custody of his daughter, Constance, the 9-year-old child over whom her mother and maternal grandmother have been fighting in Supreme Court here for more than a month.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP). -- World swimming marks are given little chance to last out the year as some of America's greatest mermaids seek new records here Dec. 30 and 31 and Jan. 1 in the third annual national Olympic stars' aquatic meet.

Considering that yesterday was the eve of the most important holiday in Christendom, the business done in New York and elsewhere was of fairly satisfactory volume. The turnover on the Stock Exchange exceeded 800,000 shares. All the markets will be closed today, but business will be resumed tomorrow.

A will bequeathing $1,250,000 to charity was filed for probate in Queens Surrogate's Court yesterday on behalf of a retired clothing manufacturer who throughout his life-time shunned organization activity of all kinds and who, when he wrote a check for philanthropic purposes, made sure that no one knew about it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- A long-standing dispute over title to the Rapidan, Va., camp, where former President Hoover rested and sometimes carried on affairs of State, was settled today out of court.

The defense finished its testimony yesterday at the General Sessions trial of Mrs. Mary Colucci, 43 years old, of 121 Chrystie Street, accused of shooting to death her husband, Joseph, on June 12 in a Third Avenue elevated train.

" Forsaking All Others," an adaptation of the play by Frank Cavett and Edward Roberts, begins an engagement today at the Capitol. Heading the cast are Joan Crawford, Clark Gable and Robert Montgomery.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Mrs. A.T. Cragin's 3-year-old filly, Double Nugget, a 15-to-1 shot, scored easily in the fifth race, the feature of the program at the Fair Grounds today.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24. -- Christmas will be just another work day for members of the Tulane and Temple football teams, which will battle here on New Year's Day for Sugar Bowl honors.

A Santa Claus for animals only waited patiently yesterday in front of the Humane Society for a horse to come along. Seated on a bale of hay, with a bucket of red apples at his side. Santa watched the motor traffic stream along Seventh Avenue and mused on the machine age, which has left but 20,000 horses in New York, and precious few of those around Fourteenth Street.

PARIS, Dec. 24. -- There are indications in the French press that the French Government's attitude toward Germany's claim to have legalized a larger armament quota than is prescribed by the Treaty of Versailles is different from that of its predecessors.
The opponents of socialized medicine seeing their case fail from a practical point of view are forced, by the process of argumentation, to delve into the realm of metaphysics.

MONTREAL, Dec. 24. -- Though scoring by Toronto slumped in the past week in the National Hockey League, Harvey (Busher) Jackson, Maple Leaf left wing, was able to hold command in the individual figures released tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Currency inflationists are planning a conference here to consolidate their position and attempt to force a showdown in Congress, under advice from one of their leaders that whatsoever "truce" the President may have had with business is over now.

Resale of a West Hudson factory and purchase of a dwelling for part of the plaza leading to the entrance to the new tunnel to uptown Manhattan were the outstanding realty transactions in New Jersey reported yesterday.
VIENNA, Dec. 24. -- This Christmas probably finds more mourning homes in Central Europe than at any time since the wounds of the great war began to heal.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 24. -- Gloria Vanderbilt played hostess tonight at the home of her aunt, Mrs. Harry Payne Whitney, at a Christmas Eve party to her cousins, the children of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson and Mr. and Mrs. Berklie Henry, all of whom live on near-by estates.

The city is thoroughly justified in its move to build a municipal light and power system to escape the rates charged it by the utilities, Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the State Power Authority, declared yesterday.
A Wall Street broker received the distinction yesterday of being America's best-dressed man in an informal selection by a jury of tailors, according to The Associated Press.

Mrs. James Tilley Houghton and Mr. and Mrs. Wharton Poor gave a tea dance yesterday in the ballroom of the Pierre for their debutante daughters, Miss Carol Prichitt and Miss M. Frederica Poor. The hostesses and their daughters and Miss Sarah Sanford received near the entrance to the ballroom against a background of arborvitae trees and Australian ferns.

A dinner dance was given last night at the Pierre by Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Kipp of Passaic, N.J., for their debutante daughter. Miss Peggy Kipp. The debutante, who received with her parents, wore a gown of white taffeta and carried orchids.

For nine of the Neediest Cases in all New York this Christmas will be a time of peace and joy. Three large gifts arrived yesterday designated for those nine cases and providing completely for them through the coming year.

In homes, in offices, in stores and on the streets New Yorkers joyously anticipated yesterday the gayest Christmas in years as the confident word was passed from mouth to mouth that the depression was dead, dead as a door nail.
ALBANY, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Christmas Eve found most members of New York State's official family at their firesides in other parts of the State.
ELKO, Nev., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Three children and the pilot were found dead today in the snow-covered wreckage of an airplane which crashed in a mountain storm sixty miles north of here yesterday.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 24. -- The body of Mrs. Loretta Wilson, 19 years old, of 265 West Twenty-first Street, New York City, was found this afternoon in a clump of scrub oak on the west side of the Port Jefferson-Coram Highway, three miles south of here.

An iceboat club has been formed among members of the Larchmont Yacht Club. This marks the first time that this cold weather sport ever has sprung on a substantial scale from within one of the large water-racing clubs. The organization is to be known as the Larchmont Iceboat Club.

President FRANK W. SMITH of the New York Edison Company must have startled many of those who listened to his radio address on Sunday or read his published statement in Monday morning's newspapers when he gave the figures covering the taxes currently paid by the companies composing the Consolidated Gas Company system.

In the brave days when the relation of bacteria to disease was still both an alarming and a reassuring discovery, the great PASTEUR thought of collecting micro-organisms from a hot-air balloon and thus throwing some light on the manner in which epidemics spread. Such were the difficulties that he contented himself with conducting experiments at elevations as high as 6,500 feet in the Jura Mountains.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 24. -- The racing silks of the W.C. Winfrey Stable were carried to victory twice today at Tropical Park as Impromptu won the second race and Stone Martin captured the fifth before a fairly large pre-holiday crowd.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 91 leading cities on Dec. 19 shows increases for the week of $367,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations, $54,000,000 in other securities, $572,000,000 in government deposits and $19,000,000 in time deposits, and decreases of $215,000,000 in net demand deposits, and $107,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Gifts from afar -- flowers, dolls, beds and a hundred varieties of toys -- were taken into the Dafoe Hospital here over the weekend and prepared for the Christmas of the Dionne quintuplets, Marie, Emile, Cecile, Annette and Yvonne.
ROME, Dec. 24 (AP). -- Premier Mussolini vigorously defended Italy against Abyssinian charges of waging aggressive warfare in the desert region of colonial North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- Chairman Nye of the Senate committee investigating the munitions industry will confer Wednesday with President Roosevelt on legislation to take the profits out of war, the Senator said tonight.

To my mind one of the most amazing evidences of the lack of appreciation of our whole governmental structure is that displayed by the Federal Power Commission in its latest decree respecting public utilities.

;Yoseph Clark Baldwin 3d will return today from France with Mrs. ]aidwin and their baby On the Ile de France of the French Line. Henry J. Allen, former GOvernor of Insas, is also on board with rs. Allen.
An injunction suit by the national heads of the pro-Nazi Friends of the New Germany against leaders of the "revolt" of the New York local of the league was disclosed in Supreme Court yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 24. -- The selection of William H. Sullivan, '35, of Allenhurst, N.J., as captain and Robert H. Everitt, '35, of East Orange, N.J., as manager of the Princeton varsity polo team for the coming year was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of the Princeton Polo Association.

In the slowest trading since Nov. 5, the listed bond market fluctuated within narrow limits yesterday. Trading on the Stock Exchange lived up to its characteristic dullness on the eve of Christmas with a turnover of only $8,970,700. Dealings in United States Government bond amounted to only $770,700, with most of the closing prices irregularly lower.
Wall Street trading floors shone with Christmas decorations yesterday with transactions carried on at times in an effulgent atmosphere worthy of the season.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- Samuel Sharfstein opened his wine and liquor store at 315 Saw Mill River Road at 8 o'clock this morning, greeted Norman Zeitsoff, his clerk, and smiled inwardly in anticipation of a rushing Christmas Eve business.

EATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 24. -- Bearing Huey Long's "O.K.," Bernie Moore on Jan. 1 will step into the shoes of Captain Lawrence (Biff) Jones, who resigned as head football coach at Louisiana State University following a tilt with the "Kingfish."

A pantomime setting of Bach's Christmas Oratorio that united music, dancing, poetry and the arts of the stage to produce a presentation moving in its simplicity, and wholly suggestive of the spirit of the day, began this morning one minute after midnight.

LONDON, Dec. 15. -- Christmas furnishes a good pretext for an interval in the drama of international politics. The curtain has come down. Behind it, however, there is activity; scenery is being rushed into position and the actors are hurrying to their appointed places.

A three-month term in the workhouse was imposed in Special Sessions yesterday on Mary Dorrington, 78 years old, a retired trained nurse of 91-38 109th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens, for having defrauded the city by obtaining an old-age pension in 1931 when she had enough money to maintain herself.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 24 (AP). -- Loss of the schooner Jean Smith in Friday's blow was reported by her crew when they landed at Codroy, Nfld., today. The schooner, a Newfoundland vessel, was bound for Gloucester with a cargo of herring.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The House Military Affairs subcommittee investigating War Department transactions recommended today that the Mercur Corporation, operators of the army base property at Newark, N.J., be required to make "a strict accounting in the courts" of its operations.
Scattered snowflakes falling between 6 A.M. and noon yesterday prevented the white Christmas legend from becoming entirely a myth in New York.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., Dec. 25. -Harold G. Hoffman, Governor-elect of New Jersey and State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, spent Christmas Eve and Christmas quietly with his wife and three daughters in their home at 178 Broadway, here.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 25. -The gayest Christmas here in many Winters was marked today by many dinners, dances and parties, including family gatherings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Laughing children this morning scrambled over the large bed in the White House, where on every other morning of the year President Roosevelt dispatches the first business of his crowded days.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- The legislatures of forty-three States which meet next month were urged today to coordinate all welfare activities so as to work more in harmony with the Federal Government's social and economic program.

Mr. and Mrs. Dean Emery of Short Hills, N.J., gave a dinner dance last night in the Park Lane Hotel to present their daughter, Miss Isabel Valle Emery. The hostess and her daughter received in the reception room, which was lighted by candles and festooned with evergreens.

Renewed criticism of our unbalanced budget has come in the last few days from HENRY H. CURRAN, Professor E. W. KEMMERER and former Secretary MILLS. The latter, pointing to our huge floating debt and the fact that the budget has now been out of balance for five years, declares that the groundwork has been laid for a potential bank credit expansion of $88,000,000,000 or even $125,000,000,000.

The Christmas item at the Rialto is a dynamic little melodrama called "Murder in the Clouds." With complete disregard for the Yuletide note of peace on earth, it presents a nice assortment of cutthroats, swashbuckling heroes and ladies in distress.

Passenger travel in the intercoastal service returned to the 1930 levels during the past year, according to a summary published yesterday by the Panama Pacific Line, a subsidiary of the International Mercantile Marine Company. A renewed popularity of the higher priced quarters combined with a reduction of rates in producing the result.

The Christmas Day response to the appeal for New York's Neediest Cases was very heartening. Yesterday's mail brought 452 contributions, totaling $7,447.55. This amount was considerably more than the receipts on the same day last year. Thus the Fund's "deficit" was cut down again, although the total, $205,144.55, is still short of last year's total at this date.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, with characteristic generosity, piles its Christmas basket with box-office goodies in "Forsaking All Others," which enjoyed a lyric holiday reception at the Capitol yesterday. The new photoplay offers three of the cinema's most eminent exponents of glamour, Miss Crawford and the Messrs. Gable and Montgomery, in a technically flawless screen comedy which promises to delight a vast public as heartily as it will irritate the discriminating filmgoer.

The annual review of registration in American colleges by President RAYMOND WALTERS of University of Cincinnati is of more than usual interest this year. It reflects a new factor in college attendance, especially in the freshman year. Nearly 100,000 students have been enabled by the Federal Emergency Relief.

CALLANDER, Ont., Dec. 25 (AP). Among the many Christmas greetings received by the Dionne quintuplets on their first Christmas day was one from "the grand old lady of Dalhousie Lake," Mrs. Mary Ferguson McIntyre, who is 101 years old.

Mr. A. P. HERBERT, one of the most delightful playboys of Mr. Punch, novelist, playwright, barrister who has never taken any but Misleading Cases, loves to defend the rights of Englishmen. He whacks bureaucracy and the divorce laws. The licensing regulations annoy him.

STONY CREEK, N.Y., Dec. 25. -Children in this Adirondack hamlet of about 300 inhabitants today are proudly fondling dolls and beating upon drums, their Christmas presents, made possible by Sam Coplan, Brooklyn toy salesman, who for the last twenty-six years has been playing Santa Claus to the needy of the North Country.
SEDALIA, Mo., Dec. 25. -- The explosion of a match at a Christmas party started a fire which cost the lives of three children and their mother and severely injured two other persons today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- Economic and social theories of the New Deal will be appraised by leading social scientists of the nation in meetings of twelve learned societies which open a joint program in Chicago tomorrow. The meetings will last until Saturday.

ISTRES, France, Dec. 25. -- Raymond Delmotte, French speed pilot, flying here today, is believed to have set a world speed record for land planes when he averaged 502.465 kilometers [312.22 miles] an hour. Official declaration of a record will not be made until the plane's instruments are verified.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The administration's policies on recovery and the broad questions for consideration in the next Congress will be shaped by President Roosevelt when he confers tomorrow with his Cabinet and economic advisers.

There were several parties for debutantes last night, the largest being the supper dance that Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Dounton Williams and Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Holmes Brown gave jointly in the roof garden of the Pierre for their daughters, Miss Janet Brevoort Williams and Miss Barbara Brown.

Being in a dressing-gown mood Samson Raphaelson has written one of those comedies that dance on the border-line between the theatre and life, "Accent on Youth," which was put on at the Plymouth last evening. His principal character is a celebrated playwright; what happens in his private life becomes intricately involved with his talent for theatre technique.
The whole world -- London steeped in fog, Berlin covered with snow, New York under gray skies that shook down occasional flurries -enjoyed a happy Christmas yesterday.
ATLANTA, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Definite progress toward financial stability of State governments marked 1934 in the agricultural South.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP). -- A movement among governments throughout the world toward closer control of agriculture seems to be broadening, as the situation is presented by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The bureau keeps watch upon international developments.

A thrilling dash by Frank Boucher, with only a second left to play, climaxed the New York Rangers' victory over their city rivals, the Americans, in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The blue-jerseyed sextet, warming up to its task after a rather slow start, carried off the honors by the score of 3 to 1, evening the city series at 1-all.

The second in the revived series of Dolphin Dances was given last night in the main ballroom of the Pierre and drew an attendance of many young people in society, including debutantes of this year and next season. The dances originally were arranged for girls who will not be introduced to society for another year or so, but now several debutantes of the current season are among the subscribers.

Bishop Manning, Cardinal Hayes and other church dignitaries officiated in Christmas Day services yesterday, as large throngs turned out to fill many of the city's churches and to hear pleas from the pulpit for altruism and unselfish devotion to their fellow-men.

In an atmosphere reminiscent of the days of their prime, 200 aged and indigent men and women put aside their cares yesterday and gave themselves up to feasting, merriment and reverence in the quarters of the Advertising Club at 23 Park Avenue.

With two black eyes and a bruised and swollen face, Charles L. Railey, 29 years old, of 680 Madison Avenue was arraigned yesterday in Yorkville Court charged with having robbed three young couples in automobiles at Sixty-fifth and Exterior Streets, near the East River front.

An aged man and a young mother were in a serious condition yesterday in two Brooklyn hospitals as a result of attacks upon them by burglars who tried to rob their homes late Monday night. In both cases the thugs fled without taking anything.

An imposing delegation of young tennis stars from many schools and colleges will invade the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, today. Seventy-three will seek the national junior indoor singles championship, while seventy-nine others will begin play in the national boys' tourney.

Ganudensio Cesine, 83 years old, father of Mrs. Mary Cella, president of the Eastern Bergen Woman's Republican Club, was killed by a hit-and-run motorist in front of his home at 156 Bergen Boulevard in Fort Lee, N.J.. last night, according to The Associated Press.

Now that the Tiny Tim department is home and in bed, the legion of the faintly damning can again walk the streets of Times Square. Write down, as Item A, the play called "Piper Paid." which last evening lighted the Christmas decoration for the Ritz Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- As an indication of the improvement resulting from the Federal Housing Administration campaign it was announced today that building permits in 772 cities showed modernization work in November amounting to $13,071,000, as compared with $8,110,000 for the same month last year, a gain of 62 per cent.

Yielding to the wishes of the British, George R. Jacobus, president of the Professional Golfers Association of America, announced yesterday through The Associated Press that the 1935 Ryder Cup matches would be played at the Ridgewood, N.J., Country club on Sept. 28 and 29.
TORONTO (Wednesday), Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- W. A. Kingslands, vice president and general manager, central region, Canadian National Railways, issued the following statement early today:

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Business progress in 1935 will be influenced to a large extent by monetary stabilization, cooperation between capital and labor and coordination of governmental and private business aims, according to Frank Purnell, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

The holiday theatre goes on to numerous attractions today -- morning, afternoon and night, adult and juvenile. The three larger parcels for the attention of the elders (not necessarily, of course) will make their appearance as follows:

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25. -Beautiful afternoon, marvelous race track, magnificent, stanch and sleepy old mountains in the background (sounds like Graham speaking). It is all of that. And some of the coyotes that I was persuaded to make a small wager on are as stanch and sleepy as the mountains.

SAARBRUECKEN, Dec. 17 (AP by Mail). -- Two mines dug by the French under the Franco-Saar frontier serve as a guarantee that Germany will pay France for the territory's mines in an unusual experiment in international dickering.

Dr. Hugh S. Magill, president of the American Federation of Utility Investors, announced yesterday that the organization planned to petition Congress in protest against government competition in the public utility industry.
Radio listeners enjoying a program of Christmas entertainment yesterday afternoon from Station WOR heard this appeal broadcast at 4 o'clock:

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- King George, speaking as "the head of this great and widespread family, sharing its life and sustained by its affection," broadcast his Christmas greeting to the whole British Empire this afternoon.

MONTREAL, Dec. 25 (AP). -- The Toronto Maple Leafs jammed a 6-to-2 defeat into the Montreal Canadiens' Christmas stocking tonight and gave a holiday crowd at the Forum a smart demonstration of why they are leading the international group of the National Hockey League.

The forthright declaration of Ambassador Troyanovsky in Yokohama that he was confident that Russia and the United States would soon settle their debt problem gave rise here yesterday to the belief that a formula for settlement had been arrived at and that soon after M. Troyanovsky reached Washington the agreement would be announced.
Controller-elect Frank J. Taylor denied last night a published report that he would select this week the heads of the various bureaus which will enforce and collect the new relief taxes.
Walter Duranty is at work on a new book, largely autobiographical, which Simon Schuster will publish, they hope, next Fall.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25. -- Anticipating a dazzling display of tricky football when Tulane meets Temple here New Year's Day in the inaugural Sugar Bowl game, Coach Ted Cox today put his big Green squad through a hard defensive drill, while ninety miles north at Baton Rouge Pop Warner continued work on the Owls' offense.

I must have overlooked the defense of the classics in Topics of The Times, but I have just read the commentary on it by Rita Lenihan. I wonder if in the discussion in the universities proper weight is given to the factor, not easily perceptible but overwhelming, that, though we call ourselves Americans, Englishmen and Frenchmen, we of the Western World are in fact as much Greeks and Romans as Pericles and Caesar.

Four persons were injured, one of them seriously, in a fire that burned out the basement and first floor of a four-story rooming house at 114 East 121st Street early yesterday. A short circuit in the electric lights on a Christmas tree caused the fire.

The city's present move to build a municipal power system for its lighting and power needs closely parallels the action taken by the Board of Transportation prior to the opening of the new Independent Subway. When the board in 1928 and 1929 proposed building a municipal subway power plant it obtained from the New York Edison Company a 15 per cent reduction in its bid for the power contract.

MOSCOW, Dec. 25. -- The Communist drive against the remnants of the old Trotsky-Zinovieff opposition has taken a new direction with a demand for the purging of all such elements from the faculties of Soviet schools and colleges.

AGNES ROTHERY'S "Images of Earth: Guatemala" (Viking, $3) is a curious mixture of the good and the bad. When Miss Rothery is conveying information, or describing mountain and jungle, or setting vivid vignettes before you, she is both interesting and charming; when, on the other hand, she attempts to write fiction about people she has encountered in Guatemala, she indulges in the sort of sentimentality that can only be spoken of as tear-jerking.

The New York Civic Orchestra will play at the Museum of Natural History this afternoon a program of Christmas music by RimskyKorsakoff, Rebikoff and Tchaikovsky, with an air from "Aida" sung by Louise Taylor.

Captain Gerald Lowry, the first British officer to lose his eyesight in battle after England entered the war in August, 1914, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, accompanied by his wife and Colonel J. L. Sleemen, Chief Commissioner of St. John's Ambulance Brigade Overseas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- Telephone users who are disgruntled over the extra charge made for the appliances known as "French phones," those transmitters and receivers combined in one piece which replaced the old desk set have ground for cheer.
Betty Gow, the nurse who put the Lindbergh child to bed the night he was kidnapped, returned here yesterday on the Aquitania from Glasgow to testify at the murder trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann.

In a hard-fought game before a holiday crowd of 1,500 fans at Starlight Park yesterday Brookhattan defeated the Brooklyn Hispanos to gain two points in the American Soccer League's annual championship competition.

I was interested in the editorial comment on the size of a person's vocabulary, and particularly in the quoted assertion that the average reader of newspapers and magazines can recognize the meaning of from 25,000 to 35,000 words.

The wind was freshening to a wintry blast in the Chinatown narrows yesterday afternoon. A bootblack operating under a striped canopy had his oil stove going full blast, and was huddling over it for comfort. Upstairs at 3 Pell Street the Old Bucks and Lame Ducks Club, remote from scenes of economic stress, sat placidly smoking after an abundant dinner, waiting to see what Santa Claus and "Mr. Zero" had in store for them.

ELLAVILLE, Ga., Dec. 25 (AP). -A 17-year-old negro, hunted as the slayer of Chief of Police W. B. Souter, was captured in the swamps near here tonight and hurried for safekeeping to a jail whose location waa undisclosed by his captors.

MANILA, Dec. 25 (AP). -- The Philippine Islands possess the "most important source of war material under the American flag," the United States Senatorial mission declared today in a memorandum released by Senator Millard Tydings of Maryland.

Speaking of vocabulary, in a single issue of THE TIMES recently I found more than seventy words I did not know. By "know" I mean that I could define satisfactorily or use in a sentence illustrating its meaning. And that was only one day! Here are some of the words:

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25. -Coach Frank Thomas went into executive session with his University of Alabama football players in the Rose Bowl today. "No admittance" was the sign on the one unlocked gate and the curious found the sign meant just what it said.

When Santa Claus distributed presents yesterday afternoon at a Christmas party of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, 2 East 105th St., more than 150 boys and girls under 16 years of age were rapturous with joy and enthusiasm.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25. -- New Deal, the 3-year-old gelding which has turned in some excellent performances for James W. Parrish this season, ran a fine race at Tropical Park today to account for the handicap which topped the holiday program.

BERLIN, Dec. 25. -- Christmas as the celebration of the birth of the Christ-child may be replaced in the Third Reich by a new pagan observance of the Winter solstice if some of the expressions and practices of Nazi officials and organizations should impose themselves upon the German people.

Norma Shearer and George Arliss are England's favorite screen players, according to a poll of about 125,000 film-goers there, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The late Marie Dressler was second among the actresses and Clark Gable was second among the men.

In a world where the celebration of Christmas has become somewhat stereotyped there remained in this city yesterday at least one rugged individualist. He stayed home and made himself some lima bean soup and liked it.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- Toys, provided by the Westchester Child Welfare Bureau, were distributed today to several hundred needy boys and girls in Westchester County. Some new toys had been bought by the bureau, while other playthings had been donated by friends and repaired by the bureau staff.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (Canadian Press). -- The Arsenal displaced Sunderland at the head of the English League First Division soccer standings as a result of today's games.

One point in your editorial "How to Live on 20,000 Words a Year" raised a question in my mind. That is, if it requires a vocabulary of 20,000 words to read The London Times, how many does it require to read THE NEW YORK TIMES? I feel that it would require considerably more, though I know of no figures to prove it.
MOSCOW, Dec. 25 (AP). -- Christmas was "just another day" in Soviet Russia, where the government will have nothing to do with religion.

Gloria Vanderbilt and her bodyguard arrived at 49 East Seventysecond Street at 10:25 yesterday morning and left about seven hours later after the 10-year-old girl had celebrated Christmas with her mother, an aunt and a wide-eyed cousin half her age.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP). -The Public Works Administration today checked over allotments of $47,000,000 already made for municipal power plants and renewed an offer to assist cities whose projects of this kind were challenged in the courts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- A level of industrial output better than usual for November was recorded today by the Federal Reserve Board in its regular survey of business for the preceding month.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP). -- His squad back in shape after a series of illnesses and injuries, Coach C. E. (Tiny) Thornhill today announced the end of heavy scrimmaging for his Stanford football players who are preparing for the Pasadena Rose Bowl game.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 25 (AP). -- Displaying a brilliant running and passing attack that left its opposition bewildered, Scott High School of North Braddock, Pa., routed the Miami Stingarees, 26 to 13, in an intersectional football contest today.

At a time when great public projects are being promoted and exploited, it is quite simple to prepare, and release in franked government envelopes, through the press and otherwise, an attractive prospectus. Investors know from experience the difference between estimated and actual earning power.

In your editorial "Wholesale Inflation" an effort is made to answer certain questions concerning the distinction between characterizing the expansion of currency and expansion of interestbearing government bonds as wholesale inflation. I do not believe that your editorial meets the issue squarely.

John Strachey, English author, lecturer and a Communist, arrived yesterday on the Aquitania accompanied by his wife, formerly literary editor of The London Spectator. He is here to give a series of forty lectures in the principal cities and will deliver the first one at Mecca Temple on Friday.
