ALBANY, Dec. 25 (AP). -- His Christmas holiday over, Governor Lehman will hurry back to his desk tomorrow to begin one of the most important weeks, politically, of his career, a week which will begin for him a new term with a Democraticcontrolled Legislature to do his bidding.

Only two passenger ships, the French liner Ile de France and the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, reached port yesterday. Customs men were at the Hudson River piers when the ships arrived and hurried through the formalities of examining trunks and bags so that the 732 passengers were able to hurry off by train and bus to belated Christmas reunions.

For so many years all the rest of the country looked to New York for its theatrical entertainment that it has been hard, especially for the East, to reconstruct its point of view. The South, the West, the Middle West, known to New York as "the road," adapted itself readily to movie, carnival and radio amusement, with a sprinkling of serious "little theatre" activity.

After a lapse of seven years Paul G. Waner, crack outfielder of the Pittsburgh Pirates, came back to win the batting championship of the National League, according to the official averages for 1934, released for publication today.

Raymond Rose, watchman for a meat packing concern in Jersey City, has returned a $1,500 diamond ring he found ten years ago and will have his reward, it became known today. Rose is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two sons at 196 Pearsall Avenue, Jersey City.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 25. -Mrs. Ernest Thompson Seton, author, traveller and lecturer, of Greenwich stated today that she would file counter claims for divorce in Mexico or Connecticut against her husband, of Santa Fe, N.M., who has brought divorce proceedings against his wife in Mexico.

HAMILTON, Ont., Wednesday, Dec. 26. -- At least fifteen persons were killed and at least forty to sixty injured when a Canadian National Railways express train crashed into the rear end of a standing passenger train at Dundas, Ont., seven miles west of Hamilton.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Emperor Hirohito presided today at ceremonies formally opening the regular annual session of the Japanese Diet.

A four-day national conference on Jewish welfare work will begin here Jan. 3 with a luncheon at the community house of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street. Felix M. Warburg will be general chairman of the conference, which has been called by the National Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds.

WITHIN recent years there has come into being in baseball something of a new office, and perhaps it might be well to point out to the alert and ambitious young men of the game that possibly here is something more worth while than the job they usually set as their goal.

Since he took great pleasure, as the phrase goes, in presenting "Fools Rush In" for the first official time last night at the Playhouse, it seems but courteous to reply to Mr. Brady this morning that it is a pleasure to have it around.

Thousands of New York families had a brighter Christmas yesterday because New York newspapers raised $437,000 for dinners, toys and relief. Many more families will be sustained by the funds throughout the coming year.
A letter printed in your editorial page today tries to prove an economic notion by taking a segment out of the economic cycle.
New York City was host yesterday at one of the biggest Christmas parties ever held, according to a statement issued by William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 25. -- An autopsy on the body of Mrs. Loretta Devine Wilson, found in a thicket here yesterday, revealed today that she had died as a result of an illegal operation. An inquest will be held tomorrow.

Columbia University's chess players, aspiring to displace City College as champions of the Intercollegiate Chess League, made a distinct gain in yesterday's two sessions of the annual tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club and, at the close of the day's play, had a slight edge on their rivals, when the champions failed to complete either of their two matches.

MEXICO, D F., Dec. 25. -- President Lazaro Cardenas today predicted increased Federal income for 1935. He has sent Congress a budget estimating the total at 275,800,000 pesos [the silver peso is currently quoted at 27.85 cents], only 2,000,000 short of the 1930 high-water mark.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (AP) -Rip Van Winkle, a six-year-old bay gelding, displayed speed in a stretch drive today to win the featured mile and a sixteenth Christmas Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
Scoring twice in each period, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club hockey sextet downed the hardskating Lewiston Cyclones, 6 to 0, in an exhibition game at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The United States is being progressively enticed into the League of Nations, contrary to the expressed will of its people, Representative George H. Tinkham of Massachusetts said in a statement issued today. Mr. Tinkham contended that this country's acceptance of membership in the International Labor Office would be followed soon by entrance into the World Court, preliminary steps, he argued, to full membership in the League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Official and unofficial Washington observed Christmas at home today. As always in the capital, it was a quiet celebration and one varying but little in diplomatic or American households.
DETROIT, Dec. 25 (AP). -- The Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 2 to 1, in a thrilling National Hockey League match before a crowd of 10,000 tonight.

Plans for a council of fifteen to draw up a coordinated hospital program for the city, in accordance with a recommendation of Mayor La Guardia, were announced yesterday by Dr. S. S. Goldwater, Commissioner of Hospitals.

The Metropolitan Opera Association gave yesterday a Christmas matinee performance of Humperdinck's "Haensel und Gretel" before a big audience, in which children predominated. The renovations in the opera house, which have added much to the comfort and brilliance of the scene, were in turn admired by the younger generation, whose elders at last Saturday's "Aida" had shared in the opening spectacle of the new season.

In the general Christmas benevolence, the leaders of Congress promised the country a gift. This is to be in the form of a short session. The chairmen of important committees are to put their heads together and, in conference with the President, decide what is to be the very minimum of legislation.

The increase recently in the consumption of nickel gives promise that the absorption of this metal may yet attain the record established in 1929, according to Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.

With Miss Geraldine Farrar making her debut as radio interpreter for the Metropolitan Opera, the opera went on, literally with a thud, yesterday afternoon and, although the thud caused a short interruption, it failed to mar the presentation of "Haensel und Gretel," either for the 3,000 children in the house or for the radio listeners.
NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 25. -Three persons were injured when a mysterious explosion demolished a three-story wooden house and shook the entire centre of the city here early today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25. -- Many forward passes were tossed today by the all-star aggregation of Western football players preparing for the annual New Year's Day charity football game with outstanding Eastern athletes.
SAN PEDRO, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP). -- The personnel of the United States fleet played host today to 1,500 youngsters, many of them from poor families in San Pedro and Long Beach.

A plea to rename the village of Bronxville in Westchester County, a plea poetically stated in American Speech, linguistic quarterly published by the Columbia University Press, failed to move Arthur W. Lawrence, son of the credited founder of the village, last night.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 25. -- High Glee, C. V. Whitney's 3-year-old filly, celebrated the return of horse racing to Southern California today with a surprise victory in the $5,000 added Christmas Day Stakes before 50,000 spectators.

Your editorial "How to Live on 20,000 Words a Year" goes to the heart of a very real problem. I have been a country lawyer for over forty years. I recognized from the first the necessity of a large vocabulary in a practice covering all sorts of subjects, and based my studies in that line on good fiction -Dickens, Thackeray and Scott -- as well as other lines of reading.

"I read with extreme interest and pleasure your recent appeal to lovers of wild life to give a thought to our feathered friends in the cold months ahead," writes Roger Cory Peterson. "With the spirit of Christmas abroad, I think it especially fitting that all of us extend peace and good-will to winged creatures as well as our fellow men.

The city should be freed of the mandatory State laws that protect the overstaffed and overpaid county offices and which "hamstring" the Board of Estimate in making the annual budget and tax levy," the Citizens Budget Commission declared in a statement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- A new issue of about $75,000,000 in Treasury bills dated Jan. 2 was announced by Secretary Morgenthau today. The bills will be used to retire an issue of about the same amount maturing on that date.

FORT ERIE, Ont., Dec. 25 (Canadian Press). -- For a few brief hours today Mrs. Josephine Ortenzi and one of her twin sons, Dello, were reunited with the husband and father, Barnabas Ortenzi, and two other children, Mary and Rinaldo, at the Fort Erie ferry landing.
BOSTON, Dec. 25 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons battered the Boston secondary defense men to gain a 5-3 victory over the Bruins before 10,000 spectators tonight at the Boston Garden.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 25 (Canadian Press). -- Still pondering prospects of new regulatory measures in 1935, traders on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange saw today one of the most active and exciting years in the annal of the Exchanges slipping into history.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 25 (AP). -- Esker Lee Gilpin, 19-year-old St. Louis high school football star, was found fatally wounded in a home two doors from his own early today. Police quoted the owner as saying he had fired several shots, believing a burglar to be in the house.

Yesterday between 11 and 12 in the morning as New Yorkers and other residents of the Eastern standard time belt went about their leisurely Christmas duties they heard over the radio the Los Angeles Symphony Orchestra under OTTO KLEMPERER playing BRAHMS.

One of the most encouraging factors of the 1934 realty year has been the strong interest in well-situated suburban property. The announcement yesterday of a large deal in Shrewsbury, N.J., seems to indicate no lessening in demand as a result of the holiday season, and brokers report that the new year doubtless will show greater interest in country homes.

GENEVA, Dec. 25. -- For nine years the League of Nations has kept an official on duty Sundays and holidays against the possibility of an emergency arising somewhere in the world requiring urgent attention. Today for the first Christmas this "peace sentinel" had to announce the arrival of telegrams reporting there was not peace on earth.

One fact is obvious after seeing the new Revue Folies Bergeres, which had its gala premiere late Christmas night at the refurbished French Casino, formerly the Earl Carroll Theatre. The production of it definitely sets a high-water mark in elaborate, expensive and spectacularly varied cabaret entertainment in New York since the repeal of prohibition.

About $5,000,000 gold has been bought abroad in the last few days for shipment here, bringing to $207,000,000 the amount imported or engaged for import since Nov. 1. Imports of $1,750,100 gold, $1,360,000 from England and $390,100 from India, were received yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

It has long been a Communist maxim that the end justifies the means, that a dictatorship of the proletariat cannot be firmly established without a ruthless suppression of free speech, in the sense of fundamental criticism. Events in Russia illustrate what inevitably happens under such a policy.
BOSTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Edward A. Filene, merchant and economist, described the outlook for 1935 as "at the same time very bright and very dubious" and pointed to several "two-way signs."

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Manon," with Mme. Lucrezia Bori, Richard Crooks. Givseppe De Luca and Leon Rothier in the leading roles, this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House which has been taken over to raise funds for Sir Wilfred Grenfell's Mission in Labrador.

Treasury statements recently have shown at one point a striking change. This is a sharp decline in expenditures charged to the Federal Emergency Relief Administration. They amounted last month to less than $30,000,000 and thus far in December to less than $27,000,000, compared with more than $100,000,000 a month for the period from August to October.

In his speech the day before Christmas Mr. ROOSEVELT'S citation of ANDREW JACKSON as "the embodiment of courage" inevitably, without intention on his part, suggested his own most striking quality. JACKSON'S patriotism, chivalrous spirit, love of the people, are Mr. ROOSEVELT'S also.
After a stormy hour of discussion yesterday of the city's relief activities the Board of Estimate authorized the expenditure of $38,498.990 for relief in January and February.

If we listen to statesmen we learn some remarkable things. Each wishes for his own country no more than "reasonable" protection for its industries. Each wishes to see once more the free flow of world trade. But, alas! the other countries are perverse. They depreciate their currencies, they subsidize their exports, they erect fantastic tariff barriers, quotas, exchange restrictions.

The principal article of furniture in the study of the Rev. Cornelius Fitzsimmons, pastor of the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Fourteenth Street and Avenue A, is a billiard table. The principal ornament on the walls is a cuerack.

BURLINGTON, Wis., Dec. 26. -Entries from liars from all over the world began arriving here today for the international competition of the Burlington Liars Club. There were contestants from England, Turkey, France, Italy and even China.
Another cold wave arrived in New York last night. The Weather Bureau said it probably would send the mercury to 10 degrees above zero by this morning, and might be accompanied by snow flurries.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- A resolution urging that France decline to accept any renewal of her naval ratio provided under the Washington Naval Treaty was adopted unanimously today by the French Academy of Marine and forwarded to the Minister of Marine, Francois Pietri.

Controller-elect Frank J. Taylor will, if he can do so legally, use relief workers to staff the city bureaus to be set up to collect the city taxes imposed to raise funds for relief, it was learned yesterday.

Prices on the commodity futures markets were generally higher yesterday on the resumption of trading after the suspension over Christmas. The volume of trading was not large. A sharp advance in cottonseed oil futures was a feature. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, rye, oats, lard, cocoa and eggs were higher while cotton and silk were lower.
LONDON, Thursday, Dec. 27. -The Warsaw correspondent of The London Daily Express reported yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Use of a picture of President Roosevelt in an advertisement by the Schenley Distilleries has caused the White House to take action in accord with the practice to refuse to permit the President's portrait to appear in connection with advertising.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (Canadian Press). -- The long holiday grind for the English Football League clubs was over tonight, with matters pretty much as they were.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- Governor Lehman is expected to recommend to the Legislature, soon after it convenes next Wednesday, that New York State abandon the practice of borrowing money for unemployment relief.

General Hugh S. Johnson, former NRA Administrator and author of a forthcoming book in which it is said important Washington figures are dealt with in plain terms, attacks "hero-sniping" in a book review in the current issue of Today.
MANILA, Dec. 26. -- Four American scientists managed to reach Tawao, Borneo, today after five day adrift without water on the Sulu Sea.

The post-holiday market for bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday was comparatively quiet, with prices moving irregularly lower. Trading amounted to $11,531,700, of which dealings in United States Government direct and guaranteed obligations accounted for $3,355,700.

In 1933 WASHINGTON'S Birthday was celebrated in Connecticut by a deal between Old Guard Democrats and Republicans, equitably dividing between the two sets of patriots a lot of minor judgeships, appointment to which is made by the General Assembly. This was done over the head of Governor CROSS, and in the teeth of public opinion, as was soon amply shown.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (AP). -Dealt a crushing blow by the loss of their halfback ace, Duane Purvis, Coaches Dick Hanley and Andy Kerr revised the back field and battle plans of the Eastern team today, meanwhile speeding up practice for the East-West charity football encounter to be staged New Year's Day.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 26. -The annual holiday dance at the Round Hill Club tonight was attended by 150 members of the younger set, home from schools and colleges. There were several dinner parties preceding the dance.

SNOW HILL ISLAND, Weddell Sea, Dec. 26. -- Our second Christmas in Antarctica has come and gone and still our objective, a transantarctic flight, is not in sight. Clouds still hang low over Snow Hill Island, clearing sometimes to the east or west, but to the south the dullness of the heavens seems permanent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Reciprocal tariff treaties with Brazil, Colombia and Haiti, the chief countries from which we import coffee, are expected to be signed next week. They will be the first concluded since that signed with Cuba last Fall, the only other one completed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -Five publishing companies joined today in asking the Supreme Court to reconsider its recent decision under which they would be forced to stand trial on charges of having violated the Sherman anti-trust law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- In their recommendations to the President the business men who gathered last week at White Sulphur Springs did not disapprove "useful public construction projects not created primarily for the purpose of relief." They struck at what they called "wasteful public works" created for that purpose, and Administrators Ickes and Hopkins decided that the shoe fit them, as was made plain by their harsh comments on the recommendations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Federal Trade Commission's investigation of the electric and gas utilities, which already has covered companies with total assets of $9,930,000,000, will be continued next year with particular attention to natural gas and pipeline companies.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- Arthur [Dutch Schultz] Flegenheimer, who was released Friday on $75,000 bail on charges of revenue tax evasion, will appear before United States Commissioner Lester T. Hubbard tomorrow. A decision is expected soon as to whether Schultz will be taken to the jurisdiction of the Federal Court of the Southern District of New York.

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein leaned back in his chair in sombre Jefferson Market Court yesterday and watched as Francis Hunt, a 200-pound patrolman, gave his version of a "hootchy-kootchy" dance on the witness stand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- An estimate that the value of conservation work done by the Civilian Conservation Corps up to Sept. 30 totaled more than $291,000,000 was made today by Robert Fechner, director of the corps.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26. -- Kept alive since Spring by repeated blood transfusions and persistent efforts of her impoverished parents to find relief, Roma Garrett, 5, of Peekskill, N.Y., was buried today after living almost to the minute the life span which doctors gave her.

Plans have been tentatively agreed upon for cooperation between the city and the Federal Government in building power plants here and for an interchange of electric current, Maurice P. Davidson, Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, indicated yesterday.

Governor Lehman has been requested to incorporate in his message to the Legislature suggestions for legislation to establish higher moral and social standards in the motion picture industry. The request was made in a letter, made public here yesterday, from the committee on motion pictures of the Social Service Commission of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this diocese.

Despite the readiness of hundreds of persons to give blood to save her life, Olga Farber, Bronx schoolgirl for whom a radio appeal for blood donors was broadcast on Christmas afternoon, died at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at Beth David Hospital.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 26. -Houston will pay tribute to Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, tomorrow, when a bronze bust of the financier will be presented to the public library.

In reading Colonel John Buchan's "Montrose" I find, among many wise and quotable things, the statement that Falkland had given true conservatism its motto: "When it is not necessary to change, it is necessary not to change."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The sales tax, centre of half, a dozen conflicts in Congress, was pushed forward again today by a Republican member of Congress as a method for raising funds to meet "increasing" expenditures.

The liner Manhattan having arrived in port last Sunday, and its skipper having failed to get any action from the Atlantic Ocean which has been in a notoriously peaceful mood of late as we have all read, he thought it would be nice to observe Christmas by going up in an airplane and see what motion and vibration are really like.

Pay no attention to the morose sentiments that find lodgment in this column this morning. Aimee and Philip Stuart, who wrote "Nine Till Six" and "Lady Clara," have now written an emotional drama about a maid of 16 who sickens at the thought of her widowed mother's remarrying.

HAMILTON, Ont., Dec. 26 (AP). -A "misplaced switch" was blamed tonight for last night's Canadian National Railway's disaster, in which fifteen persons were killed and thirty-one injured at Dundas, Ont., seven miles west of Hamilton.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 26. -- The American Editorial League, denounced by striking employes of The Newark Ledger as a company union, was organized here today. Articles of incorporation were filed with the Essex County Clerk. It was said the league planned to organize units throughout the nation.

I read in THE TIMES a statement by Professor Edwin R. Embree that no Southern college or university is great enough for national recognition. As a student of the College of William and Mary I resent this statement. William and Mary has an AAA rating in the National Education report of last year, a position as high as any college in the country.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 26. -- A panel of forty-eight talesmen, including twenty-one women and twenty-seven men, was drawn today for the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, charged with the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. The trial will open here next Wednesday.

Commissioner Davidson made an impassioned radio plea to save the city and the nation through lower rates for electricity. Why such bunk when a 50 per cent saving to the average householder would be no more than 5 cents a day -- the price of a morning and evening New York newspaper?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Unification of the country's entire supply of electricity under Federal control, linking publicly and privately owned production in a system designed to promote economy and stability, was recommended today by the President's Mississippi Valley committee in its report to the Public Works Administration.

Contending that the price of scrap copper has declined while that of new material has increased, the Code Authority for the NonFerrous Scrap Metal Trade has demanded that the NRA make a thorough investigation into activities of the custom smelters, large users of scrap, it was made known here yesterday.

There has been a large subscription for the annual dinner dance in behalf of St. Vincent's Hospital which will be held tonight at the Central Park Casino under the auspices of the Ladies' Auxiliary of the hospital. Proceeds will further the work of the institution in caring for destitute patients.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26. -- Charges that the slaying of Sergei Kiroff, Communist Political Bureau member, on Dec. 1 was part of a general plot to overthrow the present Soviet leaders both by internal terror and intervention of capitalist countries were made tonight by the Soviet Government.

In concluding their seventh annual mid-Winter meeting on Monday, Jan. 21, members of the New York State Bankers Association will give a dinner in the Hotel Roosevelt for Joseph A. Broderick, retiring State Superintendent of Banks.

OTTAWA, Dec. 26. -- Canada has become the chief beneficiary of the Ottawa agreements, in that month by month she sells more in British Empire markets, but as a buyer she gives her custom increasingly less to the empire than to the United States, according to trade figures for the eleven months ended Dec. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- An assertion that there is no question of the authority of the Federal Reserve Board to fix the interest rate on time and savings deposits in member banks, under provisions of the Banking Act of 1983, and that its recent action related only to such banks, was made tonight by Marriner S. Eccles, Governor of the board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP). -Railroads serving New York Harbor petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today to modify its decision in the New York lighterage case to permit them to maintain competitive rates between the New York lighterage zone and New England without extending such rates to include Northern New Jersey points.
Four matters requesting attention tonight in the still fevered local theatres:
OKMULGEE, Okla., Dec. 26. -- A meteor split the noonday brilliance of the skies in three Southwestern States today, causing several persons to report that they had seen an airplane fall in flames.

Action by holders of voting trust certificates of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company on the proposed agreement between the Interborough and the Manhattan Railway Company for division of equity in a unification deal with the city was postponed yesterday until Jan. 7 because proxies for a majority of the certificates had not been obtained.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today granted the reinstatement application of George Pipgras, Boston Red Sox pitcher, and denied the claim of the Brooklyn club to services of player John Vander Meer of Scranton.

Net operating income of the New York Central Railroad dropped $107.080 in November from the amount reported for the same month in 1933, bringing the decline for the eleven months this year to $3,450,797. Gross revenues for the eleven months ran $9,987,210 ahead of the total for the same period last year.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- Requests for tickets for the second inauguration of Governor Lehman continue to pour in to the Secretary of State's office, although the capacity of the Assembly Chamber, where the ceremonies are to take place on New Year's Day, is only 1,750.

HALIFAX, Dec. 26. -- A fifty-mile gale snapped the towline between the Belgian steamship Emile Francqui and the salvage tug Foundation Franklin shortly before midnight tonight and the rudderless freighter was being driven toward the treacherous Sambro Ledges while the tug was trying to put another line aboard.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The administration is trying to work out a program for extension to purchasers of electrical equipment throughout the nation of the benefits received by residents of the Tennessee Valley from the operation of the Electric Home and Farm Authority, it was said at the White House today.

King GEORGE made a Christmas Day plea for a new sense of unity in the British Commonwealth. This was perhaps partly intended as a reminder of the coming Imperial Jubilee celebrating the twenty-fifth year of His Majesty's reign. Yet one part of the British Empire remains aloof and sullen.

The Misses Patricia Wood and Dorothy Ordway made their debuts last night at a dance in the Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria given by their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Hill Wood, and Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gilman Ordway. Miss Wood wore a gown of white tulle and carried an elbow cuff of mignon roses, and Miss Ordway, white tulle and silver lame and she carried a Colonial bouquet of white and silvered flowers.

A modified reorganization plan for the $10,205,307 Series Q issue of guaranteed mortgage certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler. Under the modified plan the issue, which covers 847 mortgages in Queens and Nassau Counties and is held by 3,248 certificate holders, will be managed by three trustees selected by the certificate holders.

The volume of business done in the first quarter of 1935 will be moderately larger in most lines, in the opinion of editors of leading industrial publications as revealed in a survey by Associated Business Papers, Inc., according to The Associated Press.
Notices were issued yesterday for 17,000 bales and a sufficient quantity of cotton came back on the market to depress prices 3 to 9 points at the finish on the Cotton Exchange.

Erie County, N.Y., announced yesterday that it will offer a new issue of $2,750,000 on bonds for award on Jan. 3. The projected financing will consist of $1,500,000 of tax revenue bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1935 and due from 1936 to 1940, and $1,250,000 of unemployment relief bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1935 and due from 1936 to 1945.

It seems to me that the recent events in Shelbyville, Tenn., are of a particularly heartening nature. True, there was a mob filled with barbaric frenzy, but that, unfortunately, occurs all too frequently in the United States and in some other countries. The heartening aspects of the matter are:

When Casey Stengel's Dodgers make their first 1935 appearance at Ebbets Field some of the Flatbush fans may take a look at one of the outfielders, rub their eyes in astonishment and exclaim that Hack Wilson is back.

Magistrate David Hirshfield called a parrot to the witness stand in Bay Ridge Court yesterday to establish its identity. Those familiar with the annals of the Brooklyn magistrates' courts could not remember a similar incident.

Daily average crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,423,150 barrels, compared with 2,418,850 in the preceding week, a rise of 4,300, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 8,100 barrels in the daily output of California and an increase of 7,050 in Texas were the most important changes.

Resuming business after the Christmas holiday, the Stock Exchange saw its business expand yesterday but with a small shrinkage in quoted values. Neither the enlargement in trading activity nor the decline in prices was considered extensive enough to indicate any change in Wall Street's attitude toward the markets.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- The National Recovery Act has failed markedly to attain its objective, according to an analysis made by economists of the Brookings Institution of Washington. They told a meeting of the American Economic Association here today that the NRA, regarded as one of the important elements of recovery a year ago, now presented a problem as "it is now seriously questioned in important ways by every agency concerned."

A slight increase in the average tax rate of leading cities in the United States and Canada in 1934 was offset by a reduction in assessed valuations, according to C. E. Rightor, director of the Atlantic City Survey Commission, in his thirteenth announced compilation of comparative tax rates.
The New York Stock Exchange firms of Lapham, Holden Reimer and Walter J. Fahy Co. will be consolidated on Jan. 1 under the firm name of Lapham, Fahy Co., it was announced yesterday.

Justice Henry L. Sherman of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, who died July 11, 1933, left an estate appraised at $536,786 net in the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday with the State Tax Department. The gross estate was appraised at $655,007.

GLASGOW, Dec. 26. -- Reinforced guards were ready tonight to prevent a renewal of rioting in Barlinnie Prison here, where dissatisfaction over curtailment of exercise periods and prohibition of smoking caused disorders in the last few days.

Magistrate Overton Harris was derided with a "Bronx cheer" and with a chorus of boos and hisses by 400 spectators in the Essex Market Court yesterday at a hearing for nine women and five men arrested Dec. 18 for disorderly picketing in front of S. Klein's, 6 Union Square.

The revival of Richard Strauss's "Der Rosenkavalier," a special New Year's Day matinee of "Tannhauser" and the debut of the new Italian lyric tenor, Dino Borgioli, in "La Boheme" on New Year's Eve will mark the second week of the Metropolitan Opera season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The decision of the Navy Department not to use stainless steel in the new airplane carriers Ranger, Yorktown and Enterprise applies only to the gasoline tanks of these vessels. It does not apply to the use of stainless steel for equipment which does not come into contact with salt water as did the interior of the Ranger's tanks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Seven arguments against payment of the veterans' bonus were presented to President Roosevelt today by Henry Goddard Leach and James E. Boyack, editor and associate editor of The Forum, which has been campaigning against cash payment.

Melvin C. Eaton, chairman of the Republican State Committee, has flatly rejected the demand of Chase Mellen Jr., chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, for a meeting of all the Republican County chairmen in the State, to work out a legislative program for the Republican minority in the State Legislature at the 1935 session which will open at Albany next Wednesday.
A unique plan to guarantee the permanency of public fishing and hunting in Connecticut was proposed by Thomas H. Beck at a recent meeting of the State Association of Fish and Game Clubs.

Fair response to Winter apparel clearance events featured post-holiday retail trade here. Cloth coats and fur garments received the greatest attention. Rain affected volume, but inasmuch as trade here suffered from a snowstorm on Dec. 26 last year, it was believed a slight gain over 1933 would be shown.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP). -Pass Christian, 4-year-old gelding owned by W. C. Morris and ridden by Jockey J. Chestnut, scored in easy fashion in the featured fifth race at the Fair Grounds today.

HALIFAX, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Captain Freeman Anderson, who held his motor vessel Mary E. Kenney off Barnegat Light, near the New Jersey shore, for nearly two weeks under the surveillance of a United States Coast Guard cutter, complained today concerning that surveillance.

Miss Mary Louise Graves was introduced last night by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Morse Graves, at a dance in the ballroom of the Park Lane, which had been transformed into an old English garden of evergreen and arborvitae trees.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 26 (AP). -- H. H. Kung, Minister of Finance, declared today that rumors that the Chinese Government was planning to nationalize silver, adopt paper currency and devalue its standard dollar were "spread by unscrupulous persons hoping to profit from disturbed financial markets."

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Dec. 26. -- In the first round of the girls' national indoor title tennis tournament, which started at the Longwood Cricket Courts today, Miss Helen Bernhardt, 13-year-old New York entrant, proved to be the outstanding player.

After thirteen hours of deliberation the board of managers of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange abandoned at midnight last night their attempt to work out terms for a settlement of the "squeeze" in December sugar contracts resulting from the inability of members of the Exchange who are short of the contract to get sugar for delivery.

John Murgo, 34 years old, of 81 Monroe Street, who used counterfeit stationery of the Municipal Civil Service Commission to defraud persons aspiring for city jobs, was sentenced yesterday to an indeterminate term of not more than three years in the penitentiary by Judge Corrigan in General Sessions.

Charging national leaders of the pro-Nazi Friends of the New Germany with an "anarchistic, terroristic, illegal attempt to transform a peaceful and idealistic group into a weapon of evil," revolting leaders of the New York group of the organization replied yesterday in the Supreme Court to an injunction suit brought against them by the national leaders through Henry Woisin, national treasurer.

A gay little exhibition of oils and water-colors by Irene Racz opened yesterday at the Piggins Art Galleries in the Hotel Roosevelt, Vienna, Munich and Paris have all had influence in the shaping of this young Hungarian artist's work before she came to this country to "go American."

The city's public school system is still "heavily handicapped" by the lack of adequate appropriations, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, declares in his annual report made public yesterday. The report emphasizes the need for Federal and State funds for school housing and the extension and improvement of educational services.

AFTER spending years in Far Eastern lands, George Sokolsky has returned to take a look at his own country. His viewpoint, as set forth in "Labor's Fight for Power" (Doubleday, Doran, $2), is somewhat unique. Mr. Sokolsky has seen catastrophe, starvation and revolution in both China and Russia. By contrast, the United States, even in depression, seems to him a land of milk and honey.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Alabama's football team went Hollywood today.
For the first time in its history the New York Curb Exchange's bond sales have reached $1,000,000,000 in a year. The previous high record was $981,297,000, made in 1931.
GENEVA, Dec. 26 (AP). -- Oil appeared likely tonight to increase the friction between Italy and Abyssinia.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 26. -- R. G. Morrison of Spring Lake, N.J., won the qualifying medal in the thirty-second annual mid-Winter golf tournament today when he carded a 77 to lead a field of more than sixty players. Scores ran high, and Jack Ryerson the Cooperstown, N.Y., favorite, barely managed to qualify in the first flight with an 83.
BERLIN, Dec. 26. -- A second blood purge, directed in part against monarchists, was viewed today as a possible sequel to recent raids on cafes and private houses frequented by the sexually abnormal.

A program of proposed amendments to the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Law for which consideration will be sought when the Legislature convenes next month was drawn up yesterday by representatives of local liquor associations meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 26. -An "assessment" was levied by the Sheriff's office for press seats at the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann today and another county official promptly announced that an investigation would be made to determine the propriety of the action.
Mrs. H. Carleton Tobey introduced her daughter, Miss Ida Louise Tobey, yesterday at a tea dance in the ballroom of the Park Lane in a setting of evergreens and smilax.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade were firm in undertone from the start today, due to low temperatures over the Winter wheat belt, the cold weather prevailing as far south as Kansas, in which State it caught the crop without snow protection.

Miss Anne Douglass Gould, 21year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Gould of Carlton House, 22 East Forty-seventh Street, and great-granddaughter of Jay Gould, the financier, was married to Frank Spencer J. Meador, 24, of San Saba, Texas, at 3:40 o'clock yesterday morning in the town hall at Harrison, N.Y.
One of the first real estate transactions negotiated after the interruption of trading by the Christmas holiday was announced yesterday by Benjamin Winter, operator.

BELGRADE, Dec. 26. -- Premier Bogolyub Yeftitch has been rebuffed by the leader of the former Serbian Radical party, Aza Stanoyevitch. M. Stanoyevitch informed the press he was unable to accept the expression of thanks made by Premier Yeftitch to all the political leaders with whom he negotiated during the recent government crisis.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26. -- Mrs. J. J. Dolan's Spoilt Beauty, a 69-to-1 shot, turned in the first important upset at the new Santa Anita track today when she scored by two lengths in the Mount Baldy Graded Handicap. Mrs. Silas B. Mason's Dark Devil was second in the six furlong event, with High Tensions third.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt attended Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's recital at the Mayflower this morning, heading a large and distinguished audience, which turned out to welcome Mme. Grete Stueckgold, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, and Emanuel Feuerman, 'cellist.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26. -- The principals in Dixie's Sugar Bowl football classic had an opportunity today to tune their attacks on a muddy field.

Detective James E. Branigan, bodyguard to former Mayor O'Brien, who resigned from the Police Department on Dec. 30, 1933, was reinstated yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine as a first-grade patrolman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- President Roosevelt centred attention today on the budget, with the purpose of deciding definitely what expenditures to recommend for the next fiscal year before finishing his general message to Congress.
All the ranking players moved through their initial tests of the national junior indoor tennis championship yesterday as the tourney got under way on the Seventh Regiment Armory's courts.

Your editorial "Plant and Public" should be placed in the hands of every New York City taxpayer and thinking citizen. Delays when utility companies propose increased rates are always in order, but any delay in the proposed New York City-Federal lighting plant program apparently should spell not less than solitary confinement for "obstructionists."

TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 27. -- The naval estimates, as agreed upon last month by the Finance and Naval Ministries and now circulated among Diet members, show that in the past four years Japan's naval budget has almost doubled.

Free concerts are scheduled by the State Symphonic Band this afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum and tonight by the Greenwich Sinfonietta at Columbia University, Waverly Dance Orchestra at Hartford House, Gotham Dance Orchestra at Hartley House, Stuyvesant Quartet at the Educational Alliance, Brooklyn Trio at the Hudson Avenue Boys Club and Harlem Trio at the 137th Street Y. W. C. A.

For the European, the extension of the curricula of American universities and colleges to include the teaching of applied music presents a new and altogether encouraging solution for a problem that has baffled the Old World, Bronislaw Huberman said yesterday in the course of a talk with newspaper men at the Ambassador.

The nominating committee of The Associated Press will meet at the general offices here at 11 A.M., Thursday, Jan. 17, to name a ticket for directors. Under a resolution of the membership the committee must name not less than ten members as candidates and present its report to the annual meeting in New York City on April 22.

BOSTON, Dec. 26. -- Henry M. Bohlen, former Harvard athlete and real estate broker, shot himself with a shotgun early Christmas morning and died eight hours later at the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital. This was revealed today when Medical Examiner George Burgess MaGrath announced a verdict of suicide.

The new issue of The Retail Bookseller, published monthly by Baker Taylor, book wholesalers, contains the list of the twenty best sellers for 1934. For the second successive year "Anthony Adverse," by Hervey Allen, leads all sales, although its own 1934 total was not as high as its 1933 total.

With many public-utility issues selling at new low levels for the movement, security holders looked no further for an explanation of yesterday's general but rather modest decline in prices. There was pressure against both stocks and bonds.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 26. -Colonel and Mrs. James R. Branch gave a party today at their residence on Royal Palm Way. Guests included Mr. and Mrs. Avy Barrell Smith, Mr. and Mrs. James King Clarke, Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Hayes, Mrs. Peyton J. Van Rensselaer and her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Ver Planck Newlin; Mrs. John Edwin Dietz, Mrs. William B. Jarvis, Mrs. Frances Wann Randolph and Mrs. A. Howes Torrey.
The Fund for New York's Neediest Cases fell back again yesterday, when the day's mail brought in only $4,027.75, contributed by 319 persons.

The annual series of intercollegiate sports meetings got under way yesterday with the session of the Eastern Intercollegiate Athletic Association at the McAlpin Hotel. The gatherings continue through Saturday, with the Association of Eastern Intercollegiate Football Officials meeting in the final one on that day.

An increasing demand for steel, particularly from automobile manufacturers, "has held the holiday interruption in steel works activity to a minimum," according to the review of The Iron Age. "Plans to suspend mill operations for three days -- from Saturday night to Tuesday -- were generally revised and in most cases Christmas shutdowns have been limited to three or four turns," says the review.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Hogs were in demand today and prices rose 50 to 75 cents a hundredweight as the result of small receipts. The upturn was the largest for one day in more than three years. The full advance was held at the close.

Jewelry valued at $35,000 was taken from the safe of Lido Jewels, Inc., 563 Madison Avenue at Fiftysixth Street, some time between 5 o'clock Christmas Eve and 8:30 yesterday morning by expert burglars who left their tools behind them after looting the safe from the rear.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Japan's formal denunciation of the Washington Naval Treaty will be deposited in the State Department Saturday, Ambassador Hiroshi Saito said today. This will automatically terminate the pact on Dec. 31, 1936, the date on which the London Naval Treaty expires by its own terms.
BERLIN, Dec. 24 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Dec. 21 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

New York City's own "blue eagle," in the form of posters for retail stores authorized to collect the 2 per cent city sales tax, was made ready for distribution yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

Dr. and Mrs. Raymond P. Sullivan gave a supper party in the Persian Room of the Plaza in celebration of the birthday of their daughter, Miss Katherine Burnett Sullivan, a student at the Marymount School. The other guests were:

Another financial readjustment in the Van Sweringen railroad system is under way in the form of a recapitalization of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad, it was disclosed yesterday. The Rio Grande is controlled jointly by the Missouri Pacific, largest unit in the nationwide Van Sweringen chain, and the Western Pacific Railroad, which is controlled by A. C. James.
The passenger list of the President Roosevelt of the United States Lines, leaving today for the Channel ports, includes:
Money market was stagnant so far as business was concerned. Replacements made up the bulk of the turnover. Quotations for all classes were carried forward without change.

PARIS, Dec. 26. -- After a threeday recess the Bourse resumed today under moderately favorable auspices. The generally improved morale as regards European peace, the French budget and the government's program to reduce rates of interest gave strength to rentes.

MOSCOW, Dec. 26. -- An alleged plot against the life of Joseph Stalin and the intervention of "capitalistic powers" to overthrow the Bolshevist leadership of Soviet Russia was disclosed tonight in a communique narrating the testimony of Leonid Nikolaieff, assassin of Sergei Kiroff and thirteen of Nikolaieff's associates.

The City College chess team scored its fifth straight victory in the seventh and final round at the Manhattan Club yesterday to hold first place in the annual championship tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League for the Harold M. Phillips Trophy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- The Mississippi Valley Committee's report, in suggesting a $1,000,000,000, twenty-year program of public works in the valley, recommended that dams constructed to aid navigation or flood control be used to generate power as well.

SAABRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Thursday, Dec. 27 (AP). -The Sear frontier was closed at midnight until after the plebiscite Jan. 13 as the League of Nation's Plebiscite Commission moved dramatically to exclude possible trouble-makers from the territory.

In a recent issue of your paper an article appeared in which a magistrate, speaking of proposed changes in the Women's Court, is quoted as saying, "the most depressing thing about this court is its utter futility."

NOT since the ancient Diogenes set out with a lantern to find an honest man has anything seemed to have caused quite so much astonishment as the recently avowed intention of Powel Crosley Jr. to find an honest dollar in Cincinnati with the aid of some powerful floodlights.
ROME, Dec. 26 (AP). -- The gold stocks of the Bank of Italy have been increased by nearly 31,000,000 lire ($2,650,500) in the last ten days, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Definite quickening next year of business recovery, led by a "decided forward movement in the fundamental heavy goods industries next Spring," was predicted by Secretary Roper today.

SALONIKI, Greece, Dec. 26. -Police forcibly broke the strike today of 370 tobacco workers who had been self-imprisoned in their factory for the past two weeks. It was necessary for them to break down the walls and destroy bales of tobacco used as barricades before the workers, weakened from hunger, could be ejected.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Seven persons were instantly killed today when the automobile in which they were riding was struck and ground to bits by the Chicago-bound International Limited of the Grand Trunk Railway in Harvey, Ill.

Miss Isobel Steele, 23-year-old resident of Hollywood, who spent four months in the custody of the German Government at the Moabit prison in Berlin, returned yesterday on the liner President Harding. Although she did not object to having innumerable photographs and motion pictures taken, she refused to give details of her experience because she had sold her story for publication.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26. -- The most efficient apparatus yet devised for harnessing sunlight to do man's work is part of the exhibition of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, which opens its annual Winter meeting here tomorrow.

If all the factors, practical and psychological, that go to the making of a good or bad performance of opera could be known and cited, there would be some interesting and perhaps amusing revelations. A good cast may give a dull performance, or a bad cast a lively one.

The Citizens Budget Commission has explored anew the morass of waste, graft and incompetence into which county government in New York City has sunk. In a report of 261 pages it traces the origin of the counties back to the days of WILLIAM the Conqueror, and describes some of the abuses that have sprung up on this side of the water.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- Moving to establish a general headquarters air force, to embrace virtually every army combat unit in the United States under a commander who would serve directly under the chief of staff, Secretary Dern announced today the appointment of Lieut. Col. Frank M. Andrews as commander of the new defense service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- President Roosevelt was reported ready today to recommend to Congress that it appropriate whatever additional funds were necessary to complete the Senate investigation of the American munitions industry and its foreign connections.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26. -- George D. Widener's Kawagoe struck his winning stride at Tropical Park today to score in the six furlongs of the featured Boca Raton Handicap.

Dr. Arnold Knapp gave a tea dance yesterday in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center for his daughters, the Misses Elisabeth Knapp and Miss Ellen James Knapp, the latter a debutante. The guests included:

ALBANY, Dec. 26 (AP). -- While the method which the 1935 Legislature may employ in reorganizing the State Department of Agriculture and Markets remains a matter of speculation, the number of candidates for the $12,000-a-year commissionership is steadily increasing.

Individual fielding honors in the National League for the 1934 season were gained by two Giants and one Dodger, the latter setting a new record, according to the official averages released for publication today.

TRENTON, Dec. 26. -- A slight decrease in factory employment and total weekly payrolls in New Jersey during November, but a gain in average weekly earnings was reported today by John J. Toohey, State Labor Commissioner.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 26. -- Commenting on the report yesterday by the House Military Affairs Committee attacking deals connected with the lease of the old army base at Port Newark to the Mercur Corporation, Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein said today he expected that within a week action would be taken by Attorney General Cummings to oust the corporation from the base.

The Eastern Intercollegiate Boxing Association held its annual meeting yesterday, awarded the 1935 championship tournament to Penn State and reported that thirteen colleges and universities might be represented. The tournament will be held at State College, Pa., on March 15 and 16.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 26. -- Christmas was celebrated in blood in the Chaco, since no truce was agreed upon this year. After a solemn midnight mass in various sectors, at which hundreds of Bolivian soldiers received communion, the Paraguayans attacked on several fronts.

Trading was considerably more active on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but there was another fractional decline in the average of prices. The market moved within a narrower radius and year-end selling for tax purposes extended to a wider assortment of stocks, even if the reaction did not go so far as on Wednesday.

On a cloudless day in midsummer 33,000,000 horsepower-hours of energy fall from the sun upon each square mile of Idaho. Enough solar heat is received to melt a terrestrial layer of ice 424 feet thick every year. About 1,800 times more energy annually inundates the Sahara than is contained in all the coal mines.

The State of Maryland Roads Commission made the award yesterday of a new issue of $1,100,000 of 4 per cent bonds to a syndicate composed of Edward B. Smith Co., Alex. Brown Sons of Baltimore, and the Metropolitan St. Louis Company.

The first of the holiday fatalities is "Mother Lode," which will close tomorrow night at the Cort. It opened there last Saturday evening and, with two matinees this week, will have given nine performances. An elaborate production, it stars Helen Gahagan and Melvyn Douglas under the management of Bushar Tuerk.

Fliers, explorers and adventurers, friends of Lieutenant Walter Hinton, a member of the navy's NC-4 flight around the world, assembled to greet him yesterday at a luncheon in his honor given by the Exchange Club of New York at the McAlpin.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. has given to the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research the block of land bounded by York and First Avenues, Sixty-seventh and Sixtyeighth Streets.

An immediate convention of 1,200 newspapers to consider the National Labor Relations Board action in The San Francisco Call-Bulletin case "as it affects their continuance" under the Daily Newspaper Code, was announced through The Associated Press last night by Howard Davis, chairman of the Publishers' National Code Committee.
Many dinners were given last night before the various subscription dances for members of the younger set who are home from school for the holidays.

VIENNA, Dec. 27. -- After fifteen years there are sudden signs of a lessening of tension between the "revisionist bloc" -- Italy, Austria and Hungary -- and the "status quo bloc," as the Little Entente and France might well be called.
More than a score of properties were offered for sale at auctioneers' stands in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday.

A few days ago our President returned from Georgia, exclaiming joyfully that the cotton growers had voted by a large majority for his Cotton Code and it had saved their lives; Senator Bankhead also expressed gratification at the vote for his bill which paid growers fine doles for plowing up cotton.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- Two alienists reported today to Walter A. Ferris, District Attorneyelect of Westchester County, that Albert Fish, 64 years old, held in the county jail for the murder of Grace Budd, is legally sane.

COMPLAINT about the parlous condition of modern poetry frequently reaches this office. Among the less avid, the less professional, the less intellectual, readers of verse, the consensus seems to be that T. S. Eliot and Ezra Pound have substituted shorthand for the English language, and that all aspiring poets of recent years have felt compelled to master this shorthand.

A substantial majority of college football coaches favors Alabama to beat Stanford in the forthcoming Rose Bowl intersectional battle at Pasadena. Polled yesterday by The Associated Press, 16 out of 27 coaches selected Alabama to win, while 6 picked Stanford and 5 straddled the issue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- A special assessment running to possibly $750,000 a year to finance a trade promotion plan for the lumber and timber industry was proposed today by the Lumber Code Authority at an NRA hearing before A.C. Dixon, deputy administrator.

Defending his postal surplus of $12,000,000, James A. Farley, Postmaster General, in a radio speech last night, declared he had followed the method of his predecessors and omitted the ocean and air mail subsidies.

HARTFORD, Dec. 27. -- One person was killed every fifteen minutes and one injured every thirtyone seconds in automobile accidents throughout the country this year and the deaths totaled 36,000, yearend statistics of the Travelers Insurance Company showed today.

While the holiday this week reduced the activity of dry goods wholesalers, they picked up some odd lots which mills were anxious to clear out before the first of the year. Jobbers, however, made preparations to visit this market next week, when renewed buying of Spring styles will be done.

Motor fuel stocks in the United States, including the amount of unfinished gasoline contained in naphtha distillates, at the end of last week amounted to 51,468,000 barrels, against 51,107,000 at the close of the previous week, a gain of 361,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

RUSH D. HOLT, who is Senator-elect from West Virginia and five and a half months under the minimum age in the Constitution, is not expected to challenge that venerable instrument. His friends believe Mr. HOLT will wait until his thirtieth birthday before submitting his credentials.

As a lifelong conservative it is hard for me to accept many of the prophecies of what is going to happen to the Republican party under the new deal. Chase Mellen, Kingsland Macy, Senators Borah, Nye and Norris to the contrary, I am of the opinion that the Republican party will remain a conservative factor in the politics of our country.

SOMETHING distinctly novel and designed for the best interests and development of a popular sport is about to be launched by the National Billiard Association of America. And if it succeeds, as it doubtless should, perhaps it would not be a bad idea for other sporting enterprises to employ the stunt.
Quietness pervaded all sections of the credit market, resulting in a firm array of quotations which showed no variation from prior levels.
A new dance step -- the Americano -- for those who are afraid of the tango was introduced last night at a special holiday meeting of the Dancing Masters of America in the Hotel Astor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Registration of two security issues, one on the Chicago Exchange and the other on the San Francisco board, was authorized today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In type of melody and finesse of detail one of the most French of French operas, Massenet's "Manon" served neatly yesterday afternoon to divert the young season of opera at the Metropolitan from its preponderantly Italian and German beginnings, as well as to present a cast of favorite singers in roles to their liking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- A Far Westerner was projected today into the race for the House Democratic floor leadership, bringing to nine the number of candidates for the second highest post in that branch of Congress.

La Argentina made her second appearance of the season last night at the Town Hall in a program which differed largely from that of her previous recital. Only three dances were held over, the other eight consisting for the most part of old favorites from other seasons, but including one entirely new composition.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 27. -Engaging in 366 contests during the calendar year, Princeton sports units won 240, lost 117 and deadlocked in nine, to compile a percentage of.656, the university Athletic Association announced today.
PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 27. -- NRA code price-fixing, even in transactions a part of interstate commerce, was held unconstitutional today by Federal District Judge Merrill E. Otis.

New Yorkers with money to spend in public celebration of New Year's Eve seem more numerous than a year ago, it appeared from reservations made up to yesterday. Hotels in particular have found it necessary to add seating and dancing space by calling terraces and lounges into such use.

Though he had played seventy-odd Shakespearean roles in his career, it was only last night that Walter Hampden brought for the first time his Richard III to a New York stage before one of his respectful, almost reverent audiences at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre.

Arrangements to start trading in crude oil and gasoline futures on the Commodity Exchange, Inc., are about complete, and it is understood in the trade that operations probably will be begun soon after Feb. 1. A committee appointed by the Exchange has been studying the proposal several months.

A tea dance was given yesterday at the Junior League Club by Mr. and Mrs. Herman Alfred Prosser to introduce their daughters, the Misses Edith and Ethel Prosser. Evergreens and Christmas trees lighted with silvered electrics decorated the ballroom.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP). -Kuvera, owned and trained by Anthony Pelleteri, got up in the final strides today to score in the featured fifth race at the Fair Grounds.

ALBANY, Dec. 27. -- Governor Lehman will take his oath of office for the second time on Monday at 9:30 P. M. It will be administered at the Executive Mansion by his brother, Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals. This will be the sixth time Judge Lehman has acted in a similar capacity, his first being when Alfred E. Smith became Governor.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Dec. 27. -- Stringent regulations are being enforced by the Saar Governing Commission to prevent unwanted individuals from entering the territory after tonight. Entrance permits will be difficult to obtain, as the commission is determined to exclude mere sightseers who are hopeful of witnessing a little excitement.

A Frenchman was asked how soon France would go Fascist or monarchical or set up a dictatorship. His answer was that she would never do either. The reason for this opinion, which he gave in the January issue of Foreign Affairs, is the simple one that "They had not got the men."

BELGRADE, Dec. 27. -- Another step toward consolidation of four individually weak Yugoslav Fascist movements, all of which demand a corporative State, was taken last night when the four united under the title of the Yugoslav People's Movement.

Controller-elect Frank J. Taylor got his first taste of the role he is to fill in the Fusion administration yesterday when he sat in at special meetings of the Board of Estimate and the Sinking Fund Commission at City Hall.
Several business buildings were included in the New Jersey realty conveyances reported yesterday.
A new and striking adornment hangs over the fireplace in the dining room of the Anglers' Club of New York, that noontime sanctuary for a select group of metropolitan sportsmen.

MANILA, P.I., Dec. 27. -- A possibility that the Filipinos will swing over to a plea for some type of dominion status for the Philippines, instead of insisting on complete independence, was being discussed here today as the United States Senatorial mission headed by Senator Millard E. Tydings of Maryland started on its trip homeward.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation acted under "implied powers" of the law when it prescribed maximum interest rates on time and savings deposits and with a view to preventing discrimination against non-member banks of the Federal Reserve System, Chairman Leo T. Crowley stated today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- The United States should return as soon as possible to a fixed gold standard, ninety -five of the nation's leading monetary economists, here for the annual meeting of the American Association of Economists, agreed tonight.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

The plan for reorganizing the Paramount Publix Corporation and its subsidiary, the Paramount Broadway Corporation, owner of the Paramount Building in Times Square, was outlined yesterday at an all-day hearing before Judge Alfred C. Coxe in the United States District Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Legislation by the new Congress to set up a substitute for the National Industrial Recovery Act, with large changes, was advocated today by the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

A large audience attended Mr. Bagby's 377th Musical Morning yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The artists were Mme. Elisabeth Rethberg and Richard Bonelli of the Metropolitan Opera, and Emanuel Feuermann, violinist.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Economists, political scientists and sociologists attending the thirteen meetings of their national associations here today put out warning signals against possible inflation, resulting from an unbalanced budget and excessive spending on public works.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 27. -- The public choice Bubblesome and the 15-to-1 shot Stand Pat staged a game duel in the stretch run of the mile and a sixteenth Stuart Purse at Tropical Park today, with the favorite triumphing by a nose.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Banks credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 26, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,493,000,000, an increase of $22,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $205,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1933.

DUBLIN, Dec. 27. -- The Free State Government entered today upon what is regarded as a new offensive in the trade war being waged with Britain with the coming into effect of the decree prohibiting the importation of coal except under license.

A dinner with dancing was given last night in the Corinthian Room of the Pierre by Mr. and Mrs. James Lakeman Ward to introduce Miss Marianna Ward. The debutante is the daughter of Mr. Ward and Mrs. Atwood Ward.

The Bondholders' Protective Committee for Republic of El Salvador, which is headed by F. J. Lisman, announced yesterday that it had established what it believed to be a record for holders of foreign bonds, both from the percentage of bonds deposited and the funds obtained for depositing bondholders.

The nervous system "spoke" to more than 300 astonished physicians and scientists attending the annual meeting of the Association for Research in Nervous and Mental Diseases at the Commodore yesterday. The "speech" was greeted with enthusiastic applause by the scientists, who spent the greater part of the day listening to technical papers dealing with abstruse problems in medical research.

Continuance of the Roerich Museum and its cultural programs was declared to be assured yesterday, when the museum building, at the north corner of Riverside Drive and 103d Street, was sold in foreclosure proceedings as the first step in a plan of reorganization.

Cooperation between the Federal Government and the city in building their own electric power plants in New York was definitely agreed upon yesterday morning in Washington at a conference between Federal and city officials.
A feature of apartment renting in the city yesterday was the leasing of large suites in houses on and near Park Avenue. Brokers also were kept busy signing up tenants for buildings on the West Side.

Creation of a State mortgage authority to direct rehabilitation of guaranteed mortgage certificate issues, in line with the policy of Governor Lehman, will be recommended by the joint legislative committee on banks, Senator Thomas F. Burchill, the chairman, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The Washington monument is not "lost" any more. It stands exaactly latitude 38 degrees 53' 21.682, and longitude 77 degrees 02' 07".955.
Winter battered New York again yesterday, but vented the worst of its fury on New England and Central Nova Scotia, causing death and property damage in both regions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Increased receipts of hogs today, in contrast with the abnormally light movement earlier in the week, gave buyers an advantage early and the market was quoted as 10 to 15 cents a hundredweight lower than yesterday.

A 17-year-old Milwaukee youngster, Donald Leavens, who came East for the national junior tennis championship with an impressive record, demonstrated at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday that he can be regarded as one of the leading contenders for the title.

Immediate establishment of an enforcement agency for collection of the city's 2 per cent sales tax was urged upon Controller-elect Frank J. Taylor yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, when they conferred at City Hall.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 27. -Three truck loads of exhibits and documentary evidence will be brought here from Trenton and New York by the State of New Jersey in the next few days to be used in the trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, charged with the murder of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., it was learned today.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Democratic leaders of the Legislature are preparing to renew their fight early in the session for the creation of a State mortgage commission to take over the rehabilitation of guaranteed mortgage certificates.
Paola Autori and Robert Miller will sing at the Bronx Symphony Orchestra's free concert this evening at Theodore Roosevelt High School.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- The latest news of a stellar explosion which happened some 1,200 years ago was brought today to members of the American Astronomical Society, meeting at the Franklin Institute.

Directors of the National Distillers Products Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of 50 cents a share, payable on Feb. 1 to holders of record of Jan. 15. This will be the first cash dividend on the stock since 50 cents was paid on Aug. 1, 1932.

It was remarked widely in brokerage circles that seldom has an important dividend announcement caused as little excitement on the Stock Exchange as yesterday's reduction by Consolidated Gas. The general market, but particularly the stocks of utility companies, firmed up after the news came out.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- The trial of the alleged accomplices of Vlada Georgieff, assassin of King Alexander of Yugoslavia and Foreign Minister Louis Barthou of France, probably will not take place before the month of May at Aix, it was stated there today after the first legal examination of the case.

Miss Marion Gengler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Gengler, made her debut last night at a dinner dance given by her parents in the Crystal Room of the RitzCarlton, where the floral decorations were appropriate to the season.

More than 30,000 persons inspected the New York Central's new streamlined steam locomotive, the Commodore Vanderbilt, yesterday at the Grand Central Terminal. The engine, said to be the first driven by steam to be styled in the modern manner, will be on exhibition again today on Track 17.

A spurt in prices of United States Government bonds featured yesterday an otherwise irregular bond market on the Stock Exchange. The rise in the government issues ranged from 2-32 to 12-32 point, the only losses being in the First Liberty 4 1/4s and the uncalled Fourth 4 1/4s, which were off 1-32 and 2-32 point, respectively.

Trends of foreign commodity prices varied in November in terms of domestic currencies. The Annalist says, but in terms of gold they generally advanced and The Annalist international composite in terms of gold rose 0.8 per cent to a preliminary 73.2 for November from 72.6 the month previous.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 27. -- Sheldon and Burns's Little Son upset calculations at the Santa Anita track today as he led home a field of seven in the featured Alhambra Purse. He returned $49.60 for $2.

Price movements of commodity futures were irregular yesterday, with the volume of trading fairly heavy for a holiday week. Strength was in evidence in sugar, silk and hide futures while other staples were slightly lower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP). -The National Labor Relations Board today asked NRA's compliance division to remove The San Francisco Call-Bulletin's Blue Eagle for failing to reinstate Dean S. Jennings, a rewrite man.

Jack Doyle, Broadway's bestknown betting commissioner, was found not guilty yesterday in Jefferson Market Court of a charge of maintaining a gambling establishment. Philip Candello, one of Doyle's employes, and fourteen patrons of Doyle's billiard parlor at 1,459 Broadway, who were arrested with Doyle on Dec. 19 last, also were arraigned yesterday and found not guilty.

TOKYO, Dec. 27. -- Further representations regarding the hardships inflicted on foreign oil companies by the new Japanese oil law were made to the Foreign Office this afternoon by Edwin L. Neville, counselor, and Earl R. Dickover, secretary of the United States Embassy.

Why can't Republican chairmen agree in their rulings? Our Manhattan chairman, Mr. CHASE MELLEN Jr., asked State Chairman EATON to convoke all the Republican county chairmen and draw up a program for the Republicans in the Legislature. Mr. EATON refused on the ground that it was the business of the Republicans in the Legislature to prepare their own program.

Fred I. Kent, chairman of the advisory council of the New York Stock Exchange, is gathering the opinions of the council and of officials of the Exchange relative to the functions and methods which the advisory group should adopt. In a lengthy letter he has outlined his own suggestions and solicited those of the nine other members of the council.

After yielding slightly under further circulation of January notices, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied in the late trading yesterday and closed with a gain of 8 to a loss of 2 points. January ruled 18 to 20 points under March most of the session, but execution of buying orders in the spot month in the final dealings narrowed the spread 10 points.

A newcomer to the ranks of major intercollegiate track and field meets, the Heptagonal Games, sprang into being yesterday at the annual convention of the Association of College Track Coaches of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Seven Eastern athletic powers agreed on a meet, patterned after the intercollegiates, that will decide supremacy among them.

An investigation of colleges and other institutions of higher learning to determine whether any instructors are teaching doctrines subversive of American institutions and promoting the ideas of overthrow of government by force was urged yesterday by Matthew Woll, acting president of the Civic Federation, in a letter to John W. McCormack, chairman of the Congressional committee now conducting an inquiry into un-American activities.

From early morning until after dusk last Sunday twenty-nine members of the Bronx County Bird Club, in their eleventh annual bird census, toured a roughly circular district, between the Palisades, Van Cortlandt Park, Rye and White Plains, in search of birds. Dr. Ernst Mayr, associate curator of birds at the American Museum of Natural History, compared the reports of the members and announced yesterday that ninety-seven species had been recorded, one more than last year.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Dec. 27. -- A violent preplebiscite campaign against Hitlerism got under way today in the Saar as anti-Nazis charged Adolf Hitler's henchmen had staged another "blood purge" in Germany.

MUNICH, Dec. 27. -- Bad Aibling, an Upper Bavarian village, was the scene last night of a battle between 350 Austrian legionaires and townspeople in which one Bavarian was killed and about twenty-five were injured.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- Leo De Nicholais of 2,060 Yates Avenue, the Bronx, pleaded guilty here today to a charge of violating Section 439 of the Penal Law by extracting a "kick-back" from bricklayers and unskilled workmen at the State School for Mental Defectives at Letchworth Village.

Believing that there is a surplus of low-priced lodgings for men in New York City, the trustees of the thirty-seven-year-old Mills Hotel at Rivington and Chrystie Streets plan to close thc ten-story landmark on Jan. 1.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27. -- The most encouraging progress reported so far in the fight of science against infantile paralysis, with actual tests on hundreds of human beings, as well as further advances in animal experimentation on epidemic sleeping sickness, were described here today before the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Secretary of State Hull has taken under consideration a request from Maurice B. Gladstone of New York that he warn Germans returning to vote in the Saar plebiscite that they will lose their citizenship under presumption of expatriation.

Thayer Hobson, president of William Morrow Co., has returned after a visit of three weeks in London. He bought the American right to several English books, among them "National Velvet," by Enid Bagnold, the first novel by that author to appear in nine years; "Voyage in the Dark," by Jean Rhys, and a biography of King Albert of Belgium by Charles d'Ydewalle, a young Belgian journalist.
