Russell Janney is a wistful man with a belief that D'Artagnan is not dead, but sleepeth. Led by such considerations he last night rescued the Broadway Theatre from the strange tangle of cabarets and sportland palaces into which it has fallen and placed upon its dusty stage "The O'Flynn," a musical romance.

One new picture is on today's schedule, while eight other films are on the hold-over list for the week. The single newcomer is "West of the Pecos," with Richard Dix, opening at the Criterion. In the latter category are "Forsaking All Others," at the Capitol; "

MORRIS LLEWELYN COOKE was a reporter once, years ago. After that he was an apprentice in CRAMP'S shipyards and later a journeyman machinist. When he became a consulting engineer he spent much of his spare time initiating his fellow-engineers into the mysteries of the Taylor system of scientific management, then in its heyday.

The petition of the railroads serving the Port of New York for revision of the Interstate Commerce Commission decision in the lighterage case as it affects freight rates to New England probably will be opposed by New Jersey, it was learned yesterday.

Bank clearings of the twenty-two leading cities throughout the country increased 13.8 per cent to $3,993,843,000 in the five business days of the week covering the Christmas holiday and ending on Wednesday, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This compares with $3,551,353,000 reported in the corresponding week last year, and with a gain of 32.5 per cent recorded in the previous week of six days.

Aaron Sapiro, the lawyer who once sued Henry Ford for publishing anti-Semitic statements in The Dearborn Independent, waited late last night at the Federal Building to learn whether he would be acquitted or convicted of the charge that he attempted to bribe a jury in a mail fraud case early in 1933.

The story of MUNTHE'S waiting for the return of light after the operation upon his eyes presents what CHESTERTON would call one of the masterpieces of the art of life. It recalls the incident in the master-life of St. FRANCIS of Assisi when facing blindness. The remedy -- and "admittedly an uncertain remedy" -- was to cauterize the eye.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 27. -- Jonas B. Tumen, prosecutor of Monmouth County, who was said to be "guilty of a misdemeanor and nonfeasance in office," by the Naughright Legislative Investigation Committee, will be superseded in office by Attorney General David T. Wilentz, according to an order sent out tonight by Supreme Court Justice Joseph B. Perskie.

A biographical note in the program of "Baby Pompadour," which opened last evening at the Vanderbilt Theatre, identifies its author, Benjamin Graham, as "a wellknown figure in the financial world" who has connection with the affairs of many important corporations.

Financial institutions and their employes in the city have contributed $384,975, or more than 11 per cent of the $3,071,000 raised by the Citizens Family Welfare Committee to help private family welfare agencies meet the demands made upon them this Winter, it was revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Tomorrowthe Cabinet, and perhaps the entireNational Emergency Council, will betold the outlines of the President'sforthcoming messages to Congress on thestate of the nation and his budgetaryand relief plans. If the injunction ofsecrecy as to important details is obeyedas closely as recently it has been, theconferees will keep their lips tightlyclosed.

MADRID, Dec. 27. -- Premier Alejandro Lerroux announced tonight that, with President Niceto Alcala Zamora's approval, he had appointed Joaquin Dualde, Professor of Law at the University of Barcelona, to replace Minister of Education Filiberto Villa Lobos, who refused to remain in the Cabinet after an attack by Catholic Deputies in the Cortes on his secondary education policy.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Perot gave a dinner last night in the Caprice Room of the Weylin for the Misses Katherin E. Perot, Audrey Oakley, Sarah Lee Perot and Dora Oakley; Richard Tullis, Harvey Braniger, Andrew Cobb Blake and Edward S. Perot 3d.

Joseph Carcona, 12 years old, and his brother Frank, 9, were drowned yesterday afternoon despite frantic efforts of playmates to save them when thin ice on a pool in the old Rothstein estate in Maspeth, Queens, broke as the boys attempted to slide on it.

A forty-eight-word recovery program for New York State, unanimously adopted by six leading civic organizations of the State, which will submit it to the Governor and the next session of the Legislature, was made public yesterday by the New York State Economic Council. The program follows:

MANILA, P.I., Dec. 27. -- After three weeks of hearing alternate proposals offered by insular leaders, Senator Tydings of Maryland, leader of the United States mission to the Philippines and co-author of the Tydings-McDuffie Philippine Independence Act, and his three colleagues started today on their way home.

While subway traffic and elevated traffic of the I.R.T. both declined in November, compared with the same month last year, gains in numbers of passengers amounting to 2.79 per cent occurred on the Pelham Bay Park Line of the subway and of 17 per cent on the Ninth Avenue Line of the Manhattan Elevated, according to the monthly report of Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver of the Interborough.

Two patrolmen were locked up yesterday on charges of burglary after having been found in an automobile belonging to one of them with 109 boxes of candy. Denying the charge, they said the sweets had been found on the sidewalk.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Relative weakness in the markets in Buenos Aires and Liverpool dominated the trend of grains today on the Board of Trade. Many local longs went out of their holdings after the English wheat market had failed to reflect the upturn here yesterday.

Fear that many of the evils brought to light in the 1929 Carnegie Foundation report are creeping back into college athletics -- in fact, he said that a "retrograde movement" had already set in -- was expressed yesterday by Dr. Howard J. Savage, author of the famous document known as "Bulletin No. 23."

STONINGTON, Conn., Dec. 27.Thomas Withridge Cutler, 62, a wealthy resident here, was found dead today in Stonington harbor. He committed suicide by drowning, Dr. F. W. Hewes of Croton, acting medical examiner, declared. It was learned that he had been depressed for some time.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 27. -Two of the outstanding figures in the world of chess met today in the first round of the international chess tournament as the annual congress of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club got under way. Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world champion, faced Dr. Max Euwe of Amsterdam at the fourth board and the result was a draw in 28 moves.

POWELLTON, W. Va., Dec. 27. -Sixteen men were killed and fortythree injured, five perhaps fatally, by the explosion early this morning of a locomotive hauling a train in which 300 miners were riding to work.

Mr. and Mrs. Elton Parks of this city and Alderbrook, Katonah, N.Y., introduced their daughter, Miss Jane Parks, last night at a small dinner dance in the Starlight Roof Garden of the WaldorfAstoria. Miss Parks attended Miss Hewitt's School, and was graduated from Foxcroft School.
Realty trading in Manhattan yesterday centred in the midtown section. Two of the day's outstanding transactions involved apartment houses near Rockefeller Center.

HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 27. -- The home city of Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, paid tribute to him today for his services to the nation. Leading citizens voiced their praises, Mayor Oscar F. Holcombe proclaimed it "Jesse H. Jones Day" and a bronze bust of the financier was presented to the public library.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- An opinion that the child labor amendment to the Constitution cannot be legally ratified because of the lapse of time since it was submitted to the States by Congress in 1924 was expressed today by a special committee of the American Bar Association, appointed to oppose ratification.

PARIS, Dec. 27 (AP). -- As long as he behaves himself, Leon Trotsky is to have French shelter from the Soviet regime's stern campaign against its enemies. In the face of reports from Moscow that the oncepowerful Soviet official had been implicated in a plot against the Soviet regime, French authorities said they regarded M. Trotsky as the type of political exile to which France always had given refuge.

The membership of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange voted yesterday approval of a new sugar contract which will broaden the scope of trading and may avert a recurrence of the inability to deliver sugar which is facing short sellers of December, 1934, contracts.

Net profit of John Morrell Co., Inc., meat packers, and subsidiaries for the year ended on Oct. 27 amounted to $2,091,003 after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes and other charges. This is equal to $5.42 a share on 385,698 no par shares of capital stock.

Mrs. Mary Colucci, 43 years old, of 121 Chrystie Street, the mother of seventeen children of whom only five are living, was found not guilty of murder in General Sessions yesterday. Mrs. Colucci shot and killed her husband, Joseph, on the night of June 12 in a Third Avenue elevated train approaching the Ninth Street station.
BERLIN, Dec. 27. -- The commercial policy that was dramatically labeled "the road to Baghdad" before the war is again attracting German business men.
Brokers reported a good demand for business space yesterday. Office and showroom rentals, especially to firms in the needle trades, formed the bulk of the business renting activity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- November imports were $21,378,000 greater in 1934 than in 1933, according to a report on foreign trade made public today. At the same time it was shown that last month's imports totaling $150,919,000, were 16 per cent greater than in October.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Dec. 27. -- Christopher Smith Reynolds, infant son of Libby Holman, agreed today through his "next friend," R. C. Vaughn, to the settlement of the $25,000,000 estate of his father, Z. Smith Reynolds, which would give him $6,000,000 and his mother $750,000.

Friction between representatives of workers and employers which may lead to a revival of the recent strike movement among building service and elevator employes developed at yesterday's session of the arbitration committee which is trying to adjust the controversy on the basis of the settlement resulting from the intervention recently of Mayor La Guardia and the Regional Labor Board.

In an exciting finish the annual tournament for the championship of the Intercollegiate Chess League and the Harold M. Phillips Trophy at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday resulted in a tie for first place between City College, titleholder, and Columbia. A play-off is planned before New Year's.
A woman crossing Park Avenue at Forty-ninth Street was struck and killed at 10:40 o'clock last night by a large black sedan, the driver of which fled. Her body was dragged forty feet.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Relief grants to the States for January totalling $136,791,268, were announced today by the Federal Relief Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- In another day devoted almost exclusively to study of the budget estimates which will be put before Congress next week, President Roosevelt and his aides concerned with relief concentrated their deliberations today on the new program which they hope to get underway within a few weeks.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 27. -Efforts to make geology interesting to the layman were urged upon the Geological Society of America tonight by Dr. William H. Collins of Ottawa, director of the Canadian Geological Survey and retiring president of the society.
CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Dec. 27. -- The semi-final round was reached today in both the singles and doubles division of play in the girls' national indoor title tennis tourney.

The report of the Federal Reserve System for the week ended on Wednesday, published yesterday, showed an increase of $41,000,000 in the amount of money in circulation, making the total seasonal rise in the last five weeks $173,000,000.

CHANGTEH, China, Friday, Dec. 28. -- A harrowing story of how they escaped capture by Red outlaw troops while fleeing from a remote missionary station in Western Hunan Province was told today by Miss Justine E. Granner of Hubbard, Iowa, and Miss Anna M. Renninger of Reading, Pa., on their arrival here.
MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 27. -- The will of Martin W. Littleton Sr., noted lawyer, who died at the Nassau Hospital on Dec. 19, was filed for probate with Surrogate Leone D. Howell here today.

Although his efforts were rather overshadowed during the past year by the more spectacular deeds of Dizzy Dean, the left-handed Carl Hubbell of the Giants was again the most effective pitcher in the National League for the 1934 campaign, according to the official averages released for publication today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Louisiana State University, reputedly dominated by Senator Huey Long, was adversely appraised today when the Association of American Law Schools adopted a report of its executive committee, which found political influence undermining the educational facilities of the institution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Thirtyseven editors of college dailies meeting here, invited Jesse H. Cutrer, former editor of The Reveille, student publication at Louisiana State University, today to address their conference. Mr. Cutrer accepted the invitation and left Louisiana by airplane for Washington.

Rosa Ponselle returned to the Metropolitan for a royal greeting last night in the new season's fifth opera, "La Gioconda." It was brought forward thus early in view of the recent centenary, on Aug. 31 last, of the birth of the composer, Amilcare Ponchielli.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Dec. 27.Two collieries of the Glen Alden Coal Company were made idle and operations at three others were crippled today as a result of a general strike call by the United Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania, an insurgent union.

Colonel and Mrs. George Chase Lewis and Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Lucian Dent Booth jointly gave a tea dance yesterday at the Officers' Club, Governors Island, to introduce their daughters, Miss Flora Louise Lewis and Miss Catharine Tompkins Booth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- A decision of wide importance to coded industry, providing that employes in such industries must be compensated for "work interruption beyond their control," was made today by the National Recovery Administration.

The cold snap has doubled the attendance at two of the three government armories now used as daytime shelters for the homeless, and nearly doubled that of the third, Stanley Howe, First Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Public Welfare announced after an inspection tour yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 27. -Ploughing through a tampered switch, a Pennsylvania passenger train crashed into a string of empty cars on a siding here today, killing three railroad men and causing injuries to a score of passengers.
Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, in a valedictory speech yesterday, declared that the city's financial condition was such that it would not have to impose furloughs or new taxes for the coming year.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date.

In honor of the end of the year and the depression, Eddie Dowling has recently been assembling one of those handsome revue circuses, "Thumbs Up!" which was put on at the St. James last evening. It is so good-looking and it is played with such spirit that you are surprised to discover that it does not live up to the promise of the names in the program.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 28. -- The case for the prosecution in the scandal that brought down the Cabinet of Viscount Makoto Saito last Summer was disclosed last night when the Department of Justice returned indictments charging bribery or perjury against seventeen men prominent in politics and business.

As a result of yesterday's activities at the Winter meetings of the college sports bodies, there was the promise of spirited discussion of football rule changes by the American Football Coaches Association. Also, at the meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the first rumblings of action were heard on the question of subsidization of players.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- General Peyton C. March, Chief of Staff of the United States Army from May, 1918, until his retirement in July, 1921, celebrated today his seventieth birthday.

DETROIT, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Henry and Edsel Ford forecast today "a good solid year for business" in 1935, but warned against overdependence upon the "momentum" from the "remarkable improvement" in 1934.

Yesterday's mail brought 212 contributions, totaling $3,707.81, to the Neediest Cases Fund. The total for the year now is $212,880.11, which is still more than $1,000 behind the total at this time last year.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27. -- Discovery of the habitat of the gene was announced by Dr. T. S. Painter, Professor of Zoology at the University of Texas, in an address to the Association for the Advancement of Science.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Proposals for legislation looking to strict regulation of utility holding companies will be completed by the Federal Power Commission by Jan. 15, it was learned today.

SKYTOP, Pa., Dec. 27. -- Making up for lost time caused by yesterday's postponement, six games were played today in the second annual interscholastic hockey tournament for the Skytop Trophy and shortly before nightfall three teams had jumped the field with two victories apiece.
U.S. Department of Agriculture.Meat trade conditions and wholesale pricesat New York:

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Revenge was sweet for the St. Louis Eagles tonight as they defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 5 to 2, in a National Hockey League game. Two weeks ago the Red Wings handed the Eagles the season's worst drubbing, 11 to 2.

Those who left Carnegie Hall last night after the concert given by Bruno Walter and the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra were talking of one obliterating experience of the evening -- the performance as pianist and composer of Serge Rachmaninoff.

Discussion of the demand for immediate reconstitution of the Republican National Committee as an initial step in the "liberalizing" of the party seems likely to befuddle rather than enlighten the public mind as to the conditions confronting such a project.

VIENNA, Dec. 27. -- It was announced today that General Koerner, nominal chief of staff of the Republican Defense Corps, who had been imprisoned without trial since Feb. 12, was released Christmas Eve.

KEARNY, N.J., Dec. 27. -- Motorists in this town, Harrison, Newark, Elizabeth and Hillside pulled their automobiles over to the curbs early this morning to permit the swift passage of a bright red Fire Department coupe, with siren screaming and bell clanging.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 27. -- The 1935 tax equalization table which is used in the levying of State, county and special district taxes against the eighteen towns and four cities of Westchester County was adopted by the Board of Supervisors at a meeting here today after a sharp debate between its author, Supervisor Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale, and Supervisor E. Percy Barrett of Bedford, who presented for consideration an amended table.

BERLIN, Dec. 27 (AP). -- "Ridiculous and regrettable propaganda," "malicious, cowardly and baseless propaganda" and "manufactured lies" were Germany's official replies today to charges that another Nazi "blood purge" had occurred.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 27 (AP). -- Because of the increased activity of automobile manufacturers, the Otis Steel Company's semi-finishing department here operated all Christmas Day. Holiday suspensions in the Cleveland-Lorain district's plants were limited to one day otherwise.

Governor ECCLES'S defense of the joint announcement of the Federal Reserve Board and the FDIC of the reduction of maximum interest rates on time deposits to 2 1/2 per cent does not answer the original criticism of Senator GLASS. Mr. ECCLES declares that the Federal Reserve Board has the specific legal right to regulate the interest paid on time deposits by reserve member banks.

Salvatore Guarino, Tin Pan Alley barber who has removed the beards from Irving Berlin and many other song writers for twenty years, has been appointed a colonel on the staff of Governor Ruby Laffoon of Kentucky.

Six veteran policemen filed their applications for retirement yesterday. They are among the eighteen whose retirement was ordered by Police Commissioner O'Ryan last Spring. While Commissioner Valentine declared that he was "giving a good deal of thought" to requests for extensions, it was understood that most of the eighteen would end their service on New Year's Eve.

LITTLE AMERICA, Antarctica Dec. 27. -- Definite indication that the vast elevated plateau encircling the South Pole is connected with the recently discovered plateau of Marie Byrd Land was supplied in a brief radio message this morning from the geological party of the Byrd Expedition, now homeward bound from a penetration that carried them within 102 nautical miles of the South Pole.

Although they ran up a lead of 3 to 0 in the first period, the Toronto Maple Leafs had to go into overtime to defeat the New York Americans in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Plans for partial payments amounting to 2 cents a pound or $10 a bale to all producers of cotton who have surrendered certificates of production under the Bankhead act to the Surplus Cotton Tax-Exemption Certificate Pool were announced today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

The pace of post-holiday trade locally was not particularly brisk. Fair response was reported to clearance of women's Winter apparel and accessories, launched immediately after Christmas. Cold weather aided toward the end of the week and activity today is expected to be of large proportions. With the passing of the New Year's holiday, trade is expected to show up better, with continued emphasis on seasonal merchandise.

SAARBRUECKEN, Saar Basin Territory, Dec. 28. -- A violent attack on the governing commission by a pro-German Deputy and an equally vigorous attack on the German Front by a Communist were the main features of today's session of the Saar Parliament, the last before the plebiscite on Jan. 13. They represented exactly the political tension at this moment.

A firmer tone was in evidence on the commodity futures markets yesterday. Most staples advanced in heavy trading. Rubber and some of the metals eased. On the cash markets gains were scored by all the grains, eggs, silk and cotton, and lard reached a new high level.

Alternative offers to extend for fifteen years the maturity of the bonds or to make payment in "blocked" reichsmark are being made to holders of Siemens Halske A.G. and Siemens-Schuckertwerke A.G. ten-year 7 per cent bonds, which will mature next Tuesday.

SANTA ANITA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP). -- Silvio Coucci, black-haired jockey from the Bronx, crept a step closer to Maurice Peters, apprentice rider from South Dakota, in the race for the year's riding laurels today.

CHANGSHA, Hunan Province, China, Dec. 28 (AP). -- A group of fugitive missionaries who arrived here from bandit-threatened regions today revealed that while they had successfully evaded brigand armies they had been unable to outdistance the stork.
Warner Brothers are contemplating weaving two Arthur Somers Roche stories, "Lady Dick" and "Roadhouse" into a screen play for Kay Francis.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 28 (AP). -- An estimated 80,000 men met today in combat in the wasteland of the Western Chaco in what is regarded as one of the most important battles in the three-year war between Bolivia and Paraguay.

The recommendation made by the President with reference to the suppression of crime is most timely. Criminology and penology are not exact sciences and any contribution founded on experience in connection with these matters ought to be useful.

A group headed by Alvin P. Adams, who was vice president of the National Aviation Corporation, has acquired control of the Western Air Express Corporation from North American Aviation, Inc., an affiliate of the General Motors Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 28. -- The Chamber of Deputies has passed Argentina's 1935 budget authorizing expenditures 14 per cent higher than this year's. The budget totals 904,939,500 pesos. Congress estimates revenues at 778,166,500 pesos. Internal bonds will be issued for 126,000,000 pesos.

" Say When," the musical comedy starring Harry Richman, at the Imperial, will close on Saturday night, Jan. 12, Mr. Richman said last night. It had been known for several days that he wanted to get away to Florida for a rest, and that he had been trying to persuade his friend, Rudy Vallee, to succeed him in the cast.

Directors of the Parker Rustproof Company ordered yesterday a dividend of one share of preferred stock of the Parker-Wolverine Company on each share of Parker Rustproof common stock, payable about Jan. 15 to stock of record of Jan. 2.

Doubleday, Doran have received the first part of Leon Trotsky's life of Lenin, to be published as soon as the work is completed. Based on material to which Trotsky alone has access, the book is described as not only a vivid close-up of Lenin, but an explanation of the whole Russian revolutionary movement on its psychological or personal side.
In discussing headaches yesterday a group of neurologists suggested the probable mechanism of "hangovers."

In a night crowded with debutante parties, one of the largest was a supper dance given by Dr. and Mrs. Walter Palmer Anderton in the roof garden of the Pierre to introduce their daughter, Miss Audrey Anderton.

George Bond Cochran in his letter to THE TIMES on "Wages and the Tariff" suggests that wage increases under the NRA have reduced exports. To be sure, in "dollars" wages may be 5 per cent higher than they were, or so we will admit for sake of argument. But international goods are exchanged in terms of gold, and the dollar is worth about 41 per cent less than it was.

MONTREAL, Dec. 28 (Canadian Press) -- An increase of $3,596,000 in net profits for the first eleven months of 1934, compared with the same months last year, was reported today by the Canadian Pacific Railway. Gross earnings were $114,837,000, against $104,356,000. Net profits advanced from $17,615,000 to $21,212,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- How the Harvard Crimson appeared on the street outside the Yale Bowl with an account of the Harvard-Yale game that had just been played inside, the papers being distributed nine seconds before the copies of the Yale News arrived on the scene, was told to thirty-seven editors of college dailies today by the Harvard man who supervised the "scoop" -- Franklin D. Roosevelt, former editor of The Crimson.

Miss Elizabeth W. Englar gave a dinner last night at her home, 1,000 Park Avenue. Her guests were Mr. and Mrs. Frank Welton, the Misses Maida Lee Mason, Carol Barnes, Janet Mullan, Louise Tucker, Marion Myrick, Louise Lichtenstein, Muriel Smith and Miriam Hall; Oliver Wells, Frederick Duncan, Thomas Clyde, Russell Tucker, Vincent S. Mulford Jr., Lyall Jones, Mayson Tucker and Robert Whitbeck.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- How an easily made concave mirror and a specially figured glass plate, both of which can be constructed by an optician in a short time, are able to do work previously possible only with an expensive lens system was described to the members of the American Astronomical Society today by Dr. Theodore Dunham Jr. of the Mount Wilson Observatory.

To that faithful audience which awaits Handel's "Messiah" at this season in New York as a work sung annually round the world for nearly two centuries, Albert Stoessel at Carnegie Hall last night announced the Oratorio Society's regret that Grace Leslie, one of its intended soloists, could not appear.

IT is solemnly recorded of one Katherine Philips that "she was when a child much against the Bishops, and prayd to God to take them to Him." There are times when reading the new Literary Guild selection, Anthony Thorne's "Delay in the Sun" (Doubleday, Doran, $2.50), that one feels similarly about novels in the "Grand Hotel" tradition.

College basketball will move into a definite niche on the Madison Square Garden program tonight with the staging of the first of a series of six double-headers. An exceedingly attractive program is a forerunner of what court fans have in store for them.

Replying yesterday to the Roosevelt Administration's plan to transfer about 4,000,000 unemployables from Federal to State relief rolls about Jan. 15, Mayor La Guardia said he was ready to press a $310,000,000 public works program here if he could get Federal loans at one-eighth of 1 per cent interest, or no interest.

Mr. and Mrs. Earle R. Lewis gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the Pierre for their debutante daughters, the Misses Marjorie Ruth and Helen Germaine Lewis. Many in society and the musical world were in attendance to greet the debutantes, whose father is treasurer of the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- As another step to facilitate sale of new capital issues, J.F.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, has promulgated regulations under which Federal Reserve member banks may hereafter buy, for their own account and direct from the issuers, new issues of investment securities when the issuer has other securities outstanding with a broad market, and the new securities are registered under the Securities Act of 1933.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A plan to more than double the size of the Civilian Conservation Corps was under serious consideration tonight by President Roosevelt as part of a broad Winter work relief program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Charges of collusion by high army officers and War Department officials to obtain valuable government contracts for representatives of corporations from whom they received substantial fees were set forth in a final report made today by the subcommittee of the House Military Affairs Committee which has been investigating War Department transactions.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Two Brooms, a 3-year-old brown colt carrying the colors of J.R. Schuster, triumphed by a length over G. O'Keefe's Royal Purchase in the featured race at the Fair Grounds today.

Wall Street's ideas as to what caused the broad advance on the Stock Exchange yesterday afternoon were vague, but the one thought advanced over all others in speculative circles was that a Congress disposed toward some form of inflation is shortly to sit in Washington.

Open admission of the existence in college sport of recruiting and subsidization of athletes came yesterday when, at the closing session of the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, a nine-point code was adopted in an effort to control this problem.

The intention of the Bureau of Internal Revenue of the Treasury Department to demand the payment by theatrical producers of the regular 10 per cent government tax on the house receipts from all charitable and benefit performances given in legitimate theatres was indicated yesterday as a result of the recent examination of ledgers at several Broadway theatres by bureau officials.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Four large employer groups have united in opposition to a petition by the New Jersey State Federation of Labor and thirty-two central labor organizations affiliated with the American Federation of Labor seeking Chancery Court rules to limit the issuance of injunctions in labor disputes.

Mrs. Herbert I. Foster gave a dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Pierre for her debutante daughter, Miss Betty Benjamin. White trees illuminated by blue lights were used in the decorations.

Following a sharp rise in the first two weeks of this month, sales in department stores in the metropolitan area of New York fell abruptly to a level barely equalling that of a year ago, it was revealed yesterday in a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York covering the Christmas shopping period.

DUBLIN, Dec. 28. -- The most notable of the dramatic fare in Dublin this week is the production at the Gate Theatre of a traditional Chinese play, "Lady Precious Stream," as translated into English by S.I. Hsiung. Another presentation of the same play is current in London.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 28. -- Meeting Jose R. Capablanca of Havana, former world champion, in the second round today, Sir. George Thomas, British titleholder, gained his second consecutive victory in the international tournament at the Christmas Chess Congress of the Hastings and St. Leonard Chess Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Seventy-two children of the ninety who were invited attended a Christmas party given at the White House this afternoon for the grandchildren of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 28. -- The State Association of Elementary Principals adopted a resolution today urging a study by the Legislature and Congress of sterilization of mental incompetents and criminals and voted unanimously to ratify affiliation with the New York City Elementary Principals Association. The actions were taken at the final session of the organization's annual conference.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- King Levinsky, the heavyweight Rock of Gibraltar, finished flat on his back in the second round of his scheduled four-round bout with Max Baer, world's heavyweight champion, in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

EDINBURGH, Dec. 28. -- "Nova Scotia means New Scotland," Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald reminded his hearers in addressing the Gaelic League at Elgin today. "It is the place where you find the old Highlander and the old Highland woman."

Colonel and Mrs. Basil Martiau Stevens introduced their daughter, Miss Emily Custis Lewis Stevens, last night at a supper dance at the River Club that was attended not only by young people but by many of the older friends of the host and hostess.

A succession of outstanding "victories" in the last few years may be credited to the efforts and ideals of President Wilson, according to Pierre de Lanux, the director of the Paris office of the League of Nations, who arrived this week for a four months' lecture tour of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- A vivid account of pre-repeal liquor smuggling practices that portrayed the ship I'm Alone as the instrument of a New York rum-running syndicate today was presented to the American-Canadian Judicial Commission.

I crossed last week from Southampton upon the United States liner Washington, a magnificent vessel, splendidly equipped with every modern device to make passengers comfortable. She should, as her sister ship, the Manhattan, command the whole-hearted support of the traveling public.

The Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod will preach his last sermons tomorrow morning and evening as active pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. It will be his twenty-fifth anniversary as pastor. He is 67 years old.

Preparations for big doings on Monday night -- yes, New Year's Eve -- have been made by all the clubs and cabarets from Delancey Street to Yonkers and a gala evening to compare with the best that the Nineteen Twenties had to offer is anticipated.

BERLIN, Dec. 28 (AP). -- An innocent gesture of respect at the grave of Rosa Luxemburg, internationally famous as a German Communist leader, has landed two pretty young German girls, sisters, in a Nazi concentration camp.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28. -- Albert Einstein, humble man of science by inclination, whom George Bernard Shaw described as one of the eight "universe makers" of all time, gave to 400 American scientists today the treat of watching him remodel his universe. A piece of chalk was his only tool.

The restrictions on religious liberty in Russia and Mexico were denounced by Cardinal Hayes yesterday as fatal "to the very souls of children" in those countries. He spoke at the annual Christmas party in the New York Foundling Hospital at 175 East Sixty-eighth Street, of whose advisory board he is the president.

Police Commissioner Valentine took his first step yesterday in reorganizing the Crime Prevention Bureau by obtaining the resignations of Miss Helen P. Mulrooney, daughter of former Police Commissioner Mulrooney, and her friend, Miss Florence MacDonald.

The New York Board of Trade aligned itself definitely yesterday against Mayor La Guardia's plan to have the city build its own electric power generating system and called upon him to hold a public hearing on the matter before he commits the city to any financial obligations.

PORTSMOUTH, England, Dec. 28. -- In remodeling his racing yacht Britannia to meet the American sloop Yankee, owned by Gerard B. Lambert, in England next season, King George has decided to use sail equipment like that of Endeavour's and Rainbow's except that Britannia will not have a Genoa jib.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28. -- The reemployment of four or five million workers must be brought about in the near future through a great expansion of private enterprise or through further government activities, Donald R. Richberg, executive director of the National Emergency Council, declared in an address here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- Just twenty-four minutes separated the opening and the closing curtains of Stravinsky's "Mavra," given its American premiere at the Academy of Music this afternoon in the series of stage productions undertaken by the Philadelphia Orchestra.

James G. McDonald, League of Nations High Commissioner for Refugees Coming from Germany, was presented last night with the Pi Lambda Phi jeweled gold medal for tolerance at the intercollegiate fraternity's Convention dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations, including processing tax, on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Influenced by an advance in Liverpool and by strength of the stock market, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved upward steadily yesterday and closed at the top with gains of 8 to 14 points.
BUDAPEST, Dec. 28. -- Domestic difficulties may stand in the way of Archduke Albrecht's aspirations to ascend the Hungarian throne, it was indicated today.

Yet another list of the year's "ten best" motion pictures has been compiled, the selection being that of the Young Reviewers Club of the National Board of Review. The age of the juvenile critics ranges from 8 to 17. Two lists were made, one chosen by boys and girls from 8 to 12 and the other by the 13 to 17 age group.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 28. -- America is approaching choice between "competing philosophies of the national being" which will shape the nation's future, Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, told the Pennsylvania Education Association today.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Banking Superintendent, who retires from office on Monday, received the commendation of Supreme Court Justice Valente yesterday for the superintendent's handling of the liquidation of the Bank of United States.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Nineteen employes of the Omsk Railway were sentenced to prison today for counter-revolutionary sabotage, carelessness and inefficiency alleged to have caused wrecks resulting in property damage totaling 1,500,000 rubles.

DADE CITY, Fla., Dec. 28. -- Mrs. Janine Voisin Pinchot, formerly of the Paris stage and daughter of Gabriel Voisin, French automobile manufacturer, obtained a divorce from her husband, Gifford Pinchot 2d, in court here Dec. 8, it was revealed today.

A junior world's record for model airplanes was set yesterday at 101st Cavalry Armory, Madison Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street. Hyman Oslick of Philadelphia, competing in the division for boys 15 years old or under, sent his gossamer-winged little seaplane off from a four-foot tank and saw it soar, under rubber band power, for 10 minutes 59 seconds.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 28. -- Objections to the proposed plan of reorganization of the Alleghany Corporation, a Van Sweringen holding company, were heard today by Judge W. Calvin Chestnut in Federal District Court here, who deferred ruling on the questions raised. Similar actions in other cases are pending in other Federal jurisdictions, it was said.

The sale of the Red Star liners Pennland and Westernland to the Arnold Bernstein Line was virtually completed yesterday at a conference attended by P.A.S. Franklin, president of the International Mercantile Marine Company, owner of the Red Star Line, and Arnold Bernstein, president of the line that bears his name.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 28. -- Disposing of more than $285,000 in personal, institutional and charitable bequests, the will of Madge D. Miller, daughter of Charles R. Miller, former editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was filed here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Two mortgage trustees of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York and Benjamin F. Edwards, served notice on the Supreme Court today they would enter the gold clause payment case involving that road.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The decision by Federal relief authorities to hand back to States and municipalities the care of "unemployables" now on the relief rolls was viewed in Congressional circles today as giving strong impetus to the movement to enact old-age pension legislation.

Three weeks ago Mr. JAMES J. DOOLING, new leader of the Newest Tammany, went to Washington, filled with hope and ardor. Mr. FARLEY ushered him into the presence of Mr. ROOSEVELT. The high theme of patronage was discussed. Mr. DOOLING'S expectations must have been of the loftiest. His last words as he jumped happily on his train were: "Tammany "Hall is 1,000,000 per cent behind "ROOSEVELT."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Complete separation of the Postmaster General from any relationship with a political committee or party activity, and the application of civil service status to all postal employes are called for in a bill completed today by Senator Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, for submission to Congress.

The sources from which was obtained the $149,724,338 in assets and liabilities appearing in the consolidated balance sheet of the Paramount-Publix Corporation and the subsidiaries that are not in receivership or bankruptcy were given yesterday to Judge Alfred C. Coxe in United States District Court.

PARIS, Dec. 28. -- Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin announced today that the price of bread would be reduced in Paris by 25 centimes a kilo [about 1.65 cents per 2.2 pounds], starting Sunday. The rest of France will take a similar step either the same day or within a few days.

SKYTOP, Pa., Dec. 28. -- Its passing attack functioning smoothly, and its defense impregnable, the Taft School hockey team, playing under the name of the Watertown A.C. because of school restrictions, routed the Morristown School sextet, 5 -- 0, in the final of the second annual interscholastic tournament at the Skytop Club today.

Wilson Co., Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the year ended on Oct. 27 a net profit of $3,840,924, including $7.463 discount on bonds purchased for sinking fund and after providing for taxes, interest, depreciation, minority interest and other charges.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 28. -- A legislative program for Pennsylvania, to enable its municipalities to obtain the full benefits from the proposed public works program which the next session of Congress will be asked to authorize, was suggested by President Roosevelt in a letter received today by Governor-elect George H. Earle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The NRA exercised "ultimate discretion" today in the San Francisco Call-Bulletin Blue Eagle case, and referred the question to the Newspaper Industrial Board, labor disputes agency of the Daily Newspaper Publishers' Code of Fair Competition.

Stockholders of the First National Bank of Jersey City voted yesterday to effect a merger with the First National Bank of Hoboken, of which Odgen K. Hammond, former Ambassador to Spain, is president. The Hoboken bank was established in 1857.

SAARBRUECKEN, Dec. 28. -- To charges voiced in the anti-Nazi press yesterday that another "blood purge" had taken place in Germany, with 100 or more dead and thousands arrested, Nazis in the Saar Parliament replied today with bitter counter-attacks.

The opening talk in a new series of discussions for and against immediate payment of the soldiers' adjusted compensation certificates was made last night by Donald A. Hobart, of Bronxville, National Commander of the American Veterans Association, over an NBC network.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 28. -- The pool and patio of the Bath and Tennis Club were the setting for a swimming party and luncheon with which Mr. and Mrs. Wiley R. Reynolds entertained forty members of the younger set today in honor of their daughter, Miss Annette Reynolds, and their son, Wiley Jr.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Secretary Wallace announced tonight that the policy of drastically curtailing crops to enhance prices had reached its maximum, and he challenged industry to increase production in order to restore prosperity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The Washington Post will say tomorrow that legislation making possible consolidation of all transmission services in the country will he submitted to Congress by the Communications Commission before Feb. 1.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Another drop in receipts of hogs here today brought general buying by all interests and lifted prices 10 to 25 cents a hundred weight over those of yesterday. The top and average prices were up 20 cents. The top of $7.20 was the best since Sept. 21, and the highest for the Winter season since 1929-30, while the average was $6.80.

Reorganization of three member firms and formation of three new ones were announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, together with changes in twenty-one other firms affiliated with the Exchange. The firms that will be dissolved and reorganized under the same names at the year-end are Appenzellar, Allen Hill, Cowen Co. and Libaire Co.

Indeterminate penitentiary terms of not more than three years were imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Edward T. McCarron, beer tavern owner, and John Merry, a McCarron henchman, for assaulting Patrolman Henry W. Smith in East Seventy-fifth Street shortly after midnight on Aug. 13.
In a letter printed In THE TIMES A.C. Knehr states that as a result of the last thirty-eight years of our export trading there is owing to us from abroad approximately $22,500,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- How the United States began to withdraw after the World War from direct official participation in European affairs is told in two volumes of Foreign Relations of the United States, covering 1919, issued today by the State Department.
LONDON, Dec. 28. -- In Japanese circles tonight it was understood there would be no more Anglo-Japanese naval talks by the full delegations until next March at the earliest.

Aaron Sapiro, nationally known lawyer, who once sued Henry Ford charging that he had libeled the Jewish race in his Dearborn Independent, received congratulations of friends yesterday in Federal court when he was acquitted of the charge that he attempted to bribe a jury in a mail-fraud case early in 1933.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Dec. 28. -- Altar a long conference in Lynchburg today with Senator Carter Glass, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said he agrees with Senator Glass that the Bank Act of 1933 does not authorize the recent action of the FDIC ordering non-member State banks to reduce interest payments on time and savings deposits.

ADDIS ABABA, Abyssinia, Dec. 28. -- Anxiety over recent frontier incidents remains undiminished here, owing to the fact that the Italians are reported to be continuing to construct roads into territory claimed as Abyssinian.

BOGOTA, Dec. 28. -- Former Foreign Minister Roberto Urdaneta Arbalaez, who resigned from the Cabinet to lead the fight in the Senate for ratification of the Rio de Janeiro pact, admitted today that he regarded the fight as lost.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The stock markets here were cheerful today, but less active, and they closed irregular. British funds failed to hold their recent gains, declining slightly. Brazilian and Japanese issues weakened in the foreign market, while the German list was steady.

MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 29. -- Joseph Stalin, general secretary of the Communist party, has marked out a new path for Soviet industry, in which attention will be focused not merely on machines, but on the human beings who run them. He enunciated his views in an address to fifty leaders of iron and steel plants of the Soviet Union at a conference in the Kremlin Wednesday, which was not made public until 1:30 A.M. today.

An act of generous philanthropy of the kind that has done so much to encourage friends of the Neediest Cases Fund was revealed yesterday when the will of Madge D. Miller, daughter of Charles R. Miller, former editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was filed at Mineola, L.I.

The performance of Wagner's "Siegfried" last night by the Metropolitan Association had a cast which offered as its new element Mme. Konetzni's Bruennhilde, and otherwise an array of artists who interpreted the music with much fine singing and dramatic impact, reinforced by Mr. Bodanzky's excellent reading of the score.

The sharp increase in activity in securities brought o change in the credit market. There business was ns usual, along small lines and at levels which developed no variation from standing quotations. Stock ]Exchange call loans, maturity money and acceptances were quiet. while there was fair activity in commercial paper.

The international aspect of motor boating next season loomed larger than ever yesterday. One of the developments came from George W. Sutton, president of the American Power Boat Association, who, on his return from Detroit, said that an international regatta of ambitious proportions was in the making for next Labor Day weekend on the Detroit River.

Mr. and Mrs. William T. Dewart gave a large dinner dance last night in the Ritz-Carlton to introduce their daughter, Miss Mary Dewart. It was in the Crystal Room, which had been transformed into an outdoor garden surrounded by tall poplar trees.
Federal Judge Julian W. Mack fixed yesterday the compensation of Thomas E. Murray Jr. as equity receiver for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company at $3,750 a month.

A petition seeking the removal of the receivers for the Manufacturers Liability Insurance Company of Jersey City has been filed in Chancery Court at Trenton, N.J., by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., representing Elmer F. Andrews, New York State Industrial Commissioner, it was announced yesterday by the State Department of Labor.

The weather returned to normal yesterday after a cold snap accompanied by gales throughout the East. The wind died down to a mild breeze during the day and the average temperature was above the freezing point.

Having had an honorable career as a drama critic, Carlton Miles has committed the peccadillo of writing a play, "Portrait of Gilbert," which was carefully acted at the Longacre last evening. When a drama critic begins to write "exits" and "entrances" instead of "leads" and "adds," the theatre has an unpleasant habit of taking revenge for all his professional misdemeanors.

The Board of Education will ask the Board of Estimate to seek $120,747,000 from the Federal Government to carry out a three-year program for the construction of 168 new school buildings and additions to existing structures. Approval of the program was given by the Education Board members at its meeting yesterday.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 28. -- Jay F. Carlisle, owner of the noted Wingan Kennels of field-trial Labrador retrievers and pointers of East Islip, today won all three places in the open novice stake at the retriever trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association at Strong's Neck in East Setauket.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Mayor La Guardia, with a special sales tax for unemployment relief already operating in New York City, joined today with the Mayors of other cities of New York in urging on Governor Lehman and the Legislature a State-wide sales tax, with refunds to localities for reducing the tax burden on real estate.

Disclosing a thriving condition in sports undertakings of Madison Square Garden in contradiction to what he said "appears to be the general public opinion," Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, Garden president, yesterday issued a statement for the period from June 1 to Nov. 30, showing that six branches of activities drew larger attendances this year as compared with the same period last year.

New financing scheduled for next week by States and municipalities amounts to $8,575,200, compared with a revised total for this week of $8,059,477, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date was $19,212,820, although this was not necessarily the weekly average of actual sales.

The necessity of high and preparatory schools to reduce their football death toll was stressed yesterday by Professor Floyd H. Eastwood of New York University in reporting the results of a four-year survey of football fatalities.

" Dr. Butler Scores Rule by the Few; Sees Minority in Power," according to THE TIMES headlines introducing your description of his annual report as president of Columbia University. Then you quote him: "The direct primary has permanently enthroned minority rule, leaving public opinion to shift for itself."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- A definite program of banking legislation will be presented to the new Congress by the administration. Details are being worked out by the Treasury, Federal Reserve Board, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the office of the Controller of the Currency, it was indicated today.

Reform of the capitalist system by radical methods, with the use of force if necessary, was demanded yesterday by leading philosophers and educators of the nation at the annual sessions of the American Philosophical Association, Eastern Division, at the Washington Square Centre of New York University.

The first forty-eight railroads to report had net operating income in November of $26,156,000, against $31,823,000 in November, 1933, a drop of 17.8 per cent, and against $28,386,000 in November, 1932, a fall of 7.9 per cent. In October their net was $39,798,000, against $47,607,000 in October, 1933, a fall of 16.4 per cent.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (AP). -- Why a man can "go till he drops" under stress, seemingly throwing off fatigue, is explained in a new way by experiements reported today to the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The Woodcrest Construction Company, Inc., holder of a contract for construction work on one of the Queens approaches to the Triborough Bridge, has appealed twice during the last week to PWA authorities in Washington to make available funds for a payment due, it was learned yesterday.

An American Airlines mail and passenger plane carrying two passengers besides the pilot and co-pilot was reported missing last night somewhere between Syracuse, N.Y., and Albany after encountering a snowstorm in the Mohawk Valley. State troopers started a widespread search for the plane.

Locking the door of her little jewelry shop in the Hotel Marie Antoinette building at 1,965 Broadway yesterday morning, Mrs. Sarah Saeger, a diminutive woman of 60 years, struggled with two Negro theft suspects until the arrival of detectives.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Expenditure of "tens of billions of dollars" for new machinery by the durable goods industries and resulting re-employment of about 4,500,000 workers await only the restoration of business confidence and credit, John W. O'Leary, president of the Machinery and Allied Products Institute, declared today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Wholesale commodity prices in the week ended Dec. 22 remained unchanged for the third consecutive week, Commissioner Lubin of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today, the index holding at 76.7.

All classes of bonds closed generally higher yesterday in quiet trading. Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange amounted to $10,431,500, against $13,331,700 the day before. United States Government issues accounted for $1,578,500 of the total, against $1,560,700 on Thursday.
LONDON, Dec. 28. -- With the naval talks over and the Saar plebiscite still a fortnight off there is a sort of diplomatic lull here in which Britain's Continental policies come up for review.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 28. -- An age-old human skeleton encased in a crude metal cage, similar to torture chambers used by pirates, was unearthed today by boys playing in a vacant lot at Union Place and Main Street here. An iron spike 6 inches long protruded from a hole just below the right eye of the victim.

Compilation of the final returns for 1934 doubtless will reveal an increase in retail sales of 15 to 20 per cent over the 1933 figures, for the country as a whole, with gains running as high as 30 to 40 per cent in the South, Southwest and some sections of the Middle West, according to the weekly survey of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 28 (AP). -- Southern industrialists were told today that a survey of 6,000 manufacturers indicated that NIRA should be "drastically modified or abandoned altogether."

MOSCOW, Dec. 28. -- The second day since the publication of the indictment of Leonid Nikolaieff and thirteen others, arrested in Leningrad for the assassination of Sergei Kiroff and a plot against the lives of Joseph Stalin and other Soviet leaders, passed with no news of what is happening to them.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 28. -- Loyd Wright, attorney for Mary Pickford, said today he had been instructed to go ahead immediately after Jan. 1 with her long-pending divorce suit against Douglas Fairbanks.

Placing the blame for any evils which exist in college football squarely upon the administrative heads of colleges, William J. Bingham, graduate manager of Harvard, warned at the annual dinner of the American Football Coaches Association at the Pennsylvania last night that the game itself was threatened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Two former employes of the Internal Revenue Bureau and two New York accountants were indicted by a District of Columbia grand jury today on charges of conspiracy to defraud the government in income tax cases.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

In the ballroom of the Park Lane last night, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Will of this city and Roslyn, L.I., gave a dinner dance to introduce their daughter, Miss Kay Will. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a gown of silver and gold lame.

Princeton's chess players turned the tables on Yale in the championship play-off of the H.Y.P.D. League at the Marshall Club yesterday. The Tigers prevailed by 2 -- 0, the precise figures by which the Eli representatives scored the previous day.

Controller MCGOLDRICK has still another day or two to serve the city as its chief fiscal officer. But since he has already said his farewells, and since his colleagues of the Board of Estimate have already pressed the laurels on his brow, and wished him godspeed, it may be in order for a newspaper to follow suit.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Dec. 28. -- The hope for a New York singles finalist in the girls' national indoor title tennis tournament was lost today when Miss Helen Bernhard suffered defeat at the hands of Miss Elena Ciccone of Newton in a two-hour match, 14 -- 12, 6 -- 4.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

A recent English tourist in Canada was being shown the sights of Ottawa by a Canadian guide. The Englishman finally asked: "Who is that little old "man walking round and round Par-"liament House and muttering to him-"self?" The answer was: "Oh, that is "Mr. BENNETT, the Prime Minister of "the Dominion. He is holding a meet-"ing of the Cabinet."

The amended sales tax bill and a new bill imposing a levy of 2 per cent on personal property bought outside the city were signed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday after perfunctory public hearings at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Improvements in the Cape Cod Canal so as to afford safe navigation for practically all coast-wise craft by providing depths of 32 feet were recommended today by Major Gen. Edward M. Markham, Chief of Army Engineers, to the House Rivers and Harbors Committee at an estimated cost of $26,000,000.

One year ago President ROOSEVELT directed the Treasury to purchase silver mined in the United States, with a view to "absorbing annually at least 24,421,410 ounces." This action was taken on the basis of authority granted in the so-called Thomas amendment to the Farm Act of 1933.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh spent three hours this afternoon at his country estate near Hopewell, in the Sourland Mountain region, explaining to Attorney General David T. Wilentz exactly what happened the night of March 1, 1932, when his infant son, Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., was kidnapped.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Dec. 28. -- Clashes between members of the rival unions marked the second day of the general strike called by the insurgent organization, the United Anthracite Miners of Pennsylvania, at collieries of the Glen Alden Coal Company in protest against alleged pay reductions and discrimination against workers.

Professor BREASTED, the eminent Orientalist, in an address before the American Historical Association states that the Egyptian social sages preached help for the "forgotten man" and proclaimed the "New Deal" at least four thousand years ago. The dawning sense of social responsibility expressed itself a thousand years earlier.

With the pressure of "tax selling" relaxed somewhat, the share market turned confidently upward yesterday in the widest advance since last June. Net gains of 1 to 3 or 4 points or more appeared among the market leaders and the composite index of averages rose nearly 2 1/2 points. The industrial averages were up more than 4 points; the railway group, more than 3/4 point.

Delay in filling the Speakership of tl Assembly is likely if Assemblyman Louis A. Cuvillier of the Twentieth Manhattan district, himself a candidate for the post, should persist in his "unalterable" opposition to the election of Assemblyman Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, Democratic leader of the Assembly.

BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- Elated by a telegram from President Roosevelt, hailing their deliberations as important to the nation's future, over 200 student government heads and other delegates from 150 colleges in almost every State opened the annual Congress of the National Student Federation here today with discussions of students' right to free speech, and to "collective bargaining" with college trustees.

A warning that "the welfare of the game is menaced by the ever-increasing betting on results," and that "continued welfare of coaches depends upon our ability to do something about curbing the increase in excessive drinking in our stands," featured the final day of the convention of the American Football Coaches Association yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade made a tame start and a strong finish today. Little interest was shown by speculative interests until about an hour before the close, when active buyign of December corn, credited to local operators, disclosed an oversold condition and started general short covering.

A program for the retirement of $49,371,948 of special stock and bonds was adopted yesterday by the directors of the General Electric Company at their regular monthly meeting. This will leave the company without debt and with a capital consisting solely of 28,845,927 common shares of no par value.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for saving banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

Despite unemployment and relief measures, women should bend every effort to maintain the status they gained as workers during and after the war, speakers declared yesterday at a conference of the American Woman's Association arranged in its clubhouse at 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Mrs. Roosevelt today smilingly disclaimed any responsibility for or connection with any increase by the Federal Radio Commission of the wave length of the Socialist Radio Station WEVD. She added that to the best of her knowledge no speech of hers ever had been broadcast by that station.

MADRID, Dec. 28. -- After carefully considering all evidence presented by the Attorney General against the former Socialist Premier Manuel Azana and his former secretary, Luis Bello, the Spanish Supreme Court today decided there was no grounds for an indictment. Orders were telegraphed to Barcelona for the immediate release of the two.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 28. -- Displaying a powerful attack, the University of Toronto hockey team tonight defeated Harvard, 4 to 2, in a game considered as a prelude to the fourteenth annual intercollegiate Winter sports program, which gets under way tomorrow.

Methods by which the Police Department can avoid being a kill-joy on New Year's Eve and yet induce New Yorkers to start 1935 aright by observing law and some order in their celebrations were evolved yesterday in conferences between Chief Inspector John J. Seery and his aides.

BEAVER FALLS, Pa., Dec. 28. -- Unable to penetrate the zone defense of the Geneva College quintet, the previously undefeated City College of New York lost a fast basketball game tonight by a 50-27 score.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Listing of the October wheat future was deferred by the Winnipeg Grain Exchange today to prevent speculation in a crop not yet sown. The Exchange's change in policy, the third step in the Canadian Government's effort to regulate the marketing of the Dominion's grain crop, follows pegging of prices of wheat futures and limiting of fluctuations in flax.

President Roosevelt's plan to transfer the able-bodied unemployed from the dole to work relief after the first of the year may make it possible to remove from local home relief rolls about 155,000 families representing more than 750,000 individuals and reduce home relief expenditures from $8,000,000 to $2,000,000. a month, it was announced yesterday by William Hodson, Commissioner of Public Welfare.
Only one of the eight seeded players in the national junior indoor tennis singles championship failed to gain a place in the quarter-final round at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday.

Again there comes to the support of the Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools in their appeal for funds with which to provide necessary school buildings the urgent argument of the British War Minister of Education for children in general: "Educa-"tion is the eternal debt of maturity "to childhood and youth."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP). -- The seventy-eighth anniversary of Woodrow Wilson's birth was commemorated today at his tomb in Bethlehem Chapel of Washington Cathedral.
IT is a comparatively simple matter to become party to an argument in almost any corner of sport's vast domain. But somehow the most fertile field of all must be horse racing.

Various divertissements in which debutantes of this and recent seasons took part were features of the Continental Ball held last night at Sherry's in behalf of the Junior Group of the League of Nations Association. One of the unusual numbers on the program was a ballet chorus comprised of debutantes of this season, wearing black and gold Pierrette costumes.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP). -- Stanford, preparing for its New Year's football game with Alabama, held an unscheduled forenoon workout at Brookside Park today, with few observers present. This afternoon the Palo Alto squad worked again, completing the first double-header practice since last Autumn.

In speaking of words and their uses, it seems to me, too much stress is laid on the size of the vocabulary at one's disposal and not enough on its quality. Words are in a real sense clothes for thought. And just as one needs not a superfluity of clothing to dress well and tastefully, even so one needs not words running in the tens of thousands to express one's self adequately and with variety.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 28. -- Jockey Wayne Wright, leading rider at the current meeting, boosted his total number of victories for the session to twelve by completing a triple at Tropical Park today.

Superior stickwork and faster skating enabled the St. Nicholas Hockey Club to rout Dartmouth College, 5 to 1, last night at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx. Charlie Kirkland led the attack with two goals.

Sunset today will ring down the curtain on the 1934 duck shooting season on Long Island. In the gathering dusk, thousands of gunners will climb out of marsh blinds, punts and batteries and wend their way homeward.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Dec. 28 (AP). -- The value of the Smith Reynolds estate, subject of a complicated legal battle looking to final settlement, was revealed as apparently much larger than usually estimated when its custodian today added its contentions to the conflicting claims.

The president of Notre Dame University, speaking at the Sportsmanship Brotherhood luncheon, laid down one of those self-evident propositions that are not self-evident at all. Father O'HARA was arguing for the place of athletics in a well-rounded education.

UNLESS ways can be found to increase America's imports, the recovery of cotton exports on a permanent basis is doubtful. And it may be that the tariff-protected industries will not permit this to be done. It would seem, therefore, that the Southern cotton farmer is facing a new kind of competition for his foreign markets.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 29. -- An eventual dictatorship for this country was predicted by Philippe Soupault, French critic, poet and writer, at the annual meeting of the Modern Language Association of America today.

The skeleton that three boys unearthed Friday in a vacant lot in Hempstead, L.I., probably was that of an Indian who was executed by white settlers and left hanging from a gibbet in early Colonial days as an example to his fellow-tribesmen, according to one expert's view yesterday.

Polly, Moran, whose broad-gauged humors are familiar to motion-picture audiences throughout the land, was the palpable hit of the otherwise routine floor show which opened on Friday night at the new Congress Restaurant, at Fifty-first Street and Broadway.

RADIO in 1934 distinguished itself artistically more than scientifically. In the evolution of broadcasting, scientific achievements give the showmen new tools with which to shape the sounds, and it usually requires several years for artistry to catch up with what science produces.
TOKYO, Dec. 29. -- Foreign Minister Koki Hirota's statement today explaining the denunciation of the Washington Naval Treaty, makes a favorable first impression on many sections of Japanese opinion.

BELASCO used to say anybody could act -- for a half minute, at least. The movies incline to agree with him. Not only actors mime before the camera, but clowns, trapeze fliers, jugglers and crooners, who can pack all they have into the space of a minute.

THE poems in this book, which is in "The Yale Series of Younger Poets," edited by Stephen Vincent Benet, express a point of view so unusual as to make judgment hazardous. To many this originality will appeal strongly, simply because originality in poetry is even more rare than in the novel or the drama.

Recodification of the State banking law and legislation to abolish preference in the deposit of public funds will be recommended by the Joint Legislative Committee on Banks, Senator Thomas F. Burchill, its chairman, announced yesterday. The committee will make these recommendations in its report which will be submitted to the Legislature at the coming session.

MIAMI -- Among innovations featuring the welcome to 1935 will be breakfast on the terrace at the Miami-Biltmore Country Club on Tuesday morning, to be served as the first rays of the sun appear beyond Biscayne Bay. Introducing the Miami-Biltmore New Year's Eve celebration and ball, waiters in old English costumes will sing carols in the country club gardens and about the grounds of the Miami-Biltmore Hotel.

ANOTHER of the Baker board's major recommendations has now been put in effect. This body, which made a detailed study of military aviation in the United States, advised that the force of combat planes should be brought up to at least 2,320. This program was accepted with enthusiasm by the War Department and steps to make it effective have already been undertaken.

PARIS, Dec. 4. LE GOUT DU RISQUE," by the veteran Alfred Mortier, which has recently been given at the Theatre des Arts, is a rather surprising production for this erudite explorer into the literary history of the Italian Renaissance.

Skiing, which has been increasing rapidly in popularity during the last decade, enjoyed its most successful season in the United States last Winter. Especially was this so in the East, where an unusually snowy Winter permitted the holding of an ambitious program of ski jumping tournaments, cross-country and downhill races.

THERE is going to be more and less nudity on the beaches this Winter -- the sun-warmed sands of Nassau, Florida and the other Southern playgrounds. This ambiguous statement means that those going in for sun-tanning will do so in a big way; bathing suits are built for it.

In reviewing the activities of the past year in the field of fishing and hunting, one development stands out clearly. It was a year which saw American sportsmen become conservation-conscious as never before.

Probably no combination of industry and sport weathered the depression more successfully than that of the breeding and showing of thoroughbred dogs. It is confidently expected that when the final figures become available the total number of dogs registered with the American Kennel Club will have broken all records.

The second concert of concertos by Ossip Gabrilowitsch and the National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conductor, took place, with the assistance of a small chorus trained and directed by Margarete Dessoff, yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall.
Lord Jim is pretty much the story of light-harness horse racing during 1934. He won about $50,000 in prizes, was first in the noted Hambletonian, and then was sold for $8,100.

ALFREDO PANZINI of the Accademia d'Italia has for many years been one of the best known, most popular and most highly admired of writers in Italy -- in Italy, but not outside of Italy. Only quite lately the Nouvelles litteraires of Paris dedicated its first page to his writings and printed a translation of one of his whimsical short stories.

For the second year in a row the Midwest again dominated the outstanding cross-country events as Tom Ottey of Michigan State repeated in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. harrier championship and as Don Lash, Indiana University sophomore, succeeded Ray Sears of Butler as national senior A.A.U. title-holder. Still another Midwesterner, James Smith, Indiana freshman, romped off with the national junior crown.

NOT even in the vagaries of thought did Humperdinck chance to conceive "Hansel und Gretel" as a vehicle that would some day reach instantaneously the ears of thousands of listeners. Yet Christmas week brought to a nation-wide audiences two versions of this fantastically contrived fairy tale -- a tabloid presentation in English and the complete opera in German.

Glenn Cunningham, Kansas graduate student and world record-holder at the mile, indoors and out, will make his 1935 bow to New York track fans in the Knights of Columbus games in Brooklyn next Saturday, the games committee announced yesterday through The Associated Press.

One final football meeting brought the week's list of gatherings to a close in New York yesterday when the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials met at the McAlpin Hotel. The officials heard an address given by Walter R. Okeson, chairman of the rules committee, and discussed informally rules changes and other matters pertaining to officiating.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Under a new system of criminal law proposed by Professor Alfred L. Gausewitz of the University of Wisconsin, bandits, burglars and other violent offenders would hear the novel sentence:

SOME 1,200 reports and papers were presented at the meeting in Pittsburgh last week of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. A million and a half words of science. They were not delivered in announcing entirely new discoveries, but they served the useful purpose of summarizing what has been recently accomplished in such widely separated fields as cosmic physics and biology, geology and physiology, bacteriology and chemistry, anthropology and medicine.
MELBOURNE, Dec. 28. -- In a speech obviously prepared after consultation with Berlin, the German Consul General here, Dr. Asmis, before the Millions Club in Sydney, revealed Germany's trading policy.

The destructive earthquakes reported recently -- most of them in the great chain of mountains that girdle the Pacific Ocean -- bring again to the front the disputed theory of their relation to the period when sunspots are at their maxima. In other words, is there a relation between planetary influences and earthquakes?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Japan's denunciation of the Washington Naval Treaty has put up to the United States a question of whether it shall modify or adhere to its present naval building program.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Warning industry that if it does not hasten the needed geographical readjustment of industrial production it will see a perpetual taxation of the industrial and business population for the benefit of the rural population and the unemployed, John T. Ferris of the Tennessee Valley Authority today set forth a program which he proposed that national industry adopt.

A match for the world's championship and tournaments at Chicago, Syracuse and Zurich kept chess enthusiasts well supplied with master play during the past year. Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris successfully defended his world's title in a match with E.D. Bogoljubow.

With a view to possibly shedding some light on the problems brought out by Carter and Pollard in their "Inquiry concerning the nature of certain nineteenth-century pamphlets'' ! am compiling a check list of copies of the pamphlets found in American libraries and in private collections.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29. -- Dr. Robert A. Millikan, Nobel prize winner and pioneer in cosmic ray research, told a gathering of science teachers and physicists here today that he expected a definite settlement "within a twelvemonth" of one of the greatest controversies in modem science.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29 (AP). -- More droughts as bad as the disastrous one last Summer were forecast by a Weather Bureau expert today. At the same time he voiced belief that much of the damage done in the last one could have been avoided if previous scientific warnings had been heeded by farmers.

Because tomorrow is the last day of the old year and because Tuesday is New Year's Day, the pastors today preach sermons reviewing the religious and moral achievements of 1934 and giving advice for personal and national conduct in 1935. The sermons will be in preparation for the watch-night services which will be held tomorrow night by churches of all faiths.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--Japan formally denounced the Washington naval treaty of 1922 today by filing written notice with the State Department that the pact was to terminate on Dec. 31, 1936. Notification of the action was immediately communicated by Secretary Hull to the governments of Great Britain, France and Italy, the other signatories to the treaty.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29. -- The gridiron spectacle that annually comes close to sending two all-America teams into a real football battle will reach its tenth birthday New Year's Day with the long accepted battle cry: "Strong men run so crippled children may walk."

BOSTON, Dec. 27. -- A graphic representation of New England business the past year would show a line slanting sharply upward for three months, then slowly slanting downward month by month, with a dizzy drop in September, and finally again slanting upward during the remaining months until now it stands about midway behind the high of April and the starting point in January.

FIGHTING the "slug" or imitation coin industry is the latest phase of petty racket suppression. An amendment of the State Penal Code, effective on Sept. 1 of this year, furnishes the ammunition for the new campaign. An incident of the drive occurred not long ago at the Times Square subway station, where a man accused of trying to insert a slug in a stile cash box was beaten by two special policemen and a bystander.
